text: So after owning some truly high end speakers from Sonus Faber (Guarneri Evolution and Amati Futura) I HAD to listen to these due to all the hype and reviews. I mean, look at the reviews here, or in the media. No speaker in recent memory has had this much hype.Seeing that I have high end amplification (McIntosh MA8000 and MHA 100) and cables (Nordost Red Dawn and Heimdall) I figured why not try these for giggles. I sold my Sonus Fabers a while ago and have been enjoying the budget Wharfedale Denton's (which are a MUST BUY at $499 if you love rich warm rocking music BTW) so when these became available locally by me for an insane deal new in box I went for it.BURN IN IS NEEDED FOR AT LEAST 5 HOURS.. they will change dramatically after this.When I first hooked them up and they sounded good, but could not match my $500 Dentons in sound quality. The mids were recessed, the highs were brittle and the bass was TOO deep, but sounded like one note. I let them run in for many hours and checked back in..They already opened up dramatically with a huge soundstage, a nice warm character to the sound and the highs became tamer and very sweet. Detail was there but not to the level many make it out to be. For the retail cost of these, they are a deal and a steal. I would say these sound better than most $5000 speakers, and to be honest, when these were hooked up to my McIntosh MA8000 (300 WPC integrated amp) these sounded better in my dedicated room than my past Amati and Evolution speakers which were both 5 figure speakers). In fact, these little guys are now my reference, and yes, with the MA8000 the bass is HUGE, DEEP and tighter than my old Sonus Fabers.Between these and my old Sonus Faber Evolutions that cost me $25k, I do get the same soundtage and imaging effects from these but these are slightly smaller sounding, but better sounding to me. With these we have amazing midband clarity yet they are never ever thin (unless you are running them from a receiver or cheaper amp, these need MASSIVE current to come alive). With my little McIntosh MHA100, which has a 50 WPC amp, they sounded great, fantastic. With the MA8000 they became a new beast..huge open sound, huge bass, delicious midrange, again, for sound they beat my old VERY expensive Sonus Faber (only with the MA8000 amp though).The 50WPC drove them but not to the level to realize how good these are. If you are not getting huge hug sound, a wide open soundstage, amazing clarity and a nice warm full signature then your amp and speaker cables are the weak link.From the aggressive design to the heft of each speaker, they are built very well. They look odd at 1st with the copper colored UniQ driver but with sound, sitting in my sweet spot after more break in they are magical. Simply the most magical speaker I have ever heard.Yep, if you love vocals, jazz, acoustic guitar or drums, or ambient music, bluegrass...hell, most music..you will find out that these can deliver an experience that used to only be reserved for speakers $5k and up to 20-30k. While they do not have huge mid bass, which makes them anemic on cheaper recievers or amps, they do scale amazingly well and will keep on improving with each amp upgrade. For me, the combo of these, a good stand (good solid STANDS ARE MANDATORY for amazing sound to come from these), the MA8000 and my digital and vinyl source are an end game for me. I have never heard better. I have heard bigger, I have SEEN better, but when it comes to reproducing the soul of the music, swirling around you filling your room with amazing details and imaging magic, these do not disappoint. Well worthy of their Class A rating in Stereophile. Again, if you are not getting this from these you have the wrong amp hooked up. Even changing from copper wire to Nordost Red Dawn resulted in a HUGE HUGE difference, night and day. So these deserve the best you can give them in the amp and cable department.The little LS50's give some of the best vocal reproduction I have heard since my older Sonus Faber Guarneri Homage. That is saying something for these being $1500.One weakness I found... No real loud head banging with these really, so metal heads apply elsewhere. (due to non exaggerated mid bass). With that said, as I write this I have some Five Finger Death Punch playing and WOW, filling my room with a huge fat sound...but with the air and detail associated with higher end designs. Amazing.For the money other speakers that are also as good in their own ways and I really enjoy them (though can not get to the magic of the Ls50)Dynaudio X14 (less expensive, more bass and a bigger sound, but less refined, detailed and magical)Wharfedale Denton 80th Anniversary (now on clearance for $500, these are the best bang for the buck in speakers ever - if you want warm, fat and that vintage sound, these are it)So be sure to take a look at these LS50's especially if you love vocals, acoustic, jazz or even ambient music. They excel here like a $10-20k speaker. For rock, pop and others they are still fantastic but you may miss that mid bass that rock and metal needs to really have a driving force.

Wow. I bought these expecting to return them due to shoddy build, dull sound, muffled sound or just being a crappy speaker. I am a 20+ year audiophile and I have owned systems ranging from $1k to $35k. My last serious speaker that I adored was the $25,000 Sonus Faber Guarneri Evolution. The best stand mounted monitor I have ever owned or heard or seen. Should be for that money. (they are now gone as I could not live with myself spending that kind of cash on them, even with getting a deal)Since I had to sell those a while ago I have been listening to various monitors in the $1k to $3k range.I loved the looks and vintage style of these so I took the chance and bought them at the $499 price. (half off). I was trying areas models in my listening room (Dynaudio, KEF, Wharfedale, Harbeth and more)When they arrived the box and packaging was something I only saw in HiFi speakers costing $3k and up. Each speaker was protected in a baggie, white gloves were given and a beautiful booklet describing the history of the company and why these are so special.Long story short, I hooked them into my main system and the 1st hour it was bad. Closed in, muffled, dark, and raggedy in the treble.I let them run overnight while not listening and came back the next day.WHAT?!?!?!? I was blown away by these and no matter what I played through them...audiophile music, rock, metal, vocals, jazz, blues, bluegrass..they sounded rich, full, and gentle and organic. NEVER harsh. TONS of quality bass, never boomy and the treble was sweet and just sounded GOOD. There was a mid bass bloom there that gave these a warm signature, just like I remember from back in the day growing up. Big fat warm sound.No fatigue after I sat there mesmerized for 6 hours listening to song after song.Now, at $500 I can not say they beat my old $25k Sonus Fabers, but they did give me 70% of that sound. With the right gear (GREAT amp and cables) and source these SING as good as any high end speaker I have heard but they sound like MUSIC. Not far off from the Harbeth P3ESR, really. Even though these are $500, they will scale up to better amps, to a point.Give these quality amp and source, good cables (I use the latest Nordost Red Dawn) and you will be rewarded with an incredible experience. Anyone who says these are no good just has not used them in the right setting. With an AV receiver these will sound flat, thin and no soundstage to speak of.With a cheap amp they will sound decent but I am telling you, if you have a nice hugh end system buy a pair of these to try out ad you will be amazed after they run in for 40-50 hours (mine have about 60 on them and sound so BIG, full, detailed and like music. Never analytical but also never leaves me wanting for detail.My only niggle is that some times you can tell they are a tad dark in the midrange. There is a mid bass presence to give these a very full big sound but this makes them, at times, if yo really concentrate on it, slightly dark in the midband area. Bass is tremendous but never sloppy, which is amazing for the price point.Either way, I have not heard a speaker at this price that can even get close to this for build, sound or pride of ownership.the Denton's have a little more MOJO. It's crazy for a speaker of this price to be this good.It is also a shame most audiophiles will disregard these due to brand and price. They truly are special and i bet after these are all sold out and gone, a good used set will go for more than $500. They are destined to be classics IMO. Wait and see.

Love the looks as they appear to be constructed on the level of some $3000 cables i have seen. When I opened the box I was blown away by the weight, appearance and size of these cables. I assumed these would be amazing, and for the price I did not expect such quality of construction.I am running a nice setup. Macintosh gear, KEF & Sonus Faber speakers, VPI turntable, clear audio cart, etc. I have been into HiFi for 20 years. I know what I like.After taking out the borrowed Nordost Red Dawn from my system and placing these in I was sickened. If you think cables make no difference, think again. Once these were in the bass vanished, the mids were sucked in and the highs were harsh. Sound was flat, sounded like my system was now using $100 speakers instead of $20k speakers. I then switched in the little KEF LS50's and the same effect. With the Red Dawns the soundstage was HUGE, details were there, bass was huge and full and the sound was coherent, natural and gorgeous. With these cables the sound just fell flat, was harsh and the bass VANISHED.Now, not sure if the cable has an issue, but while they look amazing, the sound is not up to par even with a $25 cheap cable from Best Buy.Tried this on three systems, all the same.if you want to kill your sound then buy these. Worst speaker cables I have ever heard. They are going back tomorrow.
Wow. Best purchase I made for my Go Pro ever. This is well worth it, trust me.

For the money, this thing ROCKS harder than ANY phono stage up to $500. I have owned phono pre amps from $100 to $2000 and while there are some out there for $10-$20k, this little $200+ wonder sounds amazing with my VPI Scout 1.1. While it is not the last name in resolution, it does offer a big fat warm sound with nice details and small soundstage.I have tried this in a $15k system and it does well.There is much better but be prepared to spend $1000+ for it. Using this phono stage takes me back to my teen years as it sounds like that big fat analog sound I remember.A no brainer at the price. Seriously, and this is coming from a hardcore audiophile. Even though I crave the great gear, this is something that surprised me in a huge way.I am running stock tubes as well and this is fabulous.

Wow. Bought these as I was so so curious as to what a $3000 headphone would sound like. I mean, I already have a set of LCD-X and EL-8's, not too shabby...or so I thought! When these arrived the build, feel and fit were the best I have seen in a headphone.In the past I have owned or tested Sennheiser HD800 ($1500), Audeze LCD-X ($1700) and Audeze LCD-3 ($1900). I have all owned many headphones in the $200-$600 range so I feel I am OK to write about these high end headphones as I have heard high end sound, and been involved in high end audio for 20 years.1st off, My amp is an ALO Audio Studio 6 with the Studio 6 Phono Stage. I use a Yamaha 2100 SCD player/DAC for my digital source ($3000).I have a nice setup but it is not the be all end all of course, I would say my setup is mid level. I have heard TONS of high end gear from $10k systems to $200k systems, even a million dollar system on one occasion (not mine of course).NO, I am not rich, not even close. I just buy the things in life that I get enjoyment from. I am not a fan of RV's, Expensive watches, Fancy cars, boats or large houses. So I buy things like this as I get massive life enjoyment from them, just how I live life..I concentrate on what I love and enjoy.With that out of the way, these headphones are the best I have ever heard, period. Not even close either. Compared to my LCD-X, the HE-1000's are on another level entirely for presentation, flow, organic richness, huge soundstage. clarity, detail, imaging. In fact, I loved my LCD-X. After the HE 1000 it is very tough to go back to them. The LCD-X have the thump, drive and slam but they lack the finesse, amazing holographic sound and creamy silky mids of the HE 1000.Voices sound eerily real. Music...each instrument has its place in the soundstage. The sound is not IN your head, it is WAY OUTSIDE of the head. Close your eyes, dim the light and you are THERE.I would say this Headphone competes with 2 channel speaker systems upwards of $40k. They are that good. so max. I feel there could be more slam and impact (dynamics). The HE 1000 is very natural (not neutral) and lacks massive slam and kick. EI would say this Headphone competes with 2 channel speaker systems upwards of $40k. They are that good.verything is just a tad "soft" but this is awesome as it makes everything sound so so good. Unheard of good. As in you probably never heard anything like this on your ears.So congrats to HiFiman. They succeeded in draining $3k from my wallet. The LCD-X are now going bye bye and these are staying.These sound  good with ALL music but if you want aggressive kick, slam and music that POUNDS, this is not your headphone. This is for those who enjoy a glass of scotch, lights out, fire on, and HE 1000's on your head as you seriously get lost in the music, with performers coming right into your room.Thinly headphones that can compete with these are the STAX SR009 but that is a huge investment and from what I hear, they lack the body of the HE 1000, so I would probably much prefer the HE 1000. This is a masterpiece in design and sound quality.

Well, I want one like in the photo. With some white in it as my TT is all black. Black table, black mat, black platter, black arm. I thought the white and black would mix it up. So I bought this for the looks and novelty only. Since they sent an ALL BLACK mat I am returning it, so just beware you may not get anything like what is pictured. I did put it on my TT (I have a high end system) and it did change the sound slightly, with more treble energy. Weird, can not explain why it would happen but it did.

This is an amazing player. I will state I am an audiophile and have been enjoying amazing sound for 20+ years. I have owned $40k systems and $2000 systems. I know good sound. I have a few players..iPod, iPhone 6+, Pono and this player, the Ak120II.Between all, this player excels in all areas. Build is off the charts..you feel like  you have a $1600 product in your hand. Sound is refined, and no sign of digital ick. The amp is very competent and has driven all phones I have tried besides HD800's (they do not sound good with this player alone).Yes this is expensive, but it is made for audiophiles who spend thousands, tens of thousands and some hundreds of thousands on their home systems.It is not for the every day joe who is used to a $200 best buy stereo. That person would not appreciate this player.I can give this one 5 stars. Bought from ALO Audio while I was in Portland. NO REGRETS.I am returning the Pono this week that I bought as it doesn't even get close to the AK 120II in build, sound or usability.

Bought this locally in Phx AZ and after all the hype I caved. When I opened the box at home I was shocked at how cheaply this was built. It feels hollow, like there is nothing inside. The yellow color screams construction site and the user interface is not so hot. As for the sound, to be 100% honest, I prefer my iPhone 6+ over the Pono, that is with using headphones ranging from $400 to $1300. As for music players I have a few. This one, my iPhone and iPods and the Astell and Kern AK120 II, which is INCREDIBLE.Between the Pono and Ak 120II, it was NO contest. The AK 120 II killed the Pono for sound quality The AK had a delicacy and analogues to it that was beautiful. The Pono in comparison is a bit hard and in your face.NOW, for the price, the Pono is not so bad, though if you have an iPhone 6 or 6+, stick with that unless you want high res files. I downloaded $50 worth from the pono store (two albums) and was not impressed. Yes, there is a slight difference but 98% of normal people would not hear the difference with this player.With the AK 120 II it is EASY to hear the differences. Night and Day.So I am returning the Pono to the store this week. It's made cheap, the design is ugly and not very portable like and the UI needs a major rework. This feels like a beta product at best. Prototype.I gave it 2 stars as it is the lowest price high res player out there, but if you treasure amazing sound, and are an audiophile at heart go with an Astell and Kern player, they sound, feel and work so much better. YOU DO get what you pay for, and that is just me being honest. With the Ak 120 II you FEEL like you have a $1700 product in your hand. With the Pono, you feel like you have a $50 product in your hand.The sound difference between the higher end players and the Pono is really there. Much more refined on the higher end players with NO HINT of digital "sound". Not so with the Pono. I had high hopes, and was vey disappointed in this player.

Best Tremelo pedal Ive ever used. JHS pedals these days are some of  the best there is, high quality all the way, inside and out. Recommended if you want an organic sweet sounding them. Beat the built in them in my Princeton reverb.
Horrible quality..blurred edges and light fall off. Stay away! The quality is NOT there.
Awesome album and now with this double LP re-issue on 180 gram vinyl, a must for ANY KISS fan who spend records these  days. Sound amazing on my high end setup..rich, full, powerful.
Fantastic LED light that has saved me on a few occasions now. Highly recommended if you want a nice adjustable LED light with power and portability. Comes with a nice bag as well. Highly recommended!

Did not fit my A7s correctly so I gave it away. The grip area was too large and had a gap and the case as a whole had a sloppy fit, something that is usually not the case with Gariz. Loved their Olympus E-M1 case and Leica case but this one is a fail for me.

It works, and is not very painful at all. We are so fascinated with this that the whole family used it. Easy, mess free, and quick. Removed 90% of my nose hair which I am not sure is a good thing but it feels clean ;) Works as advertised.

Nice product, decent price IMO..but only if you have a few pedals. I had two more that would not fit so I had to order the Pedaltrain 2...this one has t go back but if I did not have the extra pedals this would have been perfect. No problem and easy to mount your pedals with the supplied velcro.
Cheap and nice enough cover for your Blues Junior. Not the nicest material and sort of cheap but then again, it was priced cheap. :) Will do good enough for my BJ which stays at home anyway.

Does not work with either of my Nikon S RF lenses. I own the 50 1.4 and a 35 1.8, neither will work with this adapter so buyer beware (will NOT mount, not even close). I went with cheap and it bit me in the rear. Have to return it.

The Sony A7II is here and I have had one for about a week before they were released and shipped. I have been using it every day and run a large camera review website where I use ALL cameras made but review only what I like and would use or recommend. I have noticed a couple of reviews here with mis information so decided to write up a short review before my huge full review on my website.First, the A7II is built to just about pro level specs. The camera is a huge step up in build from the A7, A7R and A7s. It feels solid and hefty, much like a Leica M 240 with a grip and while the grip makes it larger than the previous A7, it is in no way as large as any Nikon DSLR. It is also smaller than the Nikon Df (as well as better with IQ).The IQ has been improved even though it uses the same A7 sensor. There is much better AWB, Color, pop and overall quality to the files that is just about the best I have ever tested for real work photos. The camera is about 30% faster than the A7 with Af but is a little slower than my A7s. But focus is not an issue.What makes this camera special is the fact that it is a full frame camera that is just about near Pro Level build and feel, has 5- Axis Image Stabilization which NO OTHER full frame camera has, and it is the best IS you can get. It works with EVERY lens, EVERY lens and is groundbreaking. It will also give you 3 Axis IS with Leica lenses or any adapted lens.The buttons feel fantastic, the dials feel fantastic and compared to my A7s, it feels MUCH MUCH better, in another league better.The images I have been getting with the A7II beat out my A7, A7r and A7s images when it comes to color, sharpness, micro contrast and overall image quality. It's the best of the A7 lot for all out IQ though the A7s beats it in low light. This will not do what the A7s can do in low light or high ISO.With those points out of the way, this camera with the Sony/Zeiss 35 2.8 and 55 1.8 is phenomenal. Those two lenses are must owns but I would skip the kit zoom as it is large, soft and will not show what the camera can do. Why Sony includes it is beyond me as it cripples the cameras output.At $1698 this is the deal of the century as you are getting a camera just as capable as some $3000+ cameras all in a well made camera with loads of lenses to mount. Sony/Zess, Leica, Zeiss ZM, Voigtlander, Nikon and Canon..all of these lenses can be mounted with the correct adapter. I use Leica lenses and for me, 35mm and up are better on the A7II than my Leica M 240.This camera is for those who value IQ, great build, fast speed, the best IS you can get, the ability to mount ANY lens you want and superb manual focus capabilities. The EVF is a joy to use and quite large and the only thing I can say negative about this camera is that its AF is not blazing for continuous or sports but it has improved greatly, and its focus accuracy is SPOT ON.For me, this beats my Leica M 240, my Olympus E-M1, ANY Fuji on the market and even my A7s for all out IQ (though not low light). This and the A7s has become my main cameras and I bought my own A7II just hours after getting my review sample. It is that good.If you do not like this camera then not much will please you, or you are just a fan of huge fat ugly DSLR's.This camera is smaller than ANY DSLR made, and much thinner. Smaller than the Nikon Df, D750, yet more capable and versatile. The video is some of the best you can get as well and with the 5 Axis IS, video footage is almost "steady shot like" - awesome.The buttons and dials are great and in no way at all feel cheap. This is one of the most solid cameras I have seen all year and for me, takes the cake for best of 2014. This camera should have come in at $2495 but Sony put it out at $1698 to show that YES THEY CAN.5 Stars from me on the Sony A7II. My full HUGE review with tons of samples will be up on my website. If you do not know where it is, just google my name ;)

This is the 1st KISS album I ever heard. At Age 9 (I am now 45) I rented this from my local Library after seeing the cover and these four guys with makeup on. The 1st side, the 1st listen..I WAS HOOKED. THIS is the album that made me a life long KISS fan. I ended up having y Mom buy me this album when I was 10 and I wore out the grooves over the many years I played it. Digital came, CD's came and the CD's never sounded the same as my initial LP.With this remaster, the sound is back. Heavy, full, and BIG! The bass is back that was missing from the CD and on my turntable today this sounds so much nicer than the digital versions.It may be a LITTLE dark but it is better than the thin bright CD.My fave KISS album ever, and now on Vinyl again, remastered and sounding just like it did in the 70's, I am so happy to own it.

Bought a few of these, were way too small, even when ordering a large (I normally wear a small). Sent them all back except one. Amazon refunded me before they even got back to them. When they did get my box back they claimed only one shirt was in the box when there were six sent back, so they recharged me for all of them. Either someone at Amazon stole the shirts or they couldn't count. So I will never buy clothing from Amazon again, ever.

Bought this and I actually have two older versions of this album (Not Mobile Fidelity versions) and they sound 100% superior to this so called superior and more expensive transfer. I have a high end setup - really high end. This version sounds flat, dull, muffled and NOT good. So bad in fact that I would never listen to this version when the one I picked up for $1 at my used recored shop sounds much much better. Worst Mobile Fidelity I have heard to date.

Was happy to find this item and the price was right compared to the $150 for the VPI weight I wanted for my VPI table. Wheni t arrived i was surprised at how tiny this is. Its SMALL. Hefty but small. I have owned several record weights and clamps in my lifetime, and this is the smallest one I have seen. Covers just a small part of the label instead of the whole label like many weights do. So with this the price is not great but about right. You get what you pay for. I do not feel it is wide enough to help flatten records that are slightly warped. So, because of this I will probably return mine. Well made, heavy and looks nice..just to small to get the job done IMO.

The Nikon Df has been in my hands for only a couple of days and I will be doing a full extended review on my website (some of you may know where that is). I am not a DSLR fan, and have not owned one since the D700 when it was launched quite a few years ago. One thing I did not like about the D700 and future D800 and D3, D4, etc was the huge size and weight. New mirror less cameras have been arriving that can meet and exceed some DSLRs (Sony RX1R for one).But the Df, with its retro build and style captured my heart when I saw it. I shoot with a Leica M and a Sony RX1. When I saw the images of the Df I was taken back to the 70's when Nikon REALLY made cameras that stood the test of time in looks, design, functionality and build quality.I did not think i would like the Df as it looked huge to me in photos. Last thing I want is a heavy and large bulky DSLR. But when the camera arrived I was shocked at how light it was. In fact, my Leica M with tiny 35 Summaron felt heftier and was. The Df looks tough but feels a little cheap but I believe Nikon did this to solve the weight issue. I mean, C.mon..the D800 and D4 are TANKS and for everyday shooting they are not ideal, especially once you get a taste of those small HQ mirror less cameras.I would never buy a D800 or D4 for everyday snaps. Pro work? yes. Daily shooters? No way Jose. Just not enjoyable, and a camera has to be enjoyable for me to want to shoot with it. One  reason I love my Leica so much.As for the kit 50 1.8 SE lens, it is average. Soft wide open, very light, nothing like a classic Nikon lens. Probably worth the $100 but this camera deserves a high quality fast 50mm prime.The D4 sensor is the king of the night of any full frame cameras. I tested it at 6400 and 12,800 and saw no noise in my prints or web sized images. Astounding. The Sony A7, A7r or Leica M can not do this.I have much more shooting to do but I commend Nikon on the Df. It is handsome, rugged, lightweight and offers some of the best Full Frame IQ you can get. Pair it with some HQ fast primes, even classic AI primes, and you are all set.As for manual focus, I had no issues whatsoever manually focusing a 50 1.2. AT all.AF is fast but not as fast as my Olympus E-M1 and I still prefer a nice HQ EVF to an optical but the Df is a joy to shoot due to the smaller size, lower weight, and it inspires confidence in the manual controls and design.As for those dials, they are great. For those that want to LEARN, set it to manual and all controls are easily accessible without having to menu dive. Brilliant. Those who are complaining about the dials are just not up for shooting a manual camera. But the cool part is that you can also shoot it in full auto.Love it. THIS is my favorite Nikon camera but I have to decide if I want to keep the black or silver. :)My review samples are in and I will be testing these with various lenses over the next 3 weeks. It is a camera that gets me excited to go out and shoot, and that just does not happen for me with DSLR's. That right there tells me this is something special.I gave it 4 stars because I do feel the price point should have hit $2500 with the lens. Also, it is not as sturdy feeling as I had hoped (then again, that could have added to the weight).Some key points from my 1st use:Battery Life is amazing  - best I have seenD4 quality in a small body. Enough said,Build could be sturdier.Feels good in the hand though grip is small.AF is fast, Manual Focus is easy.Dials are superb, love them.IQ with the kit lens is good but not WOW. The kit lens is soft/average.Best low light I have seen besides the D4Light as my Leica M in real useTo those complaining about the cost (I did a little but as well) think about it... To those who do not WANT a huge DSLR like the D800 or an ugly D600 and want top class low light performance (best in class) - with the flagship sensor...$2700 is not a bad buy. You have to buy what you will WANT to shoot with. Me, if a D4, D800 and the Df was offered to me for free..just had to pick one..it would be the Df. Why? Because due to the size, weight and look of  the others I would never take them out. The Df is a daily shooter and that is what Nikon had in mind.

Ordered a Nikon Df and this lens came with it. It has been a while since I shot with a Nikon and this lens is the same as I remember it. Pretty soft wide open and doesn't get really sharp until f/2.5. This is an average 50mm lens and I'd pay $100 for it but not $279. Looks wise it has a silver ring but is still cheap in the build and feel. Nothing special at all here  - Id go with the normal 50 1.8 if buying this lens.

I am a huge Halloween fan. Have been since age 10. Halloween II has been my fave of the series and when I saw this mask, I had to have it, especially after reading the rave reviews. When it arrived I was disappointed. The mask that shipped direct to me via Amazon prime did not look nearly as good as the image in the description. It looked cheaper and not nearly as detailed. BUT with that said, it was still cool. Until I tried it on. I have a large head and I swim in this mask. I cant even see through it due to the mask being so large around my head. So IMO, you will have to tape up the back to tighten it on your head if you want to wear it.I enjoy high quality masks and this one is just a teeny tiny step up from retail store masks though I bought one of the best masks ever at a store last week for $20. Amazing quality that beats this one easily in fit and form.This may be nice as a display in your home if you are a true Michael Myers and Halloween II fan but to wear it, do not expect AMAZING, expect better than average.

I have thoroughly used and reviewed this camera over the past several weeks (review sample from Olympus) and have been wowed, shocked and surprised at the results. I originally thought this would be an E-M5 with a better build, feel and faster AF and at the end of the day I found it to be much more. Due to the lack of an AA filter, the IQ has indeed been enhanced. Images are sharper/crisper and the high ISO has also been improved. I have written 5700 words on this camera and shared a ton of images as well as a comparison against a Leica M. At the end of the day this camera is so good, I ordered one from Amazon for myself.Below is my "FInal Conclusion" from the full review I posted on my website on the E-M1:Well here we are in 2013 and the choices for all of us crazy enthusiasts are plentiful and excellent. We finally have a definitive Micro 4/3 camera body that is pro level and can do just about anything one needs it to do and do it in any weather. As always, I review cameras from an enthusiasts point of view in a real world way. There are things I do not even get into like Flash, because I have not used a flash in 14 years. I am anti-flash even though I know it is good to have on some occasions. But as an enthusiast and a passionate photographer who has seen it all and used them all, I can say with confidence that the OM-D E-M1 is one of the best cameras "as a whole" that I have ever reviewed. It is superb. Yes, there are others with better overall IQ and others with better high ISO but as a whole, speaking of the whole package, nothing else has come close.You have seen me rant and rave about a few different camera models over the year. Leica's and Sony's for the most part. Well as of today there is a new camera in town that offers the perfect mix of speed, usability, build, image quality, cost and lenses to place it at the top of the heap in the world of mirrorless cameras. Someone asked me today if I would take a Canon 6D and 85L or an E-M1 and 25 1.4. For me that choice is easy. The E-M1 only because it would go with me everywhere when the 6D would be left behind. It is just too large, too bulky and too heavy and the lenses, while fantastic are just too much weight wise for everyday use.The image quality of the E-M1 is an improvement over the E-M5 due to the new processor and lack of an AA filter. The files pop more and I feel they also have slightly different color that I prefer. Crisp. Beautiful. The exposure metering is fantastic, the AWB is fantastic, the out of camera colors are beautiful.There will always be naysayers no matter what towards this Micro 4/3 system. But those who disregard or trash Micro 4/3 or the E-M1 have no idea what they are doing or saying. There is simply nothing to trash and that is fact.It will not match full frame like the RX1 or M in all out flat out IQ but it will meet head to head ANY APS-C mirrorless and beat them on build, speed, and every other area usability area with ease. What it boils down to for me is..Olympus E-M1 or Full Frame? The answer for me is BOTH. One all out IQ monster and one usability and IQ monster. :)Also, let us not forget the lenses. Micro 4/3 has some of the best lenses made for any system, period. There are many highly recommended jewels in the lineup.  At the end of the day this camera gets my highest recommendation. Buy the E-M1 and a couple of nice fast primes and go out and use it and it will be hard to put it down. The Olympus E-M1 has the charm, the soul and the goods to Be my pick for Camera of the Year 2013. Not sure if it will as I hear Sony has something on the way but as it stands now, the E-M1 is at the top of the list. :)As of this writing (October 12th 2013) I can say that for me, the Olympus E-M1 is the best Mirrorless camera on the market today when looking at the "Whole Picture" of cost, size, build, speed, toughness, EVF, performance, features and lenses available. No one else even comes close and I should know, I have used EVERYTHING out there. Well done Olympus, you have indeed created a mirrorless masterpiece!Which would I take?Panasonic GX7 or E-M1: E-M1 no contest.E-M1 or Fuji X Body: E-M1 no contest.E-M1 or new rumored Sony Full Frame: BOTH, one for the Full Frame IQ and look and one for all that I have raved about.E-M1 or NEX-6: E-M1 due to the lenses and speed and build and IQ.E-M1 or Fuji X100s: Close, but for me, E-M1E-M1 or Pentax K3? The new Pentax looks amazing on Paper, but is still a DSLR. I can not say until I test the K3 :)E-M1 or Leica M: Two different cameras for different audiences. End of story, so BOTH :)

For under $120 this trail camera is quite amazing for what it can do. While not the fastest trigger, and not the best resolution or night distance, the wide angle lens makes this camera. I tried the 990i and returned it. This one came in, tested it and bought a 2nd one. I use these for different applications but found that the wide angle lens makes it perfect for my use. Have had no issues with the use or operation and with an aiming LCD screen and video capability, hard to complain. If you want amazing quality, buy a reconyx for speed and long term durability. If you want to capture more of the scene and have ease of use and nice night vision video or photo, this guy rocks.

Beware, there seems to have been a mix up at Amazon. I ordered this pedal and instead they sent me some sort of eventide pitch shifter pedal. I read on another eventide pedal review of the same thing happening so Amazon must have mixed up stock placing SPACE pedals in a place that was meant for a different pedal. I sent it back, was refunded, so all is well. I then ordered this pedal elsewhere and received it A-OK. As for the Pedal, it is a 5 star pedal all the way. I have had the Hall Of Fame, Stereo WET and Hardwire Reverb. This literally kills them all. Lush, organic, and HUGE. No noise. It is a high quality effect and it shows. Using it with a Fender Princeton Reverb along with a Carbon Copy delay. Superb.

Was excited to receive my Ena Micro 1. I used to own a ENA 5 and it was a wonderful machine that is still going strong almost 5 years on. Unfortunately the ENA 5 is in a new home so I wanted once again to buy a Jura.Tried Nespresso but the the pod costs are too high these days and I am not a huge fan of the nespresso "taste"So I ordered the Micro 1 from Amazon Prime and it was delivered within one business day.I opened it up, set it on my countertop, followed the step by step instructions for set up but something was wrong. As soon as I put the water tank back on it instantly just poured out of the bottom of the unit. Would not pump water as it was leaking FAST right back out, pouring all over my counter and floor.Tried again, same thing.SO was DOA. At $799, there should have been better quality control.In any case I initiated a refund through Amazon and now will take a week and a half to get my money back due to the fact that it will take 6 days to ship back to them via Ground.IN the meantime I went to Sur La Table and splurged for an Impressa F7, the new 2013 model.This one works like a charm, perfectly and Sur La Table gives a ONE YEAR return policy in case it gives me issues over the 1st year.So if you order this and it leaks, you got a DOA Lemon. I am sure when it works it is great, as are mostly all Jura products. I just had rotten luck with mine.

The dockStubz case adapter is a perfect solution for any annoying problem with external devices that aren't designed with a long enough Lightning connector. A year ago I purchased an iHome radio at Costco that has a built-in Lightning connector for charging an iPhone or iPad. Unfortunately, there is no way to charge either device without removing the case because the connector isn't long enough to make up for the extra depth. I have my phone in a thin Case-Mate case and it still wouldn't fit on the iHome's Lightning connector. That meant I had to remove the case every night in order to charge it, which became a nuisance.I stumbled across the dockStubz adapter on Amazon, and while I thought it was a bit pricey (it actually costs more than the Case-Mate case itself!) I decided to give it a try. I'm glad I did, as it's a perfect solution for this annoying issue. This device is very well designed and resolves the problem completely. It installs in an instant and the Lightning connector is now long enough to easily penetrate the depth of the case and fit solidly into the phone.The dockStubz adapter comes in two pieces in order to accommodate cases with different depths. With my Case-Mate, I snapped the two pieces together and had enough length on the connector for my iPhone 6 plus. If you have a phone with a heavier case, like an Otterbox, which makes the Lightning port even deeper, remove the spacer and the dockStubz provides additional length. I don't have an Otterbox case and haven't tested it personally, but in just looking at mine, I feel confident this would solve the problem for those owners.The dockStubz is a bit pricey, but I suspect that licensing costs from Apple are what drives the cost up. This adapter doesn't interfere with any of the iHome's functions, like setting the alarm from an app on the phone, or listening to music through the radio. Cheaper cables and adapters that aren't licensed will only provide power and no other services, however this adapter is fully functional with no limitations.I have only two minor quibbles. First, the dockStubz can easily come off the iHome Lightning connector when removing the iPhone or iPad and then needs to be reinstalled. I don't consider this a big problem, and it is way easier than taking the case off and having to reinstall it every night. Also, if you hold the adapter with the other hand as you remove your phone, the adapter stays in place.Second, the phone is a bit less stable using the dockStubz than it is when resting on the iHome itself. This is because the phone is being supported by the adapter and not the bumpers on the radio. Again, not a big problem. The iPhone is held firmly enough that there doesn't seem any danger about the phone falling off, even when setting the alarm via an app, or using the phone to select music, but there is a bit less stability using the adapter.If the truth be known, I blame the designers at iHome for this problem. Had the radio been manufactured with a slightly longer Lightning connector, this issue wouldn't exist. It would have been so simple for them to do this, but I guess no one thought about charging the phone with a case, or the folks at iHome simply didn't care.In summary, the dockStubz is a clever (although pricey) solution to a design issue of external devices with a Lightning connector that is too short to accommodate an iPhone or iPad while in a case.

I have two outdoor outlets that are in the eave of my house. Both outlets take adapters that prohibit a regular 2" cover from closing. One is a power supply for a security camera. In order to orient the plug correctly, I needed to use a small adapter to plug the power supply into. It causes the two to project about 3 1/2 inches from the base. On the other side I'm using a remote to turn the outlet on and off. The lights that they control are plugged into that.The receptacle comes with enough parts that you can configure it any way that your situation requires. There are lots of additional plates that allow the use of outlets, switches, etc. In addition, there are knockouts to allow for both rounded outlets (as shown in the photo) or the more modern type square outlet. You'll need a good needle nose pliers to remove the knockouts and a screwdriver for mounting the receptacle of whatever surface you've chosen. The box has a padded back which allows it to fit tightly over an irregular surface, like stucco.All in all an excellent product that is designed to protect electrical outlets from the weather and provide enough depth to make even unwieldy power supplies fit correctly. It installed easily and fits my needs perfectly.

For my use, this drive is just perfect, and the price was great for a 2TB capacity storage device, even better pricing at Amazon than Costco! I'm using this with a mid-2010 MacBook Pro as a backup drive. I've partitioned the drive into two 1TB partitions. I use Carbon Copy Backup to back up my drive. I alternate partitions which allows me to keep 2 copies of the last known-good configurations of my computer. I do a lot of beta testing for Apple and this allows me to be a bit more fearless than if I had only one backup.This drive was easy to work with out of the box. My MacBook Pro can't make use of USB 3, but this drive is backward compatible with USB 2 and performs perfectly fine for my usage. I like the idea that one day, when I upgrade, this drive will give me the maximum speed available via USB.I once had a Seagate drive that went bad after a few years, and I contacted the manufacturer to exercise the warranty. The drive was promptly replaced, without any questions or hassle. It's made me a loyal Seagate customer to know that they stand behind their products.If you're looking for a portable drive with 2TB, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend the Seagate Expansion Portable External Hard Drive.

These short extension cords are just about ideal for connecting a bulky power supply into a power strip without blocking the adjacent plugs. The only objection I have, and the reason I'm deducting one star, is the LED light in the connector (female) side of the plug. With 3 of these in use, they create a constant glow of three different colors that can prove annoying. They are certainly well manufactured and meet UL specifications. I would have prefered if they didn't have the LEDs, but this short size is hard to find, and I'd rather put up with the light than a longer extension cord.All in all, a well manufactured product that is perfect for its intended use. I just wish the light had been left out, but it's not a show-stopper.

I like this case, but find have three issues with it. First, it's a bit bulky. Second, the cutout in the back for the Apple logo allows dirt and dust to enter the case. Third, the stand has a tendency to revert back into the case and requires the user to disassemble the interior from the case to reset it.The Apple iPhone 6+ is light and thin, and this case makes it feel bulky and large. It certainly does a good job of protecting the phone (except for the hole in the back), but at the cost of the ergonomics of the 6+. In addition, I don't understand the hole. I know that Spigen is not the only manufacturer to do this, but what's the point of a hole that allows dirt and dust to enter into the back of the case? I get it that the idea is to expose the Apple logo so that everyone knows you have an iPhone, but frankly, that's unimportant to me. I'd prefer the protection over the ego boost.The stand is a nice feature, but it can be pretty easily dislodged. That requires you to separate the internal rubber liner from the exterior case and reset the stand. It's easy enough to do, but it's an annoying feature of this case. I also found that with my style of usage, the stand was less useful than I originally thought. You might feel differently depending on how you use your iPhone.One last point: if you own an iHome radio with a charging port on top, you will have to remove the case in order to charge the phone with that port. The bottom of this case, as with most iPhone cases, is too thick to allow the Lightning connector to connect to the phone and requires the phone to be charged with a cable or to remove the case each day to use the top port.I subsequently purchased a Case-Mate clear plastic case (also available on Amazon) and I'm much happier with it. It is less bulky, doesn't have the cutout on the back, and maintains the ergonomics of the phone better than this Spigen case. It, too, has the same problem with the iHome radio charging port.In summary, an OK case that is a bit bulky, has a cutout in the back that compromises the protection of the iPhone, and a troublesome stand that, at least in my usage, was less helpful than I thought when I purchased this case.

I have a heavy beard and shaving in the shower is the easiest and most comfortable way for me to shave. Unfortunately, when I travel, I can't do it because I've never come across a hotel or motel that has a shower mirror. After returning from a trip, I decided to check Amazon to see if there was a solution to this, and I came across this product from the Shave Well Company.The mirror is simplicity itself and is perfect for traveling. It comes with a suction cup that is easy to install and easy to remove. The mirror hangs on a hook attached to the suction cup. Simply run the mirror under the shower for a few seconds to get the temperature equalized to the shower, hang it on the hook, and you have a fog-free mirror, perfect for shaving!The mirror is not made of glass so it's safe to pack, and it's very compact and takes up virtually no room in my bag. If you shave in the shower and miss doing so when you travel, fret no more, this device belongs in your travel kit!

I originally found a pair of these pants at Sears and really liked the fit and feel of them. Dockers, in general, fit me well. To give a bit of perspective, I am 5' 11" and weigh 170 lbs. Unfortunately, Sears doesn't carry these pants in many colors, even through they're available, but Amazon has them all. Since I knew my size, I just ordered them from Amazon. They arrived, fit perfectly, and are exactly the color I was expecting.Two additional pluses for these pants are that they have a built-in elastic expansion waistband, so that they are extremely comfortable to wear, and the pants are cut high to wear above the waist. The pockets are deep so even my iPhone 6+ fits in them comfortably. The one cargo pocket on the right leg is opened and closed with a zipper and is roomy enough to throw in keys, a folded map, or whatever it is that you can't put in a normal pocket.If you're looking for an inexpensive pair of pants that has an extra cargo-style pocket, these pants are perfect. My only quibble, and it's minor, is that there is no center crease on the leg, so while these pants might be acceptable for the weekend, they probably are too casual for some situations. For me, they're ideal and I now own a few pair and wear them regularly.

This wireless remote control switch is perfect for what I needed. I have a set of decorative lights on the outside of my house that are plugged into a hard to reach outlet in the eave of the house. The same electrical circuit also controls security lights, connected to a timer, which I want to turn on and off, uninterrupted, on a daily basis. In the past we'd use a broom to move a handle mounted next to the outlet to turn these decorative lights on or off. Now, I simply use this remote control to turn the switch on and off. This allows the security lighting to behave normally and these decorative lights to be turned on or off depending on whether we're entertaining or dining in the yard. Perfect! No more broom handle.The switch was ready to use out of the box and needed no programming. I simply plugged the adapter into the outlet in the eave, plugged the decorative lights into it, and voil, I can now turn the lights on and off as needed with the remote with no programming. Since the switch doesn't use infrared, it works right through our hurricane glass slider door, something I found amazing! The manufacturer says it will work from as far as 100 feet, although I haven't personally tested that feature. The battery for the remote is an odd size, but a spare one is provided in the package and replacement batteries are readily available at either Home Depot, Lowes or Amazon.The remote can handle up to three switches which would allow me to expand this system at a later time by purchasing additional adapters. It would not require a separate remote for each one. Very smart. They also make a model that controls up to five switches, although that is way more than I need.There is one downside, albeit minor, that you should think about before buying the Etekcity remote. The switch is oriented so that the the top part of it goes well above the outlet, leaving the bottom outlet available for another electrical plug. That's fine where you have room, like indoors on a switch above a baseboard, but outside where space is limited, or where the outlet is contained in a weatherproof box, will require you to install it upside down so that the second outlet is blocked. In my case that's OK as I'm not using the outlet for anything but these lights, but keep it in mind depending on your application and needs.I'm really delighted with this device. It's one of those things that is well designed, inexpensive, and for me, solved a problem that was driving me crazy!

I ordered two of these cameras to replace older Panasonic BB series cameras. I was looking for the infrared feature as well as an improved picture. These cameras fit the bill for both price and function.Setup of these cameras is not for the faint of heart. If you don't have some technical "chops" or an understanding of networking, you're going to be very frustrated getting these cameras up and running. I'm an IT guy who has a good understanding of technology and it took me awhile to configure them properly. We have Uverse as our Internet provider, and their gateway modem does not support Universal Plug 'n Play (UPnP). That means that all network settings for these cameras have to be entered manually, and as I note later in this review, creates a problem with using Dynamic DNS (DDNS) for accessing the cameras while away from your home or office unless you manually configure your modem or router.Once the cameras are up and running, they work extremely well. The picture quality is excellent and the IR feature in near zero light is nothing short of amazing. In the past, when we were traveling, we'd leave the lights on in our bedroom 24/7 so the camera could "see." Now, with the Foscam IR feature set to automatic, the lamps are on timers and the camera still shows a great picture of the room.There are, however, downsides to these cameras that you should consider before you finalize your purchase.1. I'm on a Mac. The only browser the camera will work with (as of this writing) is Safari. I happen to be a Chrome user and there is no plug-in for it, or for Firefox. Without that plug-in you can't configure the camera. You must use Safari. For the Windows users reading this, I believe the only browser you can use is Internet Explorer, but I haven't tested it.2. There is a function called DDNS which allows you to access the cameras outside of your home or office. According to the Status page, these are configured correctly, but I have yet to be able to get them to work. I have been using a third-party application called EvoCam to manage my cameras which I prefer, but DDNS should work, and it does not appear to be easy to configure.3. The lights on the back of the camera cannot be shut off or put into privacy mode. If you use wireless, the status light on the back of the camera will blink, indicating a connection. In addition there is a red power light. In a dark room these two lights are like a beacon. If you put the camera on a surface near a wall, the lights are very visible as they reflect against any surface. This draws attention to the camera and is the opposite of it being a stealth device. The Panasonics I owned prior to these had a setting where I could enter privacy mode and shut down all status lights. That feature is missing on the Foscam camera and imho is sorely needed. (Hey, intruder, I'm over here recording you!) If you use an SD card in the camera for recording, an intruder would take the camera and smash it and you'd have no idea who had entered your home or office. Since I use third-party software to manage and record my cameras, it's not an issue for me as I'd have a picture of the person approaching and disconnecting the camera. Nonetheless, these lights should be able to be turned off once the camera is configured.So, all-in-all, a very high quality security camera for the price. It needs broader compatibility with other popular browsers, a more robust DDNS function, and a way to shut off the status lights on the device. Hey, the devil's in the details!

I wanted a simple timer to control the bedroom lamps when we're traveling. These fit the bill functionally and price wise. I've read that other reviewers think the setup is complicated and I have to disagree. You do need to read and follow the enclosed directions, but they are hardly hard or confusing. You start by setting the time of day and then the time you'd like the lamp or appliance to go on and off. You can have up to two cycles, e.g., on at two different times of the day, then off at two different times. You can also ignore the second cycle and simply have one on/off cycle per day. The timers can be set to Auto (they turn the device on and off per your settings), On (which simply enables the outlet) or Off (which disables the outlet.)I also like that they're silent! I've tried mechanical timers and eventually you start hearing the little motor that turns the timer wheel. In a dark, quiet room, that's like a dripping faucet. These timers are completely electronic and hence silent.My only criticism, and hence one less star, is that it isn't easy to override these timers without unplugging them and turning the "Auto" feature to permanently off or on. In addition, there is no backlighting to make seeing these displays easier.Looking at their functionality alone, if you're looking for an inexpensive timer to turn a lamp or other appliance on and off once or twice a day, the Woods timers are an excellent idea.

I think this is an excellent little handheld vacuum cleaner. It seems to have enough power to clean crumbs and other minor debris off our tile floor and area carpets using the floor attachment. I wouldn't recommend this as a replacement for a large, powerful vacuum cleaner, but for small jobs and quick clean-ups, it does the job.I deducted one star as storing the vacuum cleaner with the floor stick requires two locations. In other words, you can't charge the vacuum and have the floor stick attached. You'll need to detach it, store it someplace, and then charge the vacuum.Emptying the dust bin is straight forward, but like most units, you should do it over a garbage can so it doesn't spill onto the floor. Washing and replacing the filter is straightforward and doesn't need to be done too often.Lastly, note that this isn't a wet vacuum. It shouldn't be used for spills or any other liquids. For that you'll still need a shop vacuum.All in all a good appliance for quick clean-ups but charging the vacuum with the floor stick attached can't be done.

I purchased this camera for my wife for a recent extended trip to Europe. She absolutely loved it. This is much more than just a simple point-and-shoot camera. It has the ability to go completely automatic or manual, and the presets for scenes or portraits are both handy and well programmed. 20.4 megapixels is a bit of overkill, but it gives you an idea of just how good the pictures are that this camera takes.I was particularly impressed with its performance in low light. Most of the time she kept the flash off and got stunning pictures of the interiors of things that would have been impossible with a less versatile camera.I deducted one star for ergonomics. The programming dial is very easy to turn inadvertently while using the camera which will change the mode of the camera without the user realizing they've done so. In addition, there is a multiple shot feature with the HX50V that is a bit difficult to use. My wife often found herself taking three or four shots of a scene instead of one, and it was because the close proximity of the controls on the back of the camera allow for this setting to be engaged without realizing it. Once she was aware of what she was doing, and made sure her hands were placed properly, she had much better luck with this feature.While you can use this camera out of the box, you'll need to read the manual if you intend to take advantage of many of the camera's advanced features. If you take the time to do so, you'll be amazed at what is packed into this small marvel!Battery time is good. Without using the flash, my wife routinely could take 100-200 pictures a day and only needed to charge the battery every other day. I would assume that using the flash would diminish the battery life, but as I said earlier, almost every picture she took was without the flash.So, in summary, a terrific camera that is packed with features and does extremely well in low light. The controls are a bit confusing, but a short time with the manual will yield amazing results!

These packs are incredible! I tried a couple on a recent extended trip to Europe where I had multiple stops. It made packing so much easier, and everything stays organized. I don't know why I never knew about these before, but now that I've used these, I can't imagine traveling without them!They are very lightweight with a zipper that seems almost "liquid" in it's use. That's important to me as I have terrible zipper karma. They can be packed with more items than they would seem to be able to hold, and keep everything in them folded and neat. Use the large ones for shirts and the medium size one for underwear. There's even a smaller one for electronics or socks.The beauty of these items is that unpacking and repacking is a cinch, and all of your clothes get there unwrinkled and fresh looking. If you travel a lot, these packs are really indispensable for organization of your suitcase/duffle/backpack. I can't recommend them enough.

I don't know why I never knew about these before, but now that I've used these, I can't imagine traveling without them!They are very lightweight with a zipper that seems almost "liquid" in it's use. I have prior experience with BlueRigger with the purchase of a couple HDMI to DVI connectors. Based on that, I purchased BlueRigger ethernet patch cables, and I wasn't disappointed. They're a quality product that worked exactly as I expected out of the box. I understand that ethernet cables are a commodity, but in the past, I've seen the clips break easily or other issues with the cable. None of these have occurred with BlueRigger. These guys make an excellent product as a very good price. What's not to like? As long as they maintain this level of quality, they've got my business!

My wife lost her original Shaark iPad stand on a recent trip, and we purchased this as a replacement. It has all of the same great features for use as an iPad stand and folds up to a size that is easily carried in your suitcase, backpack or handbag. It adjusts to almost any angle and holds the tablet securely. I've had more people ask me about this device, and I always tell them to go to Amazon and buy one. For the money, it simply can't be matched by any other stand for utility or its ability to fold up and be a great traveling companion.Highly recommended!

There's good news and bad news with the Karcher K 5.65. Starting with the good: this unit is a great pressure washer for around the home. Our primary use is cleaning pavement and walkways of mold. We live in S. Florida and mold is a way of life here and needs to be periodically cleaned. This pressure washer is easy to use and, at 2000 psi, does a great job of removing the mold. We used it for over 6 hours cleaning up our sidewalk, driveway and backyard patio. It never quit, overheated, or stopped cleaning. That alone makes it a dependable and worthy unit for your purchasing attention. The power cord and hoses are sufficiently long that we never had to use an extension cord for either power or the handle. Your needs may dictate otherwise, but for our needs on a 1/4 plot of land, the hose and cords were of sufficient length. We also have several choices for outdoor outlets, which definitely figures in to my assessment.The bad news is that many of the outside parts of this washer, like the wheels, simply don't work as designed. I tried installing the wheel assemblies more than once, and could never get the wheels to turn when the machine was erect and being pulled by the handle. I called Karcher's warranty service, and they very kindly sent me a new set of wheels. When they arrived and were installed, it was the same problem. It is a mystery how professional engineers can go to college, study, get a degree and finally come to work for Karcher and still design a set of wheels that don't turn when the power washer is moved. Surely someone in QA noticed this before the machine was released to manufacturing. Oh well, be prepared that the best you'll get is dragging this unit from one location to the other with the wheels frozen in place.I'd also like to comment that the assembly instructions are not for the faint of heart. I'm sure if you've put these machines together in the past that this would be a piece of cake, but for two adults who are good with tools, this was a much longer project than it needed to be. There is a link to a Karcher website in the instructions to get more detail on assembly, but the link has long been disabled and now takes you to a non-relevant page on their site.In summary, I'm very pleased with the way this machine cleans and it's usability. What I'm not pleased about is that this machine sets the invention of the wheel back 5,000 years. You'd be better off buying this from a small hardware store that assembles it for you. This isn't Amazon's fault, it's Karcher's. If you're comfortable futzing with this power washer through the assembly process, you'll be rewarded with a unit that works very well.

I'm writing this review while I'm in Italy using the adapters. They are perfect for converting American type plugs for use with the Italian electrical system. Each adapter can handle two plugs, but only one with a grounding pin. For me this works fine as the plug for my MacBook Pro is a three-pin plug and the charger for my iPhone doesn't require a ground.I'd offer only one small piece of advice. First, and most important, these adapters do not convert 220v to 110v. Some appliances will not work correctly at 220v, like the hair clipper I brought along. Most computer and phone adapters will automatically convert 110v to 220v and visa versa, so no worry charging your electronics, or at least Apple products.The second thing is that these adapters require a 3-prong Italian plug, which is what you'll find most of the time. Occasionally you'll come across a two-prong plug (no ground) and these adapters won't fit.If you need a Type L adapter, these are a great product at a great price!

First, a disclaimer that while I'm an avid Amazon customer, I purchased this safe on sale at Costco where it was significantly less expensive than on-line.The only reason I deducted one star is that the safe isn't fireproof, but neither does Sentry claim it is. Other than that, I find it almost exactly like the safes you find in a hotel room. I used the predrilled holes for mounting this safe so it can't be easily carted off. Setting a numerical combination is straightforward, but needs to be reset every time you open the safe. There is no way to enter the combination permanently. There is also the option to use a credit or debit cardin fact any card with a magnetic stripein place of the 4-digit security code. It is equally easy to configure.I'm aware that this is not one of those safes that is 100% unbeatable for thieves, but I do believe that this would slow them down considerably, especially since the safe is permanently mounted. The room where it lives is protected by a security camera, so all-in-all, I feel pretty good regarding the security it offers.It is big enough to easily hold my 15" MacBook Pro and has a piece of fabric to protect it from the steel bottom of the safe. For my money and use, this safe fit the bill perfectly. As I said earlier, the one thing it isn't is fireproof, and the front door of the safe is classified as tamper resistant, not tamper-proof. To me that means that if the safe was somehow stolen, a determined thief would be able to use a crowbar to eventually gain access to it. Since I'm not leaving anything irreplaceable in it, I'm perfectly OK with those limitations. A visit to the SentrySafe website will show you that they have an extensive line of safes, so each user should consider their needs and buy accordingly. In my case, I knew what I was getting, especially since I'd seen this class of safes in just about every hotel room where I've stayed.I would also recommend this model as a gun safe. If you use your credit or debit card as the security for opening the door, then go to work or leave the house with that card, no one else (your kids) will be able to open the door without the card. This safe would easily hold a few handguns.The safe comes with two override keys and an external battery back which would be used in the event that the 4 batteries that power the door should die. The manual for this safe is, thoughtfully, provided on-line at the Sentry website.

I love Revos. I think they hands down make the best sunglasses. I purchased my first pair 10 years ago in Los Angeles. The salesperson told me that the graphite color is what cinematographers choose because they are so true to natural colors. I bought that pair and many others since, and indeed they have amazing color clarity and fidelity.I usually go to a place like Sunglass Hut because Revo's are not carried everywhere. When I needed a new pair (I lost my old ones while hawking for golf balls) I decided to check Amazon, and was delighted that they had such a large selection of Revo's. This pair was sold by an Amazon partner, but they were offered with free shipping, even though they weren't eligible for Prime, and arrived two days earlier than originally projected. The price was on a par with a retail shop, but no tax and free shipping clinched the deal!I have excellent eyesight (20-20) so I'm conscious of when my vision is distorted by a cheap pair of sunglasses. The color fidelity on the lens of the Revo Descend is as good as I've ever experienced, and it's polarized to boot! It is frameless so they are extremely lightweight on your face. I live in South Florida where the sun is extremely strong, and these glasses take away the squint, even in the brightest conditions, like the beach. They are very comfortable to wear, with or without a cap. (With a cap, the sidepiece goes on the outside of the hat.)I've tried Maui Jim and Ray Ban, but for me, nothing compares to Revo when you really want a great pair of polarized sunglasses that offer superb color fidelity. I understand that Revo has recently been purchased by Oakley, and I hope they don't decide to change the recipe. Revo's are really the Mercedes of sunglasses.

I own a 2014 Ford Fusion Hybrid that doesn't have a built-in way to access Siri on my iPhone 5. This product from Mobile Home is an excellent way to keep your phone in your pocket and still be able to access Siri when your phone is connected via Bluetooth. It works exactly as if you were using the home button on your phone except you use the built-in speakers and microphone in your car to communicate with this device.So why not 5 stars? First, the setup described in the accompanying brochure contradicts what I experienced with the device itself. When pairing the device, the instructions say to expect a green LED to come on to indicate pairing mode. Instead, the lights flash yellow and red which, by the usual association with these colors, insinuates you've done something terribly wrong.  It took me a few minutes to realize that my unit, for whatever reason, left the factory with different color LEDs.My second issue is that it takes two taps on the device the each time you use it. The first is to wake up the Bluetooth connection and the second engages Siri. After the first usage, it remains paired for awhile, then disconnects. I understand that the purpose of this is to conserve battery power (the manufacturer supplies a second battery with the device) but it is distracting during usage, especially when driving.Third, and the least troublesome, is that the manual is not available as a PDF on their website. I like to get rid of packaging and documentation and keep the instructions electronically. I've done this from minor items to major appliances. Just about everyone has their documentation on their website ready for download, but not Mobile Home.In summary, very good device for being able to access Siri while your iPhone is safely tucked away in your pocket. Just ignore some of the documentation and you'll be on your way to using it successfully.

I'm an older ex-runner who is now an avid walker in Florida. I go out in the morning for about 4 miles. In South Florida, the summer heat can be upwards of 85-90 with 70-85% humidity, so it's very important to stay hydrated. I really hate carrying a water bottle or having it hang from my waistband. I'd heard about Camelbak line of water carriers and thought I'd give one a try.The hydration system works as advertised and keeps the temperature of the water nice and cold. Unfortunately the fit of the Hydropak seems to be less than ideal, at least for me. I believe that the model I purchased, the Hydropak, has been discontinued and maybe this problem is solved in newer models. Unfortunately the Camelbak I now own isn't all that comfortable to wear, making it less than ideal to use during my long walks.I chose the Camelbak Hydropak based on price and water capacity. The Hydropak holds 1.5 litres of liquid, more than enough for my 1 hour walk. It's easy to fill with ice water from the refrigerator and it keeps it nice and cold. The Hydropak is easy to drink from using the built-in straw. When I'm finished with my walk, I simply empty any remaining water and let it air dry for the next day. If the bladder needs cleaning, it's easily removed and reinstalled.The gripe I have with the Hydropak is with the fit and location of the shoulder straps and adjustment clips. The straps have plastic adjusters to customize the fit, just like regular backpacks. These adjustment clips, unlike regular backpacks, are mounted just below the armpit. With the Camelbak on and adjusted, the buckles lie right on the side of my rib cage and rub against my arms during the normal motion of walking. It's really annoying and uncomfortable.This might be less annoying if I were wearing a traditional t-shirt, but in the summer, because of the heat and humidity, I wear a sleeveless performance shirt and the adjustment clips rub directly against the inside of my arms.It would definitely help if there was a sternum strap. That would allow the adjustment clips to be pulled slightly forward and away from where my arm brushes against my rib cage. As it is now, I am constantly aware of the buckles as my arms swing back and forth during the normal motion of walking.Another minor quibble is that the Camelbak ships with no instructions. I had no idea what the open or closed position was of the yellow shutoff valve on the mouthpiece. In fact, I had no idea it was a shutoff valve. It also took some experimenting to see how the bladder came out of the carrier so that it could be cleaned and/or dried. An additional tag on the bag with this information would have been a big help, but I guess the manufacturer feels that it is so obvious and simple that no instructions are needed. I'm pretty technically savvy and can usually figure out how things work, so spending some time with the Hydropak and a search or two on Google got me filled in on the basics. It would have been so-o simple for Camelbak to include this information, especially about the shutoff valve and bladder, that I'm a bit mystified as to why Camelbak doesn't do it.My 2 of advice is if you decide to purchase the Hydropak, try it on first, without filling it with liquid, to confirm the comfort of the fit and the location of the adjustment straps and buckles. If you have the same problem I have, you'll be able to return it to Amazon.

I received this golf watch as a birthday gift and while I enjoy using it on the golf course, not so much with my computer.I have yet to be able to sync this GPS with Garmin Connect. It always fails. Worse, the watch will not work with Safari or Chrome when plugged into your computer. The only browser I've found that works with it is Firefox. Absolutely ridiculous considering Garmin has created custom software specifically for the Mac. For Garmin Connect to then not work with Safari is beyond stupid.Another problem with the software is that it will not start automatically when the watch is connected to my laptop, even though the checkbox for this function is checked. In other words, this software is actually pretty bad.If you're looking for a convenient GPS solely to measure distance for your golf shots, the S4 isn't a bad choice, but don't expect anything to work with either the Garmin Connect software or your browser, especially if you're a Mac user.I also have to comment on viewing your golf score. The only way to do it is to connect the watch, then look for scorecard.html in Finder. The Garmin S4 looks like a drive to the operating system, and the scorecard is in the root.Forget double-clicking to open it. You need either Firefox or IE to view this information. Again, absolutely ridiculous.The watch itself is touch sensitive, but that doesn't mean that every gesture actually works. When you start the watch and try and get to the menu from the watch in order to reach the Start Round menu you're given a graphic that says to swipe your finger to the left on the surface of the phone. Good luck with that. It takes a minimum of 4-5 swipes (if you're lucky) to allow you to get to the Start Round menu. There's also no way to shut that feature off. Why if heavens name would I want the watch locked from the time screen to the golf menu??!!If you are not a techie or comfortable with technology, pass this item by. You'll just be frustrated, especially after spending all of that money on this device. I've owned a few Garmin devices and they always seem to get both the user interface and accompanying software wrong. There are better golf GPS products out there and for less money. Buy this item at your own peril!

I already had one WeMo switch to control a lamp in our living room. I wanted another one that I could use with our Bona Vita coffee maker that I could control with my iPhone. The WeMo Insight switch was on sale at Amazon and is significantly smaller than the original one I already owned. I decided to get one.Since I don't get up each morning at the same time I don't want the coffee to start when I'm still sleeping. With the WeMo Insight switch, I set up the coffee the night before, turn the coffee maker to the "on" position and then when I get up, launch the WeMo app on my iPhone to turn the WeMo on. Coffee starts brewing and by the time I get to the kitchen, it is fresh and piping hot!I have the switch programmed to shut itself off at 3:00 PM so that if I want an additional cup of coffee during the day the coffee maker will work without having to manually engage the switch. I also have it programmed to turn "on" on Fridays only at a specific time since that one day I volunteer at a local park and know when I have to get up.I'm a fan of these devices, but they do have some problems that Belkin needs to work on. Occasionally, in order for the app to work on my phone, I need to "kill" the app and relaunch it. I have a couple wireless routers in the house, all on the same network, but the Belkin seems to get confused as it passes from one to the other. Once it's found the switches, it works perfectly.The big difference between the original Belkin WeMo switch and the WeMo Insight is size, with the Insight being significantly smaller. This works much better in an area where the switch is visible, in this case on my kitchen counter. It's also well designed to allow the use of the second plug in an outlet if the Insight is plugged into the bottom outlet.The Insight also has the ability to give you a lot of details about how much power you're using with whatever device you're controlling.
