This is a jaw-droppingly bad, sophomoric and inaccurate "collection" of terms and phrases. If you are even fleetingly familiar with etymology and phraseology, you will be astounded by the amateurism and ignorance of the author.The cover is well done and makes one eager to explore the contents. However, you will not be able to get past the first page without seeing that my harsh criticism is, if anything, an understatement. The only thing more frightening than wondering how in God's name such a ridiculously awful book was published in the first place is imagining the mentalities of those reviewers here who gave the book 5 stars. What?!?This book is about 5% material, 95% filler. Again, just the first page alone shows this: apparently every Latin phrase is included in the book, as the first page alone has several. Latin phrases are LATIN and, in English usage, are neither 'bizarre', 'unexpected' nor 'fascinating'. The one entry on the first page that made me burst out laughing is this:The origin of the phrase 'Above the fold' is 'the content of a Web page that can be seen without scrolling down'.What NITWIT with even a thimbleful of knowledge of idiomatic expressions does NOT know that the term refers to a newspaper? Seriously. Just a breathtakingly awful book.

I have used Filemaker for probably 15 years. I always recommended the product to others, at times when Filemaker struggled to survive. My attitude now is that the new 'versions' they come out with are merely minor updates, priced to reward users' product loyalty with ripping them off for $180. If it was $99, it probably wouldn't be worth it really (vs. just keeping v. 9, 10 or 11), but the sense of being ripped off wouldn't be so strong. At $99, Filemaker would be making a good profit - as this is merely an upgrade - but they are now arrogant in their strong market share. Time to tell FM to piss off, as far as I'm concerned.For Windows users, MS Access is a great deal compared to FM, especially bundled in Office 2010 Pro. Unfortunately I recently bought Office 2010 Business, not realizing that then was the time to dump FM. For small biz and home users, bail out of FM and get yourself OpenOffice Base - it's F-R-E-E!

I hesitate to write this review out of fear of jinxing myself (I say great things, then a drive fails soon afterwards).I've owned about 10 external HDs over the past 5 years, most of them WD. These drives (the Western Digital WD Elements 2 TB USB 2.0 Desktop External Hard Drive AND the 1.5 TB) are the best ever. I'm a bit paranoid about losing data, because of past HD failures, so I want the best back-up drives. WD has been an annoying company, especially with the MyBook drives I had before these: asinine software that you could not disable. These new drives are perfect: no software, just a small, flat, superquiet, cool (as in no heat) drives with huge storage capacity. And, best of all, the 2TB and 1.5TB have worked perfectly for close to a year of 24/7 operation.The only thing I don't like is that the activity light is on the back: I like it on the front; the idiots who complained to WD about the light on the front now have what I have: large relections on the wall which are ten times more annoying than a tiny white light in the front; good going, nitwits.

You actually need not go further than the cover of the book to see the agenda and tactics of the author: not only does he (and/or the publisher) make Sacco & Vanzetti - the poster boys and 'martyrs' of the Massachusetts anti-death penalty crowd - the cover photo, but the signs in the photo are heavily airbrushed in order to make clear the underlying 'message' that - along with the words 'Death Penalty' in blood red ink - says "DEATH PENALTY BAD: INNOCENT PEOPLE EXECUTED".First of all, the author seems oblivious to the now-famous revelation that Sacco and Vanzetti were, in fact, guilty as sin, a fact the world knew in 2005 (papers showing that S&V's own attorney admitted to Upton Sinclair - the one person responsible for making their case famous - that he had fabricated S&V's alibis and that his clients were absolutely guilty).Secondly, regarding the author's obvious applause for the corrupt SJC's ruling of the 'unconstitutionality' of the death penalty in 1980, he could have at least PRETENDED to give a fair analysis of that ridiculous, intellectually dishonest ruling. But no, not a word about how the framers of the Mass. Constitution were the same men who helped frame the US Constitution (John Adams, John Hancock, et al.) and that they certainly DID approve of the death penalty, especially for murder and treason.Judicial activism didn't start with the current slate of corrupt SJC justices (who have infamously decreed that Adams and Hancock ALSO "intended" that two men should be able to "marry", just as a man and woman); it was alive and well in Massachusetts in 1980 as well.The author's intellectual integrity matches that of the SJC, and that is all you need to know about the book. So, if you're a ponytailed, trust-funded Leftist moonbat, you'll love this book; if you're looking for the true history of the death penalty in Mass., you won't.

New Hampshire can be brutally cold in the Winter. You would think that after hours outside with little movement that even with these socks, your feet would get cold. No, TOASTY warm - always. Well worth even the full retail price.

This is a gigantic volume on Rolex watches; you can't just thumb through it in a few hours - even if you DO just look at the pictures. Great photographs by the hundreds; every Rolex ever produced. This is the Rolex BIBLE.

Alfred Dunhill usually produce more conservative-looking watches, yet this is a prestige watch sporty enough to wear while driving your Astin Martin. Heavy, Swiss-made watch will certainly last a lifetime. If you can get it for less than a thousand, jump on the deal.
this fan is quiet, i sleep with it on just 18" from my head. keeps me cool in summer. 2 settings

what a value, 6 for a small price. i bought these for the price of one of the other bottles. there is no cover with these but you can order separately. i got these for the size first, they are the right volume for me and to fit into car cup holders. they are thick and good quality design. mouth size is just right and the cap is secure. there is a good seal, TPR or silicone not sure, but works well and the treads on the cap are smooth. i am impressed and now i have enough to have at home, in the car, 2 in the office and give two away.

this version seems to have a longer handle when extended than the older version. simply pull the handle up, it locks in. push the lifting edge down flat to the floor and the wheels pop into place. fold it all up when done to a tiny system. great for garage, trunk of car, trade shows and executions.

wow! i had a burner that i was pretty happy with that cost just a few dollars less than this one. this one has 4 times the BTUs (210,000) and a much better spread of the heat due to the burner (many holes to spread heat evenly). the frame cylinder also helps because it keeps the heat directed under the pot instead of escaping out the sides. this thing heats fast and has less rick of burning what's in the pot due to the burner design. this is the best burner you can get for big cooks of any kind. i use mine for brewing and will never go back to a traditional burner. the steel braided hose is a bonus; great quality and longer than most others. simply the best.

great light-weight backpack. i almost want to use this for my vacation to Europe this year. it's good good features and is pretty comfy for such light weight. the shoulder straps can fold/roll and dig in a bit but not very much. really nice time, good price, great value.

Aug 20th 2015 updatei reached out to the seller who replaced the blast-like component. i will have an electrician install the new part and the light again shortly.i loved the light, brightness, area coverage, thinness. but it failed after 2 months.

a life saver. boiling and sweating away in Hawaii this summer (boo hoo, i know) and this is a life saver. in addition to running the AC putting this on the couch (back or seat) with a pillow case or thin towel helps keep me from burning up and going crazy. this is a huge deal. i should get a 2nd one. i use it for 30 minutes to 40 and then back to the freezer. my skin and muscle stays cool for another 20 to 30 minutes after use. move from back, to seat to top of legs then freezer.
best pill splitter i have used. clean cuts with little presort. softish pill cradle. only comment is that it is not designed to hold oblong pills well or oval ones. still good product.

very nice fan. medium size, good remote, long enough range at 30 maybe more. the unique front vent rotates via power and adjustable with the remote. that works well, makes it like a swiveling fan but w/o fan movement, just the vent. nice lines and not too loud.
best version for brewing needs. good thickness so it won;t crimp easily
sea salt! better for you than lab salt and good value for a 2 pack. grains are slightly larger than normal salt so that could be a factor based on your use.
unusual size and just what i need for beer bottling the home-brew. wide bucket; similar height as most 2 gallon buckets, just wider. clean and no flash. good buck and good value.

good value for quality blue paper for the office. we use the blue for faxes. so we can tell what is an order and what is a print (white) form someone in the office. good quality paper and no jamming. saves a ton of work form buying at a store and hauling to work.
i used these for years for me work planning and travel. now i have the staff put their travel on these. color-code by staff member to see where they are and were they are going. still the best

feels a bit sloppy and cheap but it does the job. i have not seen great reviews for any word lock, this one seems good enough to me and the orientation of the letters makes it easy to read while locked in use.
great for the office, sending notes to staff for excellent work. stick a reward gift card in there while you are at it. clean card lines and good sealing envelope. quality finish, simple and elegant.
great fan, super airflow and good value for such a large diameter fan.
good value for tape but it breaks a little easier than a locally sourced version. it also does not stick as well as other basic tape.

i got this version for work because  hate the big ugly buy ones. this is simple and low profile. one finger did break off, but only one and at work with people cramming stuff i here it's no surprise. i do like this and would buy it again.

these are the first walking shoes i have found in years they fit well and are comfy. my right foot is bigger than my left by a half size and so it's hard to find shoes that are flexible enough to not be tight on one foot and sloppy on the other. these also have a great thin tung which stays in place, centered on my instep. oh, i have a high instep too (top of my foot) and these don't squeeze or hurt. all around this shoe is ideal for me and might be for you too. my only gripe is that the sole is very thick. so it's a bit heavy and you have to consider that it adds a bit to your step since the sole is well below your foot sole. so if you are stair climbing for example this will lead to extra effort to get your foot on the next step. something that takes getting use to.
soft enough and firm enough. solid design and construction. heavy, holds on variety of surfaces (carpet, tile, concrete). i would get more of these.
gets it done, but not the best. seems kind of flimsy and thin. does not have a quality feel, but a good price.

love Pantene shampoo. i like the feel and the pump makes it easy. this one has a unique floral kind of aroma, pretty strong. i done;t recall that form my last color preserve Pro-V. this must be different. anyway, fine when dry but seem really aromatic when in the shower. kind of distracting actually somehow.
just a touch too small for a normal bowl of cereal. i like the quality and they don't seem to get soggy with milk. just need a little bigger, but still a good choice.
really good deal. nice fit, clear lens, readers are in the right spot and work great. ideal for car or travel.
as good as normal plastic spoons but better for the environment. similar price as Costco for same unit count but this box is better packed so 1/3 smaller. that is also greener for shipping. a winner.

good, pocket is nice, great value, break-away is smart (all panels velcro together so if you get hooked on racks they come apart instead of holding you to whatever got you). hi vis, but as expected kinda warm when layered on a shirt. still, great item.

the best by far. super light weight. they sit squarely on my face which is not symmetrical. the arm length is just right (shorter than most which i like so they don't slide down my nose). the optics are fantastic, better than all other plastic ones i have, more like glass when new. no distortion or aberration that i can detect. no eye strain, my script readers give me a headache and they cost $200. the only draw back if there is one is that they don't fold down flat for travel. so what, get 4 pair and leave them at home, in the car, at work yada yada. these rock!!!Update Mar 11 2015, i had to update already. these are so great. the nose support is easy to adjust and these are so light it's like they aren't there. i put the arms around my neck and leave the glasses around my neck so i have them east to reach. i can leave them on my face far down my nose so i can watch tv unobstructed and still pick up the iPad and read it. they are like micro readers for looking over but bigger lens for reading. and i can slide them up my nose for full computer reading glasses. unbelievable how great these are.Update March 16th 2015i bought a 2nd pair for my wife. 2.25 this time and purple frame. these have the assume arm design and general format but they are totally different. the lenses are smaller. the width of the frame and lens center is 3/4" narrower too. it's not clear to me if they are really 2.25 because they don;t seem much different form my 1.75, but they are a little stronger. i actually like this size better but note they are different. i think the purple is a lady size.

this thing blew when i installed it. and yes i could have made a mistake, but i installed another LED light when this one failed and it worked perfectly so it was not my mistake. it had promise but it is pricey for what you get and hard to install (for me) and it failed on install so it gets a 2 start rating. tow, not one because it is well made as far as construction goes.
good value of these types of lights. one of the two is sensitive and inconsistent. i have others of this model and no issues in general but this two pack has one that is not perfect.

Having three kids in school you can imagine pencils break like mad around here.All the handheld manual ones are honestly such a waste of money. Its small (doesn't take up much room) its really quick with sharpening a pencil, and  you can even use batteries to operate it. It comes with a tiny screw driver to remove the screws to where the batteries are. These wipes are so handy to have. They have a very pleasant mild scent. They are durable and thick. I have used them to wipe my dogs face and eyes out and they have not bothered his eyes at all. What a great idea! This aspirator comes in it's own case and has two extra tips. The tube and nasal piece are very soft and flexible. This will not hurt your baby's nose at all. Great for parents that have small children and winter time and stuffy noses are right around the corner. I would recommend this Mumcare Nasal Aspirator by Surefine Ningbo Medcare Co., Ltd. Very good quality shaving set. This set is made of chrome plated material. Looks very nice and comes with a brush for lathering and a razor with 5 replacement blades. This set has everything you need from trimming to cutting your beard, mustache, nose hairs, ear hairs. What ever you need is in this set. This set is of good quality. Scissors are really sharp. I have had quite a few bluetooth stereo speakers and I have to say this is on top in my opinion. The speaker is definitely good quality and lightweight and does a great job. What a wonderful set of socks. They feel so good on. They fit comfortably and have grips on the bottom to keep me from slipping and sliding on hardwood or lament floors. They washed up really good and didn't stretch out of shape. I would recommend these Pembrook Non Skid Socks by Pembrook. Sample provided without obligation.

What a great eyeliner. This goes on so good and drys within seconds of applying. I can choose how thick I was the liner to be. From very fine to extra thick. I would recommend this Liquid 1 Sec Quick Dry 24/7 Day Wear Liner by Qualizzi. Sample provided without obligation.

Good quality back seat organizer. It has a mesh pouch for holding an ipad or fire or what ever you choose to put in it. It is just my husband and I so we have no need for this to hold an ipad. I was really pleased with these bamboo tongs. They can be used apart or used in the silicone holder for a great salad tong. The spoon and fork are a smooth bamboo and are lightweight and easy to use. My cousin has a Maltese pup. She has such a hard time keeping her eyes clean. They turn red underneath and nothing she has done has made it white again. 2:07 MinsAt 11 inches tall this 1/4 scale beauty is by far the largest figure I own as of this review. She's also one  of the cutest as well. There are many Fate Testarossa figures out there to choose from but none as large as this one I believe. This is a very young version of her in a skimpy bathing suit sporting her trade mark twin tail hair style. I adore her swim suit. I like the design and color of it as well as the skirt she is removing as she seams to be walking toward the beach. The skirt  was a little hard to place into her little hands but well worth it. You can display her with or with out it but I plan on doing the former. I also plan on displaying her with the golden triangle thing (?) in her mouth. I like how they mirrored this triangle in a way on the back of her bathing suit bottom. It's a detail that's easy to miss. The overall detail of the figure is remarkable though not totally perfect. It's hard to see with the naked eye but there are some small paint issues here and there.Well I could go on but I will just say that if you are a fan of Fate or of really cute anime figures then you can't go wrong with this. I recommend it.

2:40 MinsBased on a online game called Dragon Nest this is the sorceress character. I've personally never played it but I have seen videos of it being played. So I don't know too much about her but I can adore her anyways. I was attracted to her pretty face and interesting outfit when I first saw her. I love her eyes and how her face is framed by her cute pink hair and the gold crown with a red jewel. There is also a blue jewel held by the neck piece of her top. And then there are two more jewels in the staff she holds as well. Of course none of them are the real thing but they really look cool. Her outfit is interesting for sure. Besides helping to grant her some sex appeal it also helps her to look a little like her bat like mascot that's perched on her out stretched right arm. She has the hood with bat like ears and she also has tiny wings on her back. Her little bat mascot is funny looking with its yellow bowtie and body scars with staples keeping it together. So in short this figure has cast a spell on me. This is an excellent figure from Good Smile Company and I can recommend it.

1:43 MinsThis is a pretty sweet folding knife. I would say it's geared toward an EMT being that it has a O2 tank wrench / thumb hole built into the blade. I am not an EMT so I couldn't say whether or not this functions as stated. I am just a knife / sword collector and this knife is just unique enough looking to stick out in my growing collection of neat looking knives. It's pretty for sure but it's also a completely functional knife. The blade itself is very sharp. I only wish that it was serrated the same on both sides. It's completely flat on one side as you will see in my video. I love the curved shape of it. I also love the 'emergency orange' color of the handle. It comes with an allen wrench and some extra screws in case you need to fix it as well to use to switch the pocket clip to which ever side your hand dictates. It's a cool folding knife that I can recommend.

2:07 MinsI got this to go along with the other Mega Bloks CAT set that I got to go with the construction site theme I've got in mind. It was incredibly easy to put together and took no longer than a half hour to do so. The parts were all there with a few extras and they fit together perfectly. I fond no flaws with this set. There's not much to it and the only function really is the bucket that moves up and down. I like the little traffic safety cones and safety barrier as well. The Mega Bloks brand is just as good as Lego in my opinion. I have quite a few Mega Bloks sets and they have all been just as good as the Lego sets I have.I recommend it!

2:36 MinsThis is a great little set for a great price (19.99 plus tax at the time of this review). My favorite thing about the set would be the back hoe but the asphalt roller is really cool. They were both real easy to put together and all the pieces were there. The construction workers are cool and more pose-able than any Lego mini fig but they are about a quarter of an inch taller too. I recommend it.I've said it before in other reviews. Lego is the king sure but Mega Bloks is the queen, OK I laughed a little after typing that last sentence but what I'm saying is that Mega Bloks are just as good as Legos. Better if you take the cost per piece into account. If you can't find what you want made by Lego it wouldn't hurt to check and see if Mega Bloks just might!

2:50 MinsThis is one of those prize figures that you play the 'claw' game to win in Japan. That being said you should know not to expect a masterpiece when buying one of these. I've seen this on Ami Ami for as cheap as 1500 yen used (under 15 dollars) but you also have to pay at least 1900 yen (a little under 19 dollars) for the cheapest and longest shipping and handling. So add that up and you will pay a little under 34 dollars total. This is why when I saw it on Amazon new for 34 dollars with free Prime shipping I jumped on it. I think it's very much worth that and instead of waiting two weeks for it I got it in three days.It's a very well done prize figure. If you look close enough you will find flaws but it didn't cost a lot so who cares. She will fit in quite well with my more expensive figures. I'm not too sure about the scale of the figure as it is not listed on the box but if I had to guess I would say it's 1/9th since it's bigger than my 1/10th scale figures and a little smaller than my 1/8th scale figures.I like her and recommend a purchase.

2:24 MinsThis cost me under 8 dollars so for the price it's quite nice. It's not perfect. The handle is made of rubber and plastic and is very lite weight. It makes it feel as cheap as its price. I like the look and feel of the handle though. I like the sheath and the knife stays snug in it. The blade is very sharp as well. I like it and recommend it!

1:45 MinsThere's really nothing I can say that hasn't been said by everyone else and that you can't read in the knives description. I can say that this is one of my favorite knives. The assisted opening mechanism is by far the best of any that I own. It's a really sweet knife and I like it a lot. I recommend it!

2:50 MinsThis is an excellent figure. It's from Alter which is known for some of the best figures out there. It's not perfect by any means but you have to look really close to see the issues it does have. She is based on a character from an adults only pc game called Beat Blades Haruka. I've never played it but I have watched an anime based on it and it is for sure not meant for kids either. This figure is one of my favorites that I own. I really like the red of her outfit. It really helps her stand out amongst the other figures that I own. If your a fan of extremely cute anime figures then this one is for you!

1:57 MinsThis is an OK knife. The spring auto-clip is alright if you plan on keeping it in your pocket I guess. It's the only 'different' thing about this knife. I can't complain since it's a inexpensive knife but I can't really throw much praise on it either. It's really just a plain looking folding knife. The blade on mine is very sharp. The handle is a black plastic (GRN?) which really makes it seem cheap. It was a gift so I don't feel like I can really comment on the price except to say that I don't think I would have bought it for myself to be honest. I own better knives.

3:21 MinsThis is a figure of Yoko the main heroine from the anime series Gurren Lagann. If you're checking out this figure I'm sure that you know this so I wont go on and on about it. This is a pretty awesome figure that is obviously a prize from one of those Sega prize machines in Japan. It's a good one too. I like how Boota is hanging onto Yoko's top by his teeth. It makes this figure unique amongst the many, many, many other ones of Yoko out there. Also the base is unique. It is the hand of the Gurren Lagann. She does wiggle a little if you move her around but she's pretty secure in the hand of Gurren Lagann. The actual base of mine is different than the one pictured in that instead of the anniversary symbol it has a symbol of Yoko's skull shaped hair barrette. She's not a perfect figure since you can see some of her mold lines but she didn't cost that much and they're not that noticeable. She's also a lot bigger than I thought she would be at a smidgen over 12 inches high including the base. I love it and absolutely recommend a purchase.

1:51 Mins746 Mini-Onslaught Bench Made folding knife. LUM Design USA. This is by far the best and most expensive folding knife that I own. I love the AXIS locking mechanism which is much better than the normal liner locks I own. This is one incredibly designed  piece of engineering. I like the ambidextrous thumb-hole opener in the blade. I love everything about this knife.Measurements.Blade length 3 1/4 inches long.Closed 4 1/2 inches long.Overall 7 3/4 inches long.

1:13 MinsNice little folding knife for a very fair price. I've had it for a while and am quite pleased with it. I like the bored out holes in the handle and how extremely sharp the blade is. I recommend it.Measurements.7 1/2 inches overall.4 1/4 inches closed.3 inch blade.

2:15 MinsThis is an alright figure for the price I paid. You do, as they say, get what you paid for though. It has some paint issues mostly. She's a pretty figure for sure but not perfect. The skin color overlaps some of her clothes. And while she herself is not that detailed her pair of guns are quite detailed. No I really means her weapons. I also like her short sword she has on her back as well. Her wood plank base is really cool as well. All in all an alright figure.

2:18 MinsThis is now the fourth neck knife that I own and is by far the very best of them all. It cost more than the other three all together. I love the design of this little guy. I like the skinny handle that is covered with a rubber like material. I also like the blade itself. It is extremely sharp. The sheath is also really nice and keeps the blade quite securely in place. I also love the fact that unlike the other three neck knives I have this one has the same chain they use for army nametags instead of a leather cord.Some measurements.With the knife in it's sheath it's 7 1/4 inches long.The knife is 6 1/2 inches long overall.The blade is 2 3/8 inches long.The handle is 3 1/2 inches long.

3:15 MinsThis set of three mini figures of Super Sonico are extremely cute. And I mean uber cute. All three stand at almost 3 1/2 inches tall on their stands. Yes they are super small but also super detailed. They weren't cheap at almost 60 dollars (20 a piece) but I think they were worth it. For once unlike with other sets I've bought I actually do not have a favorite of the three. I love each one just the same. Super Sonico is a very popular property right now and there are a ton of pvc figures out there. These are based on an illustration by Mota which you can see on the box they come in. They look just like the art. They are also the only Super Sonico figures I own. I'm very happy with them.

1:41 MinsThis is the third Queen's Blade figure I own. I have a Revoltech figure of Alleyne but she is more of an action figure than a statue like this beauty. I also own a statue of Menace but she's not anywhere near as perfect as this statue. I'm really impressed with this little lady and I'm very happy I got her. I like that she has a totally separate nude torso instead of cast off clothes. I do not show this in my video however. I also like her near gravity defying pose.I recommend a purchase.

2:26 MinsGot this little lady from a local comic shop for under 40 dollars. She was well worth it. Don't know too much about her or the game she was designed for but I do know her character designer is Tony Taka and he is one of my favorite artist. She comes attached to her base and the only thing I had to do was place her bow in her hand. I recommend a purchase.

2:24 MinsWhat an awesome find. I went to buy a Kureha figure at a local comic book store and walked away with this gem for under 40 dollars. I will admit I know little about her. She is a foxy lady for sure. I know she's a character from the video game Shining Hearts and was created by the artist Tony Taka. She's super cute and I love her fox attributes. I really like her four knives and how she's holding them in her knuckles. She was well worth the 40 bones.

1:57 MinsThis is my second set of throwing knives. I like my first set but I really like this set much more. I love the size of them and the red cord wrapped around the handles. They are around 8 inches long and very sharp. They came out of the box with some oily residue on them but it easily wiped off. What I don't like is the sheath they come with. While it 'works' I think it's too small for all three knives. Not a big deal though. I really like them and recommend them.

There are any number of post-apocalyptic films out there with greatly varying degrees of quality. For my dollar this was one of the better.Here's the scoop. Set in Barcelona a biologically based type of agoraphobia is slowly seizing the city (the world?). If people attempt to go outside they die. Marco, a programmer specializing in cyber security is being interviewed by Enrique who specializes in firing people. As the disease spreads the two are forced into an uneasy alliance. Marco wants to find his pregnant girlfriend. Enrique needs to get to his disabled father. It's a rough journey.The internet is replete with quips on how the younger generation is a sicker lot because they don't play outside in the dirt, step in dog doo-doo or drink from the garden hose. This film uses that idea as a basis for the disease. Even these middle somethings don't experience life directly. They see things through windows, TV screens and computer screens. So it were as though the outside world simply said "to hell with you." The journey between the two is arduous. They meet all kind of people, both good and bad, with their own problems and agendas.This is a very good film and one of the best of the genre. The acting, sets, set decoration, editing and such make the viewer believe what they're seeing. There's a battle in a super market that is truly horrifying. It is directed with a seriously fluid camera which adds to the sense of immediacy. The story arc and developing relationship between Marco and Enrique I found unique. I can't say they come to actually like one another but they get to respect one another. The post script is cool as well. I won't spoil it but I think all who see it should take heart.I saw the directors' previous effort "Carriers" which is very similar in that it deals more with the human side of the situation than the situation itself. I liked that well enough but they show a more deft hand in the directing here. I'll look forward to their next effort.If you're at all disposed toward this type of movie this is a good bet.

Part drama. Part love story. This film falls somewhere in between but satisfies neither genre.Here's the scoop. Catherine (Gwyneth Paltrow) has been taking care of her father (Anthony Hopkins) who was once a brilliant mathematician but has gone round the bend over resent years. A younger math geek (Jake Gyllenhaal) has been living in the house and gleaning whatever wisdom he can from pops. Dad passes away and sister Claire (Hope Davis) flies in from New York to try and help. A seemingly brilliant math proof emerges but who is the author? Is it dad's or Catherine's?There's a lot to like in this flick. Paltrow is as good as I've seen her. She wears no makeup and looks somewhere between haunted and exhausted. She's worried she might have caught dad's crazy gene and can't finisher her math studies. She can't concentrate and knuckle down. Hope Davis doesn't get ti. She's been doing the successful New York business thing and stuff that is important to her seems trivial in light over everything else that is happening. Gyllenhaal isn't really putting himself out here. He's stretched a lot more in other recent outings. Hopkins is his usual great self and Hope Davis is at the top of her game. She means well and is sincere, but she just doesn't get it.The math speak sounds authentic. David Auburn, who wrote the script from his original play, either knows math well or did some serious research. The sets, directing, music and such are all befitting of the project. I guess the problem lies in the tug of war between Paltrow's struggling with her own demons and the developing relationship between her and Gyllenhaal. Neither has a very impactful climax. You see it. It's there. But you don't feel it. The final scene says the two might get there but it was too soft for my dollar.The average rating here from users is 3 1/2 stars and that's a safe bet. I went to the four because it deserves to be seen. Three stars might keep people from seeing a very worthwhile effort.

Hadn't seen this in a long (long) time. Thought I'd revisit. The ride was absolutely worth the fare.Here's the scoop. Frank Galvin (Paul Newman), a once prominent lawyer, is now crawling deeper and deeper into a whiskey bottle. He's lost the few cases he's had. His office is crappy and he wallows in self pity. A case comes up regarding a woman who was put into a coma during a botched operating procedure. The hospital will settle but something in him awakens and tells him to go to trial. The odds are stacked high against him so he needs to reach way down to to win this one.The script for this was derived from a book and the outline was so good it seemed it could have written itself. Galvin is up against a crack, high priced law firm. His resources, Jack Warden, are tiny. The opposition is playing dirty and, like in a Hitchcock flick, you wonder how the hero can dig himself out of this enormous hole. Director Sidney Lumet was already well seasoned when he helmed this outing. David Mamet penned the script. Though only his third outing in film he shows a deft hand. The viewer gets queezy watching the noose tighten around Galvin's neck. And, of course, you get the the tiny glimmer of light that brings hope to the entire scenario.Newman is as good as he's ever been. Jack Warden plays the loyal buddy well. He walks the fine line of being a friend but not letting Galvin stray to far. James Mason, Milo O'Shea, Lindsay Crouse and Charlotte Rampling all do stand up jobs. All the areas areas of production are likewise top shelf. This is a solid piece all the way around.Some might complain this is too cookie cutter. I can't say I'd disagree but it's so well done I couldn't care. If you like a good courtroom drama, have at it.

This is more evidence that crime/mystery series fro TV have gotten so much better over the years.Here's the scoop. In a small-ish town in norther France, someone is digging up recently buried bodies form cemeteries and displaying them in model homes as though they were a family. A middle aged mother and father along with a child. A female detective Sandra Winckler (with more than a bit of personal baggage) is brought in on the case. An ex department detective (her mentor from 8 years prior) also joins the case. The case somehow involves him and she needs to try to work the mystery of the case as well as the mystery of her new partner.This is a a very involved plot. The clues are meted out evenly but the answers still manage to elude the viewer. The sub-plots of Sandra and he boyfriend, her partner's mysterious "car accident" help flesh out the character side of things. She's got pretty severe OCD but they drop this fairly early on in the proceedings. But it's curious she would have that need for control but still wear ridiculously high heeled boots on the job. That being said, the characters are generally well written. The music score and sound design are very cool. They quietly underline the creep factor building up. And the end isn't quite the end. Not in a cheap way. The viewer realizes there is more than one story happening here.If you are a fan of "The Killing," "The Bridge," or Broadchurch," this should be right up your alley.

I'm a huge fan of the first two Mad Max movies and viewed both of them in anticipation of going to see "Fury Road." Unfortunately, it wasn't the experience I'd hoped it would be.Here's the scoop. Max gets captured by some thugs and given a glimpse of their stronghold overseen by Immortan Joe (Hugh Keays-Byrne) and his minions. He oversees a huge population and keeps them in line by meting out small amounts of water and food. He also keeps a cache of young women, known as "breeders." herein lies the rub. Imperator Furiosa (Charlize Theron) Is supposed to be on a fuel run. She is, in fact, spiriting away the breeders so they can find a better life. She and Max become unlikely allies.On the good side is the excess. This is so over the top you can't see the top. All the costumes, cars, weapons, etc. are a visual feast. You don't believe it but it's still really cool. The action is unbelievable. At the conceptual level it's remarkable. On the execution level it's even more remarkable. You simply cannot believe what you're seeing. Some stunts seem actual, some must have been CG but the blend is seamless so it's impossible to tell the difference.On the downside is the story. It's pretty thin. Just enough outline to get you from one action scene to the next. Then there's the Max character. I'm not certain why Tom Hardy took the gig. They try to couch his wanting to help the women in terms of redemption for people he tried but failed to help in the past. It's too vague and carries no emotional punch. Max has way too few lines so there is a hole where Max should be.That being said, this is still a heck of a watch. It's as exciting a movie as you are likely to see and, for my dollar, is better the "Beyond Thunderdome." It's probably better than the three stars I gave it but shy of four. If you're a fan, indulge yourself. If not......

Horror anthologies pop up every now and then and all seem to be a combo of hit and miss. Employing different writers and directors in any given project must, by nature, yield varying results. This is no different.Here's the scoop. Not unlike 1001 Arabian Nights this starts with Deborah Harry who is going to kill and cook a young boy she has imprisoned. He figures to stay his execution by reading her the better stories in the book "Tales From the Darkside." She does become intrigued and listens patiently as he reads to her.Unlike other anthologies this employs different writers but only one director, John Harrison, who directed the TV series of the same name. It's in a similar vein as "Tales From the Crypt." On the good side is seeing actors like Steve Buscemi, Julianne Moore and Christian Slater in the earlier parts of their careers. On the not as good side are the stories themselves. Story number one involves Buscemi getting revenge on a couple of trust fund nogoodniks who cheated him out of an academic high spot. It barely decent with an ironic-ish ending containing little effect. Story number two involves William hickey, head of a pharmaceutical empire, hiring a hitman to kill his cat who he thinks is out to get him. Thi si better than the previous story but only marginally so. And, again, the irony in the ending just isn't that good. Story three is the best. It has the greatest depth and is, by far, more interesting. And....I didn't see the end coming which is a good thing. It involves a starving artist (James Remar) who witnesses a demon murdering someone. But he must keep it hush hush or his life will be forfeit.This is modestly budgeted and is an okay watch. Just don't expect any real scares or great depths of thought. Get our beer and pizza and relax.

Why am I writing this? This movie is twelve years old at the time I'm writing this. When I first saw it I liked it quite a bit some something seemed wrong. Something about it irked me. Upon viewing it again it occurred to me what felt wrong. Can a movie be too perfect?Here's the scoop. Captain Nathan Algren (Tom Cruise) was a post Civil War officer haunted by his involvement in the senseless slaughter of native Americans. Now he's on a road tour hawking Winchester rifles for the company. He drinks too much and has terrible nightmares. The Japanese are working to close a trade deal with the U.S. as they become more westernized. The more traditional Japanese are opposing this and will fight for their beliefs. Algren is hired by the government to train Japanese troops to put down the uprising. As Algren gets captured by the opposition, he gets to realize a different destiny.This is an epic film in all ways. Great, sprawling landscapes. A huge climactic battle involving serious numbers of extras and a big story. But, as I mentioned, it might be too perfect. It were as though they honed the script with a fine tooth comb, laid out every shot and edit and went made it without a second thought. Given the subject matter I would figure it would have more fire but it didn't. Even the beautifully choreographed fight and battle sequences needed a bit more umph. The script looks as though it could have written itself. Once you have the outline it's a matter of filling in the blanks. Don't get me wrong. I liked it....a lot. But again, I needed some surprises. Some something that just wasn't there.All the key actors, Cruise, Ken Watanabe, Billy Connolly, Tim Spall et al do a stand-up job. For my dollar there is no weak link in this entire film. It just needed a bit more crazy.

I, like many of the of the mainland Americans, never took the ukelele seriously. I had no idea of its stature in Hawaii, Seeing the likes of Tiny Tim and others use it as light accompaniment to their singing seemed to reduce its status to a baby guitar. That all changed in a heartbeat while viewing this documentary.Here's the scoop. This film chronicles the life of Jake Shimabukuro roughly from his beginning to play the ukelele at age four to his entering the entertainment industry and beyond.This is a truly remarkable eye opener. Never have I seen the ukelele played like this. And to hear it adapt itself to so many types of music. Jake plays rock, classical, jazz, blues and on. He plays effortlessly, beautifully and with such emotion I was awed that such a range of expression could be had from such a small instrument sporting only two octaves. And his evolution of thinking about his playing when he began to realize how much can be said in the space between the notes.He is shown through all the times of his career. Early episodes with him playing in the band "Pure Heart" and on with all types of bands as well as accompanying noted singers. He was (is?) the go to guy (much like The Chieftans) for many in the music field. He himself is very engaging. He seems like a genuinely nice person and loves to perform. He is by no means a quiet performer. But listening to him talk you realize he has no boundaries. He will constantly reexamine his instrument and expand/adapt it to all styles of music.I realize it might be difficult to impart how wonderful it is to see him play what might have been considered a minor instrument. But, believe me, it's like watching a violin virtuoso. I know whose CDS are going on my next birthday list.This is as good a documentary as I've ever seen. Dig it.

David Lynch, right from the get go with "Eraserhead", has proven himself one of the more "outside" and elusive directors of our time. He may often leave one scratching one's head but his films are always intriguing. "Blue Velvet" might be one of his more accessible endeavors.Here's the scoop. Jeffrey Beaumont (Kyle MacLachlan) is in town to help out at his father's hardware store during dad's stay in the hospital. He finds a human ear in a field and gives it to the police. He befriends the chief detective's daughter (Laura Dern) who tips him off to some of the case. he two want to find out what they can on their own which leads them into the underbelly of their seemingly idyllic, middle American, town. Danger ensues.This is a crazy, scarey flick. Much of the scare comes from Kyle and Laura entering a world inhabited by true nut-jobs such as Frank (Dennis Hopper) and Ben (Dean Stockwell). Frank in particular is like a bomb that can go off at any time. You want to be as far away from him as possible. And they ARE dangerous. They are in with crooked cops in plots that involve drugs and kidnapping. The juxtaposition between these two near innocents and the likes of the bad guys is striking. And as Jeffrey gets drawn deeper in, and finds himself doing things he would never have dreamed doing, his unraveling is painful. But he is determined to help the nightclub singer (Isabella Rossallini) get her son back.I can't say I understood everything going on here. But the dark underbelly and bug subtext, the homo-erotic underpinnings are fairly constant and help add to the sense of menace. The opening scene with the red, white and blue color scape, the white picket fence and camera digging to ground level where you see the bugs in all their violent glory pretty much tell the viewer where he's headed.If you're at all a Lynch fan this should do you well.

There have been a few movies over the decades dealing with a virulent disease, being loosed on a large population, that needs to be dealt with sooner than later. Some, such as the zombie laden "World War Z" or "Contagion" are among the better. "Flu", for my dollar, is right up there.Here's the scoop. A guy, locked in a shipping container with many others being smuggled into Korea, is really sick. By the time they are set loose all his fellow containees are dead. Only he survives while the virus begins infecting the city in record time. Meanwhile, a first time responder rescues a doctor from her car which is about to plummet into an underground labyrinth. To his chagrin, she doesn't seem all that grateful. But soon he, the doctor and her young daughter are in a race to find a cure for the virus before the entire city becomes history.This is a really cool flick. It is densely and cleverly plotted which brings visions of Hollywood producers scrambling for their version of it. You have the search for the survivor, by the medical community, as he holds the key to the cure. But he's also hunted by the brother of a guy killed by the disease. Then there are the authorities trying to find the cure while keeping a quarter of a million people quarantined who are frightened to levels bordering on mass panic. Then you have the first responder who is trying to keep the doctor's daughter safe because she might be proof the cure works. And the clock is ticking. The story factions all work well. The characters a good. The hero has a comic side-kick to help things from becoming too overwrought. There are some key scenes involving large numbers of citizens beginning to riot which are staged very well. There are also scenes of what is becoming a mass grave that are quite eerie. There are other serious aspects of the story happening too numerous to note here, but let it be said, this all culminates in a very rousing climax. The split second timing of said climax might put some off and rightfully so, but it's still a heck of a ride.The directing of some of the scenes seemed a bit rushed but most were directed spot on. The main characters were generally good though they do paint the American medical authorities as being a bit too hard-edged. What really is happening here is the plotting. It's a cool story told really well.I'm not necessarily given to these types of flicks but this is about as good as I've seen.

Groucho Marx's long-running quiz show "You Bet Your Life" was broadcast both on TV and on radio. This cassette contains two episodes of the radio version. If you're not familiar with Groucho's quiz show, it was a very entertaining show which typically devoted more time to Groucho chatting with the contestants and making funny quips than it did to the actual game.On one of the episodes on this cassette, TV comedy legend Ernie Kovacs is a guest. In the other episode, Groucho's guests are two 9-year-old girls. One of them is future "Murphy Brown" star Candice Bergen (Then only known as the daughter of ventriloquist Edgar Bergen), and the other is Melinda Marx, Groucho's daughter.The episodes seem to be complete but without commercials. They only run about 23 minutes each, so the entire cassette only runs 46 minutes. If you can find these same episodes included in a larger collection on CD or in MP3 format, that might be a better option. However, for the low price of this cassette, I can't imagine anyone would regret buying it. I am recommending it for both entertainment value and historical value. However, I could not give it the maximum 5-star rating due to its relatively short total running time.

This is not the only time someone re-did non-classical songs in a classical style. There have been multiple volumes of Beatles songs done in classical style under the title "Beatles Symphonic", and various orchestras and conductors have done classical-style renditions of songs by pop musicians such as Bob Dylan, Whitney Houston, and others.I usually enjoy listening to these "converted to classical" albums, but among all that I've heard, this one is the best! Conductor Grant Gershon has shown tremendous talent in fleshing out these songs, and faithfully emulating the styles of various old-time composers. He doesn't merely have his orchestra play the familiar tunes on classical instruments; he expands on and fleshes out each song, adding atmosphere and power to the new renditions; he elevates them to the level of classical masterpieces.If you enjoy great classical music but want to hear something brand new, I give this CD my highest recommendation.I only wish there was a second volume to follow this CD. There are many more TV theme songs that would lend themselves very well to classical adaptations. For instance, how about the "Dragnet" theme played in the style of Beethoven? (I've always found the "Dragnet" theme to be a bit reminiscent of the first part of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony.)

I bought a used copy of this book for 50 cents. I definitely overpaid.This book does NOT contain well-researched insights into the subconscious. It is based on the screwy premise that dreams are a form of ESP and predicts one's future, and that only the author can tell you the true "meanings" of what you've dreamt. The author's interpretations of what your dreams supposedly predicted usually have no logical correlation to the dreams. Get this:The first part of the entry for "cats" says: "To dream of a cat, denotes ill luck, if you do not succeed in killing it and driving it from your sight."Part of the entry for "fire" reads: "To dream of seeing your home burning, denotes a loving companion, obedient children, and careful servants. For a business man to dream that his store is burning, and he is looking on, fortells a great rush in business and profitable results."Got that? According to this book, to dream you're petting a soft, furry kitten means that bad things will happen to you; but to dream of seeing your home or business burning down means that good things will happen. WTF?I thumbed through this sleazy, unscientific tome and looked up various other entries, and everything supposedly predicts good or bad fortune in some absurdly twisted way. This book was pure hogwash when it was first published in 1909 and it is still pure hogwash today. It's amazing that such a heap of trash has actually been re-printed all these years later.Spend your money on a "Magic 8 Ball" instead; it has the same rate of accuracy.

It is based on the screwy premise that dreams are a form of ESP and predicts one's future, and that only the author can tell you the true "meanings" of what you've dreamt. The author's interpretations of what your dreams supposedly predicted usually have no logical correlation to the dreams. Get this:The first part of the entry for "cats" says: "To dream of a cat, denotes ill luck, if you do not succeed in killing it and driving it from your sight."Part of the entry for "fire" reads: "To dream of seeing your home burning, denotes a loving companion, obedient children, and careful servants. For a business man to dream that his store is burning, and he is looking on, fortells a great rush in business and profitable results."Got that? According to this book, to dream you're petting a soft, furry kitten means that bad things will happen to you; but to dream of seeing your home or business burning down means that good things will happen. WTF?I thumbed through this sleazy, unscientific tome and looked up various other entries, and everything supposedly predicts good or bad fortune in some absurdly twisted way. This book was pure hogwash when it was first published in 1909 and it is still pure hogwash today. It's amazing that such a heap of trash has actually been re-printed all these years later.Spend your money on a "Magic 8 Ball" instead; it has the same rate of accuracy.

I bought this mower two years ago. It still functions as well as it did when I first bought it.There is no gasoline to deal with. You just plug the detachable battery into a charger until it's fully charged. On one charge, there is enough power to mow about two-thirds of my lawn. Then I have to re-charge it and mow the rest of the lawn the next day. (I don't know what my yard's size is in acres, but I'd say it's about average size.) Someone with a smaller than average yard should be able to mow their entire lawn on one charge. If you have a huge and spacious yard this might not be the best mower for you.It's good for mowing lawn that is at a normal "needs mowing" length, but if you have some spots with super-thick/high lawn, the motor shuts off. Just go through the thick spots quickly and you can still get them.The Black and Decker CM1936 mower is not perfect, but I'm pleased with it overall. I will probably continue to use it for several more years to come.

In this videotaped stage show from 1982, Gabe Kaplan (best known for playing Mister Kotter on "Welcome Back Kotter") does a terrific job of playing Groucho Marx at various stages of his life.Groucho tells his life story to the audience. At regular intervals, Kaplan and Michael Tucci as Chico faithfully (and hilariously) re-create some classic bits of dialogue from several Marx Brothers stage shows, films, and from a long-forgotten Marx Brothers radio program called "Flywheel, Shyster and Flywheel".This production was co-written by Groucho's son, Arthur Marx, so you can safely assume most of the facts are accurate. The behind-the-scenes information about Groucho and his brothers are fascinating and surprising. This play does a great job of simultaneously entertaining while informing.Like most of us, Groucho had his share of tragedies and setbacks in his long life, but the play never allows you to be sad for too long, as another hilarious Groucho zinger always comes promptly to lift the briefly somber mood.One complaint: For no apparent reason, there is no actor playing Harpo. Harpo is represented by periodic off-stage horn honks.Despite that one imperfection, I would highly recommend this taped performance to any fan of the Marx Brothers.P.S. There is an alternate version of this same show available on DVD called "Groucho - A Life in Revue" starring Frank Ferrante as Groucho. I have not seen that version, so I cannot do any comparisons.

First the good points: It's BPA free, and it holds 32 ounces of water, a lot more than most sports water bottles hold.Unfortunately, this water bottle is awful for use in a car. First, it's too wide to fit in a standard car's cup holder. Second, if placed on a car floor, it tips over very easily, and whenever it does, the top almost always pops open and the water spills all over the place.If you plan to use exclusively at home, you don't need to worry about knocking it over so much, so in that case I would recommend it. If, however, you want something to take along on road trips, pass it up.

I didn't expect anything exciting to happen using this thing. I thought it was just a harmless toy. My girlfriend came to my house one weekend last October and I convinced her to use this thing with me for just a few minutes. That was a big mistake!We placed our fingers lightly on the pointer, as the instructions say to do. I asked, "Hey! Any spirits or ghosts out there?" In an instant, a spirit named Repsac entered my body! I was later told that my girlfriend had to rip the plastic pointer out of my hand, and it left a permanent burn scar on my hand where I had held it!Repsac left my body in a few minutes, but has since possessed me again on numerous occasions! I never know when he will enter my body or how long he will stay. Therefore, I must warn everyone to stay away from....THIS IS REPSAC SPEAKING! DO NOT LISTEN TO THE MINDLESS RAMBLINGS OF ERIC PERLIN! One of the most ridiculous and inept movies ever made, comparable to Ed Wood's "Plan 9 From Outer Space". Unless you've seen either that film or this one, you have never seen just how bad a motion picture can be. The worst films most of us have ever seen still have a basic level of professionalism to them that "The Creeping Terror" lacks.A shaggy, faceless monster from a distant planet crawls very slowly and eats people so that aliens can collect data from it to learn about earth people so they can invade the earth. The "monster" is played by a group of people wearing a large shag rug. It moves very slowly, and its many victims just sit still and wait to be eaten. There is extensive narration to cover for a soundtrack that was somehow lost during filming, but that only adds to this film's campiness and ineptitude.It's astonishing that this film was actually released to movie theaters. I don't think a five-year-old could find this monstrosity scary. "The Creeping Terror" is a total failure as a horror film, but it's an unintentional success as a comedy.

Laurel and Hardy were the funniest comedy duo of all time. Their films are just as hilarious today as they were when they were made.This set has many of their greatest films, and is accurately called "The Essential Collection" but not "The Complete Collection".A complete collection at this point in time is impossible, as a small handful of earlier L&H films are missing or partially missing.The rights to L&H films are owned by various companies, and two of their full-length features "The Flying Deuces" and "Utopia" are in the public domain and owned by everyone.To obtain as complete a collection of L&H films as is currently possible, I highly recommend buying, in addition to this set:  > The Lost Films of Laurel and Hardy, Volumes 1 - 9 (Out of print but available used; consists of all existing silent L&H films, plus numerous solo films)  > TCM Archives: The Laurel and Hardy Collection (The Devil's Brother / Bonnie Scotland)  > March of the Wooden Soldiers (Colorized / Black & White)  > The Flying Deuces (Restored Edition)  > Laurel and Hardy Collection, Vol. 1 (Great Guns / Jitterbugs / The Big Noise)  > Laurel and Hardy Collection, Vol. 2 (A Haunting we Will Go / Dancing Masters / Bullfighters)  > Laurel and Hardy: Air Raid Wardens / Nothing But Trouble (2006)  > UtopiaLaurel and Hardy made a number of silent films between 1927 and 1929, and most of these were released on DVD a number years ago in 9 volumes. These are now out of print, and a set of all 9 volumes is, as of right now, super-expensive. So, to obtain as complete a collection as possible, wait for these films to be re-released or buy them on VHS.As for "The Essential Collection", each film is restored to the best condition possible, and many of the L&H films that exist in more than one version have both versions included. (European versions sometimes had more footage or alternate endings.)Although colorized versions of several Laurel & Hardy films have been done, none are included here, which I think is good because including colorized versions along with the black & white originals would have resulted in a much larger, bulkier and pricier set.There are approximately 50 films included in this collection. (Thank you, Scott MacGillivray, for listing the contents in your review!) While some are better than others, all of them are good. If you're not familiar with Laurel & Hardy's work, don't worry about deciding which film to watch first. You can pop in any disc in the set at random, and you're sure to see a great comedy.

Although I think Bob Hope was somewhat overrated as a comedian, I enjoyed some of his earlier movies, and I admire him for flying overseas to do USO shows in four separate wars.I caught this movie several years ago when it was shown unedited on TV, and I expected to enjoy it, but there was not a single funny moment in it at all.Besides being unfunny, it's possibly the most racially insensitive movie since "Birth of a Nation" in 1915. American Indians are depicted as non-humans. The main premise of the movie is that Calamity Jane shoots a lot of Indians, and lets Bob Hope take the credit. Bob Hope is lauded as a hero by the townspeople for wiping out all those Indians. American Indians are repeatedly shot dead on sight just because they're Indians, and this is depicted as an act of great heroism.Normally, I'm pretty tolerant of ethnic stereotyping in old movies because I'm able to understand such films' historical contexts (for example, the stereotyping of Japanese people in films made during World War II). And I can generally enjoy a good 1930's comedy film that has one or two brief scenes of ethnic stereotyping.In "The Paleface", the degrading depictions are not just one scene but a major part of the movie's plot. Moreover, it's beyond mere stereotyping to suggest that it's noble to go around blowing away every American Indian in sight.I'll probably be berated by Bob Hope fans for being overly "PC", but this film's depiction of American Indians as the equivalent of cockroaches is hard for me to overlook. To those who are planning to say, "It's only a movie", ask yourself how you would feel about a comedy that treated all Irish or Jewish people as vermin that should all be blown away. Would you still say "It's only a movie"?Even aside from all the Indian killing, I don't remember a single funny gag at any point in this film.If you want to see a good western comedy, try "Way Out West", "Cat Ballou" or "Blazing Saddles".

This is technically not a movie, but a movie-length TV special that originally aired in the late 1970's. Milton Berle introduces a series of very well-chosen excerpts from Abbott & Costello's TV series (not their movies). Additional commentaries by Joe Besser and Steve Allen are also included.Many of the best burlesque comedy skits ever performed are featured in their entirety: "Slowly I Turn", "Herd of Cows", "Floogle Street", "Who's On First", and many others. (It's not quite complete, however. I wish it included the "Mudder and Fodder" routine, but you can't have everything.)The narration by Milton Berle is dull, but fortunately, there's only a small amount of it. Aside from that, this DVD is a non-stop laugh riot all the way through! Abbott & Costello made many good movies through the 1940's and 1950's, but in my opinion even the best of them fall short of the laugh quotient of this superb compilation. With this disc, you don't have to sit through plot-advancing scenes or musical numbers while you wait for the funny parts. Pretty much the whole thing is the funny parts!If you can only own one Abbott & Costello DVD, this is the one to get.

I consider this to be one of L&H's funniest films. Liberty and most other L&H short films are easily worth buying at the same price you would normally pay for a full-length film, because there are more laughs in 20 minutes than there are in most full-length comedies.The plot has L&H escaping from prison, and they quickly change out of their striped prison uniforms and into their regular clothes while being chased by police. In their haste, each one accidentally puts on the other's pants. They look for a place to change their pants, while inadvertently being caught repeatedly with their pants down in public places.One of several places they duck into to change is the elevator to a building under construction, where Stan accidentally hits the lever, bringing them up to the top floor.There are very few comedy films of any era that can compare to those of Laurel and Hardy, and this is one of their best.

I bought this item to make homemade french fries. All you need to do is fill the fryer with oil, dice several potatoes and toss them in. In about an hour, you'll have the best french fries you've ever tasted.The basket is large enough to hold a lot of fries, and they come out great. The homemade fries made with this fryer taste better than any restaurant's fries.I NEVER add ketchup to the fries I cook in this fryer, as it would only drown out the great flavor they have.Side note: I only use olive oil when I deep-fry, as I've heard it does not clog one's arteries like most other cooking oils. Also, fries cooked in pure olive oil tend to taste better, as the potato slices absorb the olive flavor while cooking.SAFETY PRECAUTIONS: There is a potential fire risk when cooking oil gets too hot. From what I've heard, olive oil is a somewhat greater fire risk than other cooking oils because it's "flash point" heat level is somewhat lower. The maximum heating level becomes even lower when the same olive oil has been re-used several times. Therefore, it is important to always dump out the olive oil after a few uses and replace it with fresh oil, and never keep your stove above a MEDIUM level. The fries will take some time to cook, but be patient. I assure you they're totally worth the wait!

I bought this album on cassette at a garage sale about 18 years ago for 25 cents, having no idea who George Fischoff is. I soon found out that he is a first-rate composer and musician!All the songs on this album are original compositions, composed and played by George Fischoff, and therefore cannot be found anywhere else.Despite the title, there are other instruments used besides the piano. I don't know whether this music should be classified as jazz, pop, classical or what; but whatever the heck it is, it's terrific. Fischoff shows impressive versatility; some of his songs are perky and whimsical, others are slow and mellow, while others are bold and triumphant. All are purely instrumental.I'm glad to see this album is now available in other formats besides LP and cassette. To anyone who appreciates good instrumental music that differs from the standard run-of-the-mill hit rock songs that dominate the radio airwaves, I would very highly recommend "Pretty Kitty" in whatever format you can get it in.

The only edition of this book as of this writing is a "2007" edition, actually published in 2006. A lot more TV series and TV seasons have been released on DVD in the four years since its publication.It's great to have this book to tell you which DVD sets include complete episodes and which have altered or truncated episodes; which sets scramble the order of episodes (so you have to skip around to go from part 1 to part 2 of a 2-part episode); and what extras, if any, are included.However, no two people are going to agree on which TV series were good and which were lousy, so when the author praises or pans a particular TV series, you can take his opinions with a grain of salt. You already know what you like and dislike. People who buy a TV series on DVD (as opposed to movies) are usually very familiar with whatever series they're buying.Besides authorized studio releases, this book also reviews some of the budget-priced public domain TV series releases, and lets readers know about the picture quality and the entertainment level of the episodes included. (Public domain DVDs select only episodes that are not copyrighted, and these can be any combination of the best or the worst episodes of a given TV series.)If this book could be updated to reflect every major TV series release on DVD as of 2010, I would rate it 5 stars. As it is, it is worth only 3 stars but still worth owning. The information that's missing is frustrating, but the information that's there is useful. If an updated edition is eventually published, buy that edition instead of this one! If not, settle for this 2007 edition; it's better than nothing.
