That said Snoe loves her world and is confused by things I would miss, its a hard concept for me to understand but even more difficult for the author to have written no doubt, so kudos to TWB.A possible start for the Zompoc is briefly touched on and shows the power of Chinese whispers!The "scream scale" has elements of the Carry On films albeit with a demented view; new allies are made and old enemies reappear.I would love to read the EEF manual (this is my next campaign).A brilliant read throughout, hard to put down and then it ends on a cliff-hanger that left me turning my kindle over to see if there was another secret page.... My favourite all time line from a book is "roasted Snoe in a sweat sauce" made me giggle several times throughout the day.Snoes War (Zomblog 5)Ok, so this is the shortest of the books with That Ghoul Ava (brilliant) tagged on the end, so a little disappointing in the length but certainly NOT the story.Whilst harrowing and nasty, something TWB does exquisitely well, I found Snoe to be brave, if a little stupid sometimes, and I was rooting for her the whole way.Nobody is safe in TWB worlds and I have to say I was left bereft at some of the deaths, so prepare yourself. As for the whole Dominque situation, well it felt a bit quick and easy IMO; like a much wanted balloon animal that slowly deflates and is left all soggy and wrinkles.There are some great reveals and twists in this book, which excites me for the final instalment.Snoes Journey (6)TWB has a unique perspective on the zompoc, his books tend to be more about humanity with some serious issues picked up and his views expressed, most of which make sense.His characters have always been believable which makes it hard to let go of them. Some die, some fade away and others you just lose track of in the melee that is Zomblog; but many stay with me. It was great that TWB brought in the odd background character to show that all people matter in life.I think another reviewer commented that maybe the titles are the wrong way around and I have to agree! Whilst the last book seemed to fizzle out slightly this one almost tried too hard in tying up loose ends. Maybe TWB really doesnt want this series to carry on and has put a bitter after taste in!All that said I would not have missed out on it for the world, lots of really great ideas, twists, turns, gore, human depravity (now I sound like a weirdo) and some good answers to burning questions.This is a six book series and I would advise anyone to block out a weekend and crack on from the beginning!If you like these you will love DEAD and That Ghoul Ava, both long and (currently) ongoing series.

TWB has a unique perspective on the zompoc, his books tend to be more about humanity with some serious issues picked up and his views expressed, most of which make sense.His characters have always been believable which makes it hard to let go of them. Some die, some fade away and others you just lose track of in the melee that is Zomblog; but many stay with me. It was great that TWB brought in the odd background character to show that all people matter in life.I think another reviewer commented that maybe the titles are the wrong way around and I have to agree! Whilst the last book seemed to fizzle out slightly this one almost tried too hard in tying up loose ends. Maybe TWB really doesnt want this series to carry on and has put a bitter after taste in!All that said I would not have missed out on it for the world, lots of really great ideas, twists, turns, gore, human depravity (now I sound like a weirdo) and some good answers to burning questions.This is a six book series and I would advise anyone to block out a weekend and crack on from the beginning!If you like these you will love DEAD and That Ghoul Ava, both long and (currently) ongoing series.

That Ghoul Ava (1) A little novella that sparkles from the beginning...Great look at the underworld from a new addition! TWB has excelled himself with this character.Ava is a great narrator and introduces you to the darker side of life... with little quips and witty observations, shark grin!Brilliant concept loved this story and really looking forward to more episodes!That Ghoul Ava & the Queen of the Zombies (2)Love the little catch up comments... not too much for the faithful reader but enough to refresh a memory too...Bucket loads of new monsters, characters and friends. A second novel in what is no doubt going to be a truly amazing series! The humour is so wonderfully subtle you find yourself smirking and snorting through the gore and slime.No actual comedic moments... just the run of the mill everyday stuff is seen in the colour of comedy... like an excellent comedian Todd manages to point that out... giving you great snorting moments. Such as the ghost writer!Some really clever movie references..... and omg how funny at Mark Tufo (Zombie Fallout) ref!I want that story about the not real dead seeking cats!That Ghoul Ava kicks some Fairie A**e! (3)No dicing around here, straight in there with the action.  Some brief catch up notes, so you can read this as a stand-alone story if you wanted but works best as part of the series.I really enjoyed all the little nods to reality. TWB has outdone himself with the clever chapter titles and the Spotify link. Really gave a holistic feel to the whole thing.In this episode of Avas unlife we find her trying to bulldoze her way through battling fairies and discover what has got their panties in a bunch. It is a complex world that Ava lives in and nothing is what it seems; who needs politics when you have supernaturals!The humour has really been ramped up in this one, M. Knight Shamalammadingdong had me giggling for ages! The fight scene in the fairies house was brilliant; only TWB could write with Star Trek theme music and a Daffy Duck voice over and still make me feel tense.I will be ordering the Unnatural Grimoire from Amazon.su.ukMore monsters, some great connections, a few really lovely heart touching moments regarding friendship and I absolutely loved the Nessie comments!(Just a little side comment, yes I DO beta read for TWB but I ALWAYS buy all of his books; I believe THAT much in his work I wish to continue to support him. If I hate a concept or part of a book, or character I tell him at that stage, he is the talent so if that bit stays - I moan about it in the review!)

Ava is back with SASS! and a multitude of pop culture references; which are great to work out or memory joggers.When she meets a tall dark stranger, with knobs on! in the park another adventure begins.This time she is whisked off to Texas with some new and strange critters, I love the way TWB brings his own version of things to current "fictional" creaturesShe also discovers a new skill as her head starts to fill with voices. This, of course, brings its own hilarity.However, there is an underlying darkness to her situation and even through Ava thinks of herself as more the butter than the sharp knife she is great at sporting out problems that seem to surround and gravitate towards her.Not quite left on a precipice but I was left staring down the mountain of a cliff-hanger; I am thankful I have the next instalment to hand.The flashbacks to movies, songs and tv programmes are a hoot and the chapter titles are a joy all their own.RARARARA thats me shaking my pompoms for this brilliant series.

I cant help but love the way AEJ writes her characters, they feel so real, full bodied, passionate and I really miss them at the end of the books.This is another novella, a short read but full of punch, story lines and certainly moves the overall story along, but crucially fills in some missing areas.Jean-Luc is a mystery and in the last novel we met Talia - AEJ gives a great back story to Talia and really enhanced how I felt about Jean-Luc.There are hints of passion and erotica along the way, with a real will they wont they tension.The ending is well done, with some good, bad and ooooh!Really looking forward to the next installment.

Firstly, I love, love, LOVE the cover (by Jeffrey Kosh) how spooky is that!It actually sets the mood for this short story really well. Ketty & Max are on the road travelling to visit her Mum when they decide, well Ketty decides and Max acquises, to the scenic route, however this soon gets them lost.After two long days traveling and two spooky nights in horrid motels with only dorritos for dinner, nightmares which fuel a lack of sleep, stinky covers and bed bugs, one of their nightmares come true.Totally loved the ending! what a surprise! and watch out for the frog on the anthill (made me snort!)

In the world of Delham where Necrolords roam the land and bring havoc and destruction to all they touch with their undead armies, Kallie is a ray of hope, albeit with swords and daggers.After years of abuse, enslavement and torture, in the dungeons of her own home, at the hands of Duke Freye, Kallie was finally rescued by Rellan a priest of immense enigmatic power who leads the Brothers of Sorea and guides the Flock and township of Eton.After Rellans death Kallie inherited many of his powers and now lives and is loved by Darren and Gaul, the two clerics of the Brotherhood who guide and protect Kallie but also often hire her out as the infamous and secretive assassin Dirge.Kallies new task will take her back into those lands, back to her nightmares,  but having defeated at least one Necrolord will capturing one alive be possible, and for what purpose. And will her identity remain a mystery.Throw into the mix the evil Emperor Valtore who is the only other force against the Necrolords and holds a strange but compelling box. He is also keeps the company of Sorel the priest of Graff with his familiar, Mistress Rava.  Graff is the God of the underworld; Infernus.Dirge soon has the pleasure of meeting the Lord High Executioner of the Obsidian Order, Tyril, who is protecting a Necrolord but craves so much more. And is Baron Rand an ally or an enemy?Such attention to detail and in a few pages I was absorbed by this new world. TM takes on zombies (undead ghouls) in this mash up with sorcery and sword fighting and delivers this amazing story.There is no humour or lightness to this tale as with other TM novels, this is a dark and harrowing work but with all the intricacies of a thriller, some gruesome horror scenes thrown, his signature amazing fight sequences and huge element of supernatural. Full of intrigue, skullduggary, double crosses and sinister plots of revenge and power play.Little and large critters thrown in; some cute some not so much.Whilst this was neatly finished off there was a glimmer of a second story hinted at with several threads left hanging. I thoroughly enjoyed reading this new dark twist in writing skills that TM has demonstrated and look forward to more of this world.

We find MT, Baily and Oggie back on the hill where Tommy died, now buried, they are dealing with their grief when a visitor arrives and hands them more weapons and more hell; with a reluctant Bailey, MT sets off to hunt down the Lycan and destroy them.I really enjoyed all the little snide comments laced with the obvious love that MT cant help but have for his fellow companions. His internal and usually external Talbotisms still reign supreme! Even amongst the gore (and there is a lot) and the heartache (again a lot) I still had moments where I literally snorted or laughed out loud at the one liners.Loved the little flash backs to the old life.  Bear..that is all.It is soon obvious that not all is well in the realm of the Lycans, Xaviers plans are not liked by all; many have gone rogue.  The werewolf change scenes are impressive and the fight scenes terrifying, I found myself holding my breath.Matheiu. There is an element of ZardOz to his home.Baily and Azile are still high profile but in the background.The watchers are also back as the Lycans mount their attack on the townships. Each town doing as man usually does though which is really rather sadAny old enemy rears its head but not for long.The finale is amazing, the last few paragraphs had me in both stitches and tears, glad to see Trip is his usual self; yes he makes an appearance but not how you think!Whilst fishing for beavers of the coast of Kansas could be fun,  what I really want to know is do ants fart??

I dont know about every Southern cook mastering but these recipes and how LC describes them make a Brit cook want to indulge and master.LC has a fantastic way of breaking the recipe down and putting it into easy to follow steps whilst injecting her own enthusiasm for the dish, dinner parties at her house must be wonderful.I love the way she gives practical information at the start of the book re tools and utensils, in a totally non condescending way, which some chefs have a habit of doing. She even provides a conversion table link for us not USA folk.LC starts off with the simplest of meals; roast chicken  but puts her own twist on it and produces something mouth-watering just reading the ingredients. She then adjusts her timings etc to fit most fowl commercially available, a feature which I really enjoyed in her last book.Next up is the humble Mac N Cheese which she manages to turn into a gourmet dish and with four different ways of doing it, it soon becomes a repetitive dish without becoming boring.Pork, Ham and Ribs then get the LC treatment and I cant wait to try them out; my only little niggle here was I was expecting a secret BBQ sauce or dry rub recipe (not shop bought).Chicken and dumplings then get a seeing too, with various ways to make your dumplings more wow!Pudding then ends this great book and she brilliantly gives simple definitions to cobblers, crisps and crumbles, again with that friendly attitude that left me feeling like my mum/nan were giving me a cooking lesson in a warm homely, kitchen environment.I would really like to see the next in this series break out and have some pictures in it, preferably NOT of picture perfect dishes but of her own creations, possibly with the odd demonstrations of the more awkward elements of her dishes.Overall another smash hit with me! LC does well to not be TOO American in her writing or recipe style, although a possible UK/Europe/Oz version would probably go down very well; maybe she could look at some other world recipes and give her brilliant and eye and taste to?

Totally love the fact that GJ does NOT apologise for being an English author and uses all the correct spellings!He is the master of short, sharp stories and excels at it in this set. Each of the stories are based around residents in a block of flats, GJ cleverly links them all but you can read each one individually, but I challenge you just to read one and not be drawn into finishing the entire set.GJ has pulled a master stroke in managing to link every single story to each other, places, times, people, relevant news items.Really enjoyed all the prologue chatsThe Insomniac:Oh dear, poor obese Trevor is so tired keeping up with demand in his chip shop that he makes a fatal error, his efforts to make good dont go as planned.GJ Manages to do the inner dialogue perfectly giving a great view of the chippy on a Friday night with all its bawdy customers and of Trevor and how he feels about life, family, love and everything really!Then the desire for late night french fries occurs add in a little slip and an incident involving some cling film, mix in some mud and finally a twig!I did not know whether to laugh or cry at the ending, it was so beautifully thought out and executed, this author just blows me away.The Taxidermist:Fred has a disturbingly disgusting desire to start practising on his neighbours cats. Thankfully they decide to not be cooperative.I despise all animal cruelty, even in fictional stories, it was fairly obvious where this story was going but as I follow this author on FB I note that he too is an animal lover and trusted him with my emotions. I was not disappointed although the story made me feel glad in one way it still irked my heart.The horror is slow and painful to endure and made me squirm but ultimately it was the gore that made me cheer.The Butcher:GJ does clich and stereo type so well its wonderfully kitsch!Anton the Russian has been upto naughty things and tension is high in the preparation room but when Anton is giving a promotion he refuses and bloody hell reigns, how do you say no to a drug baron.GJ does well to make you like what should be an unlikable man, then feel his pain at his demise, in a rather unique fashion.The Florist:Elena is just trying to make her orchids grow the best when it all goes a bit wrong.GJ pays such attention to detail I could not help but be drawn into the story. The way he interconnects the characters is charmed, having learnt about Jimmy in The Insomniac and the sister we now meet her in all her weird glory.Elena and her son Jimmy have been busy installing a watering system and she has added a special fertilising ingredient she has found in the Sky High shop.As she gets a good dousing of the newly enhanced misting spray strangeness ensures  riveting reading all the way to the crescendo.The Lovers:Nalin and Isaac seem to have a perfect life until something random happens to change things for them.Having already met the characters I felt like I slipped into their lives unwatched and with the brilliantly researched and factual back history of Nalins life I was engrossed, and sad at the worlds history.During some amazingly erotic love making something awful (and funny) happens and I was left heartbroken at the ending.The Animal Lover:Gertrude cant fit out her apartment door but her animals keep her company.Whilst I love animals the description of the smell in her flat and what the various animals did was enough to make me gag! Over all her cruelty was far worse than Fred the Taxidermists. The ever so accurate portrayal of obesity was both sickening and fascinating.As Gertrude teeters on the edge of a heart attack on her trek around her flat to find her inhaler I found myself breath holding and waiting for the inevitable.  Her finale demise was very slap stick in what appears to be GJ signature way of killing people off, most amusing.The Agoraphobic:Gordon is the building manager with a nice money making side-line involving hidden cameras, so all the goings on are being watched, recorded and broadcast.It is in fact his best night ever with all his regularly voyeurs logging on to watch the mayhem going on in the building, and the revolting Gordon is just watching it all with  signs dancing in his eyes.It was a brilliant way to catch up on what was happening in each flat from another perspective, the time line alone was magnificent in its perfection. In a few sentences GJ summed up the night of horror.When he gets a knock on the door the person on the other side is not who he expected.The Foreigner:GJ launches from one dead body to another, and does it with superb style.Samira is a covert spy and assassin, but she also a complex and sad past, however now is the time she must make a quick escape as Gordons little internet business has alerted authorities to her.GJ could easily write thrillers as he clearly has all the knowledge and skill to lead readers down a dark path of intrigue then set them on fire with the truth.Another amazing little snippet of the bigger story, another sad ending but with that little hint of a giggle.The Geek:Poor schoolboy Benedict is often bullied and left alone by his hard working (and playing) mother, but he has been working hard on his school project and he has a dream.I loved the way GJ interjects all these little comments that just speed you make to other scenes, this would make a brilliant Tarantino style film.In the Epilogue he really rounded up the horror and giggles, tying up every loose end and give an incredible to ride to his readers.

This is a first time collaboration between Mark Tufo and John O'Brien, two authors that are known for their own zompoc series of books, Zombie Fallout for MT and A New World for JOB and it's here in Whistlers that their two main characters both crash land into this strange new world where the worst of their two worlds collide.Michael Talbot, Trip ( aka John the Tripper) and Jack Walker.As I have only read the ZF books (its my hubby that loves Jack Walker) I can say that both writers put their character across easily and leave no guess work.If you haven't already done so I would recommend reading both MT and JOBs books before hand to get some background on the characters and their individual stories, however this IS intended to be a standalone series so more maybe revealed as the books progress.Trip is still my favourite character in almost every book I read barring a few, fantasy novels; and I think he would fit right in there too. He seems to have been given more visionary skills, whereas Mike and Jack have retained their new enhancements from their old worlds.Although I think that some sort of explanation as to why the two have super powers might have helped the newbie reader.Both authors have certainly honed their writing skills now and are able to produce a story line that gels, excels, excites and is basically worth every penny spent. They mash up together very well.I was curious (and worried) as to how two such strong characters (and authors) would be able to blend but its like peas in a pod/flip sides of a coin (yes, yes I know they arent the same!! See, what I did there though!)Fabulous way to introduce the three lunatics to the rest of the world.They have distinctive voices and styles that worked really well with the alternating chapters and PoV, I loved the way a thing would happen to one character and then you would get a different view of the same thing from the other.Left on a knife edge I cannot wait until the next book is released in what, I hope, will be a long series.Negatives; there is a lot of dialogue in here BUT that does allow the characters to merge and the new readers to get to know them, however, it could get tedious for current fans.If you dont like a certain authors style then their character may get on your nerves a bit, personally I dont like all the over egged military stuff so tend not to read about every little nuance regarding guns, bullets and kick backs, again got tedious for me.

Hahaha I loved that all the immortal gang are now using Facebook!From the start you can feel that this book is going to have an explosive ending as Georgina ends up in Hells court with unlikely allies and lawyer. A loop hole has been found in her Soul Contract.A beautiful ending that brings all the little comments throughout the series together, I think this is the only book in the series you could not read as a standalone.The climax was one of those "I saw that coming from a mile away", but it wasn't lame or upsettingI could easily read this series over again many times, so lovely, so funny and wonderfully circular.

A new and suspicious Succubus arrives just as Sirens trap Georgina in a dream state from which she cannot escape.As the bond between Seth and Georgian is becoming stronger, others are starting to notice, this is not liked by many in her circle, lest of all her best friend Maddie who she is supposed to be helping to marry Seth!Whilst the gang, including human Eric, try to save Georgina she continues to be stuck in a different dimension where she is shown truth, possible futures, tainted truths and outright lies, in horrible torturous semi dreams. This is horrific to read as I have come too really like GeorginaOnly an American would suggest that Guinness goes with shepherds pie!! Seriously, NO!RM does well to keep this book from becoming too dark and utilises Georginas more light hearted friends to accomplish this; Peter and his soires really make me want to be an immortal!

Therapy works unless you sleep with the therapist and suck out their life force! Jerome has forced Georgina into therapy, she is being horrifically sulky and he has had enough of her.When that fails he sends her to Canada, to spy for another Arch Demon who is having problems with a demonic cult that are giving Satan a bad name!Another mystery for Georgina to solve as Jerome is summonded in a turf war and goes missing.Fearful that a new Arch Demon will be appointed Georgian rushes to locate and save Jerome, with the help of her current destructive relationship, gosh this girl knows how to punish herself.However whilst Jerome is captured she soon discovers that she can have rampant sex with Seth, which is not good news as he is in a different relationship and trying to make a happy, non-Georgina filled life for himself.The erotica in these books is always fresh, never repetitive, sensitive but heat inducing.More heart breaking revelations about previous relationships from the past. RM is really evolving all her main stay characters in new and wonderful ways.

This is the perfect water bottle for the younger generation. My daughter  does quite a few 5k walks and runs, and my granddaughter is 5, she actually does a few with her mom. Well, Momma has a water bottle, now, so does my granddaughter!  This 12 oz. stainless steel water bottle is perfectly sized for her, the bottle is 5.5" tall. This bottle comes with two different lids, one is a spout type lid, and the other is a screw on and off type lid. This bottle has a wide opening, so she can even have ice cubes in the summer. The BPA free bottle is easily cleaned, plus it won't stain, or rust. She is going to think she is special, just like her momma! I received this bottle at a promotional price, in exchange for my honest opinion and review.

This 3pk. Of USB charge/sync data cables definitely come in handy. I never seem to be able to find a charging cable when I need one. Between my kids and my husband, someone is always helping themselves, and not replacing it where it belongs. These cables, by Electron, work well with all the phones in our home. We all have various models of iPhones, and these work with them all! I am glad I have them. I received this product for free, in exchange for my honest opinion and review.

Another great UTIMI product. This is a 'rabbit ear' vibrator, high is awesome for clitoral stimulation. It is made from medical grade, BPA free silicone. This rabbit ear Mosel has 10 different vibrations to get you going, from a soft, gentle vibration, to a super fast, more frequent vibration. There is one level guaranteed to please every woman.  The best part is it has a mini USB charger for fast recharging.  I love that it is very quiet while in use. But, it is NOT waterproof, due to the USB. All in all, this is a very stimulating sexual toy, and it definitely will have you in rabbit mode! I received this product at a promotional price, in exchange for my honest opinion and review.

This is a good spatula. The handle is solid, very comfortable to hold, and work with. The silicone flipper base is well made. The silicone is food grade, BOA free.  I used it to turn and flip burgers, and even with all the grease and residue left on it, it simply rinsed right off. This silicone can handle high temperatures, up to 450, so it can even handle the direct flame of a grill.  There is even a loop at the end for hanging, when not in use. Definitely, a well made kitchen utensil. I received this product at a promotional price, in exchange for my honest opinion and review.

I love these floating charm lockets. This Christmas one, by Maddie M. Designs is so cute.  It is done in stainless steel, and around the diameter is a design that makes it look like rhinestones. The locket itself is around 3 inches in diameter, and it stays closed by a very strong magnet. You open the locket on the split side, and there are Christmas charms inside. The charms are a Santa, a Merry Christmas sign, a present, and a green light bulb. There are also a few floating gems, one each, white, red, and green. These are also known as memory lockets, and they have become very popular. You can even by different floating charms to put in it, maybe different holidays, a birthday, etc. the chain is also stainless, so it will last a long time. I am definitely wearing mine this Christmas season! I received this product at a promotional price, in exchange for my honest opinion and review.

I love these silicone baking molds, made especially for my furry friends. I received two molds, one with 14 paw prints, and this other has 15 bone molds.  Plus the added bonus, the basting brush. I am slowly replacing all my bakeware with these silicone type molds. The are heat resistant up to 450, and are freezer safe, and also dishwasher safe. There is so many recipes on the Internet for dog treats, there is no limit to what I can make.  Dog biscuits are expensive, and I have 4 dogs, so we go through them fast. With these molds, I can make them their treats, and know exactly what the ingredients are, rather than taking someones word on it.  The silicone makes the treats easy to remove from the molds too. mY dogs are very happy, and well fed! I received this product at a promotional price, in exchange for my honest opinion and review.

I never seem to be able to find a set of headphones when I need them. When I was offered these headphones, at a discount, I jumped on it. Near do has made a pair of headphones that is compatible with all the different iPhones that are included in my house. We have iPhones from 5 all the way through 6+.  This headphone also works well with iPhone 6 Plus 6, iPhone 5s 5c 5, iPad Air, iPad Mini, iPad Mini 2, iPad 4, iPod 5, and iPod Nano 7. It also comes with an USB Lighting Cable For Charging, plus you can use it Handsfree With Remote Control Mic. I also like that I can control music playback, answer and end calls, pause music, forward to the next song, etc. all by pressing the button on the mic, this comes in handy. I plan on keeping a few on hand, maybe everyone gets one in their Christmas stockings. I received this product at a promotional price, in exchange for my honest opinion and review.

This is a super cute diaper changing mat. It is made from a white waterproof material, with little black heart designs on it. There is a shirt handle for carrying, and a clip so I can attach it to my stroller.  On the outside there is two zippered pockets for necessities, like butt cream. You unfold this bag, and it becomes a padded changing mat. The mat is also waterproof, and easily wiped down with sanitizing wipes. Once unfolded, there is a mesh pocket you can store wipes in, plus a few diapers. I feel much better changing my little one on the portable changing pad, rather than any restroom changing station, or anywhere for that matter. If I am just going somewhere quick, like a fast trip to the store, I grab this kit, I know it's packed and ready to go. I received this product free of charge, in exchange for ,y honest opinion and review.

These bags are super nice. They are made from a thick, 1.6 ml., clear cellophane, with a adhesive line near the top to seal the bag. Each bag is 8 3/4" x 11 1/6". They are well made, good and sturdy. I actually can fit my IPad in one of the bags.  The babe are also acid free, which is great for so many craft projects. You get 100 bags, more than enough for any project. I plan on make a series of family photos, which will be framed, and given as a Holiday gift. These bags will be great for that!  These clear bags can also be used for food, as they are FDA and USDA compliant. I can even give Christmas cookies, in a cute plate, and then sealed in the bag. So many uses! I received this product at a promotional price, in exchange for my honest opinion and review.

This is the coolest thing. I have a knock off GoPro camera, and this fog harness holds it well, and works just as if it was the name brand camera. I have 4 dogs, and the harness fits each of them, it will actually fit any dogs up to 120 lbs. once on, there are two different places to place the camera, one towards the back of the harness, the other is in the chest area of the harness. Seeing that most of the GoPro and other types of sport outdoor cameras are waterproof, I am glad this harness is also waterproof. I live on Lake Huron, and my dogs love to run and jump in the water. I don't have to worry about them ruining any of my equipment. It is so fun to watch the video, and to see everything from a dogs eye view! You get an idea of what they are always searching for. See life through their eyes, and noses. I received this product at a promotional price, in exchange for my honest opinion and review.

This is a super cute baby pacifier clip! The Sunshine has the clip under it, it attaches onto the babies clothing, so baby can always find his pacifier. Attached to the pacifier, on a sturdy ribbon are six brightly colored soft beads, which the baby can also use for a teether. Each bead has a different shape, it makes great for hand play. The pacifier clip works with all kinds of pacifiers, even the newer brands. The beads and yellow sunshine are made of BPA free silicone. Everything is baby safe. This would make a cute addition to a baby gift!  My grandson loved touching the beads, and chewing on them even more! I received this product at a promotional price, in exchange for my honest opinion and review.

One of this pair of Do Not Disturb door hanger signs gets placed onto my bathroom door knob when I am in there! These are Hotel quality door hanger signs. Brown glossy background, with white lettering. These signs are 8.5" x 3.5", and they are not thin paper. They are a good stock paper, 16 pt. thick.  The hang slit is placed so the hang gag hangs properly. No more "borrowing" them from our hotel visits, we now have our own! I received this product free of charge, in exchange for my honest opinion and review.

I've got a kid with a loft bed who falls asleep reading and then, BANG, in the middle of the night, he knocks a book--or worse, his Kindle!--down to the floor.I got this case primarily because of the removable strap. Okay, to be honest, this would be even better with a high quality 100% cotton pillowcase, but this wedge, LIKE EVERY OTHER WEDGE WE OWN, has a thin, poly-cotton, nasty zip off cover. I'm reviewing this wedge for function, and compared to others like it on the market, not against a fantasy object that might be more perfect but doesn't seem to exist.First of all, we own three of these particular Hermell Products wedges (used like a headboard across a King size bed) at 4" tall; one 12" wedge for when someone's reflux is acting up (hardest to sleep on!); two 7.5" wedges that we replaced with this size; and two very shallow wedges designed for a baby crib that are used side by side across the head of a Double bed. All of these wedges came with similar, thin, zip-off poly-cotton covers, except for the baby crib wedges, which have a plastic/waterproof exterior similar to that of standard crib mattresses. Dex Safe Lift Universal Crib WedgeWhy so many wedges? Well, it started because someone has reflux, and that can be very painful, especially when lying down, trying to sleep. I ordered the first wedge upon his doctor's advice. Then, later that year, when one of the kids caught cold, we realized the wedge was also helpful for easing breathing during respiratory infections. The really tall wedge often leads to kids slumping down and sleeping sideways across their beds, however, necessitating middle-of-the-night child re-orientation. (I ordered two lower-height 7" wedges during that cold & flu season.)In between illnesses, where to store these large, ugly pillows (in their ugly, cheap poly-cotton covers?) I found myself flipping them up on the short, flat end and using them as a backrest in our bed. I discovered that "Euro" square shams would squeeze onto the 7" wedges if I folded down about an inch of foam at the narrow end (and could tolerate a gap on the tie-side at the widest point. That looked almost intentional, but two wedges didn't stretch across the entire King bed, which offended my aesthetic sensibilities and also left a gap where stuff could fall behind the bed. I searched for--and found!--this 4" wedge size, and they fit, UNFOLDED in matching Euro shams, cover the entire 6 feet width of the bed, and are always on hand if someone needs to turn them around to sleep with his or her head elevated.On two other beds in our home, we use the wedges UNDER the mattress to elevate the head of the bed, thus allowing the sleeper to use a regular pillow and case against the skin. On the double bed (using roughly 1.5" baby crib wedges), you don't even notice the elevation of the head when you walk into the room. Using a 7" wedge under a (latex) twin mattress results in an obviously elevated head of the bed, so that wouldn't work for someone who cares more about the appearance of the bed than the function.As a heavy user of these objects, I do zip off and wash the covers regularly (some shrink, most don't), but mostly we avoid sleeping directly on the cover, treating it more like a mattress pad than like a sheet. Most of us like our regular pillow, for softness, ON TOP of the wedge. For a kid who doesn't want that extra height, I'll put the wedge under the bedsheets, or tuck an extra flat sheet (or thicker blanket or even a towel if it's a stomach illness) around the wedge for extra protection.If you're going to use your wedge all the time and don't want to fuss with loose covers, try a Euro sham. Since that big square size is less popular, you can often find inexpensive ones in discount stores.

Instead of using this in the car, I got it to strap a Kleenex tissue box to the side rail on my child's loft bed. He would carry a box up with him when he had a cold, and knock it down at night. Now, the tissues are within reach and no nighttime avalanches wake up the kids.I used other automotive accessories for this application, too, and it has made my life so much easier. Just a thought for other parents with older kids in top bunks...

I bought this rug because it was very inexpensive and the colors are neutral enough to blend in my large, open plan living room. It went under the dining room table, which is why I wanted a cheaper rug that I won't worry about too much during my kids' childhood.I think it looks like a slightly homely ski sweater. My husband thinks it looks great, as does a friend of mine with a somewhat funkier aesthetic.It is fairly soft, and a deeper pile than I'd prefer under a table, but would be comfortable enough for kids to play on in a different setting.The price was right, and it serves my purposes.The rug did arrive in torn packaging with dark stains on the back, whether from shipping or manufacture, I don't know. Be cautious to inspect yours right away in case it has a visible defect. It would be challenging to return due to the large size (mine is 9' x 12'.)

My vest arrived and I charged up the battery and tested it at home. It seemed to work as expected.As far as fit, I have a tricky figure for most modern styles. I've got a short torso, but am also very hourglass shaped, with a slightly wider hip than bust now that I'm over 40. (I should wear a 10 across my back, but need a 12/14 top to accomodate the bust. My waist is a 10/12, but my hips usually need size 14.) Having read that a close fit was vital to heating effectiveness, I crossed my fingers and bought the medium, per the size chart. The medium does fit, and I can zip it fully closed, but it is just a touch closer than I'd prefer in the hip and at the fullest part of my bust, while the waist is loose. None of this is unexpected. I think this vest fits true to modern size, just not MY size.My purpose for this vest is an annual trip to an outdoor theatre festival in October where it typically dips down into the 40's at night. Last year, I froze, and my physical discomfort was the only negative in an otherwise marvelous experience. This year, I wore the heated ANSAI vest under my long, down coat. I was very comfortable, sometimes even opening the zipper on my top layer because I got too warm. I used the 25% heat setting most of the time (it was mild this year), bumping it up to 75% on the coldest night for the second act.Three hours at the theatre didn't even come close to running down the battery under my usage conditions.Personally, I would prefer a softer (no wind-proof outer shell) vest with a more fitted, hourglass silhouette, but this vest as is served my needs and added greatly to my comfort at my favorite event of the year. I'm very glad I bought it.

The "family puzzle" notion is a great one, and I'm really pleased that Cobble Hill has created this line. I've always loved doing jigsaw puzzles with my own mother, but my one child (early elementary age) who is interested in doing puzzles with me gets too frustrated by standard-size adult puzzle pieces, and I get too bored by his kid-oriented superhero scenes.Quality-wise, I somewhat prefer Ravensburger (and my even more expensive wooden piece puzzles), but the Cobble Hill pieces did click together firmly enough, and there weren't any of those annoying "does this fit or doesn't it" almost fits. These pieces were of varied shapes and reasonably thick, though I'd prefer them to be even thicker.We've had this puzzle about six months now, and we've done it several times. I'm back today looking for another (or a few...) from this line as the weather turns colder and indoor pursuits beckon.

I got exactly what I wanted with this item, and felt the price was reasonable for the utility of the tub and the fairly small market in the USA for this type of product.For many years, I have thought that I would prefer a deeper tub that was less oblong and more square. Sometime along the way I learned that the Japanese use tubs of this shape. I imagined that I might someday remodel an American bathroom to have such a tub for myself. Then I grew up, got a job, got married, bought a house, had kids, and realized that remodeling is a nightmare and I may never do a total reno job like I watched on home & garden television in my youth. We did move from our first home--with a peeling, badly refinished cast iron tub that was too gross to sit in--to a home of Barbie Dream House proportions with a beautiful master bathroom containing... a tub the size of the entire bathroom at my old house. I mean seriously, you could put 4 adults in this giant whirlpool tub. That's when I read up on the biofilm that lives inside whirlpool jets, and I lost most of my interest in soaking in my beautiful new home's bloated tub.(I'm prone to long stories, so I'll mention that the enormous whirlpool also leaked into our kitchen due to a dried out seal on the drain the one and only time we filled it 1/3 way full and ran the jets. The faucet was also clogged with a ball of sediment. Basically, a tub this size is too ridiculous for anyone to actually fill and use, so it dried up and died in the mausoleum that is our beautiful marble master bathroom...)Back to my folding, portable bathtub!Due to some health issues that are causing me aching joints, I got to thinking about my dream tub again. I read about a portable (fiberglass, like a "real" built-in tub) ofuro in someone's blog. That one was only $900! Oh wait, I've never actually used such a tub. I just THINK I want one. $900 is ridiculous for a whim. Finally searching Amazon for "ofuro" lead me to this product listing a few a like it.A two figure price tag (less than 10% of the one from the blog) made this purchase an easy one for me. I could afford it, and I really wanted to try it.The box arrived in fine condition, taped shut, with all expected parts inside, and carefully labeled in a language I don't understand. I actually think I saw Korean characters, but that's a guess, not a fact. It is true that the instruction sheet was also in an Asian language I don't read. That said, the "assembly" process consisted of:* unfold the wadded up plastic tub until it is tub shaped, like a wider, shorter trash can* insert white PVC tubes into plastic sheaths built onto tub shaped tub with the ends that look like feet on the OUTSIDE* inflate the ring around the top so it stops toppling over under its own weightI had a little fight with the cheap plastic pump included in the package. (My yoga balls and other fitness gear all came with the same style of cheap pump.) Then I realized this little ring of inflated stuff was not very big, so I just blew it up by mouth in about three breaths. The pump is NOT a deal break for assembly!Now I had a tub! It looked cheap. It smelled of stinky new plastic (and I am sensitive to such odors.) But it was in my bathroom, and it looked human sized. I let it air out by an open window for a couple of days before we filled it.Once again, I'm going to point out that my master bathroom is a little unusual in that it is the size of two bedrooms in my former 1910's home. The tub in its tiled surround is the size of New Jersey, there's lots of walking around room, the toilet has its own good-sized cubby, and the shower is a nice, extra deep, double-header. For my situation, employing the Folding Bathtub is very, VERY easy and I wasn't worried about leaks: the whole thing fits at one end of my shower enclosure and it doesn't even cover the center drain. (The 85 cm diameter top works out to about 33" across, so this tub would definitely fit in a 36" square shower stall, but that would be a very different experience for drainage, etc., than exists in my large shower.) If it had leaked or self-destructed once filled, all the water would've been contained in my case, making the experiment very easy for me. If I were using this outside of a "wet room" (room with a drain in the floor) or outdoors, I WOULD TEST IT OUTSIDE WITH THE HOSE before filling it on my living room carpet!That said, this tub is made of thick, sturdy plastic. The strong odor took about a week and a half to dissipate in a large bathroom at a time of year that windows could be left open most of the time. I also ran the shower exhaust fan for several hours at a time to aid in sucking the stink out of it. It does stink when new. The smell does decrease over time.My little son took the first bath in the tub. 1) He's been dying for a tub bath most of his life, and rarely got one after outgrowing his inflatable baby tub. 2) We didn't fill it very full in case it leaked, but that was plenty of water for a young grade-schooler. 3) I wasn't sure I would easily get in and out of this tall new tub with my joint issues, whereas the little guy can be lifted out by me (in a pinch) or my husband (no pinching required.)We've learned to fill the tub to about the user's knee level to have a nice, but not neck-level fill upon sitting down. Whomever is about to use the tub can stand in the shower stall and eyeball the water level, using the "knee high" test to decide when to shut off the shower flow. The little guy is impatient and usually gets in before the water is even at his knees. This gives him a bath level much like a standard Western tub. He has one boat that he takes in with him, and he has a good time. He uses water set at about 90 F. (Yeah, our fancy new house has showers that you turn on with the desired temp pre-set, too. It's really cool!)I make the little guy wash with soap on the other side of the shower (double-headed shower, see above) before taking his soak. When he's done, I turn the temp up to 110 F and fill the tub up to the tops of my knees to get the soaking temperature I've been dreaming of all these years. I am feeling really, REALLY much happier about our water usage knowing that we're at least getting two soaks out of a fill up of this tub, and also that the total volume of water is so much more reasonable than our giant built in one.The highest I've filled the water was at "thigh high stocking" level on my leg. (I got distracted.) I actually thought the tub would overflow when I sat down, but the water came up right under my lower lip. I will say, the sensation of weightlessness was vastly increased by this higher water level, but I didn't feel quite as relaxed as I do with water just above my shoulders. I highly recommend performing the experiment to see which water level relaxes you the most.Emptying the tub is really easy. There is an exterior valve with a twistable on-off handle that lets you drain all but the last few inches of water out the side. After that, we have room in our tub to tip it over and dump the last few inches. When I'm feeling normal to well, I can do this myself. If my joints are flaring, I ask my husband to do it. A normal woman (not physically challenged) should be able to dump the last bit of water. It isn't that heavy. IF YOUR SHOWER STALL IS VERY SMALL this might get tricky, and then the little plug in the bottom of the tub might be called for. I've never even opened that plug on my tub. (It is exactly like the one in all inflatable wading pools. Clear plastic, round, about the size of a US quarter and 1/4-1/2" deep, pressing into a same-size open hole...)I want to speak to two very important aspects of this tub that concerned me before purchase in case my experience can help you decide:1) GETTING IN AND OUTI'm fortunate to have this in a tiled shower enclosure. If I need to, I can lean my weight on the adjoining wall when getting in and out. I don't have grab bars, however. Those would make this experience MORE SAFE. I do have an autoimmune disorder (although mild) and many tricky joints (pain, weakness.) Before my sickness, I was relatively fit and flexible, however, and I can rise up from sitting cross legged to standing without any support when my joints aren't too inflamed. Before using this tub, it would be wise to attempt this maneuver (rising from cross-legged without support) on a regular floor to see how you do. THE WATER PROVIDES ASSISTANCE with its buoyancy, so I find it very easy to stand up from the bottom of the tub, even when mildly inflamed, but I was able to do so very well within the past year or so without any outside help. Getting out of the tub is easier than getting up from the floor due to the water's buoyancy assist.All this said, I did have my husband stay nearby for my first few baths, just in case. Getting up out of a steamy tub can make me dizzy. My joints can surprise me (and not in that good, breakfast in bed way...) It hasn't been an issue for me, thank God, but I would strongly recommend considering safety if you try this tub and you have health issues.2) TUB SIZEI'm a plump but not obese, short (5' 3") and short-torsoed woman. I bought this larger size because I wanted more room at the bottom for my (ahem) bottom. With the 85 cm diameter (at the top) tub, no part of me needs to touch the plastic sides of the tub. I was grossed out by the idea of touching slimy plastic, though, thus far, my tub isn't slimy. :) Sitting cross legged, I have about an inch of clearance around me on all sides in the bottom of the tub.The HEIGHT of this tub (I think 70cm? = 27.5 inch) is just a smidge higher than I'd prefer. I CAN (and usually do) pull down a bit on the inflated upper edge and use it as a neck pillow, leaning back slightly so that the tiled tub enclosure supports me with the inflated ring softening the experience. I can be claustrophobic, and would like this tub better if it were about 3" shorter so my eyes were peeping out instead of just the top of my head being above the rim. It is big enough that I don't freak out. (Also, I dim the lights and take my baths in a fairly dark room, so that eases my visual discomfort.)IF I WERE TO BUY ANOTHER PORTABLE TUB, I might opt for a slightly longer, OVAL shape tub so I could opt to have my knees bent in front of me but not folded. I think a somewhat smaller radius for the end of the oval would be fine, but about another 10-12 inches in length, and almost as much depth, would be my ideal tub. I haven't had a major joint flare since I started using the tub, but I can imagine being in such bad shape that I couldn't bend enough to get cross-legged (criss cross applesauce sitting, known as "Indian style" when I was a child.)SHOULD YOU TRY THIS TUB?* If you've always thought you'd like a Japanese style, deep soaking tub (or ofuro) but never had a chance to experience one, this is good way to try it out.* If you crave a soak that gets your shoulders fully submerged and have no joint or balance issues that could make it tricky to get in or out, try this.* If you find it difficult to get in and out of a standard, built-in Western tub, this product is probably not safe for your use as it is at least as hard to enter or exit, and possibly harder, than a built-in tub.

This book is scholarly in format, and somewhat formal in tone. I expected that, and appreciated the citations and primary sources for the work.That said, I don't believe I've ever found a scholarly tome more readable--simply ENJOYABLE to read--than I did this book.I heard about this book on a website discussing seasonal affective disorder. That more medical site mentioned the pre-modern notion of "first sleep" followed by a brief waking period, and then the later stage of "second sleep." That was enough to make me seek out the book.I'll agree with another reviewer that Ekirch did circle back multiple times to similar themes, but I never found his prose wasted. There was always a point to the digression. If anything, I might describe it as a circling down, deeper and deeper, into the meat of each point with a slightly different slant each time.Perhaps this is a book that will only interest a more scholarly sort of reader? I'm sure it isn't for everyone, but I found it a thumping good read! I even nudged my husband once or twice to say, "hey, you wouldn't believe how much I'm enjoying this book!" I read often, and I read things I like, but every minute of this particular book had me in my happy place. It was full of new information for me to assimilate so I felt smart, but it went down easily even at the end of a busy day when my thoughts should've been turning to my own sleep.I would say this was definitely more scholarly than, say, "How the Irish Saved Civilization," and yet every bit as smooth and easy to read.

Especially when a product has no other reviews, I feel compelled to write one promptly and before I've thoroughly used the item. That's even trickier in this case, since I'm reviewing an instructor's book before our school year even begins.I'm a mom who has one child enrolled in school and another learning with me at home. The one in school is learning Spanish, although in a light, casual, once a week way (not immersion or anything like that.) My mother is fluent in Spanish, and I studied it for six years in school, so I'm familiar with the language, but not actively learning it myself. My home schooler is learning German and Russian, so I'm getting more mental exercise with those languages these days.This workbook seems like a nice elementary-level classroom resource for a professional teacher who likes to teach crafts and cooking. If I'd had a "look inside" view of this book, I might not have purchased it since I'm looking for something more academic to complement my child's artsy craftsy exposure to Spanish at school. I'm not lowering my review based upon lack of fit, however, as this book didn't promise anything that wasn't delivered in terms of format/structure.CULTUREAfter flipping through the whole book, I note that the majority of the activities are based upon Mexican culture (according to the notes for each project), with one each from Puerto Rico, Panama, la Argentina, Peru, Paraguay and Guatemala. A few activities also reference "Latin American" culture and don't specify a more localized region. Again, this isn't necessarily a bad thing, but I think the title promised just a bit more of a general "Spanish" culture when it is more accurate to say "Latin American" culture.ACTIVITIESThe activities seem to be mostly designed around affordable, easily found items being used to create "in the style of" Latin American artifacts. One example would be making a huipil (ladies' embroidered blouse) by embellishing a t-shirt with fabric markers according to traditional patterns. There's a similar activity using a large, adult size t-shirt to make a poncho. These are fine activities, but designed to bring attention to a native craft's existence while making a rather far-removed version for oneself.As a mom, I'd guess that my kids would enjoy and learn something from doing these activities. On the other hand, since I can work one on one with my own children and that also alleviates many budget pressures in our case, I would be more likely to engage in more authentic craft experiences (actual simple embroidery or a real pottery class) than something like painting a traditional pottery pattern onto a paper plate.The book is 52 pages long. My quick count shows 18 "Exploring Spanish Through Art" activities, 18 ""Exploring Spanish Through Cooking" activities, and 11 "Exploring Spanish Through Games" activities. None of them seem to be essential duplicates or particularly unworthy. I did note that a game with a "London Bridge is Falling Down" type of game with a song ("A la vbora") doesn't have any written music for the lyrics, so I would be forced to go to online to complete this activity.

I went back and forth for a few minutes about whether to rate 4 or 5 stars. I ended up with 5 because these (I bought two) rugs are PRECISELY what I wanted for the balcony off of my kitchen. They arrived on time, in excellent condition, and in rather beautiful jute packaging, and they have held up for two months without any fading or deterioration.My new home is contemporary, and there is a long, narrow deck (balcony, actually) off of the kitchen. Both the kitchen and adjacent dining room have full walls of glass overlooking this balcony. Now, our house sat empty and unloved for over two years before we bought it, so we've got some exterior work to do, including replacing the deteriorating balcony. It is wood, and it is rotting/peeling/etc. Luckily, the railings are wood with aluminum and look fine. We're replacing our entire roof and many skylights in a VERY expensive project this summer, so the deck will have to wait. In the meantime, how do I enjoy my beautiful ocean view (okay, peek-a-boo view!) and gorgeous green landscape with rotting grey deck boards assaulting my eyes? The answer: these plastic rug/mats.I must add that my kitchen is very neutral, which is great (after our first home had a 1950's pink & aqua monstrosity of a kitchen) but kind of gets me down. I'm a deep, jewel-tone, color-everywhere kind of person. I've added a bunch of dark purple, mustard yellow & deep red accents, which help a lot with bringing the white-washed oak and white/black tile in line with my tastes, but seeing the deep purple and white Tangier-Plum & White rug through all that glass has made a big impact on my boring kitchen.I like these mats so much that I might buy a third to use under the kitchen table on the INSIDE! Yes, I totally agree that these are more of an outside rug product, but my children are messy little punks, and a rug I can hose off appeals to me a whole lot more than any fine Persian rug would at this stage of our family life.It is absolutely true that these are fairly lightweight. In our (coastal New England) climate, it is vital to have heavy object sitting somewhere on the rug to prevent it from blowing away when thunderstorms pass through. Since we have a couple of flower pots, an umbrella (in a heavy stand) and a table with chairs, this was a trivial problem for our situation.The best part about these rugs is how deep and intense the purple color is. I am NOT a lavender lady; I'm a Purple Person! This is exactly the shade that I hoped these rugs would be.Could they be cheaper and make me more happy? Yes, that would be great! However, I feel that I got exactly what I paid for, and I don't regret the purchase or the purchase price.

I struggled a bit with how to rate this show. I'll speak to my opinion of the entire first season.To begin with, I'm a serious theatre lover, and someone who hates musicals. I like foreign films and edgy comedy. I really like artsy, boundary-pushing shows. On the other hand, while there was a lot of very interesting stuff in Transparent, and Jeffrey Tambour gives an amazing performance, I didn't really enjoy watching this show. I don't find it funny very often. Mostly, I find it incredibly sad.I'm not troubled by the level of graphic sex in this show because of what it is, but I did feel while I was watching that I was watching *gratuitously* graphic sex. Much like levels of gore (*ahem* Quentin Tarantino) that seem like a lazy layer of icing on what could be a genius cake, it seemed to me that the characters in this show were so self-absorbed, so pathetic, so unlikeable, that the graphic sex acts as a yellow highlighter of selfishness smeared all over each fornicating character. Maybe, being so old-fashioned as to find sex a beautiful, natural act of love and joy, I'm just not hip enough to "get it" in this series?I also hold a very liberal position on adults making adult choices, alone or together. The part of this show that I did like was the fascinating process of Jeffrey Tambour's character finally blossoming into the woman he's always known was inside himself. This is sensitively done, and feels very honest, real, and, finally making the title ring true!--"Transparent!"Is it meant to be a metaphor that the father's years of hiding her true self from the world led to such insufferable consequences in the characters of her three children? This is the part I struggle with. The adult children are all vile. I can't enjoy any scene where they are the center of attention. No amount of interesting story line makes up for the pain I experience contemplating the existence of people like this.I wonder if this is why Middle America hates the coasts? I grew up in the Pacific NW, and I live in a liberal New England city, but I believe in morality (mostly as what one must live for oneself, not as a threat to hold up to the throat of others.) The very idea that these characters could seem believable to anyone leaves me reeling. I find them very hard to imagine as real.Toward the end of the season, there's an episode in which the youngest daughter has a bizarre, dis-associative date with a very butch lesbian. That storyline was one of the few I felt was actually pretty compelling and it has stuck in my mind for weeks. More character development like this, that seems like real, flawed human behavior instead of a sociopathic impulse to work as counter to human goodness as possible, could bring me back to give season two a chance.There is really good acting here, and an aggressively edgy script. I wish the totality of the subject matter made it worth watching for me. I am legitimately baffled as to what others find to love in it.

My order was fulfilled by TheNewMall in July 2015. I ordered "Traumeel Pain Relief Gel" and received T-Relief gel instead. I was disappointed, as I hoped the item name/description would be accurate. I'd read enough other reviews to know it was likely I would receive the new US distributed product instead.I've been using this on my hands several times a day for about a week now. It certainly isn't causing me any problems, but I'm unable to say for certain that it helps me, either. I'm inclined to say that it is not helping, or not helping very much. On the other hand, at least I have something that feels constructive to do when my pain flares. (My diagnosis is uncertain at this point, but it may be an autoimmune problem. My pain is almost constant and I'm also taking prescription medication for it. I'm using this for joint pain.)I will continue to use this as I don't see the harm and I will try almost anything at this point (that doesn't add side effects.) If I find over time that it helps enough to reorder this product, I will update my review and increase my rating. I'd say it is affordable enough that it is worth trying if you have pain. The odor is mild enough to tolerate (to someone very sensitive to perfumes/fragrance.) My hands don't feel weird (sticky/slimy) after use, and I'm very particular about that, too.

My son has a medical condition that makes wearing a medical ID bracelet a smart idea. First, I bought one designed just for kids, but he disliked it. It was this type: AllerMates Insect Sting Allergy Wristband Bizzzy. I thought he would enjoy the cartoonish design, but I think he found it babyish. (He was in kindergarten at the time.)He loves to wear a paracord bracelet, but I wasn't eager to spend a lot of money on an ID bracelet with engraving for a child who might 1) lose it or 2) outgrow the condition or change medications.This was a nice compromise. It was inexpensive. If he loses it, I won't be mad. This is soft enough and thin enough that it is fairly unobtrusive on his wrist. He insists that it go above his paracord bracelet because he says that "feels better" against his hand, but he's been willing to wear this.I like that I can write on it with a Sharpie and replace it several times before I approach the cost of an engraved model. I could even apply a label-maker printed sticker to update info temporarily, like with local contact info if we travel. I suspect a label would stick for at least several days on this smooth rubbery material.My needs were met at a fair price. I'm happy.*** EDIT after 4 months use ***I'm taking my review down from 5 to 4 stars. My son still really likes to wear this bracelet, but one of the snaps has broken and this is now quite tricky for him to remove or put on without the broken snap falling down and rolling away, necessitating a big production while we're trying to peacefully prepare for bed. Yes, he's worn it almost every day for a few months, and it is removed most evenings because he doesn't like the feeling of pulling sleeves over it. I think the snaps should hold up longer than this for me to be more satisfied. (Over a year, I suppose!)Also, the Sharpie writing wears off pretty quickly, eliminating its usefulness for a medical safety alert unless I check EVERY DAY to see that my son's vital information is still legible. I think it is wearing off more quickly now than in the beginning, but I'm not sure whether that's possible. Maybe I'm just more annoyed to re-write it now than in June? At any rate, I'm happier overall with the Small Adult - Teen Adjustable Medical Alert ID Bracelet~Charcoal velcro bracelet and its slip-out medical ID card. My son still likes his paracord bracelet the most (as a style statement) and this one second.Consider this bracelet if your kid isn't all that likely to need medical help without a knowing adult nearby, or if you've tried the other types and the kid won't wear them. You'll need to keep checking that the info is on this one, and you may need to replace it after a few months. It is affordable enough to be worth that bit of trouble, in my opinion.

Darn Tough socks are the amazing miracle that allows my sock-demolishing son to pass something down to his younger brother. Seriously, they are like magic!That said, of all our purchased pairs of Darn Tough (because I've switched from Smartwool to Darn Tough, too, when reasonable...) these Coolmax socks fit a little bit bigger. I'm used to Darn Tough wool socks SHRINKING, which our Smartwool pairs don't do quite so much.My son wears WOOL Darn Tough socks in a men's Small, but the men's small in CoolMax are... MINE! They fit him just a bit too big. I'd say they are just a smidge larger than the ladies' Medium I usually wear, especially in the toe box. My son could make do with these, but, instead, they've found their way into my summer sock drawer.

These underpants were bought in size 8 for a child who is just growing into that size. He's a younger sibling, so he's used to wearing hand-me-down Hanna Andersson undies in size Medium. Those last so very long, however, that some pairs have worn down to rather disreputable condition by the second boy, so I needed a few supplementary pairs.My younger son is a sports fan, so I gave these a try. They fit him perfectly well in his correct size. We are a not-so-tall family, and he seems to be a height-weight proportional child, so I'm going to say these fit true to size.The pattern is printed, not woven, but, at least in the "balls" print, this doesn't seem to affect softness or comfort. My child likes these perfectly well, and they cost a whole lot less than our usual brands (HA and Polarn O. Pyret in organic cotton.)I'm still of the opinion that the clothing closest to one's skin ought to be pure, organic cotton whenever possible, but I'm realizing that there is a huge gap between stuff for kids and stuff for adults in this category. These were affordable, cute underwear that fit the bill for my family this time around.

"Auf Deutsch", this book is 528 pages long. Is it faithful to the English version? Well, my German isn't that good, so I'm afraid I can't tell you! However, I am headed to German immersion "camp" together with my 11 year old child, and this is one of his favorite books. Since English language "Bucher" are "verboten", I bought him two of his favorite novels "auf Deutsch" so he can at least pretend to enjoy his favorite activity (reading fiction) while we are at camp. (The other book is "Die Penderwicks" Die Penderwicks, causing no end of hilarity around our household about someone having homicidal intentions toward the oh-so- beloved Penderwick sisters!)The book took a bit longer to arrive than most of my Amazon purchases, but it did arrive within the scheduled window. I'm happy to have German language books so readily available for my child's home-schooling use.By the way, in this book, three of the characters have their usual English names plunked down in the German story, but one of them is called "Kleber." Guess who! :)

Amazon tells me I bought this back in 2012.I'm a naturally lazy, geeky lady who only started exercising routinely around five years ago when life (and a couple of pregnancies) left me sore from normal daily activities like carrying groceries and/or my toddler. I have consistently done strength training 2-3x/week since then, however, and at least a couple of hours of vigorous cardio, too, so now I think I'm in the top 20% of activity for Americans! (That makes me sad, actually.)I bought the RumbleRoller when I realized that, sometimes, my strength training activities would cause knots (trigger points) that led to migraine headaches. Overall, my increased physical fitness has DECREASED my incidence of migraines (a condition I have suffered since age 9), but, if I've taken a vacation, the sudden return to intense activity can lead to painful consequences (i.e., migraines) that I'd prefer to avoid.The Rumble Roller is three years old, used moderately (several times per week between two adults of moderate size), and looks and feels exactly like new. It is an awesome tool for digging into tight muscles, and I'm glad we got it.The kids play with it. They step on it and toss it around. Sometimes, they even "use" it. My husband and I both grab it once in a while and actually use it as designed.I have other products made by "TriggerPoint Therapy" and I was really on the fence back in 2012 over which foam roller with nubs to purchase, but I'm still glad I opted for the Rumble Roller. I still doubt that the flatter nubs on the GRID roller would work quite so well. (That said, I'm also still glad I bought the "Runner's Six" set Trigger Point Performance Ultimate-6 Self-Myofascial Release and Deep Tissue Massage Kit with Guidebook (Updated and Revised) by them. It's great!)A plain (smooth) foam roller is better than no foam roller at all. I think The GRID Trigger Point Performance The Grid Revolutionary Foam Roller or the Rumble Roller are much better than plain foam rollers, at least for the kind of knots that I develop in my upper back and shoulders. If you have chronic muscle tension and pain, consider looking into trigger point therapy, by a professional or on your own. It can be pretty amazing stuff.

I'm returning these shoes. I ordered two pairs of Propet shoes (Propet Women's Mary Lou Mary Jane Sneaker) and one pair of New Balance velcro sneakers New Balance Women's WW411H Health Walking Shoe at one time, looking for something comfortable enough for problem feet (must wear custom hard orthotic inserts at all times) with fasteners I can do up quickly and even on a day my fingers give me trouble.Now, in spite of my health conditions mentioned above, I'm active and 40 years old, not elderly or generally infirm. These were some of the cutest (cute in the realm of COMFORT SHOES) shoes I've tried on in quite a while. At least in the buff color, I think these can kind of disappear at the end of bare legs as a tolerable summer shoe for those of us with sensitive feet.However, I'm returning these because the RIGHT shoe fit perfectly, but the LEFT shoe felt much too small through the arch/instep. In order to fasten the velcro, I had to pull them much to tight to be comfortable. It could be that my left foot was swollen, except that I tried on all three pairs of shoes within the same half hour and didn't have this issue with any other pair. I believe the shoes were made poorly such that there was too much difference in size between left and right.My everyday shoes are Ahnu Sugarpine mesh sneakers/light hikers like theseAhnu Women's Sugarpine Air Mesh Hiking Shoe. They look like sporty sneakers, but at least they come in beautiful colors. I'm still seeking a truly comfortable summer shoe. Sigh.

I've used Persil detergent before, but I thought the tabs might be easier for me to store. They are, and I'd recommend them for people, like me, who use different detergents for different types of laundry. Laundry detergent powder becomes less effective after the box is opened and it is exposed to air. Closing the lid every time helps, but buying a big, economy box isn't always a good idea unless you will use the product up quickly.These tabs are wrapped with two to each cellophane package inside the cardboard box. The box is also shorter in height and wider than the usual tall/narrow detergent box. I think this is less likely to get tipped over as a result, and the wrapped tabs would prevent any mess if this box did get upended somehow.Persil has a distinct fragrance. It reminds me of the smell of Comet cleanser from my childhood, but it has been decades since I last smelled that, so it may not be similar except in my memory. I actually kind of like the smell, but perhaps only because it reminds me of my mother and therefore smells so very "clean"! I usually choose Free & Clear detergents, and I don't use Persil on clothing that will be worn next-to-skin on my child with eczema. I use Persil for my cleaning towels and my white bathroom towels and any white clothing that has stubborn stains.When I've used Persil for stained clothing, it hasn't triggered a rash in my eczema-prone child yet, but I don't care to risk it for everyday use on his clothing or bedding.

I have a child with allergies and eczema. His skin is easily irritated, and he ends up with painful, inflamed skin around his nose and upper lip every winter. Since I fare better using cloth vs. disposable paper/plastic products against my own sensitive skin, I decided to try handkerchiefs for him this year.I ordered two products from this company, these, and the Childs' Organic Cotton Handkerchiefs, Small 8"x8", White (Set of 3). For a busy little boy, I figured it was safer to have at least a handful of hankies if I wanted him to get in the habit of reaching for them.Personally, I find the flannel hankies softer and more enticing than the smooth cotton (percale? sateen?) of these. My son, on the other hand, immediately declared that he wanted to carry the smooth woven ones. He also wants to wear a suit and tuck one into his breast pocket, but he's a bit of a fancy dresser. I explained that a pocket square and a functional handkerchief should probably be separate items, especially for a little boy who wants to play in the snow/mud/sand, but he still reaches for the smooth hankies first. Clearly, it is a matter of personal preference which hankie should be applied to one's nose!As far as nose-wiping goes, a handkerchief works just as well as a tissue. That point is pretty well proven by history.Some people have hygiene objections to using cloth. I will point out that:1) Many people now, and almost all people until this past generation, used, washed and re-used cloth diapers, even before the advent of modern hot water heaters and automatic washing machines. If those can be hygienically cleaned, a hankie is child's play!2) The argument that sticking a used hankie in your pocket is revolting completely ignores that fact that, while a used tissue can (and should) be dropped immediately into a waste container, they are OFTEN stuffed into pockets when no trash can is conveniently located. As a mom, I end up with my kids' used tissues in my hands/car/pockets, not even just my own. (Ick!) My kids leave tissues in their pockets and I end up with white fuzz all over the laundry. Hankies are no less gross than this, and will solve the laundry issue.In particular, I ordered two little washable pouches (Bumkins Reusable Snack Bag, Traffic & Gray Chevron, 2-count) to use as hankie-holders in little boy pockets. In retrospect, I realized that I really want a two-compartment (but tiny!) pouch to have a clean side and a dirty side for daily carrying, but that is something I would likely make use of, while my kids would mix up the clean with the dirty anyway.3) Learning to wash one's hands frequently, especially before eating, will alleviate most of the gross pocket problem anyway. I don't expect my kids to avoid touching dirt/trees/bugs, because they won't learn and grow nearly so well without those experiences, so hand-washing is a must. Focusing on that leaves me free to save a tree and use a handkerchief. It is likely to be the least disgusting thing in my son's pocket on wash day...

Bogs are warmer than old-school rain boots, and the neoprene shaft means they are less likely to crack from wear.My boys like the flexibility of the neoprene shaft. They find Bogs more comfortable than standard rubber boots.They are very heavy, like many waterproof boots, and even children might notice that they are more comfortable on long walks in supportive sneakers, but I don't think that reduces the value and quality of these boots for bad weather days.My 5th grader opted to wear Bogs all winter and decided he didn't need specialized snow boots this year. Not all fully waterproof boots would be warm enough to use for winter, too.

Jim Weiss and his stories are very popular in our family. We've probably got a dozen of his recordings."Treasure Island" was a Hanukkah gift to my kids last year. My home schooled 5th grader read the book as part of his English curriculum, and sharing the audio book shortly thereafter both reinforced the story in his memory and allowed his little brother to share in and enjoy our discussion of the novel.This isn't my favorite classic novel, but it is certainly an enjoyable read. Weiss' version obviously isn't as complete as the unabridged book, and it wasn't too scary for my 7 year old. It is about pirates, however, who take over the ship belonging to the good guys (and get up to pirate mischief, including murder, which is reported but not TOO graphically.)
