Kids who will be anxious when a favorite character is in peril are too young for even the audio version of this book!

This multi-count package of sifter jars worked out to a good price per jar. The jars were shrink-wrapped together and the correct quantity was provided. The sifter inserts were also shrink-wrapped in a separate bundle. All of the parts were carefully boxed and the box was bubble-wrapped. This meant a perfect collection of unblemished jars made it to me in pristine condition.I'm very sensitive to odors, and there was no appreciable scent in my package of jars.I could've used a smaller set of jars, but too many other products had complaints about packaging or lack of sifters, which were critical for my intended use. CoastalScents was a great choice of vendor since they packaged the items so well.

I've got to agree with previous reviewers--these run about one size small. Normally, I order a size 8 in underpants, and these fit just right in size 9.Since I listened and got the right size, I can comment on comfort with a properly fitting garment!These are thicker/heftier cotton than Felina and Jockey cotton underwear I've bought in the past. I would agree that these can have some visible panty line as a result. The (not unattractive) lace border at the top only adds to the show-through. Since my clothing is pretty modest, this isn't a big issue for me, but these aren't my choice for, say, going to the gym where I might wear a legging and have some exposure.Neither the waistband nor the legs are binding or uncomfortable. Aside from being one size larger than I usually buy, these fit me very well. My weight is primarily in my hips but I'm not thin in the thighs, so I think the leg opening is standard FOR ONE SIZE SMALLER THAN THE PACKAGE STATES.Probably because of the sizing issue, the price on these was great. I got three pairs for less than I usually spend on one pair of Felinas!

I prefer strong, black tea in the morning Taylors of Harrogate, Yorkshire Gold Tea, 160-Count Tea Bags and Darjeeling in the early afternoon Twinings Darjeeling Tea 3.53 oz Loose Tea Tin, but if I drink a caffeinated tea too late in the day, I don't sleep at all. There aren't too many herbal tisanes that I enjoy, but this Rishi Blueberry Rooibos is that rare exception. (I don't like most rooibos teas, either.)I find that many guests also really enjoy this tea. It is one of the most popular teas in my kitchen, and I have at least 20 flavors floating around at any given time...Rishi is also a lovely company. I like their commitment to organic products, and have had wonderful customer service when ordering direct from them.

It's a trash bag! :)Okay, why buy this trash bag?I appreciate the large box so I don't have to think about buying bags again for a LOOOONG time. I like the individual rolls of bags inside the large box, each one well sized to leave in the base of the household trash cans so it is quick and easy to replace the bag when the trash goes out. (An idea gleaned from the janitors at my last office.) The bags are clear, which means one can see the icky trash, but they also never clash with the decor where the bag peeps out over the top lip of the trash can.These are of moderate but acceptable thickness. Really, again, they are what I've experienced in an office. They are sufficient for all the trash in my home except for the kitchen, where we employ heavy duty trash compactor bags to avoid disgusting leaks. (We line the compactor bag with a regular plastic kitchen bag, and only throw away the compactor bag when the inner bag leaks... about every two weeks.)

Like another reviewer, I bought these primarily for travel medication containers. The 4 mL bottle is really tiny, and perfect for carrying just a couple of pills in one's purse. My doctor told me to keep one prescription with me at all times, and this is much smaller than anything they could offer at my pharmacy. My pharmacy labels include a small, peel-off sticker with the basic Rx information which I taped around the vial in case any questions ever arise about what I'm carrying.It is worth noting that these are regular screw top bottles, and are therefore not child safe if storing dangerous medications. The user will have to take responsibility for keeping these away from little hands!My preference with travel toiletries is to use really, REALLY tiny bottles on short trips--just enough to get me through a couple of days, which means less than one ounce of shampoo and perhaps a vial this tiny for a facial toner or exfoliant that I use sparingly. The rigidity of these bottles makes them less convenient for very thick creams. For those, I prefer the screw top jars in 1 oz size. Nalgene PC Clear JarA selection of 4 mL and 8 mL narrow-mouth bottles fit nicely in a Pelican 1020 Micro Case with Clear Lid and Carabineer, Yellow for a non-crushable home made "travel pharmacy" solution. We also used some of the vials from this kit Nalgene Multi-Purpose Snap-Cap Vial Kit in the Pelican, but not all of the snap-cap vials are sized for the 1020 Micro Case.

I'm rating this product for its convenient application and use as sun protection.I use sun protective clothing because I've never found a sunscreen that doesn't break my skin out terribly. All chemical sunscreens have an odor that gives me headaches. Even creams with minerals as the active ingredients are too heavy for my sensitive (yet primarily oily) skin. I have to be careful about shampoo, even, because my skin breaks out along the hairline.I'd tried mineral makeup before (Bare Escentuals and a small, locally made brand) but found something in them irritating. I now suspect bismuth oxy(?chloride?) but I'm not sure what the ingredient was that made me itch. (An Amazon listing for Colorscience Sunforgettable lists bismuth oxychloride for the product, but the brand website does not, so I can't give a definitive answer for whether that ingredient is in these products at this time.)I've added an exfoliation step (Paula's Choice Resist Daily Pore-Refining Treatment 2% BHA - 3 oz) to my skin care over the past six months or so, and, while I love what it is doing for my skin, I'm concerned that winter is over and my exfoliated facial skin needs more protection from the sun as UV levels increase into the summer. I'm trying two brands of powder mineral sunscreens in hope I will finally have a workable solution to regular sun protection that doesn't lead to pimples or painful allergic bumps.This product is hands down the easiest thing to apply. Untwist the cap, pull out the brush, rub on the powder.I applied this like eye shadow, and the color looks fine that way with no other makeup. My normal day face is washed, toned & exfoliated. I use lip balm, but usually that isn't even tinted. When I say NO MAKE UP, I mean zero cosmetics on top of my facial skin. I could wear this all alone in an eye shadow position and I wouldn't look weird.Brushed over the underye area, too, I felt the need to apply the other mineral sunscreen on top to even out the coverage. I bought a refill of the Colorscience brush on sun screen Colorescience Pro Sunforgettable SPF 50 Brush Refill-Tan and a less expensive, un-tinted formula Bee Sunny Sport SPF 35 Mineral Powder Sunscreen Zinc Oxide & Titanium Big Jar from Queen Bee to mix my own lighter shade and fill several small shakers to keep in every car and bathroom at home. After applying this home-mixed mineral sunscreen on top, I didn't look particularly made up and I didn't find the Eye Camoflage product noticeable anymore. Outdoors on a walk with my husband, he claimed my face looked "normal".Having just started with these products, it's a little early to tell if I will react badly, but my face isn't itchy at the end of the day as it was with Bare Escentuals makeup. I'll update this review if irritation develops after a couple of weeks' trial.I purchased these pots (Coastal Scents 10 Gram Round Sifter Jar (25 Pack)) and these brushes (Change Makeup Tools Foundation Brush Bamboo Handle Brush) for storing and applying my homemade mineral sunscreen mix. This combination gave me three full sets of brush-on sun screen for less than one applicator tube of the Sunforgettable product by Colorscience at its normal price. Adding the Queen Bee powder made my grand total around $61, which exceeds the retail price of the Colorscience applicator, but gives me at several times as much sunscreen product to apply. Consider buying a refill to test the Colorscience Sunforgettable first, too, if your skin is sensitive! Any clean make up brush can be used to apply.

I borrowed this book from my local library, read it all the way through, and just purchased a Kindle copy for my personal library.I don't have a diagnosis for my joint pain yet, but Rheumatoid Arthritis is a possibility. I've done quite a bit of reading on the internet, and I've met with a highly regarded rheumatologist at a Boston hospital. I would say that I came to this book already well-versed in the current understanding of RA and its treatments.I'm not sure that I learned very many totally new facts about RA, but I did find the presentation of information in this book to be excellent, and the comprehensiveness (in terms of details) really wonderful. I decided that purchase of the book was justified just by the chapters on exercise (including specifics) and medications/treatments.The exercise chapter covers what could be appropriate exercises for three broad categories of RA status: Very Inflamed Joints, Moderately Inflamed Joints and Controlled Joints. There's one chapter on overall activity and health, and another full of specific exercises, such as range of motion exercises (with illustrations.) This was far more helpful to me than advice to "avoid damaging exercises" that I've heard elsewhere! I've been doing strength training with weights for several years, and I wanted very clear, specific advice on what a good exercise program for a person diagnosed with RA might be if that's the diagnosis I end up with. I plan to show this chapter to my rheumatologist and confirm whether his advice matches the general advice Dr. Shlotzhauer offers in the book.Similarly, I've read descriptions of the various DMARDS and biologics on lots of websites, but here they are tidily packaged in one place, and the author has included a table of side effects (with their frequency of incidence) for each one. I could've printed all of this out from the internet, but this is a nice, and seemingly very complete, set of information for me to bring to my doctor visits.About the only thing missing from this book that I personally find really vital to my own choices in treatment options is information about costs. Yes, our system tends to rely upon insurance companies to pay for imaging and treatments (for those of us lucky enough to have good, comprehensive insurance), but that also means sometimes the insurance company's idea of the best first treatment for me might be based upon cost as opposed to outcomes. Knowing the cost of various tests and treatments helps me evaluate whether there might be a money motive I should know about. Consumer Reports did a report on biologics for RA in March 2013, and that document includes prices for those treatments. Elsewhere on the internet, I found a chart "Comparison of Musculoskeletal Imaging Modalities" in a scientific paper that offers a quick overview of Cost, Accuracy, Risk (radiation exposure) and Time (to do the procedure) for Radiography (X-Ray), Ultrasonography, MRI and CT scans. I realize costs vary wildly by geographic region, and the data would go out of date, but the RELATIVE costs are very important to know, and the variations in costs between medical establishments, even in the same geographic area, are frankly offensive when sick and injured people can't easily compare costs between institutions.My least favorite part of this book is the tone of the "Coping with Emotions" chapter. All of the information given is sound, but the author's tone got just a little too "self help book" for me in that section. Admittedly, I'm more data driven and I don't enjoy self-help books. I was also looking for physical/medical advice when I borrowed this book. No doubt the emotional component is vitally important for successful management of an autoimmune disease, but reading about it now (without a diagnosis) just made me kind of grumpy as I think I'd rather not think about it!Other useful sections of the book that I wanted but didn't know for sure I would find therein were:* alternative and complementary therapies* diet (including discussion of gluten-free, Mediterranean, paleo)* financial issues (insurance issues, medication costs issues)* travel with RAI'm grateful that this book was available at my local public library, and it was an easy decision to spend my own few dollars to purchase the Kindle version. If I find any issues with the formatting in the electronic version, I'll update my review. The paperback version was well-formatted and a great reference. The weight of the heavy (trade paperback size) book did present a reading challenge for me with the current state of my hand and wrist pain, however.

I order these (Swisspers Premium Cotton Facial Cleansing Pad, 50-Count (Pack of 6)) using Amazon Subscribe & Save, but I wanted an acrylic container so I could neatly store some within reach on the bathroom counter. This For Pro Square Pad Dispenser does exactly what I wanted, and the price was fair.I will say that, compared to some other acrylic countertop organizers that I've purchased elsewhere (the old "Hold Everything" catalog or The Container Store locally), this holder is just slightly less square and perfectly joined. There is about a 1-2 mm difference in alignment on the two front pieces that keep the entire side from being open. It isn't something glaring, but it is visible if one looks closely at the holder. The edges are also very square, without the incredibly subtle rounding/softening that my more expensive acrylic pieces have. The cuts are straight and unmarked by the little shatter-y marks that sometimes show up on cheap (or broken) acrylic, however.These are very minor imperfections and in no way affect the usefulness of this dispenser, but it could be worth noting if you are extremely concerned about the appearance of your countertop items!

This soap is gentle for the two eczema-prone members of my family. I'm chemically sensitive and I appreciate the minimal formula without added colors or scents.I prefer buying a large refill size and saving plastic bottles.I wish I could buy this locally and that the price per ounce of refills was less than that of new pump dispensers, but neither seems possible. Too bad for the environment!

It is bubble wrap in the harder-to-find 24" size I wanted.I needed clear as I'm using it as a poor person's window insulation for the winter. (Just use a shpritz of tap water from a spray bottle and it will cling to your single-pane window, letting in light and blocking a bit of heat transfer.)I wish the perforations could go BETWEEN rows of bubbles instead of THROUGH a row of bubbles, but the pattern doesn't allow for that and I would assume making it that way would cost a whole lot more than I want to pay.

No reviews makes me nervous on a higher priced item such as this mattress, so I'm writing one upon receipt of the 6" Latex Extra-Firm one I just got from Sleep On Latex. I will try to update after some period of use, but this is for my child's bed.I'm concerned about the prevalence of toxic flame retardants in common use in furniture foam today. I would prefer to buy an organic mattress for my child, but I'm also reluctant to spend huge amounts of money for a kid who is still young enough that accidents or illness could spoil a VERY expensive mattress.We did spring for an organic crib mattress way back when, and I never regretted it as it became a "floor pillow" later! Next step was a cheap IKEA toddler bed (for size reasons mainly) and I used an organic topper over the (probably toxic) cheap foam mattress. Now my son has been diagnosed with allergies, and his doctor said NO FOAM MATTRESSES (even though I used an allergen barrier cover.) I had to make a decision, and I opted to "build my own" mattress using an organic cotton allergen-impervious cover (Pure Rest brand, I believe) and this 6" firm latex core with a 2" medium latex topper zipped inside. If that doesn't feel comfortable for my son, I'll consider adding an organic wool topper later.So far, we've just gotten this piece and zipped it into the cover. Two adults and the child have all tested it out, and it feels like it would be a comfortable bed on its own. Until I've added the 2" layer and "filled up" the outer cover so it won't shift, I'm not making up the bed or letting the child sleep on it.I would hesitate to use this as a mattress without ANY fabric covering. I think the edges could get "worn" and start to degrade. (I would expect this of ANY similar latex block.) I'm hoping the zippered encasement that I use will protect the latex core over time. I will probably add a second allergen barrier cover made of tougher man-made materials over the cotton cover to protect the mattress a little more from risk of tearing or excessive wear from being used (jumped on, etc.) by a little boy.I was very pleasantly surprised by the lack of dust or little "pebbles" of knocked off latex bits within the packing material. I assume that means this is a high quality latex product, because I've got other latex items (pillows and a topper), some of which have crumbled a bit, especially with age or rough handling.I would also like to add that I do have a contact allergy to latex (gloves, medical supplies) that has never been triggered by any latex BEDDING I've used in the past, including handling this mattress core before I got it in the cover. Research suggests an allergic reaction to this form of latex is unlikely, but I was still nervous about handling this big uncovered chunk for as much time as it took to carefully fit it into a cover just exactly the right size. My eczema-prone hands have shown no change in the past few days since handling the mattress.

My SurfacePad has been in place for about two months.Yes, it is a first-world problem, but my husband and I have almost identical laptops and he accidentally took the wrong one to work one day. Oops! I came to Amazon looking for something to make mine visibly unique. It couldn't be too subtle, or my husband might make the same mistake again. I added a folio style cover (Macally Protective Case Cover for 13-Inch MacBook Air (SlimFolio13P)) for the outside, and the SurfacePad to the inside. At this point, he'd have to be distracted, color blind, and maybe something worse to get the two MacBook Airs mixed up again.My product arrived in perfect shape to install--no crease. I didn't have any trouble applying it to the laptop.If I have a complaint, it is that I would prefer white or purple or even dark grey. I like red, but my outer cover is metallic lavender and didn't come in a vibrant color to go with red. I hate black accessories, and, besides, I wanted a color that would POP so even my husband would notice it. Red inside and lavender outside is not ideal from an aesthetic standpoint, but my problem is thoroughly solved.

This is the product I needed that I wasn't sure I would find anywhere at any price. The quality feels good, and the tension rod is holding steady in the location I used it.I bought four of these RoomDividersNow rods in several lengths to use around my open plan house in an attempt to reduce drafts this winter. As is always true with tension rods, they work best when at the LOWER end of their range of width, but even the longest rod used near its upper limit is holding steady at the top of the stairs with a very slight bow at the middle. This shorter-size one used near its end point is not sagging at all.

This is the product I needed that I wasn't sure I would find anywhere at any price. The quality feels good, and the tension rod is holding steady in the location I used it.I bought four of these RoomDividersNow rods in several lengths to use around my open plan house in an attempt to reduce drafts this winter. As is always true with tension rods, they work best when at the LOWER end of their range of width, but even the longest rod used near its upper limit is holding steady at the top of the stairs with a very slight bow at the middle. This mid-size one used at about its middle point is not sagging at all.

I was asked to write a review by the seller, but I appreciate very much that it was a polite email and did not ask for a "positive review," just a review.As it happens, this polo shirt was very affordable and perfect for my needs. We used it as a tunic for a 10 year old boy's Halloween costume as Link from Legend of Zelda. I wanted a longer shirt (ordered a TALL size) but not necessarily a wider shirt. This worked very well for our needs.Compared to any commercial costume, this shirt was much higher quality and more comfortable to wear. It feels like typical knit material from a mass market store. It isn't in any way superlative, except, perhaps, for quality at this price. Nothing about it stood out as a "discount" shirt.

I'm not (even close to being) a teenager anymore, but I never outgrew having moderately oily YET VERY SENSITIVE skin. I look for skin and haircare products with the fewest ingredients, and especially no unnecessary colors or fragrances. Even so, I've tried a lot of different things over the years and I rarely use up a bottle of anything. After a few weeks, most "extra" products lead to breakouts for my skin. For my adult life, I've focused on good but gentle cleansing and an occasional spot of the simplest moisture I could find (Aura Cacia Organic Skin Care Oil, Argan, 1-Fluid Ounce) with a dot of spot treatment (Acne.org 8 oz. Treatment (2.5% Benzoyl Peroxide)) applied to my few blemishes as needed.I read the Paula's Choice website (and especially the Beautypedia reviews) over the past several years. I wanted to try the products, but I was skeptical of yet another "we finally have the solution!" company, although I always found the science at Paula's Choice more compelling than the average beauty site. My first step was to try the DRUGSTORE skin products that were recommended on Beautypedia. I found that many of them worked better than average (based upon past experience of buying from packaging claims) for me. The cost savings of finding a $10 drugstore brand that worked better than department store products is undeniably great. So from that experience, I learned that I can use Cetaphil Gentle Skin Cleanser 20oz 2 pack (works OK) or CeraVe Foaming Facial Cleanser, 12 Ounce and have a pretty good foundation of clean, not-too-stripped, NON-REACTIVE skin.I was off to a good start with the cleanser, but I didn't fare so well with the step Paula considers most important--exfoliation. My skin was definitely feeling different as I came to middle age, and I thought exfoliation was the missing step, too. I've always loved the results of mechanical exfoliation (those little beads or bits of coconut shell) but I would react later (from bits left on skin? from heavy ingredients?) and the argument made for AHA or BHA chemical exfoliation sounded compelling. I tried a few drugstore options, but even the most successful Olay Regenerist Night Resurfacing Elixir felt too heavy on my skin and would lead to breakouts if I used it too often.Aside from a fear of noticeable aging of my skin (though I have no wrinkles yet and am just beginning to find my nasolabial folds/smile lines a bit too pronounced), my only on-going skin issue IF I STUCK WITH MY USUAL PRODUCTS was a steady stream of one or two painful pimples at my hairline. Usually these appeared on the back of my neck (my hair is long) or around my ears, but occasionally they would show up at my jawline or temple and make me curse having zits as an adult. Last summer, I finally decided that I'd gotten enough free good advice from the Paula's Choice website, and I would try the BHA liquid exfoliant that she recommends for skin like mine.I tried FIVE of the Paula's Choice BHA exfoliant variations, and this one, the Resist Daily Pore-Refining Treatment 2% BHA is my favorite, hands down. I'm almost done with my second bottle, and have re-ordered twice now. (A bottle lasts me about two months with daily use.) None of the Paula's Choice BHA treatments caused me an obvious breakout or reaction, but this one goes on easily with a swipe of a cotton pad. It feels lightest upon the face. It is the least sticky in texture.The defining reason I like this product so much is that I've only had two or three total hairline zits since I've started using it (or since the 2nd week or so that it had taken effect.) While I used to have one or two bumps going on at any given time, now I am almost always free of those bumps.Do I look better? Well, my husband says so, but he would ALWAYS say I look better than ever because he is such a nice guy. I think perhaps my skin has slightly better texture overall, but I don't have quantitative evidence of that. The measurable improvement is in the lack of breakouts.Paula's Choice offers sample packets at low prices of EVERY PRODUCT that they sell, so order a sample if you are sensitive. For me, this product is a tremendous winner.

This leather aviator's cap was much better than I expected for the price. We bought in October for a Halloween costume, and the seller didn't raise the prices either, which was nice. A child wore this, but he has a big head. Also, the little buckles at the front and back allowed for customizing the fit. The costume was a great success, and this hat was a huge part of making it look so good. What a great find!

We bought a sisal rug on sale from a higher-end chain store when we moved into our new house about a year ago. The rug pad from the store would've cost as much as the rug, so I just skipped it, hoping our beautiful hardwood floors would be okay with the sisal rug on top. Now, 16 months later the sisal rug STILL curls up at the corners, and I kept worrying about color transfer or other damage to the floors beneath.My 9x12 SUPREME 32 rug pad arrived yesterday and I opened it up to air out overnight. No stinky smell--hurray! (I'm pretty sensitive to chemical smells.) It is nice and thick, and it didn't shed any weird bits around my living room. The kids helped me to roll up the sisal rug and slide this into place. We needed to cut off about one inch in the narrow dimension (9' width) and about four inches off the long dimension (12' length) to make it fit. We started with our usual craft scissors, but switched to my son's newer school pair (still full sized shears) to finish the job. Using SHARP scissors made the job much easier; if yours are old and dull, they may not work at all. No special tools are necessary, however.Now that I have the rug pad underneath, I feel safe using Curl Stop Anti-Curling Rug System (Pack of 4 Corners) to stop the corners from curling. (Those are hard plastic, and might've scratched the hardwood without a rug pad between them and the floor.)

I have two kids in swim lessons at an indoor pool that is apparently kept cool for the competitive team swimmers. My older child looks fine, but my younger kid would sit on the side of the pool waiting his turn, blue-lipped, shivering, and looking for all the world like he was about to drop dead of hypothermia. He still loves swim lessons, but his dad really hates it when the kids are cold, so I turned to Amazon for a solution.This suit is just perfect for our needs. My kids both think it looks cool. The 10 year old is jealous that I can't get one in his size. The 7 year old just loves it, style, fit and he says it is the warmest suit we've tried.As far as sizing, I did opt for the size 8 for my child who wears US 6/7 clothes. (He's a small-ish kid, too.) He wears a Euro size 120 in his Hanna Andersen stuff, and the metric sizing on the company website size chart gave a Euro 128cm size. The suit looked small when I opened the package, but my child says it fits comfortably. My boys do have shorter torsos than average, however, so that may be a big factor in how well this suit fits your kid. (Did they outgrow car safety seats sooner by HEIGHT or by WEIGHT? That could help you decide about this suit... For example, my 10 year old can still fit in some car seats because his height is in his legs, not his trunk.)Realizing that our summer plans depended upon knowing the truth, I opted to use the delicate cycle (in my Miele washing machine, known for gentleness) to wash the Aqua Sphere Stingray Core Warmer, and it came out perfectly fine. Of course, I put it flat on a rack to dry--no machine drying for neoprene!The black torso portion of this suit IS neoprene. It feels thicker and rubbery-er than a normal swimsuit. The colorful arm and leg portions are the same weight as our other swimwear. I try to help my kiddo in and out of the suit because I fear that the stitching between disparate materials will be a weak point, but I haven't actually seen any evidence that we are putting too much tension on the seams, even when the 7 year old is yanking on it because he forgot to use the toilet before swim class!Our other swim suits include Solumbra/Sun Precautions full leg swim pants and long-sleeve zip-front swim top as well as standard swim trunks, so that's my comparison for fabric weight/warmth.According to the AquaSphere web site, this Core Warmer offers their maximum UVA/UVB protection as well as best breathability and quick-drying.

Add me to the list of those who think Perwoll for Wool & Delicates has a very strong scent. It is fragrant, and the smell lingers around the laundry room (and the laundry) after use. I usually avoid all scented detergents and opt for "Free & Clear" versions, so take my opinion with that in mind. I decided to try the Perwoll based upon great reviews on some boards that I trust, and I do agree that it does a good job washing and, in spite of the smell, it doesn't seem to be aggravating my child's (or my) sensitive, eczema-prone skin. It is working out great (for washing performance) in my new Miele washing machine on swimwear, exercise clothes, and other delicate fabrics. I've had to reduce the suggested amount by about half to get good washing with a tolerable smell for our clothes.I will be able to use up this bottle, but I'm not positive I will buy more when it is done. I simply don't think adding smells to my laundry has any relationship to GETTING CLOTHES CLEAN. I just want clean clothing with a neutral scent. However effective Perwoll (and other European detergents I'm trying) may be, they seem just as enamored with adding smells as standard US detergents are. If I can get the same washing performance in a fragrance-free product, that will be my choice.

Thank heavens someone is making some exercise bottoms that come up to the natural waist! These are not my perfect workout pants, but they are the best I've found yet. If you want low-riders, most other fitness pants will be more to your liking, at least, according to the 20 or so styles I've tried on in the past year...I'm in my 30's and I've had two kids. Aside from my personal preference for pants that come up the natural waist (perhaps because I have an hourglass figure and my hips hold my pants up?) I also now have some stretch marks that I'd rather keep to myself. Most fitness clothing is cut very straight/man-ish, and the current trend toward low-cut waistbands also means more styles that hang straight down. These clothes don't feel modest or supportive enough for me, and they also tend to slide right down my hips. When I'm in the gym, I want to get my work done and go home, not keep hitching up my pants.Though I'm a size 12, these fit me pretty well (but loose in the waist) in a Large. Ideally, I'd like the waist to fit about an inch smaller than these do, but, again, this is BY FAR the best I've managed to find yet to fit my shape. I would love to have compression in the waist AND hips for my workouts, but at least these compress my widest measurement (hip/derriere.) I'm thinking I'll try a compression top in combination with these to try to squish both bits at the same time.The fabric on these feels matte (not shiny), thick enough (like pants not tights), and supportive. They were also amongst the least expensive brands that I tried. This is what I thought Spanx exercise would be like, but at less than half the price of the ones I ordered (and returned due to flimsy fabric.)

I'm really glad I bought this little dryer, though I'm not even close to the target demographic. I have a full size laundry set on the lower level of my house (in a dedicated laundry room no less!), but we got the old machines when we bought the house last year, and they were not quite up to my modern laundry diva standards. I'm a terrible housekeeper, but laundry is the only one of the necessary evils of home care that I don't actually hate. My new house also has a little laundry closet upstairs off the master bedroom with room for a compact, stackable washer-dryer set. I bought a nice compact washer for upstairs, but I had two qualms about getting a matching dryer.1) Upstairs would be electric, not gas like the main laundry. Our utility rates are amongst the nation's highest, and I don't want to pay that much for drying clothing just because someone is too lazy to walk downstairs to the "real" machines.2) Upstairs also has the plastic dryer venting going from the closet, through the attic, and outside in an inconvient-to-access place. Eventually, I will replace the fire-hazard plastic venting material, but I don't have the budget to do it now with so many other projects crying out for attention in the new home. Using the 110-V mini Panda dryer must produce less heat, therefore less fire hazard, so so my thinking goes.I hang a lot of my laundry to dry for environmental reasons (and to save wear and tear on finer fabrics) and my intent was to exclusively line dry with the upstairs compact washer. When my inherited-with-the-house dryer died two weeks ago just as the school year ended, planned parties were about to happen, and my house filled with guests... I ordered the Panda dryer and hoped it could see me through a very busy time while I waited for new household units to arrive.I would never compare this little dryer to a full size unit. I don't know that it gets as hot, but it does get hot and dry clothing. I didn't try to cram every item I washed into it, but I did have the option to tumble/fluff the stiff-as-a-board items I'd line-dried previously, and it got the job done every time.Because it is small and less convenient, I don't think other family members will use this at all, and that suits me perfectly. It will take up less space in my laundry closet, leaving more room to put up a shelf for my detergents and letting me avoid storing those in my bedroom or bathroom.I also felt that the luxury of having this little guy meant that I could take my time when picking out my new full-sized machines, and it meant I could afford the extra time lag of ordering them from a less expensive source. With NO laundry options at home, I would've purchased any units available for immediate delivery, because I have two messy boys who spend a lot of time outdoors.I wish the lint filter was easier to clean, but it isn't actually difficult. My mother (one of those houseguests) tells me it is like the ones in the old Maytag dryers she remembers from decades ago.I wish the supplied venting was metal instead of plastic, but I'm happy that they included the pieces that they did. It was easy for me to set the Panda dryer up on my own and get the vent directed out a window so I could work on my laundry backlog without waiting for help to hang it on the wall where it properly goes.My unit came with a faint spot of rust on the exterior top at a seam. I found no evidence of interior rust (that would affect my clothing) so I just accepted it and got on with the laundry. I considered sending it back, but felt that the price was low enough, and my need intense enough, that I could deal with a non-function-impacting defect on the exterior.I don't usually use the Panda to fully dry wet clothing, but I have done so with lightweight and mid-weight items. I haven't tried to dry jeans from fully wet to bone dry. My expectations have been met. Air dry doesn't result in warm clothes, so I'd say it works as described. Warm, which I use most often, results in pleasantly warm items pulled out. I think I've only set the dryer to hot once, just to be sure the dial worked on every setting, so I don't have a lot to say about that setting.I wish the dial felt a little more robust, but any rotary dial strikes me as less likely to need repair than any electronic dryer.I miss the buzzer at the end of the cycle a little bit, but not very much since I'm almost never setting and forgetting laundry upstairs, but rather tumbling nearly dry items that I intend to fold immediately.

I can't believe I haven't rated this album yet. We've had our copy for a couple of months, and this is probably our family's all time favorite recording. Admittedly, we are at the geeky end of the spectrum, and my husband is a scientist and university professor, so there's little surprise that we would enjoy "Here Comes Science" for its themes.On the other hand, the songs on this album are enjoyable musically as well. (Full disclosure: I own a few TMBG albums from my youth, so I'm the target audience there, too.)When your kindergartener corrects an adult spontaneously on the playground that a recent collision wasn't really about speed but actually a problem of VELOCITY (speed & direction), well... let's just say we value the album almost as much as the charming childhood anecdote. :)For myself, the very idea that a band would write a new song "Why Does the Sun Really Shine?" to make it more accurate than the earlier "Why Does the Sun Shine?" is just thrilling. I would suppose that a child who learns even one song on this album may end up knowing more real science than the average American adult.

I think I saw this movie about once a year during my elementary school years in the 1980s. Several scenes from it jumped immediately to mind when I found it while browsing for my own children. Watching it with them, I recalled quite a lot of it, and enjoyed every minute of the film. I think this movie does a good job bringing mathematical thought to a child's attention, and highlighting how much more there is to math than simply solving rows of equations on a piece of paper at one's desk.My kids are six and ten. They both enjoyed watching Donald in Mathmagic Land though I think the older one got a little more educational value out of it. Consider reading a book like Julie Ellis' Pythagoras and the Ratios together with this to cement the ideas for younger kids.

I'm delighted that this detergent is finally available on Amazon with Prime shipping! I began buying this brand of laundry liquid when my younger child was in cloth diapers. He has very sensitive skin, and the detergent that cleaned plenty well enough to leave diapers fresh-smelling and visibly clean for his older brother resulted in painful diaper rash for him. He also tends to develop a rash wherever shift cuffs or necklines sit too firmly against his skin. Switching detergents reduced this kind of contact dermatitis reaction for him, though he remains very prone to skin rash and eczema. (An example of his sensitivity is that we must carry a silk "sleep sack" for him to use at hotels or other peoples' homes to avoid reacting to detergent or bleach residue when traveling.)Atsko sells the same detergent labeled "Sensi-Clean" (marketed to parents of infants) and "Sport Wash". I contacted the company when I first sampled the product to confirm the formulations are identical. You might find Sport Wash at your local sporting goods store, but I wasn't able to find either product locally. I've been buying several bottles at a time and paying shipping for about six years now.Most of my usage has been with a modern, front-loading, high efficiency washing machine. This product works very well and does not over-suds for an HE washer.We've moved to a new home with an older washer (top loader) and I have had to increase from one capful to two capsful to avoid skin reactions for my son. I think it is actually dirt/pollution from the rest of our laundry causing my child to get a rash right now, and the fact that the water is harder in our new town, but I think we've solved the problem and I don't believe this detergent is in any way related to his recent flares of skin rash.When I've run out Sensi-Clean, I've been able to use "Charlie's Soap" or "Country Save Detergent" with pretty good results for my sensitive child. Most other "free and clear" detergents from the grocery store or "natural" products from Whole Foods have not been gentle enough for us to safely use.As an aside, we've used Atsko's Sensi-Clean Shampoo & Body Gel, too, and it was a safe choice for my child. It can be a little drying, however, so we prefer some other, more moisturizing products for his regular use. If you are reacting to everything and struggling to get to a "clean" slate so you can introduce other ingredients and try to isolate your particular allergies, this brand is a good place to start.
My kids were happy to get this. They can use it inside without risk to furniture. We enjoy it.It was a good choice.

I probably read this when it first came out in 1984. The fact that it dances into my mind once a month or so all these years later is pretty telling, I'd say. I'm wondering whether to dig up a copy of this book for my child, who is now about the age when I first encountered it, though I wonder if it will mean as much to a boy as it did to a girl...I do remember the part in this book where the disgusted protagonist notes that her "exotic" shampoo is made in New Zealand. It took me a minute, and probably a double take, to realize that New Zealand was BORING for her, not exotic... and thus I came to a new level of awareness in my own early life about relative perceptions.This is a great, supernatural story that can stay with a girl for decades, if my own experience is any guide. I highly recommend it!

I got two bundle sets of these styli in three lengths to give as gifts this year. All the recipients seemed to like them, most of whom had never before tried using a stylus on their i-devices. I wanted to try a stylus instead of buying special gloves for winter use, and I am happy I gave these a try. They're also useful when I invariably want to look at something on my iPad right after applying hand lotion.The colors are cute. The quality seems very good. It is less than a month after the first were given for Christmas, but all styli are still working, so far as I know. It was interesting to see how different family members preferred the different stylus lengths. It turns out I like the tiny little stub size (about 2") myself, but one of my kids likes these longest (5.3") models, so it isn't just about hand size.

We bought this to use for a Lego Ninjago Sensei Wu costume, so price was a big factor, and I didn't want to glue/stick anything to my child's sensitive skin. While this is clearly more Santa Claus than Sensei Wu, the boy is happy, and the price was reasonable. My kid has a pretty big head (for a kindergartener) but this is still a little loose for him. I'm not complaining, because nothing says this is made in a child size, but I thought it was worth mentioning that this does seem adult-sized.He's been wearing it all evening with no complaints about itching, so hopefully it will last until Halloween next week.We're wearing this with Asian Sun Hat Party Accessory (1 count) and his usual judo uniform White Light Weight Karate Uniform Size 0000 to 8 to which I will apply some hand-drawn patches.

We bought this for a Lego Ninjago Sensei Wu costume, so a low price was our highest priority. (Next option would've been making one out of yellow construction paper, so my needs were VERY easy to meet here!)The hat arrived on time and alone in a box with packing bubbles. I was afraid it would be squished like others experienced, but our hat came out of the box perfectly perky and conical. The child is THRILLED with it, and I am happy with the price.

This is a thin nylon balaclava. It fits snugly on my 9 year old child's head, but he has a big head, so I think it would fit (snugly!) an average adult noggin.We wanted this for a ninja costume, and the price was just right. I am satisfied with what we got for what we paid, and the item arrived right on time, as expected from Amazon.

I felt like I must add a review for this book, because it seems to have been treated rather poorly by other reviewers, and I think it deserves quite a lot better.Our family is Jewish, so perhaps we have a different perspective from some of the others who've reviewed it. The child who read it is a very precocious reader, but not particularly above his age in maturity. I read this before offering it to him, and I think perhaps it is written at a higher reading level than "children's edition" would suggest. It was very accessible to my son, but that is no guide to how a typical 4th grader might respond to it. Content-wise, there was nothing in this book that made me pause before passing it along to my sensitive child.The fact that this book uses "BCE/CE" instead of "BC/AD" makes me like it better. I feel welcomed instead of excluded, though the author is a Christian, as is made plain in the text.The fact that this book references geologic time in the scientifically accepted way makes me like it better. As a person who studies to try to read the Bible in its original language, not an English translation (which was itself translated from the Greek, most likely, not the original!), I revere the word of God, while also seeing the language as poetic and often allegorical. I am not offended by what geology tells us about the age of the planet Earth.I enjoyed reading this book, and it made me interested in reading the (full/adult) original version myself. My child, who was born an engineer, and a questioner of all that he's told, was interested in this story, was brought into the idea of the magic of the Holy Land and imbued with an interest in what makes it special. I think this book stirred something spiritual for my son.We read this before a visit to see the Dead Sea Scrolls exhibit at the local Museum of Science, and it added greatly to our experience. This was the best book on the topic that we read (according to both my son, and myself!)Read this if your reading level is middle school or above, if you are interested in the modern places that were once the real life setting for the stories of the Bible, and if you are open to the thoughts and experiences of another human being experiencing those places in a thoughtful way.

This book was recommended in the teaching materials list provided on the Museum of Science website when the "Dead Sea Scrolls" exhibit was in our city. I couldn't find this at our local library, but it was available on Amazon for a ridiculously low price (less than I pay for a fancy espresso drink!) in library binding, so I just bought it.My nine year old son found a factual error when he read it. This was a few weeks ago, and I didn't note what the error was, but it was something I confirmed at the time, I think relating to whether the person who found the scrolls was alone or with another... It didn't render the entire book useless by any stretch, but he was very turned off by the mistake, and, based upon our other sources, it WAS a mistake. We are reading history with a very clear understanding of the fact that we learn more over time, understanding shifts with the uncovering of new information, etc., so I used it as a teaching moment. He liked the book less as a result, however.I'm dealing with a very precocious reader (probably comparable to an above average high school graduate?) who is not emotionally precocious, so he could easily have caught something that was meant to be a simplification for the intended audience. The book had nice photos, was generally well written, and mostly agreed with our other readings, so I think it is still worth reading if you are studying the Dead Sea Scrolls at an elementary school level.He enjoyed The Mystery of the Dead Sea Scrolls more (a novel), but his favorite reference for this topic was Walking the Bible (children's edition): An Illustrated Journey for Kids Through the Greatest Stories Ever Told.

I ordered and received 4 x 3-packs of these socket reducer bases last week. I use these to allow for the use of value-priced 3-packs of candelabra-based LED "flame shaped" bulbs (from my big warehouse/membership store) in my new home's gazillion overhead can lights. I find the light level more than adequate with a laughably reduced wattage going this route, but I've needed to buy a lot of socket reducers.The order before, I was able to buy ZITRADES(TM) UL listed 5PCS/Pack E26 Male to E12 Female Socket Adapter Conversion socket High quality fireproof material by ZITRADES instead, and those do feel like a higher quality product in the hand. They were not available when I came back to re-order, so I gave the KOR socket reducer a try.I have installed all 12 socket reducers, and all of them worked (and are working) just fine.I've since switched to ordering tiny LED ceiling fan bulbs with a standard (medium/E26) base instead Feit Electric BPA15/CL/LED/RP Accent LED A15 Bulb, Clear or G7 Power G7G16330 G16 3W 250 Lumen LED Light Bulb, as the price is only a bit higher for a slightly lower level of lumens, but without my lingering fear of having a bunch of adapters all over my house perhaps being a fire hazard...

I really love these lights. I bought this set, plus a larger set of the longer panels NEW Designer Series SIX 18" COOL WHITE LED Panels, 2 power supplies, 2 dimmers and I'm using them in three locations around my house, but with a mixture of short (10") and long (18") panels in each place.The best part about this system, in my opinion, is the modularity. You can mix and match COOL vs WARM, 10" or 18" panels, and presumably "designer" (these have a plastic deflector/cover over the LEDS) or the basic uncovered strips. I bought a couple of shorter connector cords, too, and I mixed and matched all the bits from my few purchases to accomplish what I wanted.It is worth noting that, if you buy these directly from the maker's site, you can specify different cord lengths than those offered by default in the Amazon kits. I thought about going that route, but I opted to first purchase from a known entity (Amazon) that I already trust. If I go back for more, I may well order direct from the manufacturer. Unlike some reviewers, I totally understand that it costs almost as much to make a short cord as a long one, so I'm not going to rant about the relatively high cost of the four inch connector cord that I wanted 4" (Four Inch) Interconnect Cable for use with Inspired LED Lighting Systems to complement the parts I got in my two kits. (I do wish it had been cheaper, but I think the price is fair considering the scale of production.)I'm using these in two rooms with a motion sensor plug Westek MLC4BC Indoor Plug-In Motion Activated Light Control and it is simply plugged in at the third location. I would prefer a light sensor/motion sensor combo plug, but this is adequate for now. Eventually, I may have the electrician hard-wire the kitchen location. For right now, I've got the energy efficient lighting that I wanted in exactly the locations I desired, and I was THRILLED to have the option to purchase parts as I did.When I remodeled my kitchen in 2007, I spent more for two LED strips than I did this time for nine strips of higher quality with more LEDs. The time has come for the masses to at least give LED lights a try. Prices are now quite fair.Personally, I am a huge fan of widely dispersed light at a fairly low level of lumens. (That means I like the light level low, but spread out, so everything is visible but nothing is bright.) These products work GREAT for my purposes. My husband prefers a much brighter light source... almost everywhere! While he wouldn't use LED strips in as many locations as I prefer them, even he admits that they are working great in our new kitchen. We have a five foot wide industrial hood. As "cool" and high end as this thing is... it had no built in task light when we moved in. With the kitchen overhead lights on, your shadow landed on the stove. I used two 10" strips and three 18" strips to add even illumination along the rolled metal edge of the hood, bringing the power cord down one side to a nearby outlet. Now we can clearly see what we are cooking. While my husband might wish this were a 400 Watt halogen fixture, he is happier to have this much light than no light at all.I like COOL white light, so that is what I got. I haven't tried Inspired LED's WARM white color to offer a comparison.If money were no object, I would have already ordered these to install in my closet, under the toe kick in every bathroom, under the toe kick in the kitchen, and up on a ledge we have in a light-well beneath a skylight... I will get those eventually, but the kitchen is probably the ideal place for most consumers to start. It is amazing what a few strips of these little lights can do in a small, dark kitchen. I speak from experience on that!

I've just purchased a second unit of this item for our home use. I prefer to buy from an art supply store that is an Amazon partner, both because I love art supply companies, and because they have the best price I've found. It is worth an internet search when buying this product if price matters to you.Our last purchase was two and a half years ago, and our most recent use (last week) of the Model Magic was still soft and pliable, so the sealed packets do last a very long time. I saw no evidence of drying out, so assume AT LEAST three years' shelf life.For my family, this "classroom" pack has been the best way to purchase Model Magic. We like to use several colors at a time, but we don't need huge quantities of each color each time. I can open up one little packet of each primary color, split them between my two boys, and everyone gets to use every color (even if in a very small quantity.) When someone wants to make a specific (larger) object, I might open multiple packets of a given color. Larger packs might be a better value for those projects, but, more often, we are just playing.Admittedly, now that my kids are older (both elementary aged) and one of my son's is being home schooled, this time around I've purchased some larger packs of the earth tone colors in addition to another Class Pack-Assorted Colors. We are studying ancient history, and both of us keep thinking of fun art/craft projects that can be made with Terra Cotta or Earthtone Model Magic.For younger kids, I think these primary (plus white) packets in the Class Pack-Assorted Colors are the best combination of value and fun. For occasional use, these packets will keep for YEARS and are easy to grab and use without waste. If traveling, these small packets are "TSA compliant" and can be packed in your "liquids" bag to entertain kids in the air. (I don't KNOW if they would otherwise be confiscated, but I'm a cautious traveler.)We are about to try another product called Cloud Clay that is made by AMACO to see if we like it as well as Model Magic. I will update my review with thoughts on how the two products compare.

I bought three packs of these (15 total adapters.) I've deployed them all over my house so that I could substitute 4.8 W candelabra base bulbs in the massive quantity of overhead can lights in my new home. (I use fewer watts now for ALL the bulbs on most switches than a single one of the incandescent bulbs consumed before, and the house is still very well lit!)My only complaint is that I just came back for more, but these are no longer available. :(

I bought two of these one foot (12 inch) cables, actually, and both of them work exactly as they should.I agree that the price seems steep for a little bit of cable, but I suspect that producing the cable costs more than the materials, so a short cord is not cheaper than a long cord.It is worth noting that one can order products directly from the manufacturer and request different cable lengths than those supplied in Amazon kits. I thought about doing that, and may purchase direct in the future when I inevitably expand my use of LED lights, but I often prefer to go through Amazon on a purchase from a new supplier like this one, enjoy my Prime shipping, know the return policy, etc.I love these lights. When I bought LED strip lights for a kitchen remodel in 2007, I paid more two pieces (less bright than these) than I did for a total of nine light strips and three power sources here and now. I am a huge fan of dispersed lighting at low levels, and this company offered the total flexibility that I wanted. I think these are a solid buy, even at this price for a cable.The cheapest place I know of to purchase LED strips is the big Swedish boxed furniture chain, but there is zero flexibility with those! Inspired LED is literally lighting up my life. :)

We were able to borrow this from our local library. All told, I found it to be worth spending about an hour of our home school study time with this video and subsequent discussion.It was made around 1998, and that shows in the production values. For the first few minutes, I was afraid the whole video would be simply a classroom lecture by a slightly odd teacher (dressed in an archaeologist costume!) There were SOME on location shots of historic sites and artifacts, so it was better than my initial impression. Very little is re-enacted, which I'm actually happy about.A more recent "Discovery Channel" video will probably be more slick and fancy than this video series. On the other hand, this is designed for children, so there is no risk of some kind of "racy" adult information about an ancient culture popping up... (I'm willing to deal with radical departures from our personal morals when explaining history, but not all parents will want to explain Egyptian royal incest, etc.)This video covers the possibility that an inland lake on modern Santorini is the actual site of the lost continent of Atlantis, the Minoan civilization, and the Mycenaen civilization. I have been reading about a dozen elementary level books on these topics in the past couple of weeks, and there were no obvious errors on the video that I caught. That's actually a pretty good track record from what I've found elsewhere. I wouldn't spend my money to purchase this unless I were a teacher returning to it year after year, but it was well worth watching for our home school use.

Our family has listened to the The Classical Kids Collection: Volume 2: Tales of Enchantment and Classical Music for four years now, and we love the combination of music and storytelling. I went to the library looking for anything similar to those. A closer match is the lovely Peggy's Violin a Butterfly in Time, but I brought this one home, too. (If you are only buying one story/music combo, I'd recommend the former over this CD, but this is still a fun and useful collection!)If my children were 2.5, I would certainly play them the first track, which is a charming take on this classic American poem, and I think the before and after version of the Come Little Rabbit song would also resonate. For children so young, the remaining tracks would be unlikely to catch their interest. By around age 4 or 5, I think, many kids could hear the composers explanation of how different musical sounds bring characters to life, and they would absorb a fair bit, if largely through the emotional component of the sounds.What I REALLY liked about this disc was the chance for my older child (age 9) to hear the composer talk us through the process of creating a meaningful musical accompaniment to the poem. I think it underscores some important points about poetry and music in a way that was more fun and approachable than a lecture from mom!I believe that I, the adult, was the most interested in the background story of "Casey at the Bat." I remember it from school, I've always liked it, and I wanted to introduce this lighthearted poem to my kids. After the second listen to the disc, however, I would skip the background story. I think I've gotten all I need from that.We are a home schooling family, so I appreciated the free poetics/music lesson for my child. Even if my kids were both still in school, I would've been happy to have heard this CD with my kids. I hardly think it should be relegated only to the "educational" pile. Let's not forget how very easy it is to skip a track on these modern CD's. :)My kids find the poem quite fun to listen to, and, when my violin-playing son gets more skilled, he may well be able to play along with the Suzuki-taught children on one of the tracks where the conductor suggests children join in. Our Michael Clay Thompson language arts curriculum emphasizes poetics (The Music of the Hemispheres: Teacher Manual) and we feel strongly enough about music education that our kids attend private lessons, so that is my perspective to help you decide if my opinions are relevant to you.

I've had "Robolina" a few weeks, and she's my first robot vacuum, so that's where I'm coming from.Instead of Amazon, I bought my Moneual Rydis from my membership warehouse. They carry three robot vacuums right now--one iRobot, one Neat-o, and this one. Here's why I chose the Moneual from this selection:1) I prefer the more environmentally friendly Lithium Iron Phosphate battery, offered by the Moneual only2) If using a robot vacuum works for my family, I will buy a DIFFERENT model for our carpeted rooms. Having a machine that works better on HARD FLOORS ONLY was a plus for my situation.3) People said the Moneual Rydis had the easiest dust compartment to empty4) I thought the remote control would be fun for my kids.As it turns out, the remote control *IS* fun for my kids. Most of the time, one of them (as a treat!) or I will manually drive Robolina to the area of the room that we most want cleaned, then we hit the "Auto" button. We have a very large (over 1200 sq ft) great room with hardwood floors and a couple of area rugs, and this is where we've primarily been testing Robolina's usefulness. After Robolina's inaugural run--the same day my housekeeper had been over and both vacuumed (central vac) and dry mopped (Swiffer) the entire place--AND THE DUST BIN WAS FULL OF CRUD, I knew I was a permanent convert to the robot vacuum. In a similar vein, we broke a glass in the kitchen several weeks ago, and have vacuumed, mopped, and I even wiped the whole area by hand with damp paper towel before I let my kids back in. After Robolina's first pass at it, I found a shard of glass we'd missed when I emptied her bin.I really hate the vacuum. I hate fiddling with the cord, plugging and re-plugging as I move around the house. I actually hate the central vacuum at my new house even more, because the hose is so enormous, heavy, and unwieldy. I pull out a broom and dustpan several times a day, but I almost never get around to the vacuuming, or I beg my overworked husband to do it when he gets home. I hate the dust kicked up, the noise, all of it.I am emptying Robolina's dust catcher at least once every day, but doing that annoys me less than using the regular vacuum would. I have had to unwind a few strings from her wheels, but that is still less bother than I find the big vacuum. For me, using a robot is a no brainer. You'll need to assess your own temperament to decide if you would feel the same way. I don't expect Robolina to get my floors deep cleaned, just to reduce the dirt in between regular vacuuming on the same schedule we had before (once or twice a week.) It is pretty obvious that we are removing more dirt and dust now, because Robolina runs at least once a day when I think of it (and I would NOT have been vacuuming at these times), plus she runs another time, most days, when one of my kids asks if the robot can come out to play. How could it not be an improvement?The level of light bumping against furniture that Robolina does is very well within my comfort level. I've seen her nudge a lightweight object, but nothing even close to worrisome has occurred in our home. (Admittedly, I only have one antique piece, and I have kids, so assess your own standards here, too!) The noise level is significantly less than I find any of our regular vacuums, maybe even less than the central vac? I leave the room when someone is vacuuming, usually, but I can stay in the room while Robolina works, especially because she wanders nearer, then farther, then under the couch where she's muffled... The volume strikes me as less intense overall.If I hadn't just bought an expensive new house, I'd probably already have purchased a second robot vacuum for the two other levels in my home. I'm already that intensely sold on this method of cleaning. I may still try out a Neato or iRobot product, however, especially for the upstairs which is entirely carpeted, and reviews suggest iRobot might be the best for that situation. If I come to decide any failure on the Moneual Rydis' part is a reason to switch brands (as opposed to my love of trying every option!) I'll update this review.*** UPDATE: 8 months later ***I still love having a robot vacuum. People who come over often notice it docked in our great room and ask my opinion. I still think you need to assess your own cleaning habits and temperament to decide if one is right for you. For those of us who have sensory issues around noise, the robot vacuum fills a unique niche.I use Robolina primarily in my kitchen and my great room. These two rooms are the easiest for our family to keep "robot safe" on a regular basis. By this, I mean no little toys or tangling strings on the floor, and few delicate items left in harm's way to manually pick up before letting the robot out. For us, the kitchen floor is the easiest to keep clutter-free, therefore the robot runs most often there. In the great room, I often assign the job of robot-tending to my ten year old son. He plays nearby and comes running if Robolina sounds different or asks for help.Today, Robolina asked for help with her brush. I read the manual 8 months ago, but haven't looked at it since. I double checked that it was okay to pull off the plastic brush surround (yes) and how to remove the brush itself (a simple tug from the correct end) and discovered that there was quite a twist of hair (mostly mine) around both ends of the brush and under each of the spinning sweeper brushes to boot. I probably should have unscrewed the spinners and pulled out the brush before this and removed the hair, but that's how long our robot was able to go about her business before this chore was required in a household with no pets, one long-haired female, and use primarily for kitchen dirt on tile and dust on hardwood.Emptying Robolina's dustbin is easy and I don't mind doing it. Sometimes I need a toothpick to get a wad of dust out. I am ordering a second filter for the dustbin today because you are supposed to rinse it between uses and you have to wait for it to dry thoroughly. I often run Robolina in one room, empty the bin, then wish to immediately clean the second area without that wait.Our mopping head and "guard" got yanked off at some point and the double stick tape (IIRC) that held it on was no longer viable so we've simply stopped using this feature. It certainly showed some dirt, meaning it picked some up, but I don't see a visible difference in how this affects the cleanliness of my floors.Our charging STATION failed, so now I manually plug Robolina into the power cord after use. Since she regularly needed help docking correctly, and since I'm carrying her up two steps to one of my two regular cleaning areas, this isn't annoying to me, aside from wishing the docking station were of higher quality in principle.While I've never timed Robolina's run time, after eight months, I don't "feel" like she runs for any less time than before. I am satisfied with the battery strength and life.My children are no longer excited enough about the vacuum to ask to use it, but their visiting friends often ask if they can watch the robot go, and my kids enjoy showing off how it works.

My boys both wore permethrin-treated Columbia pants in a different style every school day above 40 F last year. Our area has endemic Lyme disease, and their school is in the woods, and stresses lots of outdoor time in all weather. Classmates had a tick almost every day, but we never found one on either of our kids after school when we checked.I got them each one pair of this style recently. Compared to the pant-sized olive green design from last year (size 10), these (M 10/12) are looser and seem a bit shorter in the inseam. We're short, so that's less hemming for me to do! The kids find these faster/easier to put on, and are happy about that. The sized pants with button/zip fly looked a touch better since they fit more closely, but their zip-off legs made that a moot point in my view.All in all, I like this style better, and I think my kids both do, too. Unless they care about fashion, pull-on elastic waist pants seem much more popular with the elementary aged boys I know.

I was thrilled to find these comfortable (full elastic waist), thin (much lighter than typical chino pants), 100% cotton pants for my child to use when we travel. Poly/nylon are quicker to dry when washed in a hotel room sink, but I prefer for my kids to travel in natural fibers in case we are ever in a plane crash since synthetics can melt into one's skin under those terrible conditions.My own travel wardrobe consists of lightweight, color-coordinated, quick-drying basics. It is surprisingly hard to find similar pieces for kids! I want to teach them to travel light, which I define as carry-on only. (That means one bag only, not a full size rolling bag plus a huge daypack.) Finding the right items to pack is part of the process. Since they carry their own bags, and kids should only tote 5-10% of their body weight, lighter fabrics really help.We layer thin pants over thin (silk) long johns to keep warm, and the long johns double as pajamas. At home, worn over thermal long johns, these pants work all year 'round, even in New England.The description should specify that these are thin pants--I'd compare the fabric to a crisp safari SHIRT weight. The fact that they are thin does not make them worse pants, but they won't suit everyone's needs. These are wearing well so far for us, but I wouldn't expect them to handle too much abrasion (rocks/asphalt.)The style is a fairly full cut. They look a touch baggy on my normal-weight child. He cares more that they are comfortable, though, and is not particularly interested in fashion. I can dress these up while we are traveling, but would not choose them first for dress-up wear at home.

I wouldn't write a review so soon after receiving a book like this--I haven't even used it with my home schooling son yet as we're covering grammar before moving on to literature later this year. However, the other review for this book is very negative, and I believe those criticisms to be unwarranted.I am an educated parent and new home educator, not a teacher. I read about the Suppose the Wolf Were an Octopus guides on the publisher's website, but wanted it used, so I came to Amazon. From my quick perusal of the titles available, the edition with fairy tales is for much younger students, and is also available here on Amazon.This edition is for grades 5-6. My son is only in the fourth grade, but he reads at a college level (technically.) I was hoping this guide would help me to advance his understanding of books written close to his emotional maturity level.There are about fifty books listed in the table of contents, and I counted 28 that I know from my own childhood (most of which I've read.) This is perfect for me, since I may not re-read every novel that I assign to my son, but, in that case, I will certainly be able to lead him through a thoughtful analysis better with the help of this book. A couple of examples of very well known titles are: Black Beauty, From the Mixed Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler, A Wrinkle in Time, Bridge to Terabithia, The Call of the Wild, and The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe.My edition of this book is (c) 1995, just in case there are different editions out there with different contents. I'm posting the table of contents here to help other parents/teachers assess whether this book contains titles with which they want to work.

I learned about the Handwriting Without Tears program from an occupational therapist. While I don't think the handwriting that results is the most beautiful style, I do love seeing the huge improvement in my son's ability to express himself on paper!We've left our previous school and switched to home schooling for this year, and my son actually requested that I order more of this paper after our first week of formal lessons using the basic filler paper from the office supply megastore. He says it is so much easier to get his letters the right size when he has the double lined paper.I shopped Amazon first, but this is a product where you will probably do better looking around the internet, including the manufacturer's own site.

I'm baffled by the ridiculously high cost of basic bookends. Unless I buy a bulk package of dozens for almost a hundred dollars, they cost about ten bucks a pair! We are home schooling this year, and, as an addicted book-hound, that has meant a lot of new volumes flowing into our home, many of them bulky textbooks, and most of them toppling over off of our newly designed "school" workstation wall. When I recovered from the faint induced by shopping for bookends, I found this Safco metal mesh divider at my favorite "bulk warehouse" store website and bought one right away.Wow, is this perfect for my needs. It keeps even heavy textbooks upright, and it lets me divide up the books by subject matter with less chance of accidental rearrangement by my elementary aged kid. It is at least as attractive as regular bookends, too, and far less likely to be tipped over. The warehouse store only sold a couple of these pieces, and I noticed an intriguing smaller size Safco Products Onyx 5 Upright Sections, Black (3256BL) in the product photo that I couldn't buy there... Naturally, I came to Amazon, and discovered I could've saved a few dollars by shopping here first. I bought my five section organizer here, and am about ready to spring for a second one of the 8-section I bought originally. (I'm integrating a decade of the results of a bibliophile buying children's nonfiction books. Most normal people could probably use one of these 8-section organizers for all of their texts.)I'm really happy to have our books staying upright, on the shelves, and no longer fear that they will topple onto my children's heads. (The bookshelves are above their desks.) The increase in organization makes me happy. These are coated metal, look pretty good, and show no signs of bending under heavy loads. I am very happy with this line of products, and expect to buy several more.

We're starting up our 4th grade home school year now, and I decided to start us off with PRE-History before we carry on with our chronological study of human history from the ancient world onwards. This book was already in our library of children's non-fiction, but it was precisely what I was looking for.At 61 pages (ours is a 1983 edition), it took my son less than an hour to read in its entirety. He did stop to ask a few questions along the way. He is a very strong reader, so I'm a poor one to comment on how the language in this book would be for a more typical 9 year old. The content, however, is perfect. As I read through the book before giving it to him, I didn't feel "talked down to". This is not a simple picture book like the DK ones with a lot of "sound bites" surrounding a minimal narrative. Instead, this reads like a simplified textbook for a grade school child. Perfect!I did supplement this book with a more recent chart of human evolution from a different (more current) source. It was easy to explain this to my son, because  All About Prehistoric Man discusses how scientists were debating whether to classify  Homo habilis as Homo or Australopithecus habilis. I'm not looking for my son to memorize our probable human ancestors at this point in his education, but I do appreciate his learning more about how working anthropologists learn more, adjust their own understanding and recategorize that information for the rest of us. He learned something about real human knowledge as adults use it as compared to typical children's textbooks which can make topics seem quite static and "dead".At its original full price, a book like this might be better suited to a school library, but it was precisely what I wanted and well worth the typical used price for my home school purposes. Even if "known facts" change, a book like this can still form a basis from which the educated parent can teach a child about the general path of human evolution and prehistoric man.  The discussion of why we now know something different than what the "best expert" of the past once said is invaluable.

When I began to read this novel, I wondered if it was just idly pleasant reading, or if it was ever going to "go somewhere." You'll need a bit of patience to get through the introductory section, although it artfully rendered a world I found alluring right from the start.I would have enjoyed this book simply for the "character study" of the Mathic world on Arbre. Once the adventure bit began, however, I started nudging my (sleeping) husband to tell him he's got to read this book... As an educated and intelligent person who's opted to stay home with the kiddos for the past many years, I positively reveled in the theorics discussions peppered throughout. This kind of exploration of ideas represents the very best that science fiction can be.I really enjoyed Anathem! On the other hand, I wouldn't recommend it to just anybody. Some people want a book they can just guzzle down like soda pop; this one requires you to chew thoroughly and swallow.
Works perfectly. I think the name should be "Guitar AND Bass To USB". It works on both.
Surprisingly good story lines and acting. Too bad Timeless doesn't release the entire series.
Gets under the eggs with ease and has a long stiff blade that is wide enough to hold the entire egg.
Very good anchor system - for Moen products. It can be adpated to non-Moen bars, but does take some creative thinking to do it. Would be 5 stars if it were a unversal design.

Another reviewer compared the bristles to a wire brush. That isn't far from the truth. These bristles will rip your gums a[part if you don't ease off the pressure.Another problem is that Oral B put the grips along the sides of the handle instead of where your fingers and thumb contact it. This leaves the slippery plastic to cause you to lose control of the brush if your fingers are wet. That may not be a bad thing since it could save your gums from being ripped apart bt those bristles.
