Colgate's new marketing kids changed a runaway success (the non-360 toothbrush) into this completely redesigned disaster. The bristles are nowhere near as good and the worst part is the round handle (that's why they call it the "360"). You can't control the toothbrush. It spins in your mouth while you are brushing, especially while your hands are wet. You have to hold it like a monkey. Maybe their market research was conducted in a zoo.It gets better: these idiots put protrusions on the back of the brush head! When you are brushing the outside of your teeth, these things rub annoyingly against your cheeks. When you are brushing the inside of your teeth, they rub against your tongue. They should call this the "Porcupine 360". Basic problem is that you have a company here whose management is asleep at the switch. This product has to be someone's idea of a joke.Try the Reach Advanced Design Full Head Toothbrush.

This review is written from the perspective of someone that is not tech savy, such as a senior.I just provided this phone to someone that has been successfully using a Verizon Samsung phone very similar to the Jitterbug and am disappointed with the misleading opening screen. It is VERY confusing for seniors - the exact opposite of the intent to make it easier to use for older people. You get a screen that has a scrolling option on it, every time you turn it on, and it has the question: "Select?" at the bottom of the screen. I can't tell you how many times the user pushes the "Yes" button and is then directed to whatever option they accidentally have on the screen. I say "accidentally" because the two arrow buttons and the "No" button will scroll to different screen options, compounding the confusion. This cannot be changed, since GreatCall's management has decided that users should not be able to choose their own screen settings. It is nothing like any other cell phone to which you are accustomed. The user does not realize that he must ignore whatever the screen says - a counter-intuitive process - and just start dialing.There is a phonebook, which is part of that confusing scroll screen and, once you program it, you can use the number buttons for speed dial. In the phone book, in the upper right corner of the screen, you will see the button number assigned to the phone number. However, to use the speed dial, you can't just press the corresponding number button to dial (unlike all other cell phones I've owned). You will have to press the button number corresponding to the phone number in your phone book. The button number then appears on your screen. You then press the "Yes" button and it will start dialing and then it will display the phone number being dialed. I am explaining all of this because the speed dial function is completely missing in the user manual sent with the phone.You will see, in the user manual, instructions on using voice dialing, which is active when the opening menu is scrolled correctly to "Voice Dial" instead of a permanent setting option. However, even though it is in the manual, the "Voice Dial" menu option does not appear on your phone initially. You must call GreatCall customer service to have them activate it (takes 2 hours for it to appear on your phone after they activate it). I mention this because there is no instruction in the manual explaining why it doesn't appear on your phone when you first receive it. Additionally - now this is TOP SECRET - you can have the phone start with voice dial as the default screen whenever you open the phone to make a call. This is a much better option than the confusing scroll screen. This info is nowhere in the manual and only one customer service agent, out of five, accidentally mentioned it to me.Other shortcomings and tips:- Speaker function does not have an identifiable "speaker" button. To use the speaker function, you must have already dialed your number and then you can press the up arrow button to turn the speaker on and off, but it does not remain in the 'on' position after you hang up and you will have to repeat this process with every phone call. Too cumbersome for a senior.- Neither a battery strength or signal strength indicator appear anywhere on either screen (what device have you ever owned that didn't show battery strength?). It is buried inside one of those scroll functions on the opening screen. It does flash a warning when you are running low on battery charge, but nothing is easily viewed before that critical warning.- If you are switching from one Greatcall device to a new Greatcall device, be prepared to have to set up an entirely new account and filling in all of the information you already have in your old account. Further, you will need a new email address, since Greatcall will not allow the same email address to be used twice, even though you are deleting your old account. Believe me, Greatcall's management are not bright. I am at two weeks of nearly daily calls to customer service agents that are ineffective at implementing what they say they will do and are not generally knowledgeable about their products or systems.- When first setting this up, be prepared to spend a week or two on daily (many times a day) calls to customer service. ANYTHING that you need added/updated to your new phone will take many attempts for GreatCall to get it right. You will also get conflicting instructions from each agent but, with enough patience on your part, eventually they get it right. The only thing they got right the first time, was taking my money.All in all, this is a device that does not conform to other cell phone standards and is prone to confusing older folks. If many of the options could be permanently set by the user, instead of having to be selected each time, including the option to eliminate that opening scrolling mess, the rating would jump substantially.
Works well. Lasts about a month before new indicator solution is needed. Be sure to allow about a month for delivery.
Perfect size for my rimless glasses and good neutral-gray darkening.

Good darkening level, but these are huge lenses. If you want a smaller size that fits rimless better, go to the Amazon "Polarized Rimless Rectangle Gray Lens Flip Up Clip on Sunglasses Eyeglass" page.

Unlike most other big brand crabgrass preventers, such as Scott's, this contains Dimension, which is the trade-name of a pre-emergent utilizing dithiopyr that works both as a pre-emergent and post-emergent for recently sprouted plants. That means that you can apply it later in the season because it kills crabgrass that has already emerged (unlike other pre-emergents) and it lasts longer.It is a pre-emergent ONLY (no fertilizer). You shouldn't put fertilizer down in the early spring anyway. It encourages top growth at the expense of root growth. Apply your fertilizer in late fall (after Thanksgiving), when the grass is dormant, and it will be there for the roots next spring. Then put down another dose of slow-release fertilizer in early June to help get the grass through the summer heat and another dose in early September.

Great for a year (6 applications) ...until the shut off plate pulls away from the bottom of the red tub, due to poor design, releasing all of the fertilizer onto your lawn. Earthway will replace the red tub, but that means that you are responsible for disassembling the spreader and putting all of those parts back together again ...and it is difficult. you will need to call them back to get instructionsThe problem is that the shut off plate that opens and closes to allow metered dispensing is retained on the tub by plastic hooks that are part of the tub. Earthway's engineers (term used losely) do not understand that plastics are sensitive to 90 degree angles (they break easily at the angle) and that is exactly how these retainers are designed. As you open and close the fertilizer release mechanism, you gradually stress those angled retainers until they finally break. When you consider that the plastic used is the same as the low-quality plastic used in your kitchen garbage can, you can depend upon these breaking before you get much use out of it.You can't do worse by trying Scott's spreaders, which is what I'll do when Earthway refuses to send me more replacement tubs whenever the hooks break.

Look at the pattern in the reviews: these don't last. Of the the three, one has failed after two months of use. The LED industry claims LED's last 20 years. Theoretically, the LED source might, in the lab, make it that long according to the accelerated tests they use, but this is not real world testing. LED's are not as simple as the tried-and-true incandescent bulbs. LED's require complex and sensitive electronics behind that light you see. It is those electronics that are so finicky and prone to failure.This is a poor value. Perhaps, if they were $5 a bulb, it MIGHT be justifiable, assuming the other two don't fail in the next 6 months. However, at almost double that price, it's not a good deal. If you need this size bulb, go to Home Depot or Lowes and buy the cheapest LED's you can find - they can't be any worse than this. Then, when those fail, you won't be out so much.

Three stars only because it works as a CO2 generator (just like anything you can make - easily - for free). However, what I wanted was the ability to hang it from the back of my tank, out of the way, as the product  information claims. I had to return this after three weeks. The hanging adapter is poorly designed and begins to break from the weight of the cylinder. Then, you have to put it on the floor like my old soda bottle standby. There are instructions for making your own DIY CO2 generator all over the internet.Nutrafin provides yeast and baking powder in this kit, although they are labeled as some kind of special-fantastic-mysterious powders. All that you are doing here is putting a little yeast into sugar water. The yeast eats the sugar and the byproducts are CO2 (which you want) and alcohol (dont try drinking it!). Any sugar will work. Start by dissolving 1  cups of sugar into 1  cups of lukewarm tap water and make sure the apparatus are always cleaned first with a hot water rinse (no soaps). Then add about  teaspoon of yeast, which should be activated by stirring it with a fork in about a  cup of lukewarm water until its creamy and has lots of bubbles in it and let it to stand at least 10 minutes before adding it to the sugar water. Although some users recommend adding baking soda (not baking powder), it isnt really necessary to buffer the mixture. The yeast is killed by the alcohol buildup, not acidic water.Speaking to that, the length of time that this will produce CO2 is a function of how long the yeast survives until the alcohol builds up to a certain level and how much yeast is in the mixture. You want to try to find that optimal balance. So, its better to start with the most alcohol resistant yeast you can get, which is wine/champagne yeast. You can buy packets here on Amazon (Premier Cuvee Wine Yeast) for about $8. This will stand up to about 18% alcohol levels, which means it produces longer than a typical bakers yeast that might be as low as 5% alcohol tolerance. Start with  teaspoon of yeast and see how long it lasts for you. Try adjusting the yeast level both up and down until youre happy with the length of time that it lasts and the amount of CO2 it produces (bubbles per minute).Were not done yet. You need to get the CO2 to dissolve into the tank water and not get to the surface where it would evaporate. Included in this kit is a large and ugly bubble ladder (ladders arent very efficient). What I do, which is a much more efficient way to get the most CO2 into your water, is to run the end of the CO2 tube into my canister filters intake pipe. I have a sponge filter attached to it and I insert the tube through the sponge to hold it in place. A power head would also work. The idea is to get the impeller to chop the bubble into minute pieces, making it much easier to dissolve.How do you know if its still making CO2? Buy a bubble counter here on Amazon (Fluval 88g-CO2 Bubble Counter - 3.1 Ounces) for about $3. With that, you count the number of bubbles per minute. Count the bubbles after about 24 hours of setting it up and monitor it every week (or more often) to see when it starts dropping off. Then you know the yeast is almost dead or gone and can decide when to make a new batch. In addition to being a bubble counter, it also acts as a gas separator, helping to prevent anything other than the CO2 from getting into your tank.How do you know if youre getting enough CO2 into the water? Well, if there is a noticeable change in plant growth over about two weeks, you have your answer. However, you can also but a CO2 drop checker (again, on Amazon: ISTA CO2 Indicator Drop Checker) for about $13. This will tell you whether or not CO2 is at a good level or is too high or low.

Ranked this 3 stars because it is not a piece of artwork. Other reviewers are giving it glowing reviews, but this thing is not pretty. However, it is 5 stars as a utility cabinet (I'm putting it in my basement). Putting it where it can be seen by your visitors is not a good idea. You will easily see the many holes along the sides where the shelf supports can be placed, the back is cardboard with folds in it and edges do not fit particularly well. It looks much better in the picture on Amazon.Assembly is fairly easy if you can follow instructions (which are clear) and have put other such items together before. It takes about a half-hour to assemble.It's a decent value if you are only expecting a good storage cabinet ...and I was.

Look at the recent trend in reviews. There is a major quality problem at Fluval. Many recent reviews are revealing the defective manufacturing of these devices. Mine were defective, as well.I tried and returned one and then the replacement had the same problem: there is no gas, under any safe pressure, that can get through these devices. Forget CO2, I went beyond that and tried pushing air through from my air pump and then tried blowing though it. Nothing gets through. Left it in overnight with the air pump running and not a single bubble the next day.

Bought the 2700K and they match perfectly to the incandescent light. I had tried the "Daylight" 5000K bulbs, but those don't look like daylight at all, so I tried these.Some observations on various LED outputs:- These bulbs seem to be very sensitive electronic equipment, which may explain the high failure rates of other reviewers. One of my bulbs, in this pack, buzzes noticeably. When I shake it, it seems to have something loose in it as compared to the one's that don't buzz, but still works. So, the message is to check each bulb carefully to see that the quality is good. Mine are being used outdoors, so I don't care about the buzz, but I'm going to expect that the one that buzzes will be first to fail. If I had four of these 'buzzers' in my bathroom (which I will be doing), it would sound like a bee hive.- 100W LED's are bigger, in size, than standard incandescent bulbs, unlike these 60W equivalents. If your incandescent bulbs are flush in your fixture,100W LED bulbs will protrude out of the fixture.

I've had the pH monitor in for over a month. It worked well for the first two weeks. After that, it turned a mustard-like color, which isn't represented on the color circle at all. Checking my pH with standard tests, I have a pH of 7.3, which is far above the yellows indicated by this test. Beware this product: it will lead you into a disastrous situation ...at least for your fish.The center 'dot' is the sensor. It is an algae magnet (I don't have an algae problem). The algae grows on the sensor and is impossible to remove without destroying the sensor. I suspect that the algae interferes with the functionality of the sensor, rendering it useless.I am very surprised that Seachem would put out such a poor product. It makes me wonder if their management hasn't changed for the worse. Could their other products be far behind?

It is bright and the pinpoint of LED light in the bulb will actually make it difficult to look at, unlike an incandescent bulb having the same light output (lumens), but that is what LED's do. I was trying this in an exterior lamp and that pinpoint of light is very obvious. Use these where you have a shade or other diffuser to try to block that intense pinpoint of light. However, this is not the reason for my low rating (this brightness is the positive aspect of my review).My main complaint is that this is being marketed as "Daylight" equivalent. It may be by ONE standard of measurement (color temperature), but there is obviously MUCH more to daylight than that very limited criteria set forth in a color temperature measurement. I suspect that the absence of the full color spectrum of the sun is the reason. Objects under this 5,000K light look nothing like they do under daylight. This light will bathe your object to an appearance of being very washed out and sterile. It fits with what the descriptions were by the men that walked the Moon's surface.Since it seems impossible to get true daylight with either LED's or CFL's, I am going to go back to what I hope will be the equivalent of an incandescent bulb and order LED's having the 2700K "warm" look. Hopefully, LED technology can, at least, be the equivalent of that.BTW: although everyone likes the idea of these lasting comparatively longer than any other type of bulb (which is why I'm trying them - cost savings really aren't that great a difference when you factor in the price of these things), the fact is that no one has had them long enough to really know. We are all just hoping that the lab tests saying they last longer translate into actually lasting longer under real-life conditions. Judging by the high number of reported failures by other reviewers, I'm not optimistic.UPDATE: bought the 2700K and they match perfectly to the incandescent light. some observations on various LED outputs:- These bulbs seem to be very sensitive electronic equipment. One of my bulbs, in this pack, buzzes noticeably. When I shake it, it seems to have something loose in it as compared to the one's that don't buzz. So, the message is to check each one carefully to see that the quality is good. Mine are being used outdoors, so I don't care about the buzz. If I had four of these in my bathroom (which I will be doing), it would sound like a bee hive.- 100W LED's are bigger, in size, than standard incandescent bulbs, unlike these 60W equivalents. If your incandescent bulbs are flush in your fixture,100W LED bulbs will protrude out of the fixture.
Just as good as any of the other 10,000 like it, EXCEPT this has an annoying giant "Aibocn" name staring at you. A giant no-name label guaranteed to keep them no-name.

I missed the detail of the motor being in the water. They promote that as a benefit, but I prefer to look at my fish and plants, not a large black device stuck in the middle of the tank. Don't know if it works, or not. Once I saw how big this thing is, I packed it up for return.

They will hold your heater. I bought these because they are clear. However, they are only clear if you use them outside of your tank. Of course, that means that your heater won't be heating any water. After a month or two in water, these turn from clear to bright white and stick out like a light in your aquarium.
It does cool the tank down by about 3 degrees F. However, it is fairly loud. In a large family room, it can be heard everywhere. So loud that I removed it.

After about an hour, every level blurs into one. They've gotten to the point where they just tell a computer to slap down a rectangle and fill it with with junk graphics. Then everybody runs around the rectangle and holds the trigger down.You get less and less with every new game. They were done after Black Ops. Hopefully, they'll do what they did for Halo in bringing back the original winner and bring back the real game: Black Ops.
Requires direct sunlight to operate, which is rare. Then, when it spins at full speed, the only air movement might be from the vibration. The fan, itself, moves no air.

This review is from the perspective of replacing incandescent ceramic (glass) C7's on a Christmas tree.Contrary to what other reviewers have said, these lights are not like the lights when 'we were growing up' other than being the same size and shape.These LED lights are of the lowest quality LED lights you can buy ...and it shows. On a Christmas tree, standard ceramic bulbs glow brightly and this highlights the ornaments and tree branches. These stringer sets glow at about half the brightness of ceramic bulbs so, they are very dim by comparison to the standard ceramic bulbs. With these lights, ornaments are not highlighted and the overall look is that of a very dark tree.Additionally, the bulbs on these stringer sets are 8" apart vs. the typical 12" of ceramic bulbs. That makes a big difference on a tree. To cover the same area on the tree as your ceramic set, you need to buy 50% more of the LED sets. Of course, this means that you get 50% more bulbs and now you start crowding out your ornaments. With this many more bulbs, you'd think that the light would be better, but it's not. The bulbs are just too dim, even when the number of bulbs is increased by 50%.From my reading, it seems that the separate "replacement" LED bulbs are far superior to the bulbs in these sets. These "replacement" bulbs have the standard screw-in small base just like the ceramic C7's and have three emitters per bulb. I assume this means three times the brightness. I haven't tried them yet as they are still very expensive as compared to ceramic bulbs. I'll check, next year, to see if they've come down in price.

This applies to CE only AND online play only. The other Halo versions are for kiddies that like to run around with machine guns blazing away.Six months later and Microsoft still haven't fixed it. They took a step backwards, about a month ago, and reduced online play to a max of 2 vs 2, rather than the original option to go up to 4 vs 4. This severely limits balancing of teams (and they haven't bothered to rank players either). Additionally, you only have access to about half of the original levels in CE (no Blood Gulch, Chiron and a few others).They seem to be listening to heavy gamers on certain websites and are trying to appease them. Unfortunately, that is about .000001% of their market and, pretty soon, they will only have about 50 players left on CE. Then they'll end support of it and wonder why no one wanted to play it.

Haven't tried it in snow yet, but expect it to be better than a very similar design that I have right now that is smaller. This is a first impression upon inspection.I avoided Garant's plastic models, as plastic tends to deflect off of packed snow, such as you get when your car packs the snow where the tires run over it. For plastic to work well, the snow must have fallen upon a smooth driveway. Any previous ice or packed snow adhering unevenly below the new-fallen snow will cause a plastic shovel to bounce over or to the side. Metal shovels can scrape up such problems.So, I looked at the steel Garant shovels, but saw some reviewers commenting about how heavy they were. Then I found this aluminum version and, having a similar aluminum shovel before, that held up well, I ordered this. This is well constructed and is still somewhat heavy, but easily workable. I can see that a steel shovel would have had me fighting the shovel itself as well as the snow. This was the right choice.4 Stars because 1) I haven't actually proven that it works yet and 2) a warning to others that they may want to consider buying from a seller other than "Ron's Home and Hardware." The shovel arrived wrapped in [what seemed to be] an entire roll of Saran wrap! It took me 15 miuntes to get through it and it doesn't provide protection during shipping. There were many areas where it had been punched right through resulting in scrapes and dings on the shovel. Since the shovel will get that anyway during use, I decided to keep it.UPDATE: First snowfall of 1-2 inches and this shovel performed as expected: lightweight, scraped under the tire-tread-packed snow well, no sticking of snow to the shovel and a good curve to the scoop that makes it easy to get maximum scooping without bending over.

Good Housekeeping was right when they picked this as their best artifical tree. You'd have to study it to determine that it was fake. From a foot away, you can't tell. Excellent color of the needles and the stems (which match nature in the brownish color) and excellent pliability and natural fullness (actually looks more natural than my real trees of recent years - if that's possible).I bought the unlit tree because I put my own lights on, but the lit tree is the same natural look. Other reviewers will have to comment about the lights' performance. There may not be an in-line timer for the lights, like the other reviewer said, but you can buy timers for $10 that will do the job. If you're going to spend $750 on the tree, you can probably afford the extra 10 bucks.I didn't notice that Amazon sold the Balsam Hill brand because they haven't collected enough reviews to pop up in a search, like other brands. I'm posting this review to try to increase the chance that others will see this opportunity. I bought mine direct, but they are the same price, so you might as well buy it from Amazon if you collect points.

We could only get through the first two episodes and, having gagged on those, threw the disks in the trash. Clearly, The Discovery Channel lost it's way on this effort. The narrator is so bad that you will be distracted (sometimes with laughter) from being able to concentrate on the show. As you know, from season 1, the episodes in this series are really about 20 minutes long, but they repeat so much that they stretch it to 45 minutes to get more commercials in. With those 20 minutes being so good, it was worth the repetition in season 1. However, when you are so distracted by the narration, you start to tune out on the content. That leaves you with about 10 minutes of memorable content and you end up sitting there, at the end of the show, saying "What was that episode about?"The problem is that this narrator is the thsweetesth guy you can imagine. The producers must have given orders to the writers to try to include as many words with an "s" in them as possible for this narrator's sing-song lisp.They should rename this to "Elmer Fudd Does The Universe." An example is when the narrator thsaths: "The thsun thsines through the thsurfaths." You may laugh, but the whole show is like that.Skip this season (the episodes aren't heavy in content anyway) and go to season 3 (I understand that they went back to the narrator used in season 1).

This is not the same quality as the original cover.1) This is beige, not taupe. It is noticeably lighter in color than the original taupe.2) There is no re-enforcing metal grommet in the hole where the spindle, at the top, screws in. It is just a punched hole in the fabric.

This is primarily a show of special effects and lots of "WOW", but it doesn't say much. There is a great deal of hypothetical questioning designed to make you think there are facts behind the questions. "What if you could travel through time and know all that can be known?" That is the type of questioning that comprises about 40% of every show. Well, yes, wouldn't that be great? They then go on to cite support of these inferences with 'physicists' like: "Anna, who has has spent most of her career (she's 28 - so that's three months) trying to prove this and believes it's possible." Yeah, well; most legitimate universities don't.It's alll sensationalist hype, but I give it 2 stars because it might (maybe) encourage someone to go off an learn about a subject in a more pragmatic way.

The canopy part of this umbrella seems well made and does the job intended. The tilt (contrary to some other reviewers comments on this style) is good - it allows for significant blocking of low-angle sun. If it were to tilt any more than it does, it might fall over.The reason for three stars, rather than more, is due to the construction of the lower half of the shaft (the section that inserts into a base). A base will have a screw-in retaining system that works by applying pressure onto the shaft section inserted into the base. Unfortunately, the shaft section is - as indicated in the description - aluminum (more like aluminum foil). The retaining screw of a base will crush the shaft of this umbrella without ever applying enough pressure to hold it firmly. Consequently, you can not lift the umbrella up (to move it around) without it pulling out of a base. You will have to grab the base itself to move the unit. This is a very awkward maneuver and puts your back at risk. Further, when the umbrella is angled, a breeze will cause the umbrella to spin out of position, since you cannot tighten the shaft firmly.If the umbrella had a steel lower section, all of these problems would be prevented.

Nothing in the picture or bullet points indicates that this is for thin metal bolts only. That info is buried in the product description. My fault, but I wanted to catch the attention of those toilet owners having the plastic bolts. Plastic bolts are too wide to fit the small holes in these rubber washers.

The songs are excellent, the mastering in this "Ultimate" compilation ruins them.This album has the most (worst) dynamic range compression possible. Every soft part of a song is as loud as the loudest part of the song. Not at all the way the songs were originally mastered. You can even hear distortion resulting from this in some songs. Look up "Loudness Wars" on Wikipedia. This mastering effort is firing all of the weapons.If you want compilation albums that are not fighting the "Loudness Wars", try "30 Years Of Maximum R&B box set", "Meaty Beaty Big & Bouncy", "Who's Better Who's Best", or "Greatest Hits" (although it's pushed a little). Don't pick "Odds & Sods", it has the same compression problems in the CD remastering. You can also get good dynamic range mastering of the original album formats in the individual album CDs, except the MCA version of "A Quick One". This good individual album mastering exists at least up to "Who's Next". I don't know about albums released after "Who's Next".

This device is the replacement for a different model. AcuRite is careful to obsolete models quickly so that consumers can't target a given model for reviews. This, like it's predecessor, will work well for the full year that you have it. Unfortunately, the sensor part of it (the one outdoors) is not robust. You can depend upon it to fail when the warranty expires.So, if you are ok spending the $30 every year for this, it is a good product. If you prefer your thermometers to last longer than a year, look elsewhere. You can find other, more high;y rated manufacturers, on Amazon by simply searching "remote thermometers".

That's why I bought it and it completely cleaned the very dirty tires after about 15 passes on the first sheet of these 30-sheet pads. The only drawback is that these are as blue as the picture indicates. Blue is not good in a home. If the manufacturer made a beige offering, i could leave this out on a section of my floor all the time.As anyone with power wheelchairs or, to a lesser extent, manual wheelchairs knows, the tires from these devices makes hard floor surfaces (like linoleum in a kitchen) a mess - even when they are only used indoors. The tires pick up every possible bit of grime and transfer it right to the floor. You need to wash your floors very frequently and then the grime re-develops after about a week. Now, with these, I can keep the pad in a closet, put it down whenever I want (I'll do it daily), and clean the tires in about three minutes to prevent the build-up. This should dramatically extend the time between floor cleanings.They may seem expensive, but you get a total of 120 sheets (they are on thin pads of 30 sheets to a pad). After your first cleaning, one sheet will probably last at least a week before it gets too dirty to re-use. So, this purchase will last you about two years. I looked all over the Internet for a cleaning solution for wheelchair tires but found nothing practical other than either spending hundreds of dollars on special machines or getting down on the floor and clean it yourself with a bucket and brush, but that only lasts a little while before they get dirty again.

Background: I have a little over a third of an acre of clay soil, with grass in it, to mow. I use a self-propelled walk behind mower for the exercise. I have neglected the lawn, other than fertilizing, for over ten years. This clay is fairly compacted.These spikes penetrate, easily, all the way into the soil. That is no issue. However, forget trying to hold these on your feet using the straps that come with it. First, I admit that the manufacturer does not recommend doing this while cutting the grass. They would prefer that you walk around your yard with these on, like a bird (lifitng your feet straight up and down like pistons). The straps might hold in that situation, but how many of us are going to do that?No, we're going to use these while we mow and, if you do that, you are going to walk in a way that moves you forward by lifting your back heel first as you take a step and that makes the straps useless. Here is what I did: buy some industrial strength Velcro on Amazon (make sure it's industrial strength). Put it on a cheap/old pair of shoes (smooth sole surfaces are best) and attach your shoe, that way, to these spikes. I did it and walked around for an hour and these held tight the entire time.The next problem, though, is how to keep your shoe from sliding off your heel. If any readers have an idea, please let me know. While the spike goes into the ground easily. You do have to pull a little to get them up. In a normal walking stride, your heel pulls out of your shoe and the blisters I got, from the back and forth, were not fun. Until i can figure out how to solve this heel issue, i won't use them again. Probably tolerable on a much smaller lawn.Also, this is going to give you a good workout. Plan on double the amount of time to mow your lawn with these on and you will have to walk in a weird way that will exercise muscles you may not be used to using.Be careful with areas of just dirt (no grass), especially if it is damp. The spikes will grab and hold large chunks of the dirt, blocking full penetration. I carried around (in my back pocket) a small three-pronged garden cultivator (you can get them cheap on Amazon) to remove it quickly. I am an OSHA nightmare when doing all of this.BTW: if you're looking at these spikes, you must care about your yard. Don't put any fertilizer on until you know what condition your soil is in. If you don't have the right soil condition, the grass won't absorb much of the fertilizer and may need different nutrients and concentrations than what you just dumped on it. Spend $10 to get your soil analyzed at a reputable university. I use Penn State (Google it). They will tell you what condition your soil is in an give you exact recommendations as to what to do, fertilizer-wise, to get it to the right condition.

I was hesitant, but the quality of the mirror is great. It fit perfectly and had good instruction. Very easy.There aren't many reviews on this suppliers' various mirrors (which made me hesitant to try them). Unfortunately, you always have to be skeptical about products that don't have a lot of reviews (like this product). However, if you look at my review history, you will see that I'm all over the place. This should give you an indication that I am not a shill for/by this company.

We've used this for over three years now. It is highly reliable and allows you to travel anywhere in Verizon's network (which is almost everywhere in the US). It is better to think of this as a cell phone device that has specialized people ready to help you as soon as you push the big button in the center. You talk with them almost instantly. You can test it by pushing that button (they encourage you to do it now and then) and that gives you a feeling of confidence. Their people are incredibly friendly and effective.If you lose your connection, the red light tells you so and you just turn it off and back on, like your cell phone, as long as you're in Verizon's massive US service area. If your home has a weak Verizon signal (like mine does) get a cell extender (Amazon and Verizon have them). They cost about $200 and will give you reception throughout your house (for you cell phones, too).With the locator function, you can authorize anyone you want to be able to go on their website and locate EXACTLY where you are, at any time, either using a map or satellite image. Basic GPS functionality and it works easily.Other reviewers have posted some negative reviews, which I will address:- Ours holds a charge. Never had a problem. Remember; it's like a cell phone you leave on all day. The battery will last as long as your cell phone battery does. They encourage you to charge it by your bed every night, although it can go days on a single charge. It remains functional while it is charging. More than three years now and it still holds the charge.- If you think a $35 one-time fee is too much, you probably don't own a cell phone. I doubt that there are any free services like this. We'll have to wait for Obamacare to give us everything free (I wonder how they are going to pay for that).- I must have forgotten that it's not waterproof. In three years, though, I've never had a problem. I leave it outside the shower. Remember: it's like a cell phone and you can't go swimming with your cell phone, either. However, it would be a good idea for 5Star to provide the option to pay more and buy a waterproof device if you want it. I can see how this could be a significant shortcoming and is the only reason I give it 4 stars. If you need it, and it gets wet, you may end up dead.Security Concern: In order to access your billing information and, therefore, have access to your account, Great Call requires you to verbally establish a pin number with them. You cannot do this online utilizing the layered security which you previously set up on their website. This is extremely insecure, as anyone with a voice could claim to be you.

First: Be careful about people rating the following review as helpful. Micca's US seller is known for seeding reviews to their benefit. As soon as I opened the box, I realized I had a problem. Note the picture of the product. It looks pretty easy to pack and travel. What it doesn't show is the normal - and large - power adapter required to run this!!! The power adapter profile is FOUR times larger than the device itself. It is going to take up quite a bit of space in your bag.As for performance, it has good functionality, but is not a high quality player. You don't get good contrast (no options) and the video crispness is lacking. I compared performance to a real video player: Western Digital's WD TV Live Hub, and there is a noticeable difference in quality.However, for a cheap knock-around [somewhat] portable player, it will do until these smaller, cheaper, devices reach higher quality.

Other reviewers are correct: this is relatively quiet and - so far - reliable.I will focus on the maintenance aspect, which is very important. This generator was not designed with maintenance convenience in mind and you will struggle with it. Based upon the poor design for maintenance purposes, I will probably try a Honda if this needs to be replaced.- The front and back covers are difficult to reinstall after removing them and the screws used for installation may be easily lost if you allow the cover to pop off once released. A latching mechanism would have been better. Both covers must be removed for full servicing.- Oil change: get a funnel with a flexible nozzle, the oil has to go in almost horizontally. When draining the oil, a hole is provided in the bottom. Unfortunately, at first, the oil gushes beyond the hole and into the housing.- Spark plug: a standard ratchet set won't be able to get into this tight fit. Yamaha provides a special toll (because the location is so poorly placed) to remove it. It is not a reliable way to ensure correct tightness.- Battery: if you think all of the above is hard, wait until you try to access the battery.All in all, the nightmare of servicing this will cause many users to just ignore it, but it really must be done to ensure proper operation when needed.UPDATE: couldn't take the extremely poor design of the wheels anymore (it's almost impossible to move this thing around). Bought, on Amazon, the Sparco Folding Platform Truck, 660 lbs., 24-3/4 x 36 x 29-1/2 Inches. The generator fits, perfectly, on this platform. The generator now can be moved around with ease.

I can't say for sure if this movie got better after the first hour and 15 minutes. I had to turn it off and try to find something more interesting to do ...like watch my dishwasher finish it's cycle. This thing drones on, making no sense (and without any point) endlessly. Minutes seem like hours.As other reviewers note, this may be the best movie of the lawless Australian wild west, but that is probably because it is the only movie of the lawless Australian wild west.They have a Russel Crowe act-alike as, I think, the main character. Hard to tell, though, if there is such a thing as a main character in this movie. They are all so bland they all seem like puppets. Frankly, after the first 15 minutes, you don't care who gets killed, maimed or whipped. It might have been better if they killed everyone off in those first 15 minutes and let you stare at the Australian sun for the next 2 hours.

Was great for a year. In two years, it rips and develops holes. The handles will start to rip at their points of contact, leaving a hole in the top of it.I take this of and put it on once a week. The rest of the time it simply covers the grill. Half the day it is exposed to the sun.My guess is that it is not UV resistant and that the UV from the sun destroys it over two years. You should consider this a throw-away item, if you wish to buy it, as it will not last very long. Annual replacement is recommended.

This is simply a way to expand the number of emitters by doubling emitters per plug. So, while the DL85K comes with four plug-in single emitters (therefore four emitters), you could effectively go to eight emitters by buying four of these dual designs.As with the single emitters, these work perfectly.

It does half of it's job very well. It receives the RF signal from my remote, a Harmony 650 (you have to place the transmitter-battery on the right side of the battery compartment), from anywhere in the house. It just can't reliably re-transmit the IR signal, to the components, from the saucer base. It works sometimes, but is more a random success. You consider yourself lucky if all of the components that you need to run turn on simultaneously. The special RF transmitter-batteries last about a month before they have to be re-charged.The individual emitters (which can be purchased separately) don't transmit through the backside where the adhesive attaches them to your component (unlike the Xantechs). So, you have to find a way to direct the beam, frrm the top surface of the emitter, into the component from a short distance away. How do you do that without hanging them mid-air? It's tough. You have to devise supports in some cases. In other cases, I attached two emitters, back to back, and hung them in front of two components and that increased effectiveness. It will take you quite a long time to find the correct positioning of these and they will be jostled out of place over time, requiring re-positioning work again.I returned the Next Gen RF transmitter and upgraded to the Xantech DL85K. Although it is more expensive, it delivers a solid IR signal to all of my components. It provides a solid burst that never fails to act upon the components of interest. My Harmony 650 now works perfectly - every time. It is so superior to the Next Gen device that you start to forget about unreliable performance and take for granted your remote system because it never fails.Spend the extra money and get the Xantech DL85K system. It works perfectly.

You can read my full review of the Next Gen extender on that product site. This is just about these emitters.They stink! They don't transmit through the backside where the adhesive attaches them to your component (unlike the Xantechs). So, you have to find a way to direct the beam, form the top surface of the emitter, into the component from a short distance away. How do you do that without hanging them mid-air? It's tough. You have to devise supports in some cases. In other cases, I attached two emitters, back to back, and hung them in front of two components and that increased effectiveness.These don't seem to transmit a solid signal reliably. I had to constantly send separate signals to various devices with my Harmony 650 remote. It will take you quite a long time to find the correct positioning of these and they will be jostled out of place over time, requiring re-positioning work again.Spend the extra money and get the Xantech DL85K system. It works perfectly.

I tried my Harmony 650 remote, by itself, and found it not able to deliver a solid IR signal to all of my components, leaving some on and others off. So, I went looking for IR extenders. After considering reviews, I chose the Next Generation RF transmitter. It worked ok on one or two components and then I bought the 6-emitter pack to reach all of my components. The emitters were finicky and imprecise. So, I went back on the hunt. This time, I was prepared to move up in price to get better quality.Looking at reviews, here, and throughout the Internet, I decided upon the Xantech DL85K. I was not disappointed. It provides a solid burst that never fails to act upon the components of interest. My Harmony 650 now works perfectly - every time.The small receiver attaches anywhere and the IR emitters (that are best placed directly over the IR receivers on your component) attach strongly, unlike the Next Gen emitters, which fall off. The Xantech emitters transmit out of both sides so, when attached over the IR receiver on the component, they transmit out the back. The transmission through the top (front) of the emitter is strong enough that it could also be placed in the vicinity of a component and still work. When a signal is sent by the remote, the Xantech receiver and all of the emitters blink, so you know the signal is being received and generated.

I'm pretty good with electronics. I'm now on my second day trying to get this thing to operate my three devices correctly. The syncing is terrible. Push your button to perform your -activity-; and you're lucky if all the devices come on. Then you have to work your way through the help feature to get everything functioning the way it should. Use the -All Off- button and good luck getting everything to turn off, which means back to the help process. Might as well just use the three remotes.You can set the remote up either with Logitech's website (which doesn't work with all browser versions - crashes with Firefox - IE may be the only one it works reliably with) or their software. Wouldn't you think they'd have both of the formats the same? Nope, not Logitech. The website is a completely different format from the software. This results in different setup of the remote and I can't figure out which one is better because some of the features are different between the two. Nine months later and Logitech has restructured their web so that setup is difficult to find and they seem to delete users after inactivity for a few months so you will have to go through it all over again. A VERY difficult company to deal with.Logitech does miss some of the functionality of your remotes. One of my devices is the WD TV Live HUB. They missed a lot of the functionality of the WD remote and the -Learn- function and drop-down button selection options, both of which are designed to add your remote button capability to the Harmony, don't work either.That's all the time I have for the review. Have to get back to trying to figure this thing out. If you decide buy it, make sure you buy it when you can take some vacation time to get it to work ...maybe.Update - one month later: Get the the Xantech DL85K extender (another >$100) and it will boost the Harmony's weak signal successfully.

I'm a sucker for this type of Moroccan cut out lantern.  I love how the light creates patterns on the wall.  I put a small oil lamp instead of a candle inside and am pleased with the results. It's a bit bigger than I expected, so it's kind of tricky to find an appropriate spot to put it, but it is very pretty (even when unlit).  I found the stand easy to assemble and adequately stable. If you don't like the stand, the lantern can be hung from a hook - I would suggest putting it on a pulley to make it easier to light.  Very happy with my purchase.

These are lovely lights.  I really like the "slow fade" function.  My only complaint is that the selected function appears to reset when you power off.  I had these on a timer to come on at sunset and every time they came on, they defaulted to the seizure-inducing flashing program.  I found that annoying. Otherwise I think they're very nice.

This case is a great way to protect your phone, but I found it too bulky. It's not particularly comfortable to hold and I found having to "unplug" the charging port each time to plug in the cable annoying.  I downgraded to a simple slim case with a screen protector and am much happier.
Don't bother.

Very Nice! I've used sterling silver up to this point and wasn't sure how my piercings would take to stainless, but they're just fine.  I like the style  - it's a thin gauge and looks great.  This style of clasp seems to be more comfortable if you sleep with the earrings in - other styles tend to poke.  Overall very happy with the look and value.

I've owned several of these types of screen protectors for various devices and I would say that the Skinomi product wins out on one key point - price.  I've used the Zagg protectors, an they're great, but expensive.  When I applied the Skinomi product I screwed it up and had to peel it back to remove cat hair.  I was concerned that because of my mistake I was going to have to contend with a bunch of air bubbles, but 3 days later, the screen is clean and clear. It adds a very slight "texture," but I would say if anything, it improves the touch screen.Make sure you follow the directions if you've never applied these types of protectors before, as they can be frustrating until you get the hang of it. The trick is using enough (but not too much) of the application solution, which is actually soapy water.
I wanted to like this, but it cracked even before I had a chance to affix it to my phone. I was peeling off the protective film and it cracked all the way through.

I found this piercer difficult to use.  It's not spring loaded and I had trouble removing the stud once the piercing happened. You basically have to squeeze it until it pierces your ear.  I found it more painful and unwieldy than a piercing gun.

This is a nice metal piercing gun for piercing your lobes. It's kind of a two-action gun in that you pull back the mechanism and push a lever down on the side of the gun to activate it.  The trigger squeezes your lobe to make aiming the piercing easier.  I suppose this is good because it helps prevent accidental piercing. I've also found that placing the earring back in the gun doesn't work very well.  I just put the back on once I've put the earring through my lobe.Please toss out the piercing studs that come with this - purchase individually wrapped, sterile studs to do your piercing.  You are tempting infection and irritation if you use the studs that came with this gun.  Trust me. I tried 4 times and had infections every time. Once I switched to sterile studs, I had no problems. Also, make sure you LEAVE THE STUD ALONE for at least a couple of weeks.  Messing with it (yes even turning it, like we were taught) is a bad idea and only invites infection.Pros:Metal is easy to sanitizeTwo-step trigger helps reduce the risk of accidentally piercing your finger (or eye)Easy to useCons:Unsterile studs - toss them and buy individually wrapped sterile piercing studs.I think the studs also contain nickelThe coating on the studs (electroplate?) wore offDid I mention the studs that come with this gun suck?I've had good luck with these:Surgical Steel 4mm Ear piercing Earrings studs 12 pair Mixed Colors White MetalIn summary, this is a great inexpensive way to pierce your EARLOBES. Do not use this type of piercer on cartilage, nose, bellybutton, tongue, sexy bits, nipples, uvula, or younger siblings. Please have those piercings done by a reputable professional

I was having a plague of frustrating issues with my internet connection through Comcast Xfinity.  I couldn't get through a complete streaming video from Netflix or Amazon without buffering issues, loss of video quality, or just loss of signal.  I continually was dropping the connection and had to fall back to my neighbor's open wifi connection. I was easily unplugging my modem 2-3 times a week to reset the damn thing. I was even having problems maintaining an uninturrupted signal for on - demand video. Yes,  I was a fool and rented the equipment from Comcast.I was hesitant to spring $200 for a new modem, but halleluja, I am so glad I did. My streaming video is crystal clear and has nary a hiccup in sight.  The signal strength is strong and clean. Range seems to be solid - I live on one level and the farthest I get away from the router is 40-50 feet. No problems so far.Setup was a snap. The password for access is located on a sticker on the bottom of the unit.  As other reviewers have mentioned, the access info to change the settings on the router are:ID: adminPassword: motorolaI did have to call Comcast customer service to have them activate the modem, but that took all of 10 minutes.I've got my Roku and Xbox connected to the 5Ghz signal and my phone connected to the 2.4 Ghz signal. (turn on the 5Ghz signal in the modem/router settings)  I did a bit of research and if the interwebz is to be believed, the major difference between the two is signal speed and range. Apparently because 5Ghz has a larger bandwidth, it's supposed to be faster, but doesn't have as much range as 2.4 Ghz.. Conversely, the 2.4 Ghz has a longer range, but isn't as fast as 5 Ghz. As of now,  I haven't noticed a difference. If I do,  I'll post an update.I would highly recommend this unit for anyone who is experiencing issues with crappy equipment.

Update 01/19/2015After 3 months of use, I still love this pillow. I might even go out on a limb and say it's my favorite pillow ever. It hasn't flattened out at all that I've noticed.  It's comfortable for both back and side sleeping.I love this pillow.  I sleep both on my back and on my side,  and because I have a gigantic melon, I tend to flatten out pillows in no time flat (no pun intended). This pillow is wonderful - very firm and retains it's shape.  Yes it can be hard as a rock at first on cold nights . . . it's thermoelastic foam  . . .meaning it changes with temperature. As your body heat warms it, the pillow gently cradles your head and neck, but retains enough firmness for support.  I was concerned that I might get too hot, but I haven't had any problems so far, even with 80 degree humid summer nights. I highly recommend this pillow.

The cover I received tore when I stretched it to put it on my kindle. RuhRoh! Sent it right back to Amazon. 5 big stars for Amazon's return policy and procedure. 2 puny stars for a disappointing product. Maybe it was a one-off quality control issue because I've had several great products from Marware, but I didn't feel bothered to replace it.

These lightsticks are a great deal.  They're as bright as the brand name(s) but not nearly as expensive.  I have purchased several different colors and while they're all great, I think the green is brightest and last longer (I think this is also true of the brand name lightsticks).  Highly recommended.

I have very sensitive skin and I get seasonal eczema (dermatitis) and can't use regular soap products. I tried Shikai a few years ago when a particularly dry winter made my skin (and and by extension, me) miserable. I had tried a variety of different products and they all seemed to dry out my skin even more.  Enter Shikai. Using it as a bubble bath for a long soak makes my skin rejoice. I've also found that it's great for softening up callouses (heels, etc).  I use it as shampoo, shower gel, bubble bath, (I even discovered it works exceptionally well as a shave gel when I had some along on a business trip and had forgotten to bring shave cream). I highly recommend it even if you don't have sensitive skin - it gets you clean without pulling the moisture out of your skin.

I was unsure if these bags would be thick enough to withstand tearing because of the price, but I found that as long as you're careful and don't overstuff the bags or abuse them, they work just fine. The problem comes if you have a lot of sharp items in your trash and / or try to compact your trash down too far.  These aren't contractor bags, they're medium duty trash bags.  I think they're a great deal.
They need to change the description of this hat.  It is NOT a fedora. It IS a trilby.

This is an excellent solution to the "floppy tie syndrome" (FTS). I hate having my tie flip around in the wind or get skewed when I take off my jacket.  These work very well, don't damage your tie, and are inexpensive.  I love these so much, any time I see a guy with his tie flapping in the wind, I want to run up to him and hand him one of these. They're inexpensive enough that I could carry a bunch of them with me and do just that!

I'm a huge fan of Mora knives - they're top quality, inexpensive, ridiculously sharp, and comfortable to handle. This knife is no exception. The knife itself is fantastic. It's the sheath I take issue with. It's right handed. The knife fits one way (it snaps in securely) and based on where the  belt loop is placed, placing it on your left side positions the blade out and the grip backwards,  which with a knife this sharp, you don't want ANY opportunity to fumble. Yes, you can attach it on your right side and grasp cross-body, but this again seems like an opportunity for bad things to happen. I would love for Mora to design this sheath such that it would fit a lefty (or offer a left-handed sheath). Otherwise, It's a five-star product.

I'm a beginner solderer and I wanted an inexpensive starter kit to try out my skills.  I had watched some videos on YouTube that suggested I not get an iron rated at less than 40 watts. I should have paid attention.  This one seemed like such a good deal, but it's rated at 25 watts and it never got hot enough to melt the solder properly. I returned this and bought a medium duty Weller iron and am happy with my purchase.

But this is ridiculous. Spend a little more, get 10 times the fatwoood, and drill the stick yourself.http://goo.gl/NOfvZ1I use fatwood as a secondary tinder. Especially if you're using a ferro rod, there are much better tinders to get a flame. Fatwood takes a substantial pile of VERY fine scrapings to get ignited.  If you're trying to light a fire with a match or open flame, Fatwood is outstanding. It catches quickly, burns hot and long, and is unaffected by moisture. If you're looking for a tinder to pair with a ferro rod, there is nothing better than cotton balls soaked in petroleum jelly.I carry a drilled ferro rod on my keychain with a striker and small aluminum capsule filled with PJ cotton. Hasn't failed me yet. ALSO, TSA doesn't give it a second look.

**Edit 03/24/14**OK, OK, Don't let a couple of dumb episodes spoil your enjoyment of MB. They brought back the Mythbusters I know and love in season 15.I guess they were just hurting for material when they put out this episode. I'll amend my judgement by saying this is probably my least favorite episode.  There are still a lot of good ones coming.I've been a huge Mythbusters fan since the beginning and unfortunately, I think it's time to say farewell. The last couple of seasons have declined in quality, and the Zombie Episode was a shining example of why it's time to wrap it up. I understand it was presented as somewhat tongue in cheek, but they're still trying to sell the "science" when the show has tipped completely into the realm of fiction. They're really stretching the content to try to fit it in the original Mythbusters format, and it's wearing way too thin. There's a LOT of rehash, revisits, and just ridiculous content (zombies).  I wish someone would step in and allow this series to retire on a somewhat graceful note rather than stretching it so thin that the show collapses in on itself. It's time to move on.

I've been looking for a strap that makes carrying my camera (Canon Powershot G15) comfortable  and yet easy to access when I need it.  This strap is a great design as it keeps the camera out of the way when you don't need it, but allows you to easily slide the camera up to shooting position when you do need it. I'm a lefty and keep the strap over my right shoulder (bandolier style) and it works wonderfully.  I do wish the strap were a bit longer, but I'm larger than your average bear and can't fault them for finding a happy medium. My only complaint (and it's small) is that the clip that connects to the tripod thread obstructs the battery / memory card door on my camera. That might be more Canon's fault than BlackRapid's.Pros:comfortableeasy access for quick shootingadjustableambidextrousCons:clip connector obstructs battery / memory card door requiring unscrewing to remove either. (minor issue)

When I watched the first episode of this show, I felt like, "wow, this family is a bit on the weird side." I have to say, they have totally grown on me.  It's fascinating to see a relatively honest portrayal of life "off the grid" in Alaska. Each season begins with the spring thaw and portrays the family in their frantic preparations for the following winter. It's really interesting to see how they rely on ingenuity and the land (as well as the family) to solve problems that most modern day families don't think twice about. I have become very addicted to the show and eagerly await each new episode.  My only complaint is I wish they'd show more of the winter life - but I guess they've deemed that not interesting enough for TV.

I have been an audio / video geek for over three decades and have tried all manner of cables.  Lets face it, for the most part, cables are cables. I've always been of the mindset that high end cables (a la Monster) are waaaay overpriced. I've also come across inexpensive cables that turned out to be downright cheap.Enter Twisted Veins. These cables are solidly built and nicely robust for a reasonable price.  I really like the braided sheaths - they give the cables a rugged feel. I've had nice, clean signals with these cables - no shorts, breaks, or bad connections. They offer a variety of lengths, and this pack of 4 cables is a great deal. I'm finding myself wishing they made audio cables as well!Pros:solidly builtgood QCreasonably pricedNice variety of lengthsCons:I wish they made cables for audio applications too!
I wasn't expecting a whole lot when I ordered these and was pleasantly surprised at the quality.  They sound great and are finished (not raw wood). They are a fantastic low cost percussion item.

I guess I get what I pay for.  The sound on this bowl is disappointing. I have another bigger bowl that I bought for about 3 times as much that sounds wonderfully mellow and warm. This one is tinny. On a positive note, it does come with a pretty green box.

I really like this device.  I found myself awash in HDMI connections and needed a solution to run multiple inputs to my projector.  The switch automagically senses the active video source and displays it.  There's both an on-unit selector and a wireless remote if you need to manually change the input. I wish my audio switch worked this well.

Pass on this one. It falls apart too easily and doesn't maintain the connection. I wanted to give it a better review for being so cheap.  The problem is, not only does it not work.  It falls apart and is a total PITA to reassemble.

I picked up a tip from a DIY website (I can't remember which one ) on how to make an excellent HDTV antenna at home with an aluminum pie pan and 4 feet of coax cable. Initially I thought it had to be BS, but I have replicated it several times and each time it doubles the number of channels I get.  The cool thing is that if it doesn't work for you, you haven't spent 40 bucks on a useless device.Here are the steps:Using tin snips or very heavy duty scissors, cut the bottom out of an aluminum pie pan.Cut another, offset circle out of the center of the pie pan bottom.  You should now have a crescent shaped  piece of metal with two points that don't touch. (I've also had success using the "lip" of the pan that I just cut off.  Just make sure you cut a gap in the circle.Cut the connector off of one end of a coax cable about 4 feet in length. strip about 3 inches off the end of the plastic insulator.  There should be a silver woven wiring around the inner sheath.  Unweave this and  twist it together to make a wire.  strip the inner sheath down to the copper wire.  Separate these two ends and attach each to a tip of the "crescent."  Make sure the silver and copper wires don't overlap or touch.Connect the other end of the coax to your digital receiver and either nail the pan to a wall, or drape the antenna and coax over the top of a couple of window  shade or drape rods (that's how I have it)Reset your channels by autotuning (check your manual).Be amazed at the increase in signal strength and quality.If you have questions, post them in this review, or web search DIY digital antenna.  It really works!

I figured for the price, the Chromecast device was worth a shot.  It is significantly less expensive than any of the other popular streaming units out there (Roku, Apple TV, etc.).  I will say that for the content that it is designed, the picture is great - Netflix, Hulu, Google, Play, Youtube. While it doesn't surprise me, I wish amazon video was supported. For any non-chromecast supported content, the image is great, but I have found that the audio lags. I tried TBS's streaming channel, and it looked great on the cast, but as the content went on, the audio lagged farther and farther behind.Setup is a snap - you plug it in to your HDMI slot on your video device, register your unit and connect it to your wireless network.  Chrome has a plugin that allows you to cast any content from your desktop, laptop, mobile device, etc. It's pretty awesome as it is, but it would be super awesome if they somehow snuck in an OTA digital receiver.  My guess is that they didn't want to mess around with antennae.Pros:Great price pointEasy setupVideo and audio quality is superb for applications that are paired with chromecastCompact and unobtrusiveCons:Needs more content available (probably to be increased in the future)Non-chromecast content quality is sketchy.Overall worth the investment if you have a nice TV or projector and you want to watch your Netflix, Hulu or Google Play  streaming content  on your home theater setup.

*Update - 10/21/13*After having played this game for several hours,  I have noticed that the designers have "borrowed" a number of ideas from several other games I have enjoyed (Burnout Paradise, The GTA series, (most noticably, gaining experience points for "super jumps", near misses, driving in oncoming traffic, etc).I'm still enjoying this game very much.I've never played any of the previous Saints Row titles, so I can't speak to how this game compares, but as a noob to the franchise,  I love the concept.  It's very much a GTA styled game with an "open world" map (although, the world is a fraction of the size of the GTA cities).  Based on how the NPC's react to you,  I'd swear it was the same AI engine as the early GTA games.  The thing I love about this game is the "superpower" twist.  I love leaping over the buildings, gliding around and racing around the streets.  For some reason, it's just a whole lot of fun. I can see how some reviewers might get a little tired of the repetitous gameplay, but I always seem to come back to it. It's easy enough that it's not frustrating, but challenging enough to keep you interested.  Also, the humor is well done.  I have actually laughed aloud at a couple of the jokes / scenarios / banter, etc. I paid full price for it and don't really regret it, because I was looking for something entertaining.  I don't know that it warrants a full price purchase.  Wait a few weeks and buy it used.  Otherwise, a very entertaining game.

I love funky lighting effects and was surprised at how inexpensive this bulb was.  I figured if I didn't like it,  I hadn't made a major investment. I'm glad I did.  It's like a multicolored disco ball effect.  It's bright, colorful and mezmerizing. Great product! Great price!

Considering that these crystals are $9 apiece, I would have expected better quality.  The edges of the crystals were chipped, the hole in the top was messily drilled and also chipped. I was a bit surprised that these weren't packed more carefully, but maybe that's the shippers at amazon.  I ordered a much cheaper crystal sphere from a different company and they arrived triple-wrapped in bubble wrap and cardboard. These two were in a ziplock bag, put in a small box and packed with inflatable packaging.

I really really really wanted to fall in love with my Fitbit Flex, but it needs more work.  My main problem was that two separate units would not hold a charge.  I tried charging the units for 3 hours (as recommended) and I tried charging the units for a full 36 hours. When my first one wouldn't hold a charge for more than a day,  I figured it was a one-off issue.  The replacement held a charge for 3 days, then when I tried to recharge it, the indicator said it was fully charged and then suddenly discharged the entire battery.After being able to use it a grand total of 4 days, I'm somewhat skeptical of the actual data recording - it was all over the place.Here's my pro/con rundown:Pros:*Simple and elegant idea*Works with myfitnesspal.com*Easy to sync*Easy to install and set up*LOVE the vibe alarmCons:*BATTERY BATTERY BATTERY*Bracelet needs to be increased in length*does not sync with Droid 4*shape of bracelet tends to catch on sleeves and backpack straps*not convinced that the recorded steps / activity is accurate.

*update 12/26/13I have moved the stix from one case to another and have found that if you do it carefully, it does not leave a residue. I tried the lower cost alternative (neoprene) and found it lacking in the fact that it stretches and gets loose. I have decided it's worth it to pay more for the silicone version and have it keep it's shape.  Also,  I accidentally placed a duplicate order and the company was very good to work with.  Overall I'd say a great product.My bank sent me one of these for a promotion they were running for their mobile app. I find it extremely handy and very cool.  I store my MBTA "charlie card" in it and then tap my cell phone to pay for mass transit. It works very nicely, keeps the card snugly secure, and I always have my bus pass handy.They say it peels off without leaving residue, but I haven't removed it, so I can't speak to that. I can't say that I would have paid $8 for this without ever having used it, but now that I realize how handy it is, I might. By the way, the review automatically assigned the color as white, when in fact the one I have is black.

I know there are a zillion reviews on these headphones and people probably won't get to my review, but I love these headphones so much, I had to write a review.  My first ever "professional" headphones was a pair of what I believe to be an older version of this model.  I used them for a good 20 years until they finally fell apart. Since then I have tried a variety of cans including Bose, behringer, and JVC.  For the price,  The sound on these 'phones is AWESOME. Big bass sound, but tight and clean.  Nice clear mids, crisp highs.  The cups cover your ears and provide as much sound isolation as you'd want (they're not active noise reducing). You also don't get that weird pressure wave that many active sound isolating headphones have. Here's the pro /con breakdown:PROS:*GREAT sound! I'd put these up against headphones three times this price. Big bass sound, clean and tight, not boomy. Clear mids and crisp clean highs.*pretty darn comfortable (I have a big melon) I've been wearing them for 3 hours straight and have no discomfort, no cauliflower ear, no sweaty ears.*good sound isolation - since they cover your ears, they block out most outside sounds to my satisfaction. you can still hear sounds, but you can't make out details.*Reasonably priced - I paid about $90*comes with a 1/8 plug and 1/4 adaptor for those of you who still have old school a/v equipment that still requires 1/4 jacks (I think that's more for plugging into a console since they ARE designated as "professional")*The fold up reasonably compactly, for as big as they are.*comes with a handy drawstring "pleather" carrying case.CONS:*Long dangly curly cord (ok, that's not REALLY a con, but I had to come up with something)*Because of their size and propensity to block outside sounds, I wouldn't recommend these for any kind of outdoor use. These are great for home or work where you aren't moving a lot. I do see people out and about with larger headphones on,(say on the bus or subway) but I wouldn't try jogging with these.

I've been following KT Tunstall since Black Horse and the Cherry Tree made it's debut, and to be honest,  that rhythmic upbeat tempo was what I liked so much about her music for the longest time. I have recently started paying much closer attention to her slower, more introspective songs and have been amazed at what I'm hearing.  IE / CM is an entire album of introspective, mellow tunes. This album is a must listen with headphones because there are a LOT of subtleties that would be easy to miss otherwise. I have been listening to it at work - it's great work music because it is stimulating, but not distracting. The way she layers her vocals (and vocalizations) is fascinating.  This would be a great album to listen to on headphones with the lights turned off and a few candles burning. Yeah,  I know.  That sounds kind of hippy dippy, but this album is mesmerizing.  Highly recommended.

Initially I balked at the price of this case, but based on the reviews, I went ahead and purchased it.  I'm glad I did.  It's very well thought out, rugged, and useful.  It's bulky, but I have unusually large hands, so it's not a big deal for me.  I like the stand that's connected to the back a whole lot - it makes viewing video a pleasure.  I like the fact that the stand will support the kindle in both landscape and portrait mode - many other stands do either / or but not both.  The typing stand is a nice feature, although I don't use it that much.  I typically hold the Kindle in both hands and type with my thumbs. It covers all of the ports nicely, fits snugly, and yet allows the touchscreen to be fully utilized.  Well worth the purchase price.
I give it 2 stars because it was very easy to install and quite comfortable.  The fact that it failed after 5 months (it's basically pressboard) really irritates me.

I've used this stove camping a couple of times now and I like it's simple design.  It's easy to set up, burns nice and hot, and uses a multitude of fuels.  You can use biomass (sticks, pinecones, bark, dried dung, etc) or you could use a small alcohol stove, or sterno fuel, esbit cubes, etc. I like the idea that it is flexible based on your needs and available fuels. The stove is sturdy when assembled - a pot full of water placed on top is stable as long as the stove is on a level surface. If you use biomass be prepared for a lot of soot on your utensils, and on the stove. The stove is very light weight - useful for everything except the most intense ultralight packing situation.As of this writing, the stove does not come with a case. My suggestion is Custom Leathercraft 1100 Multi-Purpose Clip-on Zippered Poly Bags. You get 3 tough nylon bags in 3 different sizes.  The middle size (blue) is absolutely perfect for the Emberlit Stove. The pouches have a heavy duty zipper and a swivel clip to make attaching to your gear easy.Overall I think this stove is well designed, easy to use and a good price.

This collection has a nice variety of scents and there's a TON of it. each box has about 15-20 sticks and there are 12 boxes.  Each stick burns for about 20 - 30 minutes.  If you like incense, you'll enjoy this collection.

I'm a sucker for any kind of candle holder that throws geometric patterns on the wall.  I really enjoy this piece, and the metallic finish enhances the effect. Several of these placed around a BBQ area at night would have a lovely effect.

*update: 10/15/13*I still love this projector, and I have solved the HDMI audio issue with this little device: J-Tech Digital (Registered US Trademark) Premium Quality HDMI to HDMI + Audio (SPDIF + 3.5mm Stereo) Audio Extractor Converter. It's a teensy bit kludgy, but it works.  You plug your HDMI cable into the unit and run another HDMI cable out to your video source.  There is also a 1/8 inch audio out that you'll need to adapt to whatever your stereo inputs are (I had a 1/8 inch mini plug to rca cable already on hand.) it works well and looks terrible :)I've watched all sorts of videos from DVD to streaming video to gaming to OTA digital programming.  Everything looks great - bright, clear, well saturated (I also typically use the "eco mode" which is slightly dimmer and is supposed to make your lamp last longer and/or use less juice. I find it plenty bright for anything I have needed.  The room doesn't need to be particularly dark either.  I've watched videos in full daylight and had no issues. Overall I highly recommend this projector.This my first projector.  I was shopping for HD flatscreens when my GF suggested that we look into projectors instead.  I realized we could save ourselves a good chunk of change and have portability in the mix.  I did quite a bit of research and decided I liked the "short throw" concept of not having to place the projector very far from the screen surface. There was only one review, but I've been pretty happy with Sony products in the past, so I decided to take a chance. I'm glad it did. The picture is beautiful, bright and crisp - even in bright light. There are a number of settings to modify the picture based on the content (cinema, game, living, etc).  Setup was a snap once I figured out the "keystone" adjustment - When I first turned on the projector, the image was in the shape of a trapezoid.  Going into the menu and adjusting the keystone fixed the problem. By placing the projector about 3 feet from the wall,  I get a nice big 50" image.
