The instructions say that the largest workable image is about 100".  I found 50-60" to be plenty big.Inputs:1 HDMI1 S video1 component (rca)Here's where my one complaint comes in.  The built in speaker is decent (surprisingly so), but the unit lacks an audio out.  What this means is that in order to run the audio signal through your stereo system, you need an amp / signal receiver that has an HDMI input and output. OR your video signal source needs an audio out (my HDTV receiver does - so I can watch over the air DTV and run the sound through my stereo).  I run the majority of my video content from my Kindle Fire HD, and because the output on the Kindle is only HDMI, I can't split out the audio and run it through my stereo.This is a relatively minor complaint, but if you're going to build your home theater, you'll need to make sure you have a way to split your audio signal prior to running it through the projector.All in all this is a great home projector at a fantastic price.  Every video source I've run through it is crisp, clear, well saturated, and smooth. Great for movies, gaming, sports, and general watching.

*update 09/23/2014*I've had a second Roku 3 now for almost a year and I love it.  It's easy to use, very intuitive, and the content available keeps growing.  I think the first unit that I got (reviewed below) was defective.I was really disappointed with the Roku 3.  I got one to hook up to my new LCD projector to stream Amazon, Netflix, Hulu, etc . . . While watching content from my Amazon Prime account (Mythbusters) It lost the signal 3 times and just plain stopped.  After the 3rd time, I got frustrated and disconnected it and hooked up my Kindle Fire HD to watch the same content. It was at this point that I realized how lousy the picture (and sound) on the Roku is by comparison.  The image from the Kindle is MUCH sharper, better saturated, and looks much more like HD content.  In comparison,  I would say the Roku was like S-video as compared to standard def. The roku also wouldn't recognize my HBO GO account, which my kindle has no problem with.  Here's my breakdown:Pros:Easy to set upLots of channelsCuteHeadphones plug into remoteGreat pictureEasy to search programmingCons:Doesn't come with HDMI cable

*Update 10/7/13*Still in photographic love with the g15.  I've started taking pictures in RAW format and have actually noticed a significant difference between JPEG and RAW.  The colors are better, shadows are more defined, and while I haven't tried this myself, those in the know say RAW format is much easier to edit in post production. Here's the thing - compared to JPEG, RAW format files are H-U-G-E (in some cases, almost EIGHT times as large!) No wonder the RAW images are prettier.  The JPEG files average out at about 3.5 - 4 Megs per photo, while the raw files are upwards of 27 megs . . .! I guess I'd better invest in some extra storage space!I have been a fan of the Powershot G series since the G1.  I have owned the G1, G5, G9, as well as SX200IS and SX40.  I was lured away from the "traditional" G series by the prospect of a greater optical zoom (SX200is) and ultimately the "superzoom" (SX40). Now I have returned to the G15 and I am overwhelmed with joy.  While the zoom and superzoom cameras take decent shots and have nice close-up capabilities, the overall quality of the photos (color balance, sharpness, depth of field) was lacking.  The superzoom had issues with vignetting and distortion of the image at the outer edges.  One of the things that the early G series (as well as most early model digital cameras) had problems with was low light shots.  The sensors couldn't handle low light situations without graininess.Enter the G15. It is a solidly constructed body, has plenty of functionality for the budding photographer and the serious amateur, takes GREAT low light shots, and just takes beautifully crisp, balanced pictures. I am very pleased with my purchase.Pros:*Much improved low light shooting*TONS of features (facial recognition, self portrait with a wink, "fisheye," posterizing, slo-mo video, HD video, etc, etc, etc, etc!*Dials and buttons are placed within easy reach (new exposure setting dial is very nice)*LCD is big and beautiful (doesn't flip out, but I always figured that was one more thing to break)*AUTO shots are crisp, balanced, deeply colored and gorgeous*Plenty of options to allow you to play with exposure time, aperture, timer, white balance, color swap, monochrome and much much more.*Multiple accessories allow for adapting filters and lenses, external flash, macro ring lights, remotes, slaves, and on and on.Cons:*unless you are interested in delving into tweaking your photos, all of these features might be a bit overwhelming.*body might be a little heavy for some .This is a brilliant camera.  I'm glad I came back.

I love these soaps! My favorite scents are peppermint and eucalyptus.  This stuff can be used in a multitude of ways, depending on how you cut it or what you mix it with.  I recently mixed 1 part glycerine with 1 part doc Bronner's to get a wonderful hand soap and shower "gel."  The soap itself is very fluid and I like how the glycerine thickens it up a bit and gives it a silkiness that makes your skin feel wonderful.  The "ramblings" on the label are a tad weird, but it's all a part  of the charm.  I'm not kidding when I say this stuff can be used in an endless number of ways: hand soap, dish soap, laundry soap, shower gel, shaving soap, TOOTHPASTE!, all purpose cleaner, wood cleaner, car cleaner, dog cleaner, facial cleanser, toilet cleaner, and on and on and on . . . .Doc Bronner's really is magical stuff.  It also lasts forever because it's concentrated and you can cut it with water (or glycerine) to stretch it and make it last.  It's good stuff. And smells purty!

I placed a tealight in this lantern and turned off the lights  - I was mesmerized by the patterns of shadows it projects on the walls.  It is a gorgeous piece, both lit and unlit. It could also be used as a pretty incense burner, if you didn't mind risking staining the inside of the lantern with incense resin.  Also, be careful as the lid gets very warm from the candle flame.

After seeing a number of You Tube videos and reading numerous reviews of the Stove Tec stoves, I finally decided to try one out - I'm a sucker for cool tech, especially when it's a simple and elegant design.  I have several "rocket" type camping stoves and have experimented with building a basic stove out of bricks.  I'm not sure if I bought the Stove Tec stove with the intent of using it as a barbecue, emergency stove, or just because I was intrigued by the novelty of it.  I think it was the novelty of it.  I cranked up the stove a few days ago and here are my impressions:Pros:Burns efficiently - I boiled a pan of water in about 5 minutes, and cooked up a mess of hot dogs on a circular grill right over the flames.Very little waste - several hours of burning wood in kindling sized chunks resulted in a remarkably small pile of ash (I'd estimate less than a cup)Burns any kind of combustable biomass (Sticks, grass, dung, pinecones, etc) so there's no need to purchase or transport fuel.Cons:This bad boy is HEAVY.  It's steel encapsulated ceramics. . . what do I expect?!  It tips the scales at 28 lbs, which while making it portable, rules it out of any sort of camping other than car camping.  I'd say it's even too heavy to make it worth taking along for tailgating - you could bring a portable gas grill that has a more controllable cook flame and weighs 1/2 to 1/3 as much.You have to keep it from getting wet - the instructions are pretty explicit about this.  I'm not sure if this is to protect the cast iron pot cover, the steel sheathing, or the ceramic insert, but it's mentioned several times.  This means you can't leave it out in the elements, and you'll have to be extra careful when camping or tailgating.The feeding of the fuel needs to be monitored reasonably closely - you can set it up to simmer once you have a good bed of coals, but I found the videos' claim of 30 - 60 minutes of simmer time to be a bit of an exaggeration. Now, I was using mostly pine as my fuel, so maybe using a hardwood would make a significant difference.My conclusion:If you're looking for a great option for an emergency stove,  While I think there are more portable and flexible options (The Kelly Kettle, for instance) I believe the Stove Tec stove would do a fine job providing a decent cooking option.  I also think that if you are living in an "off the grid" situation where you have a kitchen set up that doesn't move, the Stove Tec would be ideal. I just think it's too unwieldy to use as a portable stove option in camping, tailgating, picnics, etc.The stove itself is well made and sturdy.  AND it has a 10 year warranty.

I like the flexibility of this back scratcher - it's got a sharp side and a smooth side, a single point and a rounded massage tip. The claws are robust and durable.  My only complaints are that the handle needs to be longer (or a longer handle version need to be offered) and the angle of the scratcher needs to be increased.  I have trouble getting the points to make constant contact with my back. Honestly, in side-by-side comparisons, I prefer the Bear Claw Back Scratcher.I have tried a whole lot of back scratchers, telescoping and fixed length, and I believe that the Bear Claw is the best one out there.

I have owned a number of back scratchers both telescoping and fixed.  The problem with the telescoping scratchers is that they inevitably break.  The problem with most fixed length scratchers is that the heads aren't positioned correctly and/or the handles are too short. Enter the Bear Claw.  The handle is nice and long to reach ALL those itchy spots, and the claws are spaced nicely for good coverage.  They're also angled so that the tips make contact and do a great job of giving you a shuddery, goose bumpy back scratch. Some may think the tips are a bit sharp (not me), but it comes with a patch of sandpaper that allows you to dull the claws if you so desire. Wonderful product! Worth every penny!

I originally ordered these pouches to store small tools in my toolbox - I have things like picks and needles that I was tired of reaching in and sticking myself on.  I love them - I use them to store things that I want easy access to when I go camping and have recently discovered that the medium size (blue) is the PERFECT size to store my Emberlit Camping Stove. They're great all purpose bags.

I have an Emberlit stove and needed a good solution for a case.  Based on the other reviews and the pictures, this carbon fiber case seems to be a loser.  Here's my suggestion: Custom Leathercraft 1100 Multi-Purpose Clip-on Zippered Poly Bags.  You get three heavy duty nylon bags with a zipper and a swivel clip.  The medium size (blue) is the perfect size to store your stove in.  I use the other two to store small tools in my toolbox.  You get 3 bags for the price of this one pouch.

I really like these timers for turning on lamps in the evening and off at night.  These have a clock, one on time and one off time and a random function.  They're really easy to program.  Very useful if you don't need multiple times and days.

This is a nice sized toolbox to store your gear. Metal clips are heavy duty and the box has a gasket to keep water out. The tray inside extends 3/4 of the length of the box , which is nice if you have extra tall tools, or don't want to remove the tray to get at things below.  My only suggestion would be to build in small parts storage, or nest another tray.

I love the versatility of this stand.  It stores my Droid 4 in either the vertical or horizontal position, has channels and clips to route cables and keep them in place, and has a rubberized base that stays in place nicely. If you charge your phone in the horizontal position and your charging port is on the bottom of your phone, you may want to invest in a low profile or right-angle plug. I don't think there's enough clearance between the bottom of the phone and the stand for a full sized micro plug.  Of course, you could simply flip your phone over and put the charging port on top, but that would be WAY too inventive.

*update 6/24/13*I have since taken the fan to work with me and it works well on a thinner clamping surface. I like the versatility of putting the fan up off my desk, saving desk space. I retract my statement that the clamp is not useful.I've had a number of desk fans from the Vornado to Holmes and I can honestly say that this fan is a nice little desk fan.  I like the vertical profile because it takes up a lot less space on my desk  On low it provides a nice, quiet, comfortable airflow. On high, the noise level increases quite a bit and the airflow doesn't seem to be that much more.The clip is a great idea, but needs to be re-engineered.  I was going to clip it to the bottom of my window, but the clamp doesn't have enough gripping power to hold the fan in place.  The edge of my desk is too thick for the clamp, so I couldn't try that out either.  Overall,  I believe this fan is worth the money.  Here's a quick breakdown:Pros:Small footprintQuiet on lowNice airflowCons:Kind of noisy on high settingThe clamp was not useful to me

I've tried 4 of the entrees in this bucket so far and am pleasantly surprised at the quality.  These meals have good flavor, are filling, and are dead easy to prep.  Freeze dried food has come a long way.  Also, it comes in a useful reusable bucket.  Well worth the price!

I love the flexibility of my Gorillapod - it holds my point-and-shoot camera at an infinite number of strange angles and on a wide range of uneven surfaces.  I took my Gorillapod with me camping this weekend and discovered a smart design feature.  Like a dope,  I had put my camera with the 'pod attached to it in my pocket. When I bent down to pick something up,  I heard a 'pop' and thought "oh crap, I just broke my Gorillapod."  The designers are a whole lot smarter than I am, because I discovered that the 'pod has a "breakaway" feature, which means it's designed to come apart instead of break when subjected to too much stress.  I was able to easily pop my camera back on and go about my business. Fantastic device in cool colors.

Just got back from a camping trip in which we used the XL flip box as a secondary cooler.  We folded it up, brought it along and put it to use with a 20lb bag of ice which we got near the campground.  It performed better than expected.  In addition to the bag of ice, we were able to fit a 12 pack of cans, a six pack of bottles, and a few additional food items (a pack of sandwich meat, pack of hot dogs, can of soup, ) I was impressed with the capacity  - and the insulating ability.  We had no noticeable melting of the ice until well into the second day - and this is with much opening and closing to retrieve drinks and food. It provided enough insulation that the ice chilled the six pack to ice cold from room temperature in about an hour.  After 3 days, we still have a good 15 or so pounds of ice left. The cooler is about as heavy as a typical throw away styrofoam cooler, but insulates much better and is much MUCH more durable. One slight con is that the cooler allows melt water to leak, which wasn't a huge problem for us since we had it outdoors the whole time.  I guess that prevents a sludgy pool of cold water collecting in the bottom of the cooler. Highly recommended.

I read the reviews for this valve and  am wondering if it's the shower head being used that is causing all the disparity.  I purchased this valve because the showerhead I have has such a high rate of flow that it depletes my water heater in about 20 minutes.  I figured having a variable closure valve would allow each person to customize their shower experience  - from full power short shower to low power long shower.  Based on the reviews, I figured the "off position" would actually be "trickle." Here's what I found:Wide open seems wide open.  If it reduces flow rate, it's not noticeable to me.Fully closed is full shutoff - no trickle. Beware of scald when you turn the valve back on.Installation is easy - use teflon tape to reduce drips.Overall I'd say this valve does everything you'd expect it to.

I love having multiple firestarting devices on hand when I go camping and I found the simplicity of this device intriguing.  My first attempt at lighting the included incense cone resulted in a few wisps of smoke, but no combustion. My experiment occurred mid morning before the sun was at full altitude, so that may have had something to do with it. I had made some char cotton balls a few weeks ago and figured I'd give them a shot. WOW. I burned the tips of my fingers because I didn't realize it was lit already. The best kind of tinder for this device is dark in color and very flammable. I will keep a little baggie of charcloth in with this lighter forevermore.Making your own charcloth is really easy - search for charcloth on youtube for instructions.Happy lighting!

**update 04/30/2013**I paired this shower head with a flow control valve (about 8 bucks right here on good ol' Amazon) - this gives me the flexibility to back down the pressure and extend the showering time.  I found with just a slight adjustment,  I could lower the pressure enough that a long shower was possible without a noticeable difference in spray pressure.  An added advantage of a flow control is you can conserve water by shutting the flow off (or at least down to a trickle) while you shampoo / shave / soap up / etc.  Bottom line, if you have a gigantic water heater and don't care about wasting water (shame on you) go crazy! Otherwise,  I would highly recommend a variable flow control in conjunction with this wonderful shower head for invigoratingly relaxing (is that an oxymoron?) shower time.  Happy showering!**update 4/21/13**This showerhead is not, in fact a water-saving device.  I actually drained the water heater last night by taking a 20 minute shower.  I have never drained my water heater before. That said, if you can deal with not saving hot water and can keep your shower to under 15 minutes, this thing is 15 kinds of awesome. We all need at least one guilty pleasure, don't we?How is it that something so inexpensive can be so wonderful? I've tried a lot of different water conserving showerheads and I find myself disbelieving that this device could actually be saving me water.  It sure provides a wonderful high pressure deluge.  I was a little worried that I was going to drain my water heater, but I had plenty of hot water.Installation was a no brainer. I had the best shower in years. Trust me on this one.  And, hey, if you REALLY don't like it, you're out less than ten bucks. All happiness should be so inexpensive.

The first time I filled and started my Zippo handwarmer,  I was pretty unimpressed.  The filling process seemed pretty cumbersome, and the warmer didn't get very warm. After doing some research,  I learned a few things.  First of all, it may help you to judge the proper fueling amount, but I HATE the funnel device that came with the warmer.  I fill the chamber directly and had more success (warning - make sure you allow any excess fuel to evaporate before using or you'll have a fire hazard).Here's my advice to get the most out of your warmer:* Give the heater some time to get going before you drop it in the pouch - when the heater is almost too hot to touch, drop it in the bag.* If you want REAL WARMTH, ditch the fleece pouch and put it directly in a pocket.  The pouch extends the burn time, but significantly reduces the heat output.* you can also regulate the heat output by leaving the drawstring open and exposing the catalytic burner to more O2. Conversely, closing the drawstring will reduce the heat.*DO NOT place the metal warmer directly against your bare skin for more than a few seconds as it WILL cause a burn. (this is especially important if your fingers have gone numb from cold)If you don't mind the filling process and keeping fuel around, you'll appreciate the extra warmth for your fingers.

This is a nicely made SAP.  The leather is good quality and the steel insert will deliver a serious wallop. The stitching appears a teensy haphazard, but it hasn't come unraveled.  Several reviewers have said it's too big to fit in a pocket - true, but I have found it fits perfectly in the side pocket of carpenter pants or shorts. It is inconspicuous, and easy to get to in a hurry. Fortunately,  I haven't had the occasion to use it, but it's big enough to turn out the lights if you know where to target. It will also make someone think twice when used on hands, quads, glutes, knees, or shins. It's not much of a visual deterrent, because it's pretty subtle.Here's the thing. . . make sure you know your local laws regarding impact weapons.  There are very few cities / states in which it is legal to have this on your person when you are outside your home. It's considered a concealed weapon in my town and I think it's a felony if you get caught with one. It's a nice little device, just be careful where and when you have it.

My girlfriend introduced me to Paine's incense with their wooden cabin burner and I have been a big fan ever since.  I use the burner very frequently and the wood picks up resins from the incense and the constant heat of the burning cones dried out and cracked the wood.  I needed something more durable, and I found this ceramic cabin.  I was cautious about the pinon incense because I don't like the Paine's version of the pinon incense (I LOVE the cedar). I tried Santa Fe's version of the pinon, and I LOVE it. To me it's reminiscent of beachfires or outdoor campfires.  The cedar incense reminds me more of a fireplace. If you like Santa Fe's incense, I would encourage you to try Paine's cedar cones.The cabin is great - make sure you have the bottom plate set up correctly - those little nubs need to be facing up to allow airflow (just line up the door with the steps and you'll be fine.) Like any kind of wood incense, it takes a bit of time to get this incense burning correctly - hold a lighter to the edge and get it burning, blow on it to establish a "cherry," set it carefully in the slot in the cabin floor (it's very hot), and Bob's your uncle.I would highly recommend this burner and incense for anyone who likes the ambiance of a campfire.

I have a big head and had noticed that many of my hats just weren't fitting correctly.  After stretching them overnight with the Hat Jack, the hats fit better and are a whole lot more comfortable.  I love my hats and now I love my Hat Jack!  This is an accessory that anyone with a hat collection should have.

I purchased these seeds for the purpose of indoor aerogarden growing.  It's a good thing I know how to remove the hood on my Aerogarden, because this monster would have dwarfed the poor thing in a matter of weeks.  I have it set up under an LED growlight in a stack of milk crates and the plant has already grown to 5 crates high.  It is starting to flower, so I'm hoping that it will produce some nice fruit.  I will post an update if/when the fruit appears.  For anyone out there who wants to grow tomatoes indoors, be prepared to expand your growing area to accomodate a large plant.  I knew that tomatoes are typically tall plants and had grown some other tall plants in my Aerogarden previously, so I was prepared.

These plastic posts are great for recently pierced ears, or for people who's piercings tend to close up on their own. I actually have replaced the stainless piercing stud with these after a couple of weeks because the plastic tends to be less irritating  - be advised that it can be tricky to insert these if the hole hasn't completely healed yet, and you can risk infection by swapping out early.  That said,  I was able to swap them out and they are much more comfortable to sleep while in. They're also great for "stealthing" your piercings - you can put them in to make sure the piercing doesn't close up, but they're almost transparent and very difficult to see from a distance. My only complaint is that it takes FOREVER to receive them (because they come from Korea) but what are ya gonna do?Pros:*Comfortable for sleeping.*Very inconspicuous (you really have to look to see them.)*If you are crafty in nature, you could glue any number of sparkly items to the post and make your own stud earrings.*Hypoallergenic and non-reactive.Cons:*Shipping takes a lifetime and a half (well, 2-4 weeks in reality, but hey! I'm not gettin' any younger!)*The backs are REALLY tiny, so those of us with orangutan fingers have a little difficulty fitting them on the post.Overall pretty pleased with the product.

We live in a big old house that has an external stairway with lights that are controlled with various switches.  Often our neighbors have the lights turned off in their entryway, which makes the stairwell very dark.  Enter Mr. Beams.  It's smart enough to only come on when it's dark enough to need it, and the motion sensor triggers flawlessly.  The LED is bright enough to illuminate the stairs without being obnoxious, and shuts itself off after about 10 minutes or so.  Great product.

I own 5 different models of Dietz tubular lanterns as well as a variety of oil lamps.  Dietz lanterns are an excellent choice for emergency lighting, but there's a lot of misinformation about the correct fuel to use.  These lanterns are designed to use kerosene or kerosene - like fuel.  Both liquid paraffin and citronella are too viscous and will clog the wick, eventually reducing the efficiency of your burn and causing soot buildup on the globe (as well as polluting your breathing air).If you are looking for a very good fuel for these lamps that has low odor, check out "Guiding Light Oil High Performance Lamp Oil Fuel"If you are interested in more information about different Dietz lantern models, which fuels are appropriate, and information about lanterns in general, check out W.T. Kirkman's website.  Kirkman also manufactures tubular lanterns that are on par with Dietz.
These were fun and the kids loved them at my grandson's birthday party.

You might be able to use these things for something (like on a suitcase handle) but they were useless as seat belt comfort devices, in my opinion.  First of all...they are not reversible.  Secondly, when I velcroed them around my seat belt, they simply slid down as they are far too big for the seatbelts themselves.  Probably by as much as a inch.  I thought you could attach them around the belt, near the shoulder area, and they would stay there.  But they don't.
Just as amazing as Season 1...and Season 2
Love it!  That's all I can say!

My 8 year old grandson is really into WWE, especially John Cena!  I bought this shirt for his birthday and he immediately wanted to put it on...which isn't usually like him!  The shirt was great quality and the colors were very bright...they didn't seem like they would fade easily like some cheaper shirts that are dyed with ink and fade on 1st wash.

I give the tracker a 4, rather than a 5 because in spite of the great reviews regarding battery life...that has not been my experience.  The company advertises up to 30 days on a charge.  Not so!  Even if the tracker WOULD continue to function for 30 days, which it never will, you wouldn't have nearly the battery power you'd need to track your pet.  We have 4 trackers on 4 dogs.  If you live in a small house/apt, the battery life MAY last longer.  But we have to charge the trackers every other day!  And always have.  The company explains that while the dog is within a certain distance from the docking station (the device that plugs in, charges the tracker, and is basically the "brain" of the thing...) the tracker will go into power saving mode.  If you have a larger house, as with our case, the dogs are more often than not outside the "home zone" and the tracker is constantly tracking.  It's because when your pet leaves your house the tracker is tracking or locating, which uses a lot of battery power!  So, this is the key to having marvelous success with these amazing trackers:  keep them fully charged at all times!  The app will signal you when the battery is low, as well as when it's fully charged, but we've lost a dog with 1/2 battery remaining and the tracker went dead rather quickly.  We found the dog, but not with the tracker.All of that being said...I wouldn't want to be without this tracker!  I can track my dog down to a single parking space in a parking lot, if need be.  You can locate the pet and there is an option like a GPS that will take you, via verbal directions, right to you pet!  So, keep them fully charged and they'll work great!

I'm giving this product 2 stars because I feel the description was misleading.  The "product dimensions" were listed as 7" x 1.2" x 6.2".  I don't consider the package they come in to be incorporated in the "product dimensions" and was under the impression that they would be taller.  When in fact they are 2" to 3" tall.  I can see these figures are getting high reviews so they're probably great for what they are...if you know you're getting tiny figures.
Love it!  I watch it every night!
Not my type of show.
Exciting right from the start.  Loved the ending!

I haven't actually had to use this product...(we all hope not to have to use these often!) but I can tell by the design that it is going to be by far the best plunger I've ever used.  And as a landlord, I've plunger quite a few toilets!  I especially like the handle!  Most of the others (that I've ever used anyway) have the straight handle and it can be more difficult to get the grip you need to apply enough pressure to push the clog out.  I also like the narrow bottom part of the plunger because it appears that this will fit snuggly into the drain of the toilet, allowing for a tight seal.

Before I got my Fire Stick I had a Sony Blu-ray DVD player which I used for streaming.  It worked great but I liked the small size of the Amazon Fire Stick.  What I don't like, however, is that I have to use 2 remotes with this one.  There is no volume control.  It's very basic for those who like simplicity.

I haven't actually sent one of these tests in yet...but I'm amazed at the price considering it includes the lab fee!  I purchased a radon test kit at Lowe's for more than I paid for this one...and I had to send a check for $30.00 to get the test read and the results returned to me!
Great for younger children who love experimenting!  The containers sit in a little stand (which is great as they have rounded bottoms) to prevent spills.
Surprisingly sturdy and ample size for storage of any type of plunger I might need to store.

I never thought I could get so excited about a short little plunger!  But as it turns out, I had an opportunity to put the "Shorty" to work just a few days after I received it.  I was having a code inspection completed on an apartment (I'm a landlord) and the inspector advised that the bathroom sink was clogged.  Normally I would have done 1 of 2 things:  either call a plumber, or go out and get some chemical drain unclogger (which I didn't have time for this day).  The inspector said he'd be back to reinspect later that day.  With no time for either a plumber or chemical drain cleaner, I happened to remember by little "Shorty" plunger.  I took it to the apartment, put it over the sink drain and pushed down.  Immediately the plunger produced a pretty strong suction over the drain.  When I pulled the plunger back up a bunch of gross looking crap came out and the clog was cleared.  Just like that!I've been a landlord for over 25 years and have always relied on plumbers for things like clogged sinks but now I'm thinking...I'll save myself a lot of money by taking my "Shorty" and unclogging the drains myself!  I'm anxiously awaiting a call from the next tenant with a clogged drain!!
if you are, or ever work, a fan of this series, you certainly won't be disappointed with this one.the only problem is, it's hard to stop watching once you start! I can't recommend it highly enough!

Cutest books ever!!  Love, love, love them!  They're for very young children...an older child may not like it as much as a young child.  My grandson is 19 months and he is fascinated by these little finger puppet books.

I have given this Keurig 2.0 a higher rating than I would have previous to receiving my new Freedom Clip from the maker's of San Francisco Coffee!  Free of charge, this company will send you the Freedom Clip, which snaps right onto this 2.0 model and you aren't restricted to Keurig only coffees!  I received my clip just yesterday (actually, they sent 2 clips...and a sample pack of some excellent San Francisco Coffee....Fog Chaser!) and used it right away.  It was very simple to attach and worked like a charm!  I was able to immediately brew my favorite coffee, which was NOT a Keurig authorized brand!!  Here's the website to order the FREE OF CHARGE Freedom Clips!  http://www.sanfranciscobaycoffee.com/index.php/fight-brewing-freedom/
I love it!  I love films from the era of this series and I've not been bored for a minute while watching.
I've bought several of these and have no issues with them whatsoever!
Great products!  I highly recommend them and have continued to purchase them!

These are great products at a very low price!  I have seen styluses for an outrageous price in some catalogs and in some stores and I wonder WHY people would pay so much when they can get them on Amazon.com for an unbelievably low price!AND they're great styluses...  Pretty colors and every bit as good as any I've seen anywhere...at any price.IN fact, I just ordered some more!  One thing to note:  they may not arrive as quickly as some products but they're worth waiting for!

My dog seems to really love these chews (thought I couldn't personally say how good they are...)and I like the fact that they get a little "foamy" or "fizzy" when they're chewing on them because I believe that's theenzymes at work.  I also brush my dog's teeth but I also use these to prevent any tarter from building up way in the backwhere she HATES for me to brush!
This little gadget comes in handy for a multitude of charging needs!  Now, if only it had a "lightning" charger for the newer Apple products...it would be amazing!

It's hard to say, really, how I like this "stun gun" because I haven't had to use it yet (hopefully I never will) but I can tell you this...it looks and sounds very dangerous!  I can't imagine how stupid a person would have to be to continue to approach you if you had this in your hand!  And...if they WERE that stupid...I have a feeling they'd regret it!

I was surprised that the bristles are not made of the usual bristle material, because it looks like that in the picture.They are made of a soft, rubber-like material.  I'm not saying this isn't the best way to brush a baby's teeth but it justisn't what I was expecting.

I was so happy to find this Tom's of Maine product on Amazon.  Not just because I happen to BE from Maine...but because I LOVE all the Tom's products and they are getting difficult to find in the usual stores I always bought them at!  I was afraid they were being phased out...or going out of business...but seems they're still going strong!I use this deodorant for several reasons but the newest one is because I read an article about breast cancer and the nasty ingredients found in regular deodorant was found in MOST of the women who had breast cancer.  Especially in those who shaved their arm pits.  Think about it...a close shave (which is what we all strive for) opens up the skin to enable a chemical to go directly to the lymph nodes...(something like that!)  Any opportunity I can get to cut my cancer risk I'll take.I used to refuse to use a "Natural" deodorant, fearing they would fall short in the sweat/odor department but that wasn't the case at all!  I've even tried the "unscented" (that's the only one found in our area right now) and I NEVER thought the unscented, all natural deodorants would work...but guess what...they DO!  Amazing!

If you like the TV show, Antique Roadshow, which I happen to love...you'll love this DVD.If you don't like the show...don't buy the video!  I only hope I'm going to be able to find some more episodes!!

A wonderful book for very young children!  I loved the book so much, I ordered another one...as well as some of the other "animals" in the series (I call it a series because they are all by the same author)I would highly recommend them for anyone with a child 3 and under (my opinion).The book is especially cute because you can make the head move with your finger and as you open the next page...the horse is still there...(I just copied and pasted my review of the "Little Horse" book...because they are ALL equally wonderful!)

A wonderful book for very young children!  I loved the book so much, I ordered another one...as well as some of the other "animals" in the series (I call it a series because they are all by the same author)I would highly recommend them for anyone with a child 3 and under (my opinion).The book is especially cute because you can make the head move with your finger and as you open the next page...the horse is still there...

Some things are just difficult to order without seeing first...These cards are ok...but if I had seen them 1st I probably would have chosen something else.But they didn't claim to be anything special...and they aren't.

The step stool is ok... it will definitely provide the safety of having something to hang onto when climbing and something to help you catch yourself if you fall.  I've since discovered that I can buy one locally for a lower price...but I don't shop locally anymore!  I'm too hooked on Amazon.com!

I don't think I noticed anywhere that this paper is only neon on one side??  Maybe that's the norm...but the neon colored paper I've had in the past was the same color on the front and back.  This one is white on one side which can be tricky for photocopying...if you aren't sure which way to put the paper in the tray so it will print on the correct side.
Paper is paper I guess...but I like that this 24lb paper is substantially thicker than the usual photocopy paper you guy in a department store.  Also...the 96 brightness makes it nice and white!

This is actually the 2nd one of these books I've ordered!  I love the fact that I can tear out just a few pages to bring with me and if I need the answers (not that I ever do!) they're right on the back of the page!
How can you go wrong with Kelloggs AND chocolate!  It's a win/win situation AND chocolate for breakfast!!

I bought this product to weigh gold and have used it also to weigh some smaller food items.  It seems very accurate.  Each time I use it I put a coin on it to be sure the weight is exact.  For example, a nickel weight 5 grams so if the scale states that, then I know the scale is accurate...and so far it's been dead on.

I bought this for my 7 yr old grandson, which he was able to read to me, so it's probably a 2nd grade reading level (roughly)  He loved the book and I too loved it!  I especially like the "life lessons" depicted in the book.  I definitely intend to find more books in the series...or by the same author.
I love these little figurines!  I've been buying them for my daughter on occasion and she seems to love them too, keeping them displayed...and she isn't one to have a lot of "nick-nacks" around.
I don't think it makes any difference whether you use this product or not in terms of whether you'll get a hangover or not.  Not for me anyway.
This is just so cute!  The quality is excellent and I can't think of anything adverse to say about it!I highly recommend for anyone whose baby loves his "binky"
I saw this book in a gift shop and I loved it!  The prices was more than I was willing to pay at the timebut I found it on Amazon.com for much less...and of course, the quality was every bit as good!
Does not charge
The first time I charged the battery, it worked fine.  Since then, it has not worked at all.

I always hesitate to purchase clothing online from unknown sources, but I was quite pleased with this blouse.The material seems to be of very good quality, well made, buttons sewed on well, etc.I would definitely recommend the blouse.

I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of this blouse!  You never know what to expect, especially when an item is so reasonably priced.  The materials feels to be of fairly high quality...buttons sewed on well, etc.  I'd definitely recommend them.

I love these lights!  They're very bright and there is a control box connected that allows you to select the different modes or options for viewing the lights....ie:  flashing slowly, flashing rapidly, steady light, and several others.

I love these lights!  They are soft lights and the "globes" are covered with a material that's almost cloth-like.  My only concern is the electrical safety of the plugs.  They are very, very thin.  Almost like a very thick aluminum foil.  I won't leave mine unattended for this reason and I doubt they'd meet US guidelines in terms of electrical standards....but I love them just the same!
For the money, I absolutely love this chair!  I needed something fairly small for a tight space that I call my office.  This one fit the bill exactly.  I highly recommend it.
A very cute, simple book, obviously written for very young children.  My grandson absolutely loves any of the animal books in this series (and I can't seem to stop ordering them!)

This is definitely one of the cutest books for babies I've ever seen!  My grandson so loves the book that I've continued to order books with the different animals in the series.  It's a simple book, obviously written for the very young (or the very young at heart!)
I was very pleased with the product and it arrived very quickly!  My grandson absolutely loves this!
Too soon to really tell really,  after only a couple of episodes... But so far so good!

I didn't purchase my Keurig 2.0 on Amazon.  I received it as a gift.  I thought, however, that I'd take the opportunity to review this product anyway because it wouldn't MATTER where I purchased it....it would be just as much a piece of crap.  I had a Keurig...a nice one, with lots of features that I liked.  For example, I could use any kind of K-cup out there and I found one that I really, really liked.  I can't use that one anymore.  Keurig has made the new 2.0 so that you can't use the little cup that held regular coffee.  And it has to be an "official" k-cups because the new 2.0 reads the lettering on the rim of the new ones.  As far as the carafe?  It's a good idea in theory to have a little pot that will brew (supposedly) up to 6 cups of coffee (even more on some of the fancier, more expensive models).  But in reality, you can only get a little over 2 regular sized cups of coffee from the carafe. Any more and it would definitely be too weak.  The 4-cup setting is really pushing it...in my opinion.  And I don't prefer especially strong coffee.  In addition, the K-Carafes are expensive - anywhere from $16-$20 for 8 K-Carafes (which is approximately 18-20 cups of coffee.It's a gimmick...and not even a very good one at that.  Keurig is trying to dominate the K-cup market and whoever buys this machine will be sucked right into it.  I'm on the fence about returning mine, but I haven't quite decided yet.
This top is very cute!  It fits well, is somewhat tapered at the waste and plenty long enough.The material is very soft, unlike many T's I've purchased in the past.  I highly recommendthis shirt!
The dimensions given did not include the depth of the shelves.  If you wanted this for spice bottles, it would be fine.  But the shelves are too narrow for almost anything else.

This gate is adjustable but only to a certain point.  There are slots that need to be clicked into to hold the gate firm once you've reached your adjustment point.  The problem is, these slots are spaced apart 1/3", more or less, and if the distance between your doorway, wall, or what have you isn't a size that exactly fits into one of the slots, the gate will be too loose and not hold firmly.  With other gates I've had in the past, you can slide the gate to the desired position and lock it somehow.  You can't do that with this gate

The reason for the low rating is that while the food tastes great, anything that it touches will definitely HAVE to be thrown away!  I fed this to my grandson and of course it got on his bib, but it also got on his shirt.  I pre-sprayed the items before I washed them.  When they didn't come clean I soaked them for 2 days in my Oxy cleaner that literally gets EVERYTHING out!  Even those nasty underarm stains comes clean with Oxy powder.  But not so with this food.

I guess I'm not sure exactly what "Turbo" is supposed to mean but it nothing to do, in this case, with the power of the toothbrush.  When you turn the toothbrush on, mostly what happens is the handle vibrates and the brush vibrates slightly.  I bought this for my 9 yr old daughter and she came to me with the brush turned on and asked what it was supposed to do (with her previous one, at least the round part of the bristles spun around.  This one just leaves a lot to be desired.  I'll definitely be replacing it with something that at least makes an attempt at moving the bristles.

Alex Gracey had been born into privilege and was being groomed to take a lead in the politics of Ireland at a time when Protestants ruled. When he meets Mary Smyth, the daughter of a Catholic activist, however, his perspective changes. Never has he met a woman that captivated him so. He disguises who he is and becomes her protector, as much as he can. He helps her father to plant flax during the potato blight, and gets her brother a job at his familys factory. But, although he remains optimistic, hes well aware that hes playing a dangerous game on many levels, and he may very well be on a collision course.Although I found this book interesting and enjoyed it, it wasn't one that I couldn't put down, and it read more like a secular book than a Christian one. It even had some mild curse words sprinkled throughout the dialogue. Of course the time period has much about religion, because of the hatred and clashes between the Protestants and Catholics. There were very few grammatical errors, although the book is heavy in Irish dialect that occasionally sounds more Scottish. I wondered about the title, because Mr. Gracey was never rescued in the usual sense of the word. I liked the first half much better than the last, because near the end, the troubles mount and there becomes almost too much tension and misery. Still, it was a fascinating read that I would recommend. I do like historical novels, like this one, based on themes and settings not often covered.

Luke Davis had come back to Lookout, Texas after being gone for eleven years. Rachel had broken his heart when she married his friend, James. Luke didn't know what had really happened, and Rachel hoped he never found out. Now James is dead, but Rachel's hopes of a second chance at love is dashed when Luke refuses to forgive her. When his pesky cousins decided Luke needs a wife and three mail order brides show up to marry him, things get really complicated and muddled. This is a delightful romantic comedy with each character adding depth to the story. There were almost no mistakes. "Roil" being used for "roll" was likely a scanning error. The teacher was Mrs. Fairland, and I doubt there would have been a married female teacher in rural Texas in 1886, because only single women could usually teach then, but these items are minor, and the book is enthralling.

B.J. Spencer was forced to come back to her hometown because of a will. It was the last thing she wanted to do, after growing up in the orphanage there. Shed also been threatened with harm to her boyfriend right after high school, if she didn't leave. Now shes going to have to face it all again, including Jason.Jason O'Connell has never gotten over Billy Jo, and he was devastated when she left without a word. Hed eventually married, but that had ended badly. Now, with B.J. back, and them forced to live in Rose Mansion for a year, he doesn't know how his heart can survive. But, with all the incidents happening, it may be a miracle if either one of them survives.I liked this story and the characters, but there was a lot about the book I didn't like. The main thing was all the detailed descriptions that went on for pages and pages, and about things I didn't care to know that much about. Two examples are the pages describing Margarets desk in the mansion, and it took 22 pages on my kindle to get through the descriptions from the time B.J. asked for the lockbox at the bank until she actually had it. And, there were many, many more such dry pages. I just wanted to get on with the story.B.J. takes an awfully lot of photos in the afternoon for a professional photographer. The light washes out everything then and makes the pictures look drab. Margarets will said they only had to spend 60% of their days and nights at the mansion, so Jason and B.J. could have conceivably had  had to spend only 20% of the time together, but this was never mentioned. In fact, when Jason started having trouble at his ranch, he regretted he couldn't stay there overnight to help catch the culprits. Jason also found the spent bullet and casing after the police investigated a mysterious shot, but nothing was mentioned about the police missing it.There were also loads of minor mistakes:near for nearly (twice)discussed for disgustedsmooth for smoothlyquick for quickly (twice)wondering for wanderingrungs for steps (on stairs, not a ladder)Randy for Robby part of the timeRandi most of the time but Randy somecomingled wasn't in the kindle dictionaryIf you can get beyond these problems, youll probably enjoy the book. I would have enjoyed it, if it hadn't been for the overload of descriptions that slowed the story to a crawl. The last  did get better, however, and the ending was good, so use your own judgment.

Mary McKechnie finds herself in a desperate situation. Since her abusive husband died, she and her girls have sunk lower and lower into poverty. Her oldest brother is threatening to take the girls away from her and sell them as indentured servants, if she doesn't do what he tells her, and the Friends might let him, since the family is so poor. On top of all that, Amon Cayle, the man she wronged but never stopped loving, is about to come back into life. And, it gets worse.Amon Cayle is still grieving for his wife, who burned to death in a kitchen fire. He almost lost his oldest son, David, also, and even now their relationship is strained. Hes manipulated into hiring Mary to sew his threadbare, growing family some clothes, but can he stand having her around. He loved his wife dearly, but Mary has always resided in a corner of his heart. And why wont she tell him why she left him without a word to marry another?David Cayle will do anything to keep his father and Mary apart. Hes too attracted to Marys daughter, Annie, and, if their parents were to wed, the Friends will consider them as siblings. With his cousin trying to cause trouble and his schoolmaster uncle unreasonable, David sometimes doesnt know which way to turn. But he knows his heart wants to turn toward Mary.There were more grammatical mistakes than I expected. Words were misused, like understood, when understand was needed. Letters were left out of words several times, and some sentences were just poorly written, like I so not understand know why he hates me so. The nominative case pronoun was used at least nine times, when the objective case was needed  ex. between she and Grayson.This was an extremely hard book to read. It was difficult to keep all the characters straight, and the family chart at the beginning did not show well on my kindle. The first half moved by inches and was too drawn out. I liked the main characters, but nothing ever goes right for them, and much of its because of their own poor decisions and reactions and from keeping secrets. The tension was always so high these people I liked lived in misery, and it was frustrating and agonizing. I couldn't read it for too long at a time, because I had to walk away to ease the tension. I kept hoping the ending would make up for the anguish, but it didn't. One situation worked out well, but I wanted more insight to their happiness, which was skimmed over. The other situation is left up in the air for the next novel. I wont be reading it. This one wasn't worth the gut-wrenching. After much deliberation, I ended up rating it 2.5. There were certainly parts about it that I liked, but the parts I didn't outweighed them.

At twenty-nine, Sarah Taylor is tired of waiting for the right man to come into her life. She wants a family, so she decides to adopt a child as a single mother. The only problem is that shes liked Will Kennedy, her lawyer, since elementary school, but he seems to only want to be her friend. When she meets the expecting mother of a possible baby to adopt, her heart goes before her head, despite Wills warnings, and Sarah gets hurt in the process. However, she wouldn't have it any different for the mother and her baby. As Sarah know, the key to a happy life is trusting in God.I really liked this novel, but I couldn't relate to Sarah or Will as much as I usually do in a book I enjoy. I found very few errors. There was a question mark where a period was needed. I dont think dove eggs are larger than chicken eggs. And, I wondered how Sarah and Will saw each other smile, when they were in sterile outfits, including masks, in the hospital. Still, it was a good, sweet read that I didn't regret. I gave it a 4.5, which rounded up to a five.

Katie ran away from her Amish way of life to be with her English boyfriend, but he left her when she became pregnant. With no other options, she goes back to her harsh brothers farm, except he no longer lives there. The new residents, a kind Amish mother and her adult son, take her in, and Katie begins to see a different, kinder side of Amish life than she thought she knew.Elam Sutter's fiance had decided to leave the Amish community and Elam after her baptism, and it broke his heart. Now he knows he must protect his heart from Katie, who has chosen the English over their faith, but thats easier said than done.This was one of the best Amish novels I'veread in a long time. It rang true to what I know about Amish culture, and there were few if any mistakes. This one was truly a joy to read!

When Letty Morgan decided to follow in her fathers footsteps and become a doctor in 1892, she had no idea that it would so hard for a woman to find patients. When it becomes clear that Philadelphia will provide no paying clients and she finds a letter from a Colorado town seeing a woman doctor for its women and children, she moves. However, trouble seems to follow her, and one newspaperman is very troubling to her heart. Yet, with grit and determination, Letty is determined to follow Gods call on her life.I found this to be a wonderful novel. I only found two minor errors - than for then and started for startled. However, I found the character development riveting, faith woven into the very core, and I loved the book.

Carli Williams was taken by surprise when a man comes up to her in the street, tips her back, and passionately kisses her, but she cant forget that kiss. Apparently, neither can he, because he keeps turning up. But Carli has more on her mind with troubles piling up and a dilapidated estate to repair as an inheritance.Ethan Durham had staged a kiss to resemble the famous one from WWII for an art class, but he never dreamed the girl and kiss would linger with him. This may just change everything, especially when he learns someone wants to harm Carli, and he vows to protect her.I wanted to like this novel more, but I just couldn't. It seemed so fragmented and had no flow. I didn't really like either of the main characters. Carli was called spunky, and she would defy Ethan and get into trouble and then fall apart. He was always smirking and being controlling. They just didn't seem to go together. The descriptions of the many rooms on the estate were lengthy, but I couldn't picture what it was talking about. Too much of the story was awkward or just didn't make sense. How could Carli unknowingly resurrect a wall around her heart, when the passage was written from her point of view? How does someone smell amber? Sentences like, The shot had contacted a set of mixing bowls, shattering glass everywhere, could have been better written. Galvons last name was Stanfield most of the time, but occasionally it was Sinclair. Spigot was spelled spicket. And these were only some of the examples. Nothing was strong in the book, not even the ending.

BE MATURE focuses on the Book of James, where he teaches about spiritual maturity, overcoming temptation, controlling the tongue, and praying effectively. Wiersbe emphasizes  Gods Word and growing your faith.This is not my favorite book by Wiersbe, because it seemed lengthy and jumped around quite a bit. But, as with all Wiersbes book, it is biblically sound and did grow my faith. Im glad I read it.

Olivia Culps family had always been in competition with Frederick Sterlings family, but he and Olivia had been childhood friends. They had drifted apart after Fredericks accident and hed taken a job at his aunt and uncles hotel, a rival of the Culp Hotel. She thinks hes too haughty and snobbish now.Frederick misses Olivias friendship, but he can do without her sharp tongue. Why does she seem to regard him with distaste now? Perhaps if he gets her interested in Andrew Jamison, he will take her away when they marry. However, Frederick doesn't suspect his scheme might just backfire.This had the skeleton of a very good story, but it never really materialized. For one thing, the novella turned into more of a short story, since it was double-spaced, and there wasn't room to develop the plot or the characters. It also had some head-hopping and an abrupt, fast ending. I expected more.

A man and his little girl help Sophie Thatcher escape an attacking duck in the park, and she cant get him out of her mind. She cant believe she feels such a strong connection after her fiance just jilted her a few months ago. Thats so unlike her, because shes never been a risk-taker. Why, she doesn't even know the mans name!Bryce Landry is on top of the country music list, but his life is crazy. Thats why hes taken a month off to spend in the quiet town where his grandparents are keeping his daughter for him. Hed only found out about Gracie a year ago, when her mother, a former friend, found out she was dying. Thats when it finally hit him how far his life had skidded downhill, and he accepted Christ as his Savior. Now hes trying to live out the Christian life amid Nashvilles music scene. Is there room for a serious relationship, or will the complexity of everything just ruin it? He knows one thing for sure. Hes never connected to anyone the way he has to Sophie.I enjoyed this novel. There were a few minor errors, like an extra, unneeded word inserted, an important word left out, or the wrong word used. Sophie tended to say the right things but feel the opposite, and I felt the ending was a little weak. However, this novel was well worth reading, and I would recommend it.

Laurie Blake comes from a privileged background, even though her parents weren't around much. Now shes come to town to open up a photography studio and prove she can be independent and make it on her own. When she mysteriously becomes one of the  victims of a string of crimes, she meets Kentucky Chandler, a handsome policeman who sends her mixed signals.Tuck Chandler likes being a police officer and feels its his calling. Yet, he still carries a ton of baggage, since his fiance broke off their engagement because of the time demands of his job and the possible dangers it entails. He has vowed never to get involved like that again, because he doesn't think his heart could take it. However, Laurie is working her way into his heart, despite what his head is telling him. Whats a soft-hearted guy to do?I truly enjoyed this novel. I loved the characters and thought it was well-written. Although there is a police mystery to be solved, that plot is not the core of the book, for this is definitely a character-driven novel - my favorite kind. I did question how Laurie knew so much about autism from just photographing children, but I really have no criticisms. This one was well worth my time!

Julie Duncan jumps at the chance to be Mr. Calahans housekeeper, because it means she can have her four-year-old-daughter with her on the job, and she can move in with her sister. Julie has only focused on her daughter, since her military husband had been killed, and part of her seemed to die too. Never in her wildest imagination did she think she might ever be drawn to Mr. Calahans grandson. But Lane seems much more ready for romance and commitment than Julie. They scare her to death.I loved the characters, and the basic plot was good, but the story drags along much too slowly. At 30%, absolutely nothing but background and mundane, everyday affairs had happened. The book desperately needs condensing and the unneeded parts that dont move the story taken out. Its 562 pages, and thats way too long. I usually read fast, but I thought I would never finish this one. Theres also some other amateurish mistakes  some head hopping, awakened for "awoke," and pored for poured twice. It did pick up some after around the 30% mark, but still parts of it read like real life, and most of thats not particularly interesting if you wrote down what someone did each day. It is Christian and clean, so that was a plus, but it had too many long-winded prayers. Overall, it had promise but needed some more work.

Emily Dwyer likes the new English teacher, Dan McBride, but he sure does complicate her life, and its already complicated enough. She has two adopted children but was never married. She has just a friend who takes her out, and a custodian, whos not even a friend, but she brings him lunch and they eat in her room every day. If thats not complex enough, something strange is going on at school.Besides being scattered with awkward sentences and a few that are grammatically incorrect, there were too many mundane and extraneous narratives at first, which made parts very boring. There were also way too many characters to keep straight and try to remember. In addition, Emily was a strange, wimpy woman, who took most of what Dan said and did wrong, especially in the beginning. She would get mad at Dan and stand up to him, but she let everyone else run all over her big time. It was unbelievable. If she hadn't been so stupid, the story would have only been about 40 pages long. The bulk of the story was based on silly misunderstandings on Emilys part, which came across as ridiculous, and, part of the plot made no sense. What man would start doing major renovations on a house before he came up with the down payment or signed the contract?  He could lose it all. However, if it had been given more time and rewritten, I think this could have been a good story. Id planned to rate it a 2, but the conclusion was well-done. If the rest of the book had been as good, it would have been outstanding.

After an evil enemy attacked Lizanne Balmaine and her brother, leaving Gilbert for dead and trying to rape her, she vowed revenge. To carry through on that, she trains with the knights and learns to fight like a man. When she finally sees the man again, she tricks him and has him chained in the dungeon. She never considered, however, that she might set off a chain of events that would affect even her hard heart.Ranuff Wardieu has no idea why the lady imprisoned him, and she wont answer his questions, but he intends to find out and enact his own revenge. Yet, the lady is adept at tricking him, because he underestimates her. One things for certain. Hes never met a woman like Lady Lizanne.I love Tamara Leighs medieval books, but I had a hard time at the start of this one. I think it was because there was so much violence, blood, and gore at the beginning, and it turned me off at first. It would have been better for me if this had come a little later, after the characters had been introduced. However, the book did become much better, and I did come to love it. I liked the way the intense misunderstanding did not continue for the entire book. If you like historical romance, you should love LADY AT ARMS.

Jen doesn't have a good relationship with her parents. In fact, theyre estranged. When her fianc breaks up with her, it just begins a horrible week. Her roommate has to move home, and Jen can no longer afford the apartment, and then Jen loses her job. If it wasn't for two new friends, she would have really been in trouble, but theyre Christian, and she doesn't know how she feels about that. She does know that Barrett seems to draw her to him.I had a hard time getting into this book. At first, there were too many modifiers in the sentences, and some of them sounded odd. Some questions raised in the novel never were answered. For example, what was the incident that her parents blamed Jen for? And the writing sounded immature. I thought the last part got a little better, but everything happened too fast, and there was little depth to the plot, characters, or story. I did appreciate the fact that it was clean and faith oriented.

Taffie Carini loves her familys candy shop, but shes not sure shes ready to take over, like her parents want. Ryan Antonelli has been helping in his fathers appliance repair business ever since his dad had a stroke last year, but he really wants to start a marketing business. When Taffie and Ryan meet, they mesh well, and their families love each other, but can they take care of the businesses at hand?I have read several books by Janice Thompson, but this one is not up to her usual high standards, like Red Like Crimson (one of the best books I've ever read) was. This novella is too sweet with no tension or conflict. Nothing disrupts or threatens the romance. Taffie needing to figure out a way to keep the candy store profitable and Ryan wanting to be in marketing instead of appliance repair did not make an interesting plot. The resolution was obvious and easy. The book was well-written but not very interesting. This Taffie version was just too sticky sweet.

The novel opened with the typical cliche of "the evil Mr. Graynger" leering at Charlotte in the orphanage and telling her she will be forced to marry him when she turns 18 in a few weeks. She and her best friend come up with a plan for Charlotte to run away and become a mail order bride. At first Charlotte has misgivings about her future husband, but, as she gets to know him, she begins to understand.Too much of the novella (it turned out to be 149 pages) never moved the story forward. There were lengthy descriptions, mundane details, and scenes with characters that had nothing to do with this plot. I did like the main characters, and there were some cute scenes that drew me in, but not enough. It was clean and interesting in places. In the end, I gave it 3.5 stars, which rounded up to a four.

Leah Morgan has had enough of trying to manage 12 children as a mothers helper in Chicago. Shes finally saved up enough money of a train ticket west. Surely she can find a better job there.Austin Wright has been writing Victoria and shes coming to marry him. His wife had died a year ago, and his young daughter needs a mother. He wasn't expecting much, since she refused to send a photograph, but the young lady who gets off the train is lovely, and he feels an instant attraction. But why does she first say shes not Victoria and then changes her mind?Leah knows it was wrong to pretend to be Victoria, but she wants to see more of this charming man. Once she begins the lies, they build, until shes locked into the deception. Austin sets such store in honesty, how can she tell him its all a lie?The story had promise, but the execution was lacking. The book didn't seem to be finished, because it was riddled with mistakes and awkward sentences. Austin owned a newspaper, so the cover doesn't go with the story or Austins description. To be a Christian, the moral issue of lying didnt seem to bother Leah much; she certainly kept it up. I wondered who was keeping the one-year old girl when Austin went back to work. As a single woman, Leah would have never been allowed to live in Jeds home by either the church or society. I found too much wrong for the book, and it needed more depth. Everything happened too quickly without any build.. It read more like a hastily written first draft, but  least it was clean.

Beautiful Kate Schuyler is engaged to marry David Spafford when she has a change of heart and runs away the night before the wedding to marry a ships captain. Thats Kate for you. David and her family are shocked and appalled. In order to save face, they come up with the plan for younger sister, Marcia, to marry David, so the plans can go forth without scandal. Since Marcia has always thought so much of David, she agrees. But when she sets up housekeeping in the home he had prepared for Kate, and his sadness doesn't go away, she begins to wonder if she did the right thing. But someone as self-centered and hard-hearted as Kate may eventually tie her own noose.The barebones of this story was charming. However, the execution was excruciating. There were too many long, drawn-out reminiscences and details that did nothing to move the story forward. I dont think the page numbers listed are correct, because I thought the story would never end. It went on and on. It would have been a good book if it had been pruned quite a bit. This is much different than the other Grace Livingstone Hill books that I've read. The basic story was sweet, but the extraneous parts bogged it down.

Les Ogden was causing hardships for landowners near Dodge, so he could buy their land for a pittance. Jackie Laughton refused to let him do that to her and her neighbors. The ranch was all she and her brother had left of their parents. She and her friend, Darcy, started using their talents to steal Less shipments of money to pay off loans to him and to help others he had cheated. Although she tries to convince herself of the good theyre doing, the guilt is still hard to control.Hoyt Travers, a Texas Ranger, comes to dodge to help his father with a move there. He hadn't planned on being so attracted to Jackie. But something doesn't add up with her, and hes worried she may know whos robbing Les Ogdens stages. He wants to protect her but doesn't know how, since she seems to want to have as little to do with Hoyt as possible.The situation with two young women fooling everyone that they were men for two years when they held up stagecoaches and trains seemed far-fetched, and I had a hard time getting into the story. There were also mistakes, like they for the, to for too. light for like, ext for next, listed for listened, and not for now.  I cant believe that Hoyt and Rance would have gone hunting in the August heat, because the meat would not have been any good. However, as I continued to read, the story and characters grew on me, so that I can say I enjoyed it.

When Lorens father had died, she and her mother had become trapped in a bad situation with a father and sons who mistreated them. Only the younger boy, Joey, whod been a baby at first, treated Loren well, especially after her mother died. When the men decided to sell Loren to a brothel, Thad met up with them and bought Loren to save her. He thought she was a dirty child but was surprised to discover she is a pretty young lady, when cleaned up.This book had a few problems. There were run-on sentences, and most of the story was told and recounted. In 1889, Loren would have been called a heroine, not a hero. There were some inconsistencies, like when Loren started a pot of chili before the funeral, but they ended up eating vegetable soup. The novel was also melodramatic with the villains too vile and some scenes too saccharine and cheesy. Then, there were misused words, like alter for altar waist for waste, isles for aisles, and happed for happened. The core of the book, however, had potential, although it could have been a much better book with a little more work.

Adrianne and Chris made a mistake in college, and when Adrianne realizes shes pregnant she drops out and returns home with only a brief note. She knows Chris plans to go into the mission field, and she loves him too much to try to change that. Chris is devastated and tries to reach her over and over, but she wont answer. He goes to Nicaragua broken-hearted. Eight years later, they meet by accident when Chris is home for his best friends wedding. Only God can orchestrate a new beginning, but, although both are still fighting feelings of guilt, they are still strong believers.I've read several of Janice Thompsons books, but this is the best one yet. The characters are so lovable, and Lorelei, their sever-year old daughter, is delightful. It is filled with deep emotion and draws the reader into the story. Faith is woven into the very core of the novel. This is exactly how I like my novels!

Sunny Tatum is having problems trusting Dante Romero after he pretends to be a customer on numerous occasions, and she later finds out hes the owner of the restaurant where she works. Her boyfriend from high school turned out to be deceitful, and she has trust issues from it. When Dantes brother tells her what a love-and-leave-em kind of womans man he is, that really raises the red flag. But she cant deny their chemistry or how he makes her feel special when shes with him. Her head is telling her no, but heart is yelling yes!Dante regrets the prank he pulled. His friends thought it would be fun to see what kind of treatment his customers really got. Who knew hed meet the girl of his dreams in the process? Hes apologized and asked forgiveness, and he doesn't know what else to do. The best thing is turn to the Lord and his newly kindled faith and keep praying.This one had fewer careless mistakes than ONE FOOT OUT THE DOOR. It did have parts that slowed down, but not many, and the ending was stronger. I gave this one 4.5 stars, which rounded up to five.

Reeking The Bailey Flanigan CollectionThis is about the third time Karen Kingsbury has disappointed me in her books. She used to be one of my favorite authors, but not any more. I'm learning to avoid her, and that's my recommendation for this series. Skip it.Leaving - 2Bailey Flanigan is still reeling from Cody declaring his love for her and then leaving without a word. What kind of love is that? She realizes her heart is broken, but she thinks she might need to move on, so she begins to accept Brandon Pauls attention. He wants more than the friendship theyd established when theyd made a movie together. But Bailey prefers Broadway to Hollywood, and shes not sure a long distance relationship will work. When she finally works up the nerve to go tell Cody good-bye, Cheyenne, the fiance of Codys best friend who was killed in Iraq, has just been in a horrific wreck and is battling for her life, and Cody has promised never to leave her.I found this book very frustrating. We see both Baileys and Codys points of views, and both declare the other is the love of their life, yet neither will do anything about it. Instead, they see other people. Cody was particularly infuriating. *Very mild possible spoiler*  -> I can see why he left when he thought Bailey was threatened by being with him, because of his mothers drug dealers threats, but when that threat passes, I didn't understand why he didn't return to Bailey. He says he doesn't feel good enough for her, but he starts seeing Cheyenne, who is just as sweet as Bailey and even more vulnerable because of her finances death. It makes no sense! The book also left everything hanging, leading into the next one. I would have really been upset if I didn't already have the next one, but Im not looking forward to more like this one.Learning - 2This one just continued with the angst. Bailey and Cody both say to themselves that the other is the love of their lives, but they do nothing about it. In fact, the chasm between them is becoming wider and both are becoming more and more interested in someone else. This is way too drawn out and frustrating. I've never read a book series quite like it. Although Karen Kingsbury is a wonderful author, this story is the pits. Perhaps, Im just getting tired of all Kingburys books being about circumstances keeping the main characters apart. In this one, however, its circumstances and the characters themselves. I prefer books where a relationship has time to develop, even though theres problems. Cody and Bailey are never together.Longing - 2This one again continues with the not getting together. In fact, Bailey is now falling for Brandon Paul and Cody has pledged himself to not leave Cheyenne, although he now realizes he loves her more like a close friend or relative. I have never seen the same plot line continue through 3 books like this with few new twists or developments. The events just seems to push Cody and Bailey father apart, but theres few new revelations. It seems Kingsbury comes up with every way possible they can think to keep themselves apart. Meanwhile, I become more and more frustrated. I sure hope I dont go through all this and discover at the end that Ive just wasted my time. As it is, these three books would have been better condensed into one.Loving - 2(May contain some spoilers) I hate it when a romance story sets the reader up for one thing to happen but it never does. I feel cheated and deceived. The first book should have opened with Brandons point of view of wanting to connect with Bailey. Then, I would have been pulling for him and felt good when the story ended. As these are written, Im disappointed, frustrated, and angry. This series is also way too long. It goes on and on and on. Relationships are on again, off again, and who knows whereI didn't even like these characters as well I usually do those in Kingsburys novels. Bailey gives the appearance of being perfect, but she seemed way too self-centered. Everything is all about her, her feelings, and what she wants. Although hes made mistakes in the past, Brandon is so perfect now that hes hard to relate to. Cody is just so mixed up and confused that he doesn't know which way to go. He tells himself one thing but acts completely different. It wasn't until the last part of LONGING that I even began to understand why he acted like he did, and this just added to the frustrations.In addition, all the books are overly sentimental and full of saccharine moments, some of which almost become cheesy. The stories are way too drawn out with unnecessary, repetitive events that did little to move the story forward. I didn't think I was ever going to get to the end, and they became a chore to read. If I didn't know who the author was, I would have never guessed Karen Kingsbury. I feel like I wasted my time here, and it took a lot of time to get through the four, frustrating books. Because of the way the story opened and is set up, I was not satisfied with the ending, although it was a happy one. It didn't make me feel happy.
