When Michelle Cottrell faces a clients tragedy in her job as a social worker, shes afraid a similar fate awaits her because of the risks Tyler takes riding bulls in the rodeo. They have a huge argument and break up. After she loses her job, however, she goes back home to Cathedral Hills. Yet, she cant shake the despair, guilt, and feeling that God has abandoned her.Tylers best friend is seriously hurt riding a bull, and, for the first time, he begins to understand Michelles side of their argument. He decides to retire and return home. Its been a year since hes seen Michelle, and he doesn't want to wait any longer. He only hopes shes willing to give him another chance, because hes suddenly realizing how important she is to him.This short novella seemed too fragmented with too many characters and their stories. Michelle and Tylers story is only one of them. This made the book seem sketchy and shallow, when it could have been so much more. Also, some of the main characters were easy to confuse, like Tyler and Trey and Michelle and Missy. Wrong words were used, such as say for saw and their for theyre.  Even with limited space, thoughts and conversations were repeated several times, and there was some head hopping. It contained incorrect grammar, like Her and my grandfather were married. And I dont know where the sentence, Inside Treys car, things were not nearly as peaceful, came from. Are we now in omniscient point of view? I had read Brooke and Peter and enjoyed it. This one was not nearly as good.

Bethann Russell had moved from Mississippi to New York City to take care of her great-aunt. When her aunt tries to match Bethann up with her attorney, Beth is skittish. However, she cant deny the attraction she feels.Judd Baxter has the goal of becoming a senior partner in the law office, and hes always put his job first. Now Berhann is changing that. When his boss tells him he must play up to a female client and keep her happy, he starts to reexamine his goals. Shouldn't his personal life and family goals be important too, and shouldn't he be putting God before everything?The novel was worth reading, but it had some minor problems. The story slowed down in places, and the dialogue was sometimes too chatty and meaningless. It was also double-spaced, which made it appeared longer. Bethann was too sensitive and hard on people, especially men, which could make her seem self-centered and uncaring at times. She was also a pretty negative person. Wrong words were often used, like they for the, to for too, light for like, and listed for listened. The ending could have been stronger, but, I did like the story.

Beth Carter was worried her young daughter might have diabetes, since her father died with it, but when she takes her in for tests, she receives the shock of her life. Blood typing reveals Stevie cannot be their child. There was a mix-up at the hospital.Jonathan McDuff cant believe the lawyers letter saying that Lexie isn't his child. When he goes to investigate, he tries to buy off the other mother, but that turns out to be a huge mistake. Beth is nothing like his deceased wife. Her child means more to her than any amount of money. The only thing he knows to do is to have her come live with him and his housekeeper as the girls nanny. At least then he can have both girls in his care. But the more he learns of Beth the more she threatens to crack the hard wall hes built around his heart after his first marriage.Although the plot seemed a bit contrived and far-fetched, it was different than any Id read before, and I liked it. I adored the characters. I didn't like the way Jonathan drew out things toward the end, but this was still a very good book. I wish the conclusion had included more than just public announcements, but it was still an okay ending. The book definitely needed a more appealing cover, but Ill be looking for more books by this author.

Audreys life has been filled with problems, but she doesnt let them get her down. She loves working at the florist and bringing people cheer. She likes her widowed pastor, Gabriel Brookson, but she knows shed never make a good pastors wife, so she tries to steer him away or at least keep everything on a friendship level.Gabe has been interested in Audrey for a while, but she seems to only want to be friends. Yet, he finds her more and more intriguing. He likes her carefree abandonment and bright disposition. Will he ever be able to get her to date him?I had a hard time getting into this book. Audrey took some getting used to, and I didn't like her very much at first. The brassy heckling, crass humor, snarky wit, and trying to pretend she could cook when she couldn't wasn't endearing. In addition, the book seemed brief and rather shallow. However, it did have some good themes about not judging and accepting who you are. Audrey did calm down a bit, and I began to like her more. It also had a very good ending, and, for me, it turned out to be a strong four but not quite a five.

As the Crown Princess of Montevaro, a small European country, Addie had little choice in how her life would play out. It had all been decided for her. Although shed been sent to the U.S. to get her degree, she had to go back home and assume the throne, marry an approved nobleman, and produce heirs.Charlie Brewers parents traveled the world as an archaeologist and anthropologist, and he often felt abandoned. He vowed he would give his daughter roots and be there for her. The fact that her mother had abandoned Lindsey was bad enough, and it had left Charlie as a teenage single parent, but hed do anything he could for his daughter. However, when Charlie meets Addie, their worlds collide. Will it leave chaos and misery or offer a remote chance for true happiness?I didn't like this novel at the beginning. There were too many inconsistencies, mistakes, characters, and points of view, which didn't make for a smooth or enjoyable read and made the story hard to follow at times. For example, Addie had honey-colored golden hair at first, but then later on, she had dark brown hair. She had warm brown eyes and then bright blue ones. Addie also never spoke using a contraction. Words were mixed up, like not was used for nod, with whoever for with whomever, and class for glass. The princess, who supposedly had perfect speech, said things like, between Jonathan and I. However, the novel became much better in the last half, and I couldn't put it down. I turned into a beautiful love story, full of tension but hope. The ending was very well-done, and could give it no less than 5 stars.

Zoe Griffin had always wanted to be a chef. Yet, she gave up the job she loved, cooking in a five star restaurant, when she found her fianc and best friend kissing. Now they were getting married and she couldn't stay in the same town with them. A bed and breakfast wouldn't be as good, but it was a job, and she could do some cooking. However, the owner of the B & B, Nick Jackson, is making the position look a whole lot better. He was kind and protective, and that looked especially good to Zoe after her rough childhood.Nick wasn't too sure of Zoe at first, but she quickly proved herself indispensable. His wife had died two years ago. He hadn't even know she was sick until it was too late, and he was a doctor. He couldn't practice medicine again after that, so he bought the B & B.I wasn't too sure about this book at first, because it moved rather slowly. In the end, however, I appreciated that about Nick and Zoe. It turned out to be a sweet change of pace that got better and better, and I gave it 4.5 stars, which rounded up to five.

When Brooke Jameson had a chance at a modeling career right out of high school, she took it. Little did she know her agents were leading her down a dark path. And, when she does find out and goes to the DAs office, the lawyer shes sent to betrays her in an even worse way. Now shes a prisoner in her own home and doesn't know how to escape.Peter Nash had been in love with Brooke since high school, but when she wanted to model, he told her he would wait for her. He didn't want her to have any regrets about marrying him. However, hed never imagined that shed be gone for six years. After she tries to call her brother but doesn't find him at home, Peter agrees to go to New York and find her. He finds a sick, broken women, whos been given drugs to keep her cooperative. Can he get her away and help her find healing?For such a short novella, I enjoyed this story. It was hard to believe theres an escort service where men pay to have their picture taken with the woman. Most of these men likely had families and would not want their picture taken with a young, beautiful woman. Yet, despite this, I liked the characters and how the issues were resolved. The glowing descriptions of Cathedral Hills were a little over the top, too, but overall this was a mesmerizing read.

Summer Grants life had never been easy. She never knew her parents and the woman she considered her mother abandoned her when she was three. Summer thought she had found a small town where she might be happy, but the activity bus she was driving was involved in an accident resulting in many injuries, and a student she cared for dead. The accident was ruled the other drivers fault, but Summer still has a hard time forgiving herself, and she certainly cant forget what happened. When the boys father begins threatening her, she leaves, intending to go to a city in Ohio. However, shes involved in another accident on the way and has to stay there until her broken leg mends.Jake Taylors marriage was rough, even before his wifes car went off the side of a mountain along with the baby he didn't know they were having. Both were killed. When he hits a young womans car, hes relieved she isn't hurt more severely, but hes determined to take care of her until she recovers. As he gets to know her, hed like to take care of her forever, but the man threatening her just may have other plans.This was an excellent book. The characters had depth and were very realistic. Although the plot had a lot of traffic accidents, it still held my interest. I didn't really find much wrong with the novel, and I easily gave it five stars.

When Cassie Golden is left alone at the Pennsylvania farm during the Civil War, she rents it out and moves to Alexandria, Virginia to become a nurse in a military hospital. She meets Major Michael Bryon, and, despite her reluctance, she falls in love. However, there are parts about Michaels service that he cant share, and she soon finds herself kidnapped and taken to a Confederate prison. Michael finds her, but now she learns hes lied to her and is really a Confederate. Her life becomes filled with threats from the unscrupulous, espionage, and harsh prison life. Still, Michael tries to make sure she has what she needs. As the war drags on, she begins to realize shes been wrong about a lot of things.Two of the worst things with this book were the many technical medical terms used and the occasional too many details that bogged the story down. There were a lot of other questionable things, like the use of a thermometer to take temperatures, which was almost never used during the Civil War. Cassie also went everywhere with Michael without a chaperone, even an all day excursion in the woods and time at his home. Mid-eighteen hundreds society would have never allowed such behavior. Banana cream pie likely originated in the Midwest, but not until several years after the Civil War. There was also some modern slang, like some digs, meaning a nice house. At first, after Cassie intentionally spilled a glass of water in Michaels lap just to show him she could, I didnt like her very much. What an immature, selfish, uncaring thing to do! Also I cant imagine a lawyer would call a witness to the stand without interviewing him first the way Davis did.Despite these problems and inconsistencies, on the whole, this was a well-written book that pulled me in. I dont usually like novels written in first person, but it did work better for this one. I had the surprise at the end figured out before half the book was over, but that didnt detract from the story. In fact, I think it made it better for me. This is a unique glimpse at the Civil War from a different perspective, and I enjoyed the novel.

When her father decides to remarry, Millie Pritchett moves to Prescott to start a new life, but shes afraid that will never include a husband. She lost that chance with a poor decision she made years ago, and no man will ever want her when he learns her secret. When she starts working at the boarding house, however, her hope begins to grow again, when she realizes Paul might just change everything.Paul Lancaster has had to deal with one problem after another lately. The one bright spot is his new housekeeper. Hes never met a woman he likes more of is more attracted to. She makes him dream of a family with a happy-ever-after.I liked this story and felt it was stronger than the other Prescott novels, but it still had a few problems. There were a few wrong words used and a lot of nominative case pronouns where and objective one was needed. Some examples are: Let Benjamin and I, she taught both Millie and I, let Mabel and I know, and for Millie and I. Although there is a good ending, some problems were never resolved, like with Jake. I still enjoyed the story, however.

Amelia Smiths family is wealthy. Her father is a businessman from a high-society family, and her mother owns a brothel. She returns from finishing school in Switzerland to find her parents had been killed in an accident. The will requests that Amelia sell the Boston house and move to San Francisco to run her fathers gold mine. She must also marry within a year.Ben Abbot grew up in a big family with wild brothers. His first job as a Pinkerton agent is to find Amelia Smith for a man claiming to be her half-brother. After secretly following Amelia around for a few days, he falls in love with her, but she already has a fianc.So begins a very hard-to-believe plot. There was so much wrong with this short novella that I dont know where to start. First of all, many parts just didn't add up. In 1860 Boston, a madam of a brothel would not have been accepted in society. Amelias parents will made little sense, and no reason was given for the odd requirements. Why didn't Ben find Jonathan, the supposed half-brother, after the man rushed ahead to meet Amelia when hed agreed to wait for Ben to go with him? If Jonathan couldn't find Amelia (who wasn't trying to hide) on his own, how did he gather information on her fianc that Alfred was trying to keep hidden? I dont think Amelia would have been drinking whiskey with company in 1860, especially since she was running a finishing school for girls. I was surprised Ben asked her out, when he believed her to be engaged. It would be difficult to skip rocks on the ocean like Ben did. The story was not well-written. It used no contractions, which made it stilted. At least 90% of it was told after events had already happened, and the recounting became boring and tedious. Some of the characters thoughts were repeated over and over again, and all of them seemed very self-centered. The main conflict just disappears with no resolution. Wrong words were used, such as exposure for composure and ground for floor. Modern language was also used, like they were an item, hadn't  seen that coming, and complete turn on. Tuxedos weren't worn until about 1900 either. The book had so many unanswered questions, plot points that didn't make sense, and poor writing that I felt it was a total waste of my time. I really thought that it would have some redeeming parts near the end, but it didn't It did have a happy ending, but even that ended up being told rather than shown and was too saccharine. In addition, the modern cover didn't go with the story. Amelia did not dress like a cowgirl!

Branson, Missouri, is s bustling place during tourist season, but thats how the members of the Fleming family make their living. They own Illusions Theater, where they put on family friendly shows. Heather Fleming is a musician, ventriloquist, and secretary. Her best friend, Shannon, was blinded in a car accident and works there too. When police officer, Gage Cassidy comes to the theater to investigate a credit card skimming theft, Heathers world is turned upside down.Gage finds himself drawn to Heather, but at first hes afraid she might be involved in the theft. Why do relationships have to be so difficult and confusing? He realizes he needs to turn back to God and trust Him to work things out.I found the romance to be good, although theres not much mystery. However, the theft does help keep the tension going in the story. There were a few minor mistakes -- some awkward sentences and some wrong words used, like set for seat, Hather for Heather, and him for her. The worst error for me was when the narrative suddenly switched to omnipotent point-of-view by saying, Neither of them noticed Mona. It may not have been a gripping novel, but I did like the characters and enjoyed the story, so I gave it 4.5 stars, which rounded up to a 5.

Ruthy MacNeil had been taken in by the neighboring family when her parents died, but they expected her to do all the work while they berated her. Their son wanted to take advantage of her, and his parents decided they would marry. Even when they decided to head west, her future looked bleak. However all of them where drowned in a flooding river, and Ruthy almost lost her life as well. A cowboy bent on revenge came along to save her and ends up sweeping her away just a much as that raging river.Luke Stone had been away fighting in the Civil War and ended up in Andersonville. Even after the war, he found it easier to stay away than to fight with his father. However, a man murdered his father and stole the ranch, and Luke is determined to get it back. He has the deed, so the legal system is own his side. So are his former friends from Andersonville. When he finds Ruthy half-drowned, out in the middle of nowhere, he has little choice but to take her with him. She turns out to be the prettiest, most capable woman hes ever met.There was a few minor discrepancies, but, overall, this was a good, interesting story. It was a bit melodramatic, but I still enjoyed it. This one was so much better than Out of Control by the same author.

Her mother was ruining her life with alcohol, drugs, and prostitution. Renee Winters hated it, and she made a vow to God to never be like that. The one person who seems to understand her is Ian McKnight. Even though others said he was no good, Ian had always been good to her. When she runs from her trailer after one of her mothers men tries to come on to her, Ian saves her and takes her to a motel. When he wants to leave, she asks him to stay again and again. She feels so alone and just wants to be loved. When she wakes alone, shes crushed by what shes done, and she vows again never to let a man near her again until he proposes. Shell work hard to make up for her one slip.Ian knows Renee will hate what they did when she awakes. He stands watching her sleep, knowing he will never see her that peaceful again. He cant bear to see the hurt, regret, and hate in her eyes, so he leaves and joins the army. Years later, he returns hoping to make things right with the only girl hes ever loved, but shes determined not to give him a chance. And, worse yet, she sees their love and the sparks between them as dirty. He can only pray that God will take control, straighten out the mess they've made and ease her anger at her mom and him.This is an exceptional bookwithout a doubt the best one I've read in a long time and maybe even ever. Its so charged with emotion that its almost gut-wrenching at times. However, its also wonderful, strong, deep, and unforgettable. Its message is crucially important and one that needs to be heard, whether people are judging themselves or others. This is the second book I've read by Michelle Lynn Brown, and both have been excellent.

Melyn Winter had been deeply in love with her husband, but Danny died in a car wreck two years ago, and she blamed God for taking him. Her adult children decide she should get out, and they set her up with a blind date disguised as a business meeting. When Brian Capwell shows up at her door, however, Mel is pleasantly surprised, and the date goes well. However, her old lover from years ago shows up about the same time and she has a quick fling with him.Brian was taken with Melyn the first time he laid eyes on her. However, he has a new-found Christian faith and wants to end his old lifestyle of meaningless affairs. He also wants to be careful with his heart after his cheating ex-wife left and divorced him five years ago. Can he trust Melyn like he wants to?I didn't like the main characters here as much as I usually do. Melyn was too confused and seems only interested in sex through most of the book. Brian falls in love with her at first sight, but it seems to all be based on her looks. I couldn't accept that Brian believed whatever Melyn told him every time he saw her with another man, since he had trust issues. They both seemed to be secretive, hid what they really thought and felt, and had a series of misunderstandings because they didn't communicate. Since the novella was double-spaced, it was really much shorter than what I thought, and it didn't have much development or depth. It could have been much better if it had been expanded some.

Lindsey Solberg had been away for years, first training to be a chef and then establishing herself as a good one. But when her mother dies, she goes home to be there for her sixteen-year-old sister. However, she never expected that Nick Harrison would also be back. He had been the top dog in high school and broke her heart by pretending to like her and then dropping her. Now hes a youth pastor, no less. She cant believe hes changed that much.Nick has changed, and Christ changed him. He regrets the conceited jerk he was in high school, but hes never been able to get Lindsey from his mind. Now he wants to show her how precious she is to him and how much hes a different man. Will she give him a second chance?This was a cute story but it moved too quickly. Lindsey and Nick were passionately kissing over and over again on the first date. The whole relationship only took about five or six weeks. I thought Lindsey was a little too wrapped up in herself and her feelings, although she was considerate of her sister. Still, I liked the novella.

When the Thoresen family immigrates to Nebraska from Norway, they come with more than most for their new start, but they dont speak English. Even with their supplies, the prairie isn't an easy place to live. The sod has grassroots a foot deep, which makes plowing difficult; all kinds of storms blast the land; drought is always threatening; and locusts can devastate everything. Amid this environment, tragedy is bound to hit.I liked the plot and the characters, especially Jan. However, most of the story was told and not shown, so, instead of becoming involved with what was happening, I stood on the outside observing. With so much head-hopping and rapid changes in point of views, it was almost dizzying, especially in the first half of the book. It was over-packed with too many minute details, like several lists of what they brought and what they bought. At times it wandered all over the place. For example, Soren was talking to a neighbor, it was not following his point of view, there was no one around to hear them, but we see and hear their conversation. In addition, I doubt the ladies would have been canning in the remote Nebraska location in 1866. They also knew a lot about disinfecting and boiling to sterilize. It was first published as LAND OF DUST AND TEARS. This book had a lot of potential, but I didn't find it quite as good as A ROSE BLOOMS TWICE. For one thing, the ending was very weak. It basically just ended without much of a conclusion at all.

Ginny Porter had always done what was expected of her and was known as a good girl, but she was nave and wanted to please, so she fell victim to the first smooth talking guy when she went to college. She came home pregnant, and her parents went ballistic. With their help, she managed to finish college, but then she took her daughter and ran, trying to establish a new life for them away from her controlling mother. She goes to tutor a young boy on a farm in Idaho, and she marvels at the family life there. But somehow, trouble still finds her, and she has to learn to fight for whats important to her. The thing is, Dallas Reid, her boss, is becoming one of those important things.This was a lovely story of learning to forgive. There were a few mistakes but nothing major. Points of view were switched without a break or any way of noting it. Wrong words were occasionally used, like along for alone and opening for openly. There were also a few very awkward sentences, but it book was still quite readable. I thought Dallas figured out what was going on a little too quickly and the ending could have been stronger, but I liked the characters and the slow building of relationships. All in all, it was a very enjoyable story.

Chloe Thibideaux has flunked out of college again. Hey, shes more interested in partying and the social side of things than the academics. Her parents decide to take away her credit cards and car and make her stand on her own. At twenty, they think its about time she learned some responsibility. When Chloe goes to stay with her brother and sister-in-law, she has no idea how much her life will change, and Stephen Hayes, their pastor and friend, will be a big part of that.I found this to be a well-written book that was hard to put downone of those that will stick with me for a long time. Despite Chloes immaturity and bad decisions at first, shes very likable, and Stephen is wonderful. It was interesting to see how Chloe slowly changes over time. The two things I didn't like about the book was the crass language (not profanity, though) throughout the book. I wished this had changed, too. Also, there were strange question marks in the middle of sentences that broke it in two parts. This had to have been a scanning error, but I cant imagine why they weren't proofed and corrected.

Debbie Carmichael wants to take the stress off her father after he had a heart attack, and she works hard to help out in their Laguna Beach soda shop . She also wants to hold a benefit to help pay off the mortgage, and teen star, Bobby Conrad, would be just the person to do that. But when Bobby has scheduling problems and has to cancel, the new guy, Johnny Hartman, agrees to take over. Although Debbie is disappointed at first, she soon realizes shes underestimated Johnny on several levels.Johnny is a pastors son from Kansas who just loves to sing. Hes determined to stay true to his faith, even in Hollywood. Maybe God had brought him here to find Debbie and show some others what they are missing if they dont have faith. He just hopes Debbies focus will move from Bobby Conrad to him.I thought this book had somewhat of a slow start, but when it started rolling, it really took off, and I could hardly put it down. At first there seemed a lot of filler geared toward the reader and not the story. For example, the family laments that gas prices might reach 50 cents a gallon and stamps 5 cents. Yet, this turned out to be one of the sweetest love stories I've read in a long time, and its very well done. I think it would be appropriate for anyone and not just young adults. I loved it.

Dorrie Miller likes her job okay, but what she really wants to be is a writer. If she could publish like Mya Elizabeth Linscott, her dream would've come true. Of course, a hunky husband and family would be nice too. But Dorrie has never seemed to be good enough for any of the men shed dated or for her father either.Jermiah Jacobs has just moved into town and joined the writers group there. Hes wowed by their leader, Dorrie Miller, but, after his wife left him, hes vowed never to remarry, although hes a widower now. One broken heart was one too many. Besides, he has secrets he cant divulge. But when they end up driving to a writers conference together, the attraction grows.How to rate this book? The first half had a few parts I really liked, but most of it had scattered scenes and the characters thoughts that were too detailed, often silly, and usually boring. It went on and on with every thought and every movement described. Dorrie over- thinks everything, and its just too long and drawn out. When Dorrie and Jeremiah start to the writers conference it gets a bit more interesting, but the plot breaks down. I couldn't accept the fake wedding scenario, and this was crucial to everything that happens. It just didn't make any sense to me from the very beginning, and the way it played out didn't change that opinion. The last part of the novel did get much better, but I couldn't understand why Dorrie didn't fall in love with Jeremiah right away, since he seemed almost perfect. There were a number of wrong words throughout the book, too. It would have been a stretch for me to rate the first part of the book a 2. I bordered on hating it, and did hate parts. The ending was definitely a 5. After much deliberation, I went with a 3. Although the last part was redeeming, the first part was just too hard to wade through. If it had been edited better, it could have easily been a five. And, with 363 pages, there was plenty of room to cut out some of the cumbersome details.

When Willas brother and friend decide the friend should marry her, since she had no prospects, Willa doesn't know what to do. Like all young women, she wanted more than a humdrum marriage. She decides to kiss Daniel to see if there might be a spark. She spots him in the garden and pulls off her thick glasses before she approaches him. When they kiss, a fire ignites between them. Then, she discovers its not Daniel but his prodigal brother, Alex. Her Aunt Honore comes to whisk her off to London, and thus begins a wild adventure.I had read the first in the series, Lady Fiasco, and found it entertaining, but this one was even better. Much of the weaknesses Id found in the first one had been corrected here. The humor was better, Honore wasn'tt quite so outlandish or risqu, and there's even less of the mild curse words--only six in the book. There are no sex scenes in either of them. I found this one very amusing and quite enjoyable.

Hetty grew up in the town orphanage, and the beratings she suffered daily left her feeling worthless. Even when she goes to work as a housekeeper at a ranch with a family she adores, she runs thinking she didn't deserve such a great family.Isaac Wheeler has a secret thats eating away at him. Hes promised himself he will never marry, but hed never planned to meet someone like Hetty. She almost renews his faith in women--almost.I really liked this novel in the beginning. There was some head hopping and wrong words used, and Isaac first had brown eyes and then blue. Hetty's irrational feeling that she didn't deserve anything good went on for too long and seemed too severe for the circumstances. I overlooked it until she ran back to the orphanage to work. From that point on, things became too unbelievable for me. There was no reason for Isaac not to go find her and set her straight, especially after his family situation got better. I couldn't believe that Hetty stayed washing mounds of laundry at the orphanage and being constantly scolded, when shed had some good news and could have left at any time. And, having a party after a devastating fire was ludicrous. My rating plummeted from a five to a three, but the ending was better, and it rose again to a four.

Caitlin Harrington moves into her deceased grandmothers house in a small town and away from Boston. Shed lost her teaching job there and she needed to escape a demanding boyfriend who wasn't nearly as nice as hed seemed at first. She should have stuck with her original plan and never dated. Her parents nasty divorce should have taught her that lesson. Now Sean Taggart, a local fireman, is inching himself into her heart, but someone is trying to tear them apart permanently.I liked the first part of the book. There were too many unnecessary and unimportant details, but I liked Caitlin and Sean. As the story developed, however, parts of it just didn't make sense. The misunderstandings and second-guessing went on for too long. One of the main characters seemed to be two completely different people in the last half, and I didn't like his intense insecurities, which made him so different from the competent person he was to begin with. And I couldn't conceive that Caitlin wouldn't recognize something about a guy shed dated for a good while, even if he was disguised. He didn't disguise his voice. It might have worked for someone she didn't see that often, but not otherwise. However, the last part of the book was hard for me to wade through. The climatic scene was too drawn-out, telling every little move and minute detail. It went on and on, and I thought it would never end. What should have been exciting became very boring. And when the action was over, the story continued with more misunderstandings and misgivings. It would have been a good book, if it had been tightened up. As it was, it seemed to take way too long. At least it was clean, and that was a plus.

ROMANS  Julia lives in Pompeii with her family, but her life is about to change in ways shed never imagined. She meets Marcus, a man she could actually be interested in, instead of the disgusting fish merchant, Brutus, who is as evil as he is smelly and dirty. Then, hot ash and rocks start raining from the sky in a terror no one had ever seen before.This could have been an excellent story, but it was too short and skimpy. All the Bible verses were good, but that meant there was even less to Julias story. It was more like a short story. The first chapter gave too much away, and should not have been pulled out of order, with the rest backtracking.CORINTAINS  Julia finds Paula in Corinth after the upheaval in Pompeii, but Tiros parents wont let them married, because they think Paula is just a servant. Drusilla, a harsh, unscrupulous woman, has her sights set on Tiro, much to his dismay, and his mother supports Drusilla. However, Julia is about to reveal a secret her mother has kept about Paula. Will it hurt or help the couple, and how will it all play out?This one had many of the same problems as the first one. Again, it would have been better if the first chapter had not been pulled out of order, because it gave too much of the story away at the very beginning. I liked these characters, but the story was so short, nothing was well-developed. The modern language seemed very out of place, regardless of how the author tried to rationalize it in her notes. One example is dressed to the nines. This one also had several unnecessary commas, it talked about things like the tired wooden wall of the ship, had Paula for Julia once, and used terms like err face and err nose over and over. I finally guessed it meant e-r-r, like a groan.EPHESIANS   Julia is eager to find her sister Lucy, whom she hasn't seen in the two years since Pompeii. When they find her, shes upset that she hasn't heard from Quintus who promised her hed find her when she fled the burning city. Julia and Marcus take her to Ephesus, where Quintus has established his home. But when they get there, Quintus is engaged to Lady Livinia. Yet, he still looks at Lucy the way he always did, with love. Whats going on? Quintus offers no explanation, except hes betrothed.All these stories have minor mistakes, This one had Ephesus for Miletus, Marcus for Quintus, and mixed up phrases, like visitors had frequently gotten got lost. There were some awkward sentences, such as she could think of not one good reason. Engagement rings did not usually have stones in them until after 1476, but all the ones in these stories did. Besides being short and shallow, this book also had a huge gap in the plot. It seemed implausible that Quintus didn't tell Livinia who Lucy was when she showed up and ask permission to tell Lucy the truth. Although this story pulled me in more than the others,the plot ans characters seemed even thinner.Although each story had promise, they needed more, and came up lacking on many levels. Still, they had some merit, so I gave the collection a 3.5, which rounded up to a four.

Sky Fischer's friend at work set her up with a pretend boyfriend to make the guy back home jealous and hopefully notice her when she goes there to celebrate the Fourth with her family. Brody Boone seems to know a lot more about her than she does about him. Although their offices are close at the bank, she's rarely been aware of him. As the weekend progresses there's drama with her brothers, and she begins to gradually wonder how much Kevin has changed from the person she knew and fell in love with. He doesn't even seem like the same person most of the time. And Boone somehow manages to do all the right things, despite the hard times he's gone through growing up. This may just be the most interesting Fourth of July ever.I really got into this book and had a hard time putting it down. It was extremely well done until I got to the end. The ending was okay, and there was a HEA, but it was weak and I wanted more. With a strong ending, it would have knocked it out of the park. Still, the rest was so good it deserved at least a 4.5, which would have rounded up to a five anyway.

Ashlynn Peters had just been dumped by the boyfriend she thought might be the one. They had only been dating a couple of months, but things had looked promising. Then, he broke it off with a text message! So, when Jeremy Adams walks into the jewelry shop where she works, she's glad to see the man that shed had a crush on years ago, before he moved away. Everything is going great, until she learns of his checkered pass where women were concerned. Shes saved herself for marriage, so this hits her hard.There was a lot good about this book, especially the life and faith lessons, but there were some problems, too. Head hopping was a major issue, because it went back and forth between different points of view so often. So much time was skipped in places it left the reader feeling as if they were missing out on too much of the story. For the first 60% of my kindle edition, there was a lot of thinking and second-guessing but little to no conflict. The tension picked up between 60% and 75% but then fell off again, and everything was resolved. The last part just tied everything up. I did like the book, but it could have been much better with just a little more work.

Margaret Kassmel jumped with excitement. She'd been accepted on a luxury cruise liner as a dance instructor. She'd teach 2 hours a day and then be free to enjoy the vacation of a lifetime, something her waitress pay would never allow. A handsome CEO makes her cruise experience a dream come true, However, an important secret hes kept sends all those dreams spinning into one horrible nightmare.This story started off to be really good, but it went downhill fast and became downright cheesy. After knowing Dominic for 3 days, she was wanting to invite him to her room for the night, and in 5 days, they were sleeping together every night. The reviewer that said it was a nice, clean, romantic story must not have read it. Their sex was described very explicitly. The ending was so predictable and sugary that it left a sickening feeling. And, for those of you who are bothered by language, there was about 50 times in 101 pages, including 14 times of taking God's name in vain. I wish I'd skipped this one.

Amelia Stalwood's guardian had sent her to his London house when she was eleven, while he stayed in the country. She'd grown up with only servants and her governess/companion as friends. When she accidentally meets Anthony, the Marquis of Raebourne, a man with a rakish reputation, she soon realizes he's changed his ways. His friends, the Hawthornes, adopt her into their family, but jealous women stir up trouble. Despite the wrongs done to her, Amelia is determined to let God's grace shine through.I thought this novella was better developed than most. At first Amelia;s ineptness seemed overdone, and, near the end, her loving reactions to malice was too perfect, but overall I enjoyed it a lot.

When her stepmother died in childbirth, Hannah Dandridge's father could no longer stand to stay in Vicksburg, Mississippi. He forces Hannah to end her engagement and move with him to Texas, so she can care for her young brother and infant sister. She soon sees that her father is a harder, more bitter man than he had been, but she loves him and knows he loves her. When he comes up missing, she worries about what she'll do if he doesn't come home. Horace Locklear wants to marry her, but he's much older, and she doesn't care for him. With the war still raging and the Comanche on the warpath, it seems a mixed blessing when William Barnett returns. It had been his ranch before the Confederates confiscated it and awarded it to her father, but he appears to be an honorable man, despite his service in the Union Army. In fact, he proves quite helpful in many ways, but her future seems even more uncertain.I enjoyed this story, although sometimes I questioned its execution. There were lots of  questionable material. For example, the family was eating burritos, but the first documented one came in 1922, and this was 1863. They wouldn't have called God you in their prayers but Thee and Thou. It was stretching things to have Hannah home canning in the Texas frontier in 1863, when the process was just catching on. Why would Hannah have put an Indian in danger to send a letter back to the ranch when she knew Juanita and Berto couldn't read English, and the children didn't read well enough? In the 1800s the Commanche did not dig graves and bury their possessions with the dead. They wrapped the body in a blanket, rode off and deposited it in a cave or crevice if possible, and covered it with stones. Then, all the possessions were burned. People didn't drill wells for water then either. Wells were either dug or driven. Since Hannah had come to dislike Lockhart so much, I couldn't understand why she invited him to go to Dallas with her and the children. There was even an omniscient statement, very unusual for such a well-know authors book. However, I still liked the book and was glad I read it.

Jade Millers main goal right now was to be the mother her son needs. After all, shes all he has. She refuses to date because of this, and, after Lukes father ran off, she doesnt need that kind of drama and heartache. When she witnesses a murder, however, shes put into protection until the trial, and Gavin Emerson, her protector, threatens that resolve.Gavin has been the black sheep of the family, and some of his choices have been downright wrong. Hes used women for moments of pleasure and worked for Vegas crime bosses, but hes finally got his life on a better path. Still, he would have said marriage and a wife was the last thing he needed, until he met Jade. Will he be able to keep her and Luke safe, and can she see him as the changed man he is. She certainly makes him want to be an even better one.I liked his plot and story better than the others in the series, but I didnt like the main characters as much. Jade and Gavin are grittier and pushier. Arent I going to get a little more than that? is the only grammatical mistake I saw. However there were over 40 mild curse words, if that bothers you.

All four adults carried heavy baggage. Maureen Chandler believed a mans lies and, as an unwed mother, ended up placing her baby up for adoption. David McMillan had lost his beloved wife 2 years ago and now regrets that he let his career interfere with family time. Claire Summer had a husband who left her after cheating on her for years, and shes now a single mother struggling to make ends meet and having trust issues where men are concerned. Keith Watson was taken from a drug-addicted teenage mother when he was three, and, although he had great adoptive parents, he has self-concept problems and a need to prove himself. Claire Summerss daughter wrote a simple letter wanting a philanthropist to help find the son her neighbor had given up. Who knew it would bring unexpected results and draw people together in unexpected ways?This was a wonderful book filled with second chances and important truths. God uses one simple letter to work miracles in so many lives. Its an uplifting story thats sure to bring many smiles.

Miranda Woodruff loves her home construction television show. The bad part was that shed taped the first season right before her planned wedding, so she talked about Robbie as if they were already married, because she knew they would be by the time they aired. But Robbie left her with just a brief note and disappeared. The director and producer insisted she keep up the ruse. When her ratings start to dip, they bring in a guy to play her husband just as shes meeting a man she could really fall for. When he turns out to be a reporter, things really get complicated.I thought the book started off a little shaky with abrupt changes of scenes coming too often. There seemed to be lengthy descriptions of objects but few about the people. And, Cee acted more like a four-year-old than a girl of nine at first. This changed, however, and the novel became riveting. The characters were well-fleshed out, had plenty of strengths and weaknesses, and were very realistic. Matthew was especially well-done. However, the ending was too quick to have such a long huge build-up. Still, the book was plenty strong enough to warrant a five.

Rachel Branigans step-cousin raped her 3 years ago, but when she became pregnant, he and his father told the town she was just a loose woman who seduced men. She was asked not to come back to church until she repented. Now theres a new preacher in town, and hes different. As Rachel and Reverend Caleb Stone become interested in each other, will the situation change, or will Rachel just impede Calebs ministry? Caleb also has a past that threatens to cause problems.I liked this plot, but the execution was rather simplistic. There was something very juvenile about the two main characters, especially Rachel. There were constant point of view changes without any separation and a few grammatical mistakes, like between she and Caleb.  The cover certainly didnt go with the story, because Rachel had very dark hair. I still liked the book. It was a quick, clean story that had important truths.

Heather Tornsten has never been a risk-taken; her brother got all of those genes. When her brother dies sky diving, her aversion to danger got worse. However, when she and his mother manipulate Wyatt Lawrence into emceeing a gala fund-raiser at the art museum, she cant deny the attraction, but she cant put herself through the heartache shes felt at losing someone she cared for again.Wyatt almost falls in love with Heather at first sight, but shes skittish. She almost bolts when she sees a video of him riding a bull. When she comes to an event where hes almost trampled, hes afraid hes lost her forever. How can he show her their love is worth any risk?I enjoyed this plot and the characters. The title was woven into the story nicely, and it was a clean read, But I didnt expect it to end so quickly. It felt like half a book, and the ending, if you could call it that, was definitely rushed. You see, the story ended at 47%, and the rest is made up of a few chapters from three other books and ads for other books from Redbud Press. I wouldnt even call 79 pages a good novella - more like a short story. It took me about an hour to read. It felt as if the author, for whatever reason, stopped before she finished. I gave it 2.5 stars, which rounded up to a 3.

Laurette Martels college roommate had talked her into going to Sitka and working for Southeast Alaska Maritime catering to the cruise ships. But then the roommate couldnt go because of family illness, so Laurette ends up going alone. At first her co-worker, Ryan Nichols, seems sullen, but as they get to know each other better, he seems happier. Laurette finds a room with an elderly woman with failing memory, and although she loves her, this adds more stress and worry.Ryan has never met anyone as special as Laurette. It makes him happy to just be around her, but what does he have to offer? He lives in a small trailer and only has a job during the summer months, when the cruise ships are in port. He even lost most of his faith when his mother remarried. Yet, as his feelings for Laurette grow, he begins to understand his mother better.This was a very sweet, uncomplicated story. All conflicts come from the weather or other people, and not from Laurette and Ryan. Laurette is perfect, without a single flaw, and it made her seem unrealistic and flat. I looked on what was happening, as I read the book, but I was never pulled into the story. Therefore, the book was somewhat one dimensional, too. It was clean, sweet, and had a few humorous lines, however. I dont regret reading it.

Rebecca Butler spent a summer Salzburg, Austria. From the moment she was greeted by Khalil Khoury's melodic tenor, she began falling in love with him. But he is studying to be a Jesuit priest, and his ordination is next year. When he begins to feel the same emotions, he tells himself he can love Rebecca in a platonic way and still become a priest, but the more time he spends with her, the more she consumes his thoughts. It is a magical time for both of them, but it begins a time of inner struggles beyond belief.The butterfly and the snail that the couple discover on the way up a mountain holds a lot of meaning. Rebecca is the butterfly and Khalil is the snail. What does the future hold for two creatures who are so different, yet so very much alike?There were parts of this book I loved, but I didnt love the chapters and chapters that flashbacked to their childhood. These sections were told and not shown, as the character recounted what had happened. It would have been better if these chapters had pulled the reader into the action by transporting them to that time, instead of just telling about it. If it was going to recount the stories, they should have been condensed, so they gave enough to develop the character, but didn't become so boring. Also contractions were often used in an odd way to end a sentence, for example, I love you for who your're instead of you are. This was done with various contractions over and over again. It also ended rather abruptly, although it did have an ending. I just wanted to see more of how it unfolded.That being said, I loved the opening chapter and the chapters involving Rebecca and Khalil. The writing depicts their love, emotions, and struggles beautifully, in a distinctly special way. I could see how Khalil's love for Rebecca brought him closer to God, because reading about it brought me closer to Christ. Those chapters were not just a good read; they were an experience.

Nori Kelly would love to marry and have a family, but, as the years tick away, that looked less and less likely. Right now, she'd just settle for a boyfriend or a date. She's only a little overweight, and she runs a successful business, so what's wrong with her? She's never even been kissed.Zachary Martin has always felt different. With an I.Q. of 160, he's never fit in, because others see him as too much of a geek or nerd, and he's always been awkward in social situations. He's been interested in his neighbor since the first time he saw her, but he's always so nervous around Nori that he acts foolish. How can he ever get her to see him in a positive way?This is a cute novel of two misfits who need each other, although Nori doesnt know it. I enjoyed their story. It was both different and heart-warming.

When David loses his sight in a mining accident, he pushes everyone away in fear. He's so afraid he'll never be any use to anyone, especially his beautiful fianc. What would she want with a blind husband she has to take care of?Karen goes along with David's mother plan to force him to marry her, but David seems to resent her all the more. When the situation goes from bad to worse, they both despair. Will they ever be able to work out their misunderstandings? Will their once strong love be enough to bring them together again?This ended up being a quick, interesting story, but David's bad mood went on for too long, and it became old and depressing. The novel got better toward the end, but the ending was abrupt and not developed as much as I would have liked. It is still well worth reading, however.

Marc Thompson had only been married for six weeks to the woman he adored. Then, Natalie fell down the basement steps and was rushed to the hospital unconscious. After agonizing hours of waiting, he learns she will be okay physically, but she has lost all recent memory and doesn't know who he is. On top of all this, they find out she is pregnant. Thus begins a long, difficult journey. Can he get Natalie to fall in love with him all over again? Things progress much too slowly for Marc, especially after Natalie moves out of their house. But her friends at TeamWork put together a camp to help the couple reconnect and in the process they learn some important lessons of faith.I loved Marc and sympathized with Natalie. The book was overly sweet, sentimental, and sappy in places, but it was still very good and hard to put down. Any romantic will enjoy this read.

A tragedy in his youth had left Luke Morgan a scarred man. When his sister died leaving him custody of her sixteen-year-old daughter, he wanted to protect and care for her, but he was unsure of just how to go about it. Finally, Emma Darby, Ruth's teacher, steps in to help, but she may cause even more problems for his heart. Just when he thinks things are looking up, Ruth and her boyfriend start repeating the same mistakes Luke made, and it terrifies him.This was a very good novel. Luke was a very complex character, but he was certainly interesting. However, the ending disappointed me, because it seemed too rushed, and there were loose ends that were never tied up. Why didn't Pastor J.D. talk to Mr. Atkins and those three deacons about the way they were acting? What is going to happen to Luke's business, and will his customers come back? The situation with Jasper was never resolved, either. I felt it was a little better than a four, but it couldn't reach five stars for me without a more complete conclusion.

When Raelene Strattford's parents are killed by their wagon overturning, she's devastated and angry at God. She is alone now, and although the farm is hers, no one will do business with a woman in New Castle, Pennsylvania, in 1739. Gustaf Hanssen came to her rescue and is assigned to oversee the farm for her. She appreciates his effort, but she wonders if he's not hoping to gain the farm for himself. However, his hard work and honest spirit shows her differently. As part of her father's will, she must marry by her eighteenth birthday in six months. Gustaf promises to help her find a husband , too.Gustaf is saddened by Raelene's refusal to turn to God, because he knows that's what she needs. As his love for her grows, so does his frustration. She apparently considers him as a country oaf and beneath her. Yet, how can he find her a husband and walk away? Hell just have to rely on God and trust in Him.I liked this story and the characters. There were some glaring historical inaccuracies, however. For example, in 1739, the community would never have allowed Raelene to stay on the farm unchaperoned and for Gustaf and her to be alone so much. She might have embroidered but not quilt squares. Quilts at this time were still whole cloth quilts. And she was canning vegetables over a hundred years too early! In addition, words like scalawag werent used until 1850.This book came close to being a five, but I just didn't feel it quite made it. However, I did like it and didn't regret reading it.

Emma Wyatt has learned to do nearly everything she needs to, although shes blind. She is working toward having her own place and kennel when some bad circumstances arise. In order to get the funds she needs quicker, she accepts the job of tutoring a newly blind man whos become angry and bitter. As he begins to learn to accept his situation, someone is sabotaging everything Emma holds dear.Ian MacGregor, a Navy seal, goes into the hospital for a wounded shoulder and comes out blind. He tries to drown the situation in alcohol, but when Emma comes, its all taken away. He tries to be mean enough to her to run her off, but the woman is stubborn and persistent. When he becomes ashamed of how hes acting, he begins to soften, but how can a blind man protect the woman hes beginning to love? And, with his secret phobia, doesnt she deserve someone better?I loved this book. It didnt have a lot of faith woven throughout, but it was Christian and clean. The ending wasnt quite as strong as I would have liked, but the rest of the book made up for it. What a wonderful story and a beautiful job of writing!

Rebecca is stunned to find the years are passing her by, and she hasnt found the man for her yet. She thinks it could be Jonathan, her boss. Theyre friends who can tell each other anything, and its fun to flirt back and forth, but Jonathan has a steady girlfriend. When she meets Michael, he gets her attention, but hes a Christian, and his moral values get in the way of what Rebecca expects. Is there a God, and how can Rebecca find out for sure?I read THE PERFECT CATCH in the same series and enjoyed it, but I didnt find this one nearly as good. I found it pretty hard to find anything to like about Rebecca and couldnt understand what Michael saw in her. I didnt see the relationship grow, and it didnt feel real to me. The book had little depth, and it was very short. The ending was  blah, sterile, unemotional, and a letdown.

Fiona Hawthorn as grown up running independently over her fathers estate. She can ride and swim better than most men. But she has the reputation of being a jinx, because unusual disasters happen to people around her. Thats why she goes to London with mixed feelings wondering what will happen there--that and the fact she needs to get away from Lord Tyrell Wesmont and his delicious kisses. However, after the kisses he declared he would never be leg-shackled in matrimony. Yes, she needed to get away.Tyrell cant believe how badly he acted with Fiona. The girl has always had the ability to confuse and draw him at the same time. He needs to get away before he completely loses his head. Hell go to London. Thats the trick.I didnt find the book particularly humorous, as advertised, but it was cute and entertaining. Fionas Aunt Honore was quite over the top and made the book risqu in places, but at least it had no sex scenes. I does have some suggestive dialogue and mild cursing - about 25 of them. It was a short, quick read, but I think I would have tired of it had it been much longer. I found the ending a bit too quick and rushed, but I still liked the novel.

I have this as well as one of its sister products, the Amplifi 150.  There's a lot to like about this product, when you can get it to work properly with the Amplifi Remote software. The features have been well-covered in other reviews, so I'm posting this review simply as a notice to Apple IOS users who may be contemplating a purchase. As of today, the Amplifi Remote app that's required to use the amp the way it was designed to be used - i.e., sending custom amp and effects tones to the amp via mobile device Bluetooth (IOS or Android), as well as sending songs from your mobile device's music library so you can play along - doesn't work with recently released IOS 9. The app will crash immediately when you try to connect with Bluetooth. It's not a random issue: Line 6 has acknowledged the problem since the IOS 9 beta was released and still hasn't issued an update. So if you've already updated to IOS 9 and buy this amp, you won't get much use from it (other than playing through the four factory preset tones, which are pretty lousy) until Line 6 issues a fix for the app. You can't control the device via a computer; while it has a USB connection, that's only for firmware updates (and only through Windows, not Mac).I like the amp...it's a great practice tool. But alas, Line 6 has never been dependable on the software side. I've owned products from them dating back to the original Axsys amp: firmware and software updates tend to be far and few between and are often as buggy as what they're endeavoring to fix...

There's a lot to like about this product, when you can get it to work properly with the Amplifi Remote software.  The features have been well-covered in other reviews, so I'm posting this review simply as a notice to Apple IOS users who may be contemplating a purchase.  As of today, the Amplifi Remote app that's required to use the amp the way it was designed to be used - i.e., sending custom amp and effects tones to the amp via mobile device Bluetooth (IOS or Android), as well as sending songs from your mobile device's music library so you can play along - doesn't work with recently released IOS 9.  The app will crash immediately when you try to connect with Bluetooth.  It's not a random issue: Line 6 has acknowledged the problem since the IOS 9 beta was released and still hasn't issued an update.  So if you've already updated to IOS 9 and buy this amp, you won't get much use from it (other than playing through the four factory preset tones, which are pretty lousy) until Line 6 issues a fix for the app.  You can't control the device via a computer; while it has a USB connection, that's only for firmware updates (and only through Windows, not Mac).I like the amp...it's a great practice tool.  But alas, Line 6 has never been dependable on the software side.  I've owned products from them dating back to the original Axsys amp: firmware and software updates tend to be far and few between and are often as buggy as what they're endeavoring to fix.

Fantastic tuner.  I bought one of the PolyTunes when they first came out and was blown away by the ease of checking the tuning of all six strings with a single strum, and how easy it was go from there to the identified out-of-tune strings and easily tune them individually.The PolyTune 2 supposedly provides increased accuracy, and also offers a strobe-like function, which allows for even greater tuning precision for users accustomed to that approach.  I tested its accuracy using my Peterson Strobe Tuner - a very accurate tuner - and the found the Polytune 2 to be right on target across the board.  Finally, while the red/green lights of the original Polytune and regular Polytune 2 are plenty bright in their own right, I really like the blue/white combination even better.  Best pedal tuner(s) I've ever owned (for the record, I was a dedicated Boss TU 2/3 guy for many years until I came across the PolyTune line but today my second choice after the Polytune would be the Korg Pitchblack line).

Cleverly designed little knife/opener.  This replaced on of those ubiquitous aluminum bottle openers on my keychain, the kind that chip, wear and generally become useless after opening a few dozen bottles.  Well-built, with a handy little knife blade and a bottle opener that functions perfectly.
Best box knife I've ever owned.  This thing is rock solid and the blade extender/retractor system works flawlessly.  It has some heft to it, so it's easy to control while cutting.  Worth every penny.

These are the third set of Bluetooth headphones I've owned, and easily the best.  In evaluating Bluetooth headphones I find one has to look at battery life, Bluetooth range, and ease of pairing along with the criteria for traditional wired phones (i.e., sound quality, comfort and fit, construction quality).  So, I'm going to focus a bit on these aspects.My first pair were from Sony - DRBT50's - and were okay.  They're well-built and comfortable, and of the over-the-ear design I prefer for headphones.  They paired easily and the battery life was decent but not great.  They charged via a separate AC adapter, which some people would find more convenient, whereas I prefer phones that charge via a USB cable and computer.  It's easy to find an AC adapter to use with a USB cable, but not so easy to remember to carry around a proprietary charger.  The sound of this set was middling, but they were among the first available, so I found the sound acceptable since there weren't many options without spending a fortune.  Range was only average, they began to cut out about 15 feet from the sound source.My second set were Parrot Ziks.  Frankly, I hated them though they were the darling of the audiophile class when I bought them.  The design is totally quirky IMO.  They're bulky, and they earpieces didn't extend far enough for me to get a comfortable fit.  They don't come with a case, though they certainly should for the price.  Pairing was a nightmare with every device I tried though I eventually got them working with everything (phone, iPad, computer).  Tech support was nonexistent, though it may have improved; I don't know.  One feature I liked was the replaceable battery, permitting one to buy and carry a spare.  Another was the "tap to control" feature for volume adjustment. Sound was stellar, but to me that was the only strength to these otherwise overpriced phones.  Range was good, not great; about 20 feet maximum with no obstructions.That brings me to the Bose.  I'd prefer an over-the-ear design, but at least these are very good for an on--the-ear design.  They fit well and are extremely comfortable, they just don't block out as much ambient sound as I wish they did.  I also wish they were noise canceling.  Battery charging is easy using the supplied USB cable (and since I had a ton of similar cables laying around and always keep one in my briefcase to charge other stuff it means I'll never be without a means to charge them).  Battery life is fantastic, I regularly get the claimed 15 hours.  I also like having the controls on the rear of the right earpiece.  They work flawlessly for adjusting volume, skipping songs, etc.  Early wired phones had no way of controlling any of these; while later wired ones do, usually via a cable in-line design, they tend to be iffy in my experience, working with some devices (often only ones from Apple) but not others.  That kept me wedded to my iPod when I'd have preferred to simply use my phone (currently an iPhone 6, but I've had every other generation of the iPhone as well as a Galaxy S4 and Note 2).  These phones finally let me cut the cord to my iPod.  I now exclusively use my iPhone, and can easily adjust volume or skip songs just using the earpiece controls.  Finally, these have excellent range, about 25 feet with no walls, and 15 or so with.Now to the sound.  It's very good, comparable to the Ziks.  If you're a Bose QC user you'll like these.  If you prefer Beats, these will be lighter on the bass than you're used to.  As a final note, you can listen to these via a supplied cable if the battery runs down, but the sound gets comparatively tinny, so it's only useful in a pinch.  If these phones were over-the-ear and had noise canceling they'd be perfect, but even without those features they're still a great pair of Bluetooth phones.

Great toolbox for the price.  Sturdy (the metal clasps are a big plus over the plastic ones on some other boxes, which tend to break quickly in my experience.  The storage boxes on the top are well-designed and configurable, and you can buy replacements.  I really like this box.

It's cheaper than the self-adhesive variety, and offers reasonably similar protection but is a bit of a pain to apply.  It's not that hard in the end, but it essentially works like a waterslide decal, so you have to soak it for a few seconds, then apply it, squeegee and wait for it to dry overnight.  I suppose the one advantage for some people is that you have a bit of time to move it around to get it seated properly.  Still, I found that the fit wasn't perfect, and a few air bubbles remained even after a week of setting.

Great product, fast service.  There are other varieties of this that look nearly identical EXCEPT for on important feature: on this model the USB and AC connections are at the rear, on most of the others they're on the left and right sides, respectively, which I find inconvenient.  This is the one to get.

I really wanted to like this bag, as it's a good-looking bag and at first looks to be of pretty good construction.  It has one fatal flaw, however, and another minor one.  Many of the snaps are of VERY poor quality and simply won't stay fastened.  The problem is with the male ends of these snaps; they're poorly formed as well as flimsy, and the female end simply can't be fastened securely.The minor flaw is that the padded camera section that fits into the interior bottom of the bag is a separate - and loose - compartment that isn't integral to the bag itself and merely rests in the bag, rather than being part of it.  That leaves gaps between the bag and the padded compartment, and while not a deal-breaker it doesn't exactly bespeak quality construction.Too bad, because absent these two defects, I'd have given this five stars.

I'm guessing this latest pair is at least my 15th, and what junk they are.  I've only had them a couple of months, and they're already falling apart.  The insoles, which only span the rear half of the shoe, have separated from the rest of the shoe and will no longer stay put.  They've curled up like parchment.  The leather uppers have completely lost their shape.  My son bought a pair at roughly the same time as I bought these, and his have suffered the same fate (he's only 15, and he's never had a pair before, so he's got a pretty bad impression of Topsider's at this point).  While I can't imagine it could be relevant, I'll note my current pair are Sahara (as are my son's), while all my previous Topsider's were Classic Brown.  Unless the quality flaws are peculiar to the Sahara color, all I can say is that Topsider's have really declined in quality.  I'm used to these things lasting for a year or more (i.e., until the soles wear out; the insoles and uppers have never been a problem).

This stand is very well-designed and easy to use, and it's very rugged.  Unfortunately, it has - or at least mine has - a major flaw that undermines what otherwise would be an extremely sturdy and stable stand.  The flaw is that the head, which swivels down to fold against the main tube, isn't parallel to the floor when raised: it leans several degrees, thus wanting to tip the stand forward.  Naturally, the problem is exacerbated under a load, i.e., as soon as you mount a bike.I took mine apart to find the cause.  In my case, the head's rear wall thickness either wasn't sufficient to brace the wall against the post early and evenly (there's a gap between the rear wall and the post, so they don't make contact until the head beam leans a few degrees), or the holes on either side of the beam that accommodate the swivel post were drilled a couple of millimeters forward of where they should have been (resulting in the aforementioned gap at the rear).  I had to have a 2mm-thick metal rectangle  (roughly 1.75" by 1.75 " welded to the inside rear wall to gain sufficient thickness so that it would make contact against the post early enough to prevent the lean.Were it not for this, I've have given this stand five stars: as it is, I'm tempted to give it only two, but will settle at three (but barely).

These are amazing.  First, they're bubble free, or at least they become so within a day (as noted in the instructions).  They're easy to apply, because they're a bit stiffer than most screen protectors.  Once applied, there are very few bubbles, and even those disappear within 24 hours (and I mean COMPLETELY disappear).  Once that happens, you can't tell there's a screen protector on the phone.  I've been using them for over a year; I generally replace them about every two or three months, but they could easily serve longer.Oh, and these are indeed crystal clear, as the name implies.  They have only a negligible - indeed, if any - effect on screen brightness or contrast.  A truly great product.Note that the average # of stars so far is being dragged down by a single reviewer, whose complaint was about shipping, rather than the product.  There's one in every crowd...

Amazon recommended this as one of the ink packs available for my Pixma MP980, and their compatibility checker verified it was compatible.  It's not: the MP980 requires CLI-221 cartridges.  Now I'm out $43 for the box I opened, and I've got to go through the hassle of sending the other boxes back.  In short, don't trust Amazon to determine the proper ink for your printer: go to the Canon (or other mfr.'s) website to be sure you know the correct replacement cartridges.As you can see from other reviews, this is a common problem here.

I've owned two of these now, and both have failed in less than a year of use.  I switched to an OWC Elite drive after the second Lacie tanked.  I've only had the OWC two months, but so far so good (though I'd have said the same thing two months into owning the first Lacie).  Compared to the Lacie, the OWC has a substantially smaller footprint, and is MUCH quieter.  This drive is one of the noisiest I've come across.  I really didn't realize just how loud it was until I switched out the second one for the OWC and discovered the noise that I'd been attributing to my MacPro was actually coming from the Lacie.  It's also slow compared the OWC.  I've always associated Lacie with high quality products, but I can't recommend this drive.

Let me start by saying I'm not the audiophile I used to be.  Back in the 70's and 80's I was an audiophile gear junky, always buying the latest and greatest top-end stuff.  These days I'm content to have a "very good" system, as opposed to a "high-end" system (many of which don't offer any improvement in sound IMO).  I can remember when back in the old days we obsessed over "total harmonic distortion" measures the way some people do over CPU gigahertz today.Anyway, I'm a longtime amateur musician (guitar, bass) with a pretty well-equipped home recording studio, so quality sound is important to me: I just don't obsess over audio gear like I once did.I bought these speakers for my office at home, which I work out of about 50% of the time (and spend a lot of time in outside work).  I use them with a Mac Pro that has a topnotch sound card (I do scratch pad recording on the machine using Logic Studio and then move it to my home recording setup, which is also Logic-based, on a different Mac).  I've got an extensive music collection that includes everything from classical to hip-hop and rap (the influence of having two teen-aged sons and a pre-teen who's into the same stuff as his brothers).  Mostly I listen to rock, blues, and country - I'd say they make up 70% of my listening, with classical and jazz comprising most of the rest.I've probably owned a couple of dozen computer speaker systems since I bought my first desktop in the mid 80's, and virtually all have been mediocre at best.  A few later sets from Harmon-Kardon and Altec-Lansing were decent.  This Bose system is very good in my estimation, for what it purports to do: provide high quality sound from a computer.  No, they don't compete with 5.1 home theatre surround system, and one shouldn't expect them to.  But they do provide very good sound in a compact setting.  The stereo separation is decent even though the speakers aren't intended to be spaced very far apart.  The bass is excellent (and adjustable to taste).  The mids and highs are clear and distinct without being shrill, though it would be nice if Bose provide an EQ adjustment for these (and at this price arguably they should).  Acoustic music, like acoustic guitar and piano, sounds sublime through these.  All in all I'm highly satisfied.  After experimenting a bit with these, I'll offer the following suggestions:- Make sure you have the sub centered beneath your computer desk.  Some may try to tuck it to one side or another for space reasons, but it really compromises the stereo field and can make the sound seem really out of balance on some tracks.- Don't point the satellite speakers toward yourself.  I've found that the best stereo field is created by having the speakers facing straight out, and relatively close to the listener.  I tend to sit erect or even lean forward a little when I'm typing: I keep the speakers about a foot to 18" in front of me and about 30" -36" apart.  If I roll my chair away from my desk the stereo field narrows, so you want to position these relative to how you'll be sitting most of the time.  You want to lean more toward having almost to your side than in front of you (figuratively that is).Nice system.  Pricier than most, but better too.

These earphones looked promising, but ultimately proved a disappointment.  First, the bass is weak to nonexistent: the bass on my $29 V-Moda's is far superior (as is the overall sound quality of the V-Moda's), and these don't begin to approach my Bose or Shure phones.Second, the construction quality is very poor.  The volume control didn't work from the start, and the right headphone failed after just two months.The only positive is that - for me, at least - they fit snugly and stay in place.I have to admit to getting a chuckle from the reviewer below who suggested that improper use is the culprit for those of us who can't hear any bass in these phones:1) I've owned over a dozen in-ear sets, and know how to properly insert them.  These simply don't sound very good.2) The reviewer cites the use of these with an iPod or MP3 as an example of failure to use them properly: what does he think Apple makes these to be used with?  Duh....There are far better phones from V-Moda, Etymotic and Shure for roughly the same (or slightly more) money.  The $30 V-Moda's are a real bargain.  They're a tad on the flimsy side, but no worse than these, and are less that half the price.  And they sound a lot better.

As others have said, this album isn't for everyone.  Mainstream Brad Paisley fans are apt to buy it and then wonder, "what the heck is this about".  Personally, while I acknowledge Brad as a guitar virtuoso, I'm not a huge fan of him as a "country artist".  On the other hand, this album is killer if you're into virtuoso guitar playing and pure musical artistry.  By "virtuoso guitar playing", I'm not referring to the physical gymnastics of the average shredder: though Brad can shred with the best of them, as this album shows, this isn't an attempt at showing off his ability to play aimless scales, but rather an eclectic tour de force that showcases a variety of styles.  He's as melodic as anyone else I can think of (I'm a player myself, so I prize players that can play melodically).My favorite songs are "Departure", which indeed is a departure from Brad's typical country musings, and "Cliffs of Rock City".  "Departure" is at once familiar and distant.  It sounds like music you've heard before, but you can't put your finger on exactly where you've heard it.
