One gets the impression that this could not be the first time she has done this.The story basically follows Annas life and thoughts, but her day to day actions are interspersed with paragraphs about conversations that occurred between Anna and her therapist and conversations or memories between Anna and her lover.  These interruptions of memories from her life are how the character development occurs through the story and they allow the reader to learn who Anna is and what drives her to the bed of another.I found the first half of the book to be tedious to read.  I could not relate to Anna or how she led her life.  The storyline felt as boring as Annas life at times.  It was difficult to relate to Anna who seems to given into every whim, who doesnt take her own life or family seriously and who just drifts through it all without fear of consequences. But it is thanks to the ongoing passages about her life that I did begin to at least understand her better.  The second half of the book therefore was more interesting to read and the last 50 pages or so were difficult to stop reading.Hausfrau is a challenging book to read as it is a perspective into the mind of an outsider who is full of despair in her own home.  Her husband inadvertently pushes her on her destructive course through his own actions and disregard for her.  And Anna keeps on the course even though she knows she should not.  The author allows Anna to blame much of her problems on the Swiss coldness and rejection of outsiders.  This theme is visited time and time again.  But, it is Anna herself who is to blame for the choices she makes with the opportunities she is given.  Can she keep it all together and hidden?  Will she be punished for her lies and adultery?I didnt really enjoy this story about depression, but the ending has kept me thinking about it after finishing it, so there is that.

I loved playing operation as a child and so I was excited to share this SpongeBob edition with my nephews and nieces.  The game board is basically the same as the classic game, but features SpongeBob on the game board and the items you need to try to remove are related to the show.  You need to retrieve shells, crabby patties, etc from the holes in the board.The pieces are made of plastic and are a bit slippery to grab.  But the openings are generous for older kids who had little trouble with most of the pieces.  The wire connecting the tweezers is stiff and we found often got in the way while trying to remove pieces on the left side of the board where the wire is attached.Overall, good fun, but only for a short time.  Once removing the pieces was mastered the game didnt make it off the shelf for a while.

Olivia works for an investment firm in New York.  One day one of the traders in the firm comes into the office, yelling at her and goes as far as to pound on her hand, breaking two bones.  Olivia is then fired and her reputation is ruined because the traders puts out the word that she is trouble.  Olivia's life in investments is over.  Fortunately, she knows some tough guys.  Very tough guys including her uncle who has served time.  Her uncle hangs out at a place run by Beck who was wrongfully accused and sent to prison for a few years where he met the others.  Once out, Beck started helping other men who were coming out of prison to get back on their feet.  And now Beck and the others want to help Olivia.  What they dont expect is what sort of web they untangle when they do.Among Thieves is fast paced and suspenseful.  It is also violent and the author explains the damage that blows cause during fights.  The book starts with a brawl, setting the pace of the book, but also revealing a lot about Beck.Beck is the leader of the band.  He is indestructible and the man with the plan.  He is able to see several steps ahead and plan for it.  Beck reminds me a lot of Lee Child's character, Jack Reacher.  If you replace Reacher's past in the Army and his knowledge of how it works with Beck's past in prison, you have similar types of  backgrounds with the exception that Beck doesnt roam and his loyalty to family and friends are what keep him in one place.The writing is very good.  Despite the constant action in the book, the character development happens slowly as information is teased out of the characters through dialogue or thoughts.  The slow buildup is essential to the plot since it adds to the suspense.I really enjoyed Among Thieves and I look forward to future books by John Clarkson.

Calvin Klein ETERNITY for Men AQUA has a light, crisp scent.  It is described as opening with a hints of cold cucumbers, citruses, lotus and green leaves.  I do notice the cucumbers and citric which gives the fragrance part of its crispness.  There is also a bit of warmth with floral elements.I can see this as being a nice spring and summer fragrance, but not something that I would reach for in the winter.  I found that the scent fades away in a few hours.Overall, if you want to try an aqua, I recommend this.  If you are unsure if an aqua is for you, most larger department stores carry the product so that you can sample it first.

The TP-Link Archer D2 AC750 is a combined modem and router that offers multiple wireless protocols over 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz as well as one USB port (2.0), and Four 10/100/1000M RJ45 ports for connectivity.  The specifications for this router are good for the price, but TP-Link also makes other modem routers with higher specifications and more features.The range of the wireless signal depends on the spectrum you are using (2.4GHz or 5Ghz with 2.4 GHz offering better range, but potentially more interference from other devices).  I am using the 2.4 GHz spectrum in my two story, timber frame house and the signal coverage is good to strong throughout the house.Note that the modem is an ADSL modem and it will not work with VDSL.  If you are unsure which type of modem you need, check with your provider.To set up the modem, I connected it to my computer via the included CAT5e, Ethernet cable.  I used followed the Quick Installation Guide (you can find the guide and the manual on the TP-Link website).  Setup was actually very easy if you want just the basic settings.  I had the router up and running in no time.  In addition to giving your wirless networks names and security, be sure to change the administrative login name and password to prevent others from accessing the settings and taking control of your network.Future modifications to the router settings can be done by again connecting the router to a laptop or Using the Tether App, you can manage the router from mobile devices instead of needing to connect to it with a computer.  There is a QR code in the Quick Installation Guide which takes you to the App Store or Google Play to download the app.The AC750 offers a lot of advanced settings for those who want more out of their router beyond the basic settings.  The user manual is 120 pages long, but gives only basic information.  The manual does highlight what can be done, but you may need to search the internet to figure out what all of the advanced settings mean if you dont know already.  However, some of these settings were a lot more difficult than the quick setup.  For example, I tried to put the device into the Wireless Router Mode to use it just as a router and found the setup to be not at all straightforward.If you visit the TP-Link website, you will also find instructions for setting up a media server, storage sharing, a print server and a FTP server.Overall, a good combined modem and router capable of providing wireless coverage for your home.

In the heady days of the '89 Democracy Movement in China, Li Huasheng, commonly known as Peanut found a way to express his anger at the government at the way his father, an intellectual was tortured during the Cultural Revolution, many years before.  He begins to give information to British Intelligence from his collection of like minded friends who are working on projects for the military.  But, the Democracy Movement came to an abrupt end and Peanut disappeared into prison.  Twenty years after that, the anger still burns in Peanut as he escapes and again contacts his network to try once again to sting the establishment that hurt his father.  But, China has changed dramatically during Peanut's twenty year absence.  He becomes a rogue operator in a world he doesnt understand.  So too has British Intelligence where serving ones country is changing into serving ones company first.  Peanut makes contact again and this time offers a prize that the British cant help but respond to.  And so begins a web of intrigue which drags the characters into it and threatens to destroy them all.Night Heron is fast paced and an enjoyable read.  The author doesnt spend a lot of time describing the locations which the characters are constantly moving through, but when he does the description of the locations in China and the conversations feel real, most likely due to the author's own experience in China.  The Chinese government is very definitely shown as Big Brother.  The constant motion in the book overrides the chance for character development.  We know the main character's past and their current relationships, but we know little about what they are thinking beyond how it impacts their behavior.I enjoyed this dark tale of espionage and if the author writes a sequel, I would definitely be keen to read it.  Just dont expect a lot of depth in the characters.

The Avery Index Maker Double-Column Clear Label Dividers (13150) add class to binders that are in use professionally or just look nice for binders at home.  If I am using a binder to organize documents for a project, I really appreciate the nice, printed tabs instead of hand written tabs that tend to smudge.  This particular set is good if you want to have a lot of tabs in your binder.  Avery also has smaller and less expensive sets if you want to have fewer tabs.There are minimal instructions with the labels.  For some reason, typing in the number on the Avery website didnt take me directly to Design & Print Online, but a Google search on the product number did.  From there, I could choose the text for the labels and add graphics (either my own or a stock graphic).  The design you create can be saved which is a time saver for situations where you want to use identical designs for different binders.  Printing involves the creation of  PDF through the website which you then print onto the labels.  The process could be better documented, but it is not difficult once you play around with the different options to see what can be done.  There is even live chat available 7 days a week if you run into trouble.Overall, I am pleased with the results and how the printed labels make the binder look tidy and professional.

It is 1978 and Slaney has just escaped from prison after serving four years of a sentence for drug running.  Slaney and his friend from childhood, Hearn had this great plan to bring marijuana up from Columbia on a yacht.  It didnt end well for Slaney which is why Caught opens with Slaney is on the run.  While everything in Slaney's life is telling him not to, Slaney has a plan to get back into the drug smuggling business.  He just needs to get clear across Canada, get down to Columbia to pick up the drugs and to get them back.  What could go wrong?The writing is good and the development of Slaney's character is excellent.  As the reader, I really wanted him to succeed despite it all.  There is a constant give and take in the dialogues between characters which keeps the book moving right along.  However, the author does use a writing style which I found a bit disorientating at first which is to omit quotes when the characters are speaking to each other.  When you pick up reading again after you put the book down, you have to figure out what is being said and what is just an action or a thought.  This takes very little time to do, but I found I had to get used to it.I found the book to be a page turner and I was through it in no time.Overall, a good read.  This is my first book by Lisa Moore and I am now keen to read more of her works.

Wow.  Stephenson is a master of creating world and storylines that are massive in scale.It is this year and a mysterious agent causes the moon to fracture into seven pieces.  This event is met by gawking from earth but not more concern other than beyond what could have caused this.  But, then the fragments collide, splitting the fragments into more pieces and the scientific community makes a horrible realization that the world as we know it will end.  The exponentially growing population of fragments will eventually fall from orbit, smashing the earth and increasing the temperature of the air to the point that nothing will survive.A plan is set to launch as many space capsules as possible to create a swarm of survivors that will continue the human population beyond the end of days in the hopes that thousands of years in the future, the Earth can be repopulated.  The plan is well thought out at first and then becomes more of a DIY effort as thousands volunteer to help to build the rockets to hurl those chosen by national lotteries into space at a frantic pace.  Finally a swam of space capsules hosting thousands of people is created in space to survive as the earth burns, but the survivors are faced with what to do next and how to survive in a very hostile environment where even a tiny pebble flying through space can kill without warning.It is a story of innovation, sacrifice and tenacity.  It is for the most part an optimistic story of how the human race would react to ensure its future when facing the end of the world. But the survivors bring with them the frailties that have plagued civilization including greed for power and life.  In that sense, it is not a pretty picture of the future, but probably a realistic one.The book is very thick and it does take time to get going but that is because the groundwork must first be laid for the story.  For example, the title of the book didnt click into place until I was halfway through the book.  From that perspective Seveneves is very similar to Anthem or Reamde.  However, the book is very readable and I did have a difficult time putting it down most of the time.In Seveneves, the author gives the reader a lot of detail to paint the world in which the storyline takes place which is typical of a Stephenson book.  The detail can go on for pages and so the author will often then include action or intrigue scenes so that the pace of the book does not get bogged down.Overall, I really enjoyed Seveneves.  I certainly recommend it.

This battery case fits snugly on my Galaxy S6. In fact, it was a challenge to get the case to come apart so I could put my phone in it. Directions would have been nice!Beyond that, I have charged it several times with my phone in the case and with just the case. Personally, I don't notice the problems that I have read in the some of the other reviews but I will update if that becomes an issue in the near future.For now, I like the case. It charges my phone (and I can charge both at the same time) and it protects my phone. I have a new phone and have been trying different cases for days.I like the way this one fits my hand. It feels solid and is easy to grip. It hasn't gotten hot while charging or being charged. It seems to be a nice battery case that provides protection and the backup power needed to keep me going all day.I was offered a promotional discount in exchange for testing and giving my honest opinion of this product. If you liked my review and found it helpful please feel free to vote helpful.

This phone case for the Galaxy 6S is a really nice case. I have the white and it is a "winter" white which is nice as it is a soft color and it doesn't stand out when carried.I like that this case is snug. REALLY snug. It is not meant for the phone to be taken in and out of on a daily basis. It also has a wrist strap that can be removed.The cover includes three slots for credit or business cards and an area to slip your cash or key. It is closed with a magnetic strap. The magnet keeps the case closed (unless I put too much stuff in the storage compartments - it does have it's limits) and is nice to be able to carry it instead of my larger tote when running errands.If you are looking for a solid protective case for your phone that also serves as a small wallet, I would recommend this one. It comes in a large variety of colors.I was offered a promotional discount in exchange for testing and giving my honest opinion of this product. If you liked my review and found it helpful please feel free to vote helpful.

I love these socks! I was worried they would be itchy because of the wool but they are not. They are so soft and warm.The designs are cute and the colors are bright and cheery. The set includes five pairs of socks sized 9-11. I wear a size 10 shoe and these fit me without bring too tight or short.And talk about being warm and soft! They are from 40% wool, 55% polyester, and  5% spandex. Warm, Comfy and Stretchy.. three for three!Unlike other wool products, these socks can be laundered with your normal clothing. Another win in my book!These socks will keep your feet warm while looking good too! Add these to your stash of socks or consider them as a great gift for someone else.I was offered a promotional discount in exchange for testing and giving my honest opinion of this product. If you liked my review and found it helpful please feel free to vote helpful.

Almost every adult has memories of dragging the blankets off of the bed and lining up the kitchen chairs to drape the blankets across.  Along with the space under the kitchen table this area was instantly transformed into a special tent area to play in. It became the most magical place to play under at least until it was either bedtime and the blankets were needed or dinnertime and the chairs were needed. Throw your belief system about dieting, food and exercise out the window! Sheridan turns all the usual information fed to us by those with vested interests in the industry, on its head and explains why we have to start thinking logically about what healthy really is. After reading this book, you will see the exercise and weight-loss industry in a new light.

A more definitive guide on what leadership is and how to cultivate and share it with others, is hard to find. It contains clear implementable steps to find your inner leader and to better it. A good book for parents to guide their children from a young age to inspire others to greater heights, a must-have quality in todays business environment.

Women (and increasingly, men) have always wanted flawless skin, no matter what age. Rose combines Eastern and Western systems to treat problem skin (or just that of aging) in a holistic way, from making sure you relax, to understanding how your diet affects your entire system, not just your skin. A lot of good information.
Writing is not as scary as many think, and with this guide it becomes even easier to cultivate writing skills, and find ways to be paid for it.

This book is one of those things where everybody wonders why such an obvious problem had not been solved before. The authors have gone to great lengths to bring a solution to information overload and using the book as guide, readers will save many hours trying to find what they are looking for to help them be more productive.

With the many wonderful apps on the market, it is difficult to become expert at just one. Castro has done a great job in organizing the many tips and tricks for Evernote to become your go-to app to not only organize your day into manageable chunks, but to share information, tasks and lists with others as well.

Insecurity in all your relationships hampers your forward progression in life. With the many helpful tips in this book to help you become more secure in those relationships, you will be more successful in work-, personal-, and social life. The book covers the full range of topics, from work success right through to becoming more communicative in your personal relationships.
Genes are strange things; they live on through your progeny. Jack Reacher lives on through the son who is looking for him but may never find him. Quick and fun to read.

At first I was skeptical about a book that boasts improving ones scores. However, it did exactly that. I can say, without a doubt, that this study guide definitely prepared me for my CNA certification. Furthermore, this book will be great in case I ever have to re-certify because my husband and I move. I've now got a quick guide that will help me refresh and move on. This was absolutely worth the price.

The business of gifting within the philanthropy arena is not an easy one to be in. Sooch is clear about the good and bad sides of gifting within the fundraising sphere and in this book, he covers in great detail on the how and what you need to do to develop plans (strategies) to successfully campaign and sign your gift giver.There are so many roles within the understanding of gift giving, that lines become blurred all the time, but Sooch shows you how to incorporate all the roles to ensure you reach your targets. Although the book is focused on the actual getting of the gifts, he has not lost sight of the individuals and their emotional well-being while they do this most important of work; if you are happy in your daily tasksreaching your goals consistentlyyou will automatically be happier and that will in turn drive your success.

Our daily lives are so rushed that we lose sight of what is truly important. Woodards updated edition is a reminder of the many things we can and should be grateful for. She leads us on a path of changing our lives to live it better, with more purpose, and gives practical techniques to live a fuller life.
An interesting idea that has the potential to mature into a standalone novel. The opening scenes are used well to grab attention and keep you reading.
A few genres thrown into one to make an interesting story. Well thought out and characters build towards an unusual ending with many surprising twists and turns.

As many Americans and others across the globe will attest to, dieting in any shape or form does not work. However, understanding the causes of obesity and then how to remedy it is well described to take you from yo-yo dieting with its inevitable weight gain, to permanent weight loss and healthy lifestyle.

Having a guide to help you find the books you enjoy reading is one of the better inventions. Being updated when your favorite authors add books is even better! With millions of books published, easily find what you are looking for in this well organised and logically listed guide.

Stevens takes his time to develop his characters into believable people. With todays almost-instant eBook publications, it is refreshing to find an author that takes the time and respects his readers enough to give them an intelligent thriller. Leave the dishes, stay in bed and enjoy this book!

It takes only one person to bring about change. Throughout history, great individuals came to the rescue of nations to free their minds and bodies from unmentionable inhumanity. Weiss paints a sobering picture of what life could be like if good people dont fight for freedoms so necessary to flourish.

When it comes to nutrition, dieting and exercising, there is a minefield of information. Most books give you a one-size-fits-all solution that supposedly guarantees results. However, Simpkins goes into much more detail to tell you why you cannot sustain weight loss and teaches you how to personally manage your weight-loss routine and muscle building goals.

Panic attacks and fear rooted in unknown causes are debilitating, but because the person experiencing them has no idea where they come from, they live with it. Alison takes the reader through understanding causes, then how to deal with those causes and how to manage attacks in the future. Well written and a must read.
This turned out to be a smart book for me. It makes a lot of sense and with the help of the book, I took steps to repair my credit.

With our stressful lives, it has become almost impossible to relax. But Hunter shows us how ageless techniques can be used in our modern lives to find stress relief. He carefully analyses the many influences that impact our life, health and relationships and gives the easy remedies to balance it all out and live a relaxed life.

When theres a new badge in town, Alpha Citys dark secrets slowly emerge to reveal the lurking evil all around. When dead bodies turn up and people start disappearing, things become a bit confused, especially when Bruno starts to investigate the mayors disappearance. Fast-paced with a nail-biting cliff hanger to perfectly introduce Book 2.

Ive had a book locked in my head for a while now and had tried a lot of different ways to get it out of my head and onto paper. After reading this book, Ive already got an outline down and am chunking away at it. If youre someone who has always wanted to write a book but had no clue where to start...pick this book up.

Many heroes are small in stature, and that is exactly what makes them larger than life. The universal story of the righteous triumphing over the oppressors is perfectly captured, in the form of one brave mouse standing up for what he thinks is right. Adults will enjoy this well-written book as much as children.

Entrepreneurs advance by collaborating, but there are few guides on what strategies to follow. Rivera bases this guide on his years of experience to help entrepreneurs form lucrative relationships that benefit all involved. The practical steps are clear to guarantee viable outcomes. A must-have in the entrepreneurs library.

This is a very good book. The author gives us a very clear step-by-step method to invest & make money using Bitcoin. He also exposes all the options available. However, some of the sections of the book could be more detailed. But overall, a great book to start earning passive income using Bitcoin.

Engineering success is more complex than mere hard work or having a high IQ. Author has studied numerous successful people to arrive at the conclusions. This summary is detailed enough to give the reader a good insight into the original book. It will help the reader re-examine the idea of how success is achieved and how successful people use their environment to achieve the successes they do.

It is said that a cluttered living space is a reflection of some deeper psychology. The author explores this in the decluttering book to help free your physical and mental space. This guide is precise in its summary of the steps needed to reach that freedom. This summary doesnt lose any of the original concept but clarifies many of the steps.

Management books can become tedious and too detailed, putting many people off reading them. This guide helps by giving an overview of each chapter, from the background, through to the study of many companies, to arrive at the findings and conclusions from the study. Written in a way that gives quality content but which prompts the reader to delve deeper into the original book. It is also an interesting read as background information of those companies discussed.

War is often seen as a men only endeavor, but The Nightingale gives the womens perspective. This summary and analysis clarifies many of the hard-to-spot contributions made to the overall story. It also analyses the characters and give more explanation of their purpose in the story, together with their motivation for their actions. It should be used as a reference guide when reading the original book.

Modern medicines impact on our daily lives and therefore the end of it, cannot be disputed. The book offers a different viewpoint and approach to that thinking. This summary has kept many of the analogies and anecdotes to illustrate the points the author was trying to make. As a guide, it needs to be next to the original book as a reference.

Author's classic business management and self-improvement book has and will endure time. Each of the seven habits is summarized so that readers take action to become better in character, not personality, so that they can set their path to success. It is a great guide to have alongside the book to clarify points and ideas Covey was trying to get across.

This extraordinary follow-up book is complex in its story-line and this summary and analysis is much needed to make sense of the characters and history. References to Mockingbird ensures the connection between the two books become clear. Readers who want more background and explanation of this and the previous book and their connection to each other, wont be disappointed.

This classic is perfectly summarized to enable readers new to Lees books to understand the thinking behind the period of time in which the story is set. Due to the now incomprehensible prejudices which ruled at the time, it is good to have explanations of the reasoning and judgments those people were subjected to. It is also a good guide for those who want to read her new book without reading To Kill a Mockingbird.

The summary version of the complete book should be kept as a reference guide to give the reader a deeper insight into the lives of the couple seen from the train, as well as that of Rachel, the one who views others lives from a passing train. The chapters are well summarized without giving the story away, or indication of the ending.

Despite time-saving gadgets, we still dont have time to get to our to-do list. GTD makes the methods of goal-setting easy to understand by using every day analogies. Project planning methodology is simplified and made available for everybody to use, from the boardrooms to students chasing better grades. GTD leads the reader from basic planning, to being a master GTD.
Landing that sought-after job isnt easy, but this book helped me improve my skills and techniques, and I can use them in the future too.

Every family has a black sheep, but in the La Cour family there is a particularly bad one. Using his beautiful sister as the fall-guy for his failures takes being bad to a new low. Gambling, treachery and double crossing is the order of the day, and Lacey will have to make sure everybody comes out unhurt.

A fresh and original take on the (re)creation of mankind. The book explores the total annihilation of mankind by machines they themselves built, with the subsequent recreation of man by those self-same machines. While reading, you will question our very own existence and supposed intelligence which led to our extinction. Are the machines any better?

The combat arts are rich with history and Mr McCall illustrates this history through detailed explanations. He goes into the background of Judo so that the reader, thus practitioner, has an understanding of the reasons certain moves are done. Of importance is the preparation for competition and how to avoid injuries.

Following on from the first book, Vasquez has managed to write a sequel to rival and better the first. The story follows on nicely from Book 1 and develops the characters brilliantly, giving more twists and turns than a bowl of spaghetti.
As a young adult book, it delivers a good story and Vasquez developed the characters with an insight into how young people act and react. The story-line is gripping and is unique in its subject.

An appropriate name, Mulligan: soup made from odds and ends. This book is just such a collection for kids and adults alike, with many jokes playing on words to teach the language with humor. Great resource to keep kids entertained and can also be used to teach English in a fun way.
Thoroughly gripping and enjoyable read. I am a huge fan of historical fantasy novels.

As a male, you are under constant pressure to perform but our modern lifestyle influences your testosterone levels, which in turn impacts your performance, from the bedroom to the boardroom. Lanes book clearly describes the problems and the natural remedies to ensure you perform at your peak so that you become the leader of the pack.

From the opening chapter, there is action all the way with some parts showing the human side of tough characters. Tension builds brilliantly to lead the reader to unexpected places, all the while ensuring empathy with the main character with whom the reader can identify. The sequels are much anticipated.

Allens first book turns a game into a story with all the hallmarks of a good game  rules, points, and levels to urge the reader further into the story. It builds nicely to keep interest and to root for the heroes.
Experience the game as a story to better understand the rules and prizes of Minecraft. Excellent for non-gamers to grasp the fascination of the game.

Focused on users with a basic knowledge of Linux (or programming) already, this guide gives specific command lines with clear and short explanations of the commands job. Grouped so that you can find what youre looking for quickly with support for all GUIs and operating systems within Linux.

Noori gives deep insight about the reasons we are harsh with ourselves and then goes on to show how we ourselves can rectify the things that keep holding us back. He writes with a sense of wonderment at how we can transform by following a few simple steps to become more accepting and loving of ourselves.

Rimmel quality is always excellent, but the picture looks at least two shades lighter than the actual product.  I'm keeping it to punish myself for forgetting that you cannot trust colors on websites.  In fact this Urban Green is even darker than the Jane #10 Deeply Green I wanted to replace with a shade in between my very dark and very light green.  Much as I hate shopping on foot, when it comes to makeup I have no choice.

The ones I received are definitely NOT non-stick.  Purchased in November 2014, hardly used, by July 2015, going on 50% of the coating has flaked off and more is loosening up.  Egg omelettes stick especially badly, even when greasing them with coconut oil in hopes of a better result. I prefer the flexible silicone kind, even though the shapes are only round (that I've seen).

I have not purchased this particular dress, but have bought others like it at Amazon, and I love the style and the fabric.  I use mine for sleepwear that I can also wear around the house and outside if necessary.  One star off is an advisory that some garments from China have a very strong chemical or fuel odor that will not wash out even with with several machine cycles.  For this reason I recommend returning any that smell bad before you wear them and invalidate the return.  If there is no odor they make a very nice dress or top.

Many gadgets I buy are more wishful thinking than reality, but this sucker actually does what it says: gets the gunk out of the bottom of cups.  I drink tea with ultra-pasteurized half and half, which makes deposits that cling stubbornly to the inside of the cup that even my dishwasher can't get out.  Being efficient (or lazy), I hate having to work harder than absolutely necessary, so when I saw this brush for $3.00 at Safeway I took a chance on it.  No regrets!  I can't speak to its durability, but after a week of use I feel it's worth recommending (especially at a more affordable price).

This is a carefully designed kitchen tool, as practical as it is sleek. To quote the enclosed instructions: "Not all garlic presses are made equally, do your homework." It's handy to have both a crusher and a slicer together.  I thought the item would be a bit larger and double as a slicer for shelled nuts, but nuts are too hard and they get stuck in the slicer.  It's just right for slicing my cat's large vitamin tablet however.  I plan to purchase some garlic for it as well, because the little tool that fits neatly in the handle is perfect for cleaning.
Virtually everyone who wrote a review of this item apparently received it free or discounted.  For this reason I cannot be sure of its quality.

The original Skin-So-Soft bath oil is a very successful bug repellent (which I can assure you is no myth, although it may not work for some people).  Unfortunately this bug guard product has fallen victim to the notorious "Coca-Cola Syndrome" (over-tweaking a good thing).  Whatever "picaridin" is does not agree with my lungs--makes me cough.  I went back to the original bath oil, and use the new stuff on kitchen counters and on top of hummingbird feeders to repel ants, for which it does work (but I must be careful not to breathe it in).

Based on one experience, this Bartelli can opener is brilliant.  I tried it on a 3-ounce cat food can (only 2-5/8" diameter) made of unusually thick metal that is stubborn to open despite the tab.  The opener went around but nothing seemed to be happening and it did not stop by itself, so I gave it another go-around and pressed the button again to stop it.  When I dubiously lifted it up, the lid had been amazingly transformed.  It could now be reused, fitting neatly inside the original diameter of the can, and not a rough edge to be found on any surface!  A pet could eat straight from a Bartelli-cut can without being injured. It outclasses all other can openers I've ever used, and I hope it's as durable as it is elegant.  By the way, the packaging was very easy to open (no clamshell battle) and the batteries were super easy to load into the top (no tiny screws to mess with).  This tool seems to reflect the famous Italian talent for engineering design, but the country of origin is not stated on the machine, the box, or the paperwork, nor do they have a website.  This too bad as I wish I could personally thank the inventor of this genius design.

I was shocked when I opened the box and found all the shapes and sizes of bandaids mixed up together.  To find the size you want, you must fumble through all 280 of them until you get lucky.  Who needs this in a first aid emergency?  How Johnson & Johnson could treat customers this way is beyond me, and I will certainly look for different brands in the future.  I will not waste even more of my time trying to contact the manufacturer, as they obviously have no interest in customers.  This product is an insult to paying customers.  I don't know how long it will take me to organize them with rubber bands, but it will definitely not endear me to Johnson & Johnson.  If this product has not been farmed out to China, I would like to know where it was dreamed up.  Solution:  The least J&J  could do is sell the band aids in a divided plastic box at no extra charge.

I like the style of this water pitcher and it reminds me to keep hydrated, but I wonder if the filters make it worth $64. I purchased it due to the focus on "alkaline", after reading the hype on how healthy alkaline water is.  Then I bought a pH test kit, and lo and behold, the alkaline level of Tucson tap water is exactly the same as this filtered water. I have no way of checking the quality of the filtering, but the alkaline part was my main concern, so I doubt I'd have purchased it if I'd  done more research first.  At least the pitcher helps me keep track of how much water I'm drinking, as it holds eleven cups of water, but the cover on the spout keeps coming loose.  Researching after the fact, I would not purchase bottled water either, but will probably go back to tap water when the filters are used up.  If I notice any great beneficial health effects due to the filtering alone, I will update this review.
A lovely garden accent, that is also practical by discouraging birds from flying into my window.

I wear a 6.5M shoe, and the Okabashi 6.5-7.5 fits me perfectly (might be a tad short for 7.5).  I love that they have half sizes, so I will buy them over another brand any day.  Okabashis are always top quality yet affordable, and I have several styles.  Needed these for gardening.  The arch support isn't very high, but it is quite adequate for me and I have high arches.  By the way, Okabashis never wear out, but the population is increasing so fast, they can still make the profit they deserve, I hope.
Lightweight and imaginative.  I bought this because of the author's outstanding book on writing, "From Where You Dream."
I gave these as a gift and they were well received.

The video demonstrating this doorbell decided my choice, and it turned out to be accurate.  The audio quality of the tunes is amazingly rich, especially coming from such a tiny source.  The non-traditional tunes are delightful, and there is more than enough variety.  The transmitter is touch-sensitive and more stylish than the typical mechanical button.  It took me a few tries to get the two units communicating, but the directions are simple and correct.  I love the styling and the performance, and the unit is well worth the price.  The only thing the Advantek DT41 could use is a weatherproof housing for the transmitter, but that would increase the cost.  However, since my transmitter has to be outside under an overhang, I made my own housing.  METHOD A:  (1)  Using the insert with a hole in the middle that comes with the doorbell, I bent the cardboard to fit around the transmitter.  (2) Lining up the bell symbol with the hole, I cushioned it with the molded white foam.  (3)  I put the transmitter wrapped in foam and cardboard into another small box and cut a hole where the bell symbol was located.  (4)  Covered the whole thing in Contact paper, threaded a  long twist tie through it, and secured it to my gate.  METHOD B:  Come to find out, the transmitter is so sensitive that it works even through a layer of clear stiff plastic, so you can weatherproof it simply with a clear plastic box.  Live and learn.  It is a fun change from my old doorbell which only played one tune.  I hope the Advantek DT41 will prove as reliable as it is elegant.

This is a beautifully designed machine, take it from a senior lady. I'd been looking for a trimmer that was cordless, lithium battery, no string, easy to handle, and affordable.  The MLG is the only one I could find after scouring the internet several times, but it exactly fits the bill.  It is light, maneuverable, easy to assemble (all the assembly is done except for adjusting the length, adding the handle and the guard).  I trimmed  the tops off the expired wild flowers in my whole yard (40 x 40 ft), and the battery still hasn't run out.  The safety instructions and provisions are excellent as well.  I thought I wouldn't need the wheel, but on second thoughts it comes in very handy when you want to set the trimmer down without damaging the blades.  Last but not least, it's very ego-boosting when I can do this all by myself without hiring anyone, thanks to the ease of use.  Thank you, MLG and Amazon!

This solar pump is a little champion and works just as strongly as the more expensive ones that look the same.  The solar panels are interchangeable with similar models, but not with the kind that come with the fountains, which have the male/female connection reversed.  I have four of these pumps as I'm somewhat obsessed with fountains, and the oldest combo has lasted about four years with no problems.  The solar panels are very sensitive (unlike the kind that come in a frame), but they have no means of attachment so you have to improvise.  I use Velcro or Gorilla tape.

This fountain is well made with a lovely glaze, but the problem is the solar panel and pump.  At first I thought there was a cover on the solar panel blocking some of the light (not just the protective film), but after prying off the top frame I discovered there was no additional protection!  So all I proved was that I had to glue the frame back together, and either the panel or the pump is defective, or both.  Rather than return the fountain, I spent another $15 for a different pump that works perfectly.  Hard water problems:  (1)  If you have hard water, keep putting vinegar or other water softener in it, because if you let the calcium build up you will never get it off.  (2)  Another trick is to coat the outside top surfaces of the fountain with oil periodically to prevent the deposits from forming in the first place.  (3) If the calcium deposits are too far gone, you can simply spray paint the entire fountain, calcium and all.  I used Rustoleum outdoor spray paint on three small fountains ruined by hard water, and they turned out beautifully.

This fountain starts at five stars, but if you have hard water it should be replaced about every three years.  I purchased this model from a different company in June 2010 and it worked very nicely until 2015.  Now the rubber plug in the top jug is beginning to deteriorate, so water splashes outside the bowl.  The calcium buildup from the hard water has become impossible to remove, so it looks ugly.  If you add a calcium remover to the water, animals might get poisoned, so I'll put it in the garden where a slight leak won't matter.  I'm replacing it with Amazon's low-profile, blue ceramic Koi fountain, as I've found this type of thickly glazed finish is easier to maintain.

I love this leaf blower because it's very light and effective for ridding my carport and ramada of leaves.  It cleans better than a broom, uses less of my energy, and I wouldn't need anything heavier or more powerful than this.  Also the customer service from the vendor in helping me with a question was outstanding, up to Amazon standards.  I don't use it very often, but it is easy to charge and has worked perfectly so far.  Highly recommended.

I'm relieved to confirm that the size "XL" light-duty rain boots fit perfectly over my women's size 6.5M shoe, not too tight and not too loose.  I plan to keep them in my car for the rare occasions I've had to walk through unexpected puddles away from home, like last week when I soaked my good shoes.  These boots look well made and the zippers seem sturdy, and I expect they'll be great for emergencies, but should not be confused with regular rain boots.  Update:  I got to try them out today and they worked exactly as hoped.  They were easy to slip on and off, and I was able to operate the car pedals with no problem.  Good buy.

UPDATE:  I ordered and reviewed the wrong L'Oreal Mousse!  The "Sublime" is not at all like the "Absolue" that I reviewed.  I didn't know they had two mousses.  When I got around to using the Sublime, I discovered it is NOTreusable; it's just the regular made into a foam for one-time use.  Also, the #70 color in the Sublime is much darker and is brown, not dark blond.  No wonder it was much cheaper.This is for the Absolue REUSABLE mousse:  Wow!  I have short grey hair, and from one can of mousse I got two complete colorings, with plenty of foam left for a third treatment.  I started in September, and the second coloring was just as strong in November.  There was still plenty of foam for a third treatment in December, but I was mistaken in thinking it was still just as strong, because it was not.  However, not having to mix liquids is wonderful, not to mention there is zero dripping.  I won't be going back to the old way.

I gave these as gifts without opening the boxes.  Apparently there are no directions inside the box, and the giftees weren't sure what they were supposed to do with them.  It seems obvious when you see the infusers on the website with the descriptions and comments, but my people seemed more confused than thrilled.  I think the infusers are a great idea and I'll probably get one myself.

Pros:  affordable, stylish, well made, length is right.  Cons:  The width is really wide, not medium, and the heels are way too wide for the typical European foot.  This is a common problem with Chinese shoes, and unfortunately I usually forget to make sure where shoes are made.  Italian shoes conform to the foot much better.  If you try to compensate with thick socks, the toe part is too tight.  In future I'll need to either buy narrow shoes, or avoid Chinese shoes. I'd return them except I've been returning too many bad choices lately, so I'm going to live with these shoes.
Elegant looking, easy to use and clean.

This lab coat is very stylish, beautifully made and excellent value.  Usually a 36" bust requires a Medium, but I ordered the Small in case it ran large, and everything fit well except that the sleeves were way too long for me.  Unfortunately the button design of the sleeves makes it impractical to shorten them so I had to return it, which is painless thanks to Amazon's wonderful system.  If you don't have short arms, this garment is a bargain.

My elderly cats, a mother and son 15 and 14 years old, ignored this toy until I tied a 12-inch long narrow ribbon at the end of the wand, at the base of the feathers.  That got their attention right away.  They have always liked strings better than feathers.  Something to try if your cat needs encouragement.

The fabric and fit are fine (except the sleeves are a bit too long for me), but the color is much darker than the turquoise in the picture.  Due to the deep teal color I washed it separately in a tub, and it was still bleeding so much color after three water changes, I would never risk washing it with other garments.  I thought of bleaching the color to a lighter shade, but the tag says not to.  It is made in Cambodia.  Having washed it I may not be able to return it, so all I can do is alert others.

Like other reviewers, I've tried many "affordable" creams to deal with dry, thin, elderly skin.  CeraVe beats them all.  It absorbs quickly and then seems to stay in the skin, keeping away the dry spots for a long time, while the other creams had to be applied again soon.  Right before CeraVe, I bought one that was full of herbs and organic stuff and was supposedly hypoallergenic, but when I put in on my face after a shower it gave me a rash.  CeraVe feels good without being oily.  I'm very glad I stumbled upon it while searching for a better answer.

The Medium-size length is just right for my 5ft. 2in. height, bust 36, weight 125 lb.  (A similar dress in another brand was two inches too long and I had to return it as the fabric would be hard to shorten.) The polyester jersey  feels silky and luxurious to wear.  The weave is dense enough that you can't see through it in normal room lighting, but if the sun or a strong light is aimed directly at the skirt, you can see outlines.  I love the color variations, and since they are so affordable I ordered three more while they last.  I plan to wear these maxidresses in winter (Arizona) with a sweater on top or turtleneck under, to cover imperfect legs as an alternative to long pants.  The standard shipping for these dresses was very fast, four weekdays.  UPDATE #1:  I'm taking off one star because the elastic around the waist is not very strong under normal usage.  Fortunately Dritz and others sell black elastic thread, and it doesn't seem hard to make repairs, just a bit of a bother.  UPDATE #2.  Oops!  More stars off.  The elastic shirring is definitely a problem.  Trying to replace the elastic thread is no fun at all, especially since the original was put in with chain stitch, so if it breaks the whole length can go.  I gave up and removed two broken rows on one dress, and I can see ending up with no shirring at all.  This won't be the end of the dress, but it is a disappointment.

When we find ourselves out of sorts, it's time to sort it out.I feel extra appreciation for authors who use words well, who seem to weigh them and taste them and then arrange them with care. Sarah Bessey is one of those authors. Whatever aspect of life she's talking about, she reveals its hidden glory, she shows us where God has touched it.The first chapters hooked me right in, because she dives into the metaphor of "sorting things out." We feel compelled to sort material possessions when a major change happens. We sort when somebody dies. We sort when we have to move. We sort when we want to pass along one of our treasures to somebody else.Sarah feels that it is much the same with faith. Sometimes a piece of our faith seems to die, and we're left sifting through the memories. Sometimes we have to move on, and we feel suddenly rootless. And all the time, we want to pass on the good of our faith, but the graces may be buried in the negatives.This book was born from Sarah's sorting, and as she "unpacks the boxes," you may see things that you recognize right there in her hands. As is must be with any storyteller, she speaks from her heart but the words echo in yours.Sarah tells us that she has always felt an ease in her communion with the Spirit. It didn't keep her from struggles, or fears, or terrible loss. But through it all, she has been known, and she knows it. This comes out in her writing. The Jesus that she is madly in love with is a living Jesus, a God-Incarnate whom she meets in the Gospel accounts and on the street and around her kitchen table.He's the One Eugene Peterson described, who could "say the big nouns: joy, glory, peace; and live the best verbs: love, forgive, save."And because of him, Sarah will not walk away from the people that he calls his body. She will not forget that he called us into a kingdom: a way of being fully human; of spending our moments well; of being present with people the in presence of Christ; a way of working towards what is good, especially when it's hard.If you read Out Of Sorts, you will come away with something valuable. I came away with an expanded vision of what Sarah calls "Eternal Living." When a Christian says "eternal life," the world hears "that disembodied forever existence that you think you're getting- if you're not on God's sin list."That cannot be what Jesus was referring to when he said that we had his life in us.When Sarah hears those words, she hears something more like "Eternal Living"- doing life as if God was right there in it, as if it were all caught up in Christ- finding its grounding and glory in him.Treat yourself to this book. It's positive without being fake. It's serious without being despairing. It's full of truth without arrogance. It sounds kinda like a conversation between her, and you, and Jesus.I thank Howard Books for providing me with this review copy.

The publisher's blurb refers to this devotional book as "unique and life affirming," and in this case the marketing team is exactly right. Sid and Rosie, an older couple participating in the daily adventures of life, will both enchant and encourage you as you encounter them in these little parables.Having read some of Penelope's other novels, I knew that she is capable of exploring wide, high, deep truths through simple "fictional characters." I hate to call them fiction, though, because she renders them so realistically. They're fully human, clumsy and flawed, and they want to live well, so they try hard to find the rhythm of kindness and joy.Sid is a Quaker, having come to this path later in life. For him, the idea that Jesus is the Way is of primary importance. No amount of religion can make a Way- and a Way is what we need to walk in. Sid is slow to speak, and sensitive, and provides a sounding board for Rosie.Rosie is a self-professed spiritual ragamuffin, having worked her way through many faiths and their teachings as an adult before she met Sid. She is curious, passionate, and ever open to new ways of thinking. Together, they're an encyclopedia of quotes and insights from God-chasers and Life-lovers the world over.And we readers get to snoop into their days, eavesdropping on their stimulating conversations and witnessing the satisfaction they find in being together on this good earth. From Rosie making bread to Sid quoting poetry, to interpersonal misunderstandings and the required forgiving, their shared moments are ordinary. Yet they've determined to look up the sunbeams to the Sun, and to recognize the glory that grows in the ground and falls from the sky and lights up each other's faces.They'd be good friends to have, Sid and Rosie, friends who don't pretend to have God in a box, who aren't stuffed with sureness about God's will, but who do believe that God has given a Way, and they put their small feet on it and walk.If you're looking for a little wisdom, and a few smiles, and some new thoughts to chew on, then try this as a devotional. I don't see how you'd regret it.I thank Penelope Wilcock and Monarch Publishing for gifting me this book in exchange for a review.Penelope says:"My aim in writing is to make goodness attractive. I love simple human kindness and gentleness, and I am moved by human vulnerability. I am fascinated by the power that is within our grasp to lift one another up, to heal and strengthen and encourage each other - our power to bless.In the novels I write, I think of the reader sitting down to enjoy a book, the door of their imagination open wide to allow the story in to influence and shape their spirit. I accept the responsibility that confers as a great privilege, and it is my intention that when you put down any book of mine at the end of reading it, you will feel hopeful, peaceful and comforted, more ready to look on your fellow human beings with compassion and see their point of view."

"It's Not What You Think" is a perfect title for a book like this. The "it" Jefferson speaks of is the Gospel, and a lot of people think they know what it is. And they think it hasn't got much to do with their strongest fears, deepest desires, and greatest hopes.The Gospel has been to reduced to a transaction between you and a guy named Jesus. Thanks (somehow) to his sacrificial death on a cross, you get into heaven when you die. (Try not to sin too much along the way.) But what if there's way more to the whole thing than a ticket to posthumous paradise?What if the Gospel and its God-touching-man narrative actually had to do with reality?What if the Gospel met our need, not for more religion, but for renewal? And what if it conferred a responsibility to us, a "burden of care" that we share with God Himself?If you're ready to think about the whole Christianity thing in a different, life-affirming way, then let Jefferson be your guide. Of course, he'd probably rather be considered a fellow traveler rather than a guide, a traveler whose insights provoke new thoughts and fresh conversations.For me, these were two of the foundational concepts-"The Kingdom's Not Where You Think." We aren't peddling pie-in-the-sky, enticing you to restrain yourself down here so you get a better reward up there. We're offering new eyes to see the work of God today, where you never recognized it before."People Are Not Who You Think." What if those new eyes suddenly showed you a glory in the people all around you, a weight and worth that re-invents them for you even if they never change.If you let this book do its job, your may begin seeing the sacred (the meeting place of God and man) each day.I thank Thomas Nelson for giving me this review copy.

I read this book several moons ago now, and I hesitated to review it because I had loved it so much that I didn't think I could do it justice. In the inhospitable landscape of dating advice, we all might need Kate's words to reassure us.I needed her straight-talk, and her sense of humor, and her strong grip on both spirituality *and* reality. Particularly, I needed her bravery when she said that while singleness is certainly no curse, it's also hard. It's probably harder for a mature adult single person, rather than for a young adult, but still- you feel an absence. We belong to a species that was designed to be paired, and we feel separated when we're not. I look at couples, and families, and I want that belonging. I want to be a link in the chain of generations. Acknowledging this deeper hunger means being vulnerable, and that takes guts. Kate has them.And it takes another dose of guts to say "I'm going to own this longing, and not attempt to satisfy it with substitutes, and I'm going to live well in this tension and find goodness in this life of mine, whatever my relationship status." Kate has a suitcase of that kind of guts.Without platitudes, or sentimentality, or self-pity, or browbeating, Kate leads us to think about purpose and satisfaction and opportunity and gratitude and grace, all without sounding like a zillion other "Christian Dating Books."Really, this is much more a book about being a healthy, whole human being. But there's plenty of talk about Love and Relationships too- you won't feel cheated if you're one of those singles who compulsively reads relationship books. :-)Because this is a book about living life well, Kate invites us into her personal journey of growing closer to the heart of God. And, like the best of storytellers, her questions and reflections lead you to your own.I thank Harvest House Publishers for my review copy.

There is no delicate way to say this, so I'll be frank: The Gospel is such incredible good news that sometimes it doesn't seem to have anything to do with daily life.After all, isn't the Gospel our Big, Important Spiritual Truth, and everything else is just hit or miss attempts?What could our days (full of washing dishes and stopping at traffic lights and reading to children and trying to plan family reunions and working overtime) possibly have to do with God-in-Flesh and a Cross-carried-for-us?J. D. Greear agrees that there's a lot of Ordinary Life to live, but he thinks that every moment of our living is grounded in the Gospel that we've been given. Preaching the Gospel to ourselves throughout our days, he says, will reorient our minds, strengthen our hearts, nourish our spirits, and guide our hands.It is this being "rooted and established" in God's love that we experience in the Gospel that teaches us what we need to know to live well. The chapter titles may clue you in: "The Gospel as Gift-Righteousness," "Changed by Sight," "Urgent Mission," "Expect Great Things," "But if Not..." and "Extravagant Generosity," just to name a few.The Gospel is the only thing that can convince you of God's love, and it is the only thing that can grow the love of God in you.It will show you God as the source of all the goodness, and teach you obedience to his good ways.It will convince you of God's steady care and tenderness, and adversity will not destroy your hope.And once you have received God's Gospel, and you know his kindness and his mercy, then you'll be able to give others what God-in-Christ has given you.I thank B&H publishing for giving me this review copy. It was much appreciated.
Bought this for a Shepherd-obsessed cousin of mine. He'll love it. The graphic is well done and it's a nice military green color, too.

When you look around the natural world, you see that there is a rhythm to the way it moves. There is intense and purposeful activity: the verdant growth of spring, the chorusing of mating frogs, a wild snowstorm or powerful thunderstorm, deer running in a field.And then there are also periods of seeming inactivity: geese flocked together on a pond before they migrate, bears hibernating underground, the empty trees when all the leaves fall down, a dry creek in a drought.If you don't have the right eyes for looking, these moments will appear as wasted time instead of the holy pause that they are. You'll see unchanging dark instead of dawn on the horizon. You'll see unmelting snow instead of hearing stirring sap.The natural world doesn't know to complain when the pace slows down, but I do. When things seem to stall, I get nervous. Waiting seems too much like doing nothing. After all, I shouldn't "wait" for a job/friend/community to come to me, I should go look for a it. Right? Perhaps right. But even when I'm doing my part, there will still be times of stillness, when all my efforts echo in the air. There will be times when the pieces don't fit, and my frustrated striving won't change that."Waiting on God" by Wayne Stiles is a book for those times. It's a book to remind you that maybe you don't have to choke on that horrible word "wait." You're not being asked to doing nothing. You're not being told that this time means nothing. You aren't being sold a pie-in-the-sky destination. This waiting period, it's more of a bearing period. Bear this time, this tension, this want-unfulfilled and fear-unresolved. Bear it, and while you carry it inside you God is making space in you. And God wastes nothing. It all adds up to something.I thank Baker Books for providing me with this review copy.

If I met somebody who had no time for pretense, who knew how to use strong language, who'd seen more garbage than they should have, and who was trying to make a difference in the crazy world, I'd hand them "Accidental Saints."Why would I choose this book for them? Because Nadia Bolz-Weber is a straight-talker who could never be accused of hiding in organized religion. Indeed, she has some words for those who use Christianity as an invitation to unreality: "We've lost the plot if we use religion as the place where we escape from difficult realities instead of the place where those difficult realities are given meaning."In this book, she stretches her eyes wide (to her own discomfort) and looks hard at everything around her. She recounts some of the ways her life has collided with other lives, in births and deaths and sin and forgiveness.It's ugly reading at times, because that's how it is when you're capable of hurting people and being hurt.It's beautiful writing sometimes, because she finds Gospel-beauty alive and growing in this world.We often talk, in Evangelical circles, about helping our children to "find a faith that will survive" in this wicked, pernicious, tempting world. (Insert ironic eye roll.) After reading this book, I wonder if maybe it's more that we need to learn to survive our faith. After all, our faith is hung upon a Man who went down to the lowest and the darkest and the most ragged places, and so following him means we have to go there too.I'll close this book recommendation with one of my favorite quotes. Half-way through the book, Nadia ends a chapter by saying "... the holy things we need for healing and sustenance are almost always the same as the ordinary things right in front of us."I thank Convergent Books for giving me a review copy. "Accidental Saints" indeed.

"The Surprising Imagination of C. S. Lewis" is a delightful and provocative read. As the authors acknowledge, imagination has been reduced to a very narrow definition, usually applied to creative children. In this book, they explore the works of C. S. Lewis to show us more of what human imagination is.As we read, we see that imagination....Re-enchants the familiar.Show us bursts of glory in the "ordinary" world.Sends us on the genuine quest for truth.Teaches us justice, as we recognize a thing's value and give it due esteem.Takes us beneath the obvious surface of an issue, to the heart of the matter.Lets us see the world rightly, aligning the self with reality.Of course, human use their imagination wrongly too. We can dream ourselves into delusion, and justify evil things. We can inflate things above their proper importance, and neglect what really matters. We can hide our flaws from our own eyes.I have a hard time categorizing this book. It's not academic. It's not straight-up theology. It's not a systematic study of C. S. Lewis' writing. It's a carefully written examination, with the keen eye of a meditation, that sometimes turns into a celebration, all about the imagination.I'm glad I read it. I've got a fellow C. S. fan in the house to share it with, too.I thank Handlebar Publicity for providing me with a review copy in exchange for an honest opinion.

I wanted to read this book because it was a sister-story. When you have a sister and you're growing up together, sometimes you feel like the two of you are really one person. You know your sister. You can read her face and her tone of voice, and you know when she needs you. You know when she's being her authentic self and when she's faking it. At the same time, you are two separate individuals, and so you can hide from each other. You can deceive each other. You can hurt alone."Never Said" captures all of these sister dynamics. Shifting back and forth between Annie's rush of thoughts and Sarah's more careful narration, "Never Said" is a fast-moving read. Sixteen year-old Sarah is all twisted up inside, struggling with anxiety and an unfinished relationship while worried sick over her twin sister Annie. Annie was the beauty pageant winner, the outgoing show-stopper, the life of the party, the confident and commanding presence. Now, Sarah doesn't know what think. Annie has deliberately and methodically undone every aspect of her former self.This is a book about shame and renewal and identity and friendship and acceptance and family and cruelty and ignorance. It's how we hide and how we heal.I thank Blink YA Publishers for providing me with a review copy in exchange for my opinion.

"The Hardest Thing to Do" is book four in a most wonderful series. I marvel at the way Penelope has imagined the whole world of St. Alcuin's Abbey, peopling it with fine, deeply human characters and plotting it with startling surprises and satisfying resolutions, and then giving us that world through her novels.If a monastic community in the 1300s sounds too far removed from your daily life to be remotely relatable, then think again. The men of St. Alcuin's are each distinct unto themselves (and they become more themselves as you meet them in each episode) but they are Everyman too. The essential struggles of being human- choosing and renouncing, becoming and accepting, receiving and losing, growing and remembering- are their struggles, and yours and mine too.The other thing I really enjoy about this series is their integrity, by which I mean that they have no pretense. They're not a story varnished with "Christianity" so that they can stay within the bounds of "Christian Fiction." Instead, they're the stories of men who've sworn to lay down their very lives for a Risen Christ. The brothers' preferences and attitudes, their time and energy, their animosity and comradeship, their doubts and prayers and work and calling- it finds its grounding in the Gospel.Because of this, and thanks to the sensitive heart of the author, the character's conversations and meditations (and most of their meditation is really wrestling with God!) show us what they're learning about life and the One who gives it. There's a lot for a thoughtful reader to think about, and it all belongs to the characters of the story. It's not an awkward sermonette from an author, who interrupts the story to deliver a Christian PSA.Because of this, if a non-religious friend thought the books sounded interesting, I'd loan them in a heartbeat.If I've piqued your curiosity at all, do yourself the favor and get this series onto your shelf

"Just Show Up" is both a practical guidebook and a personal revelation, co-written by two friends, Jill and Kara. At the time of the writing, Kara was fighting cancer, and Jill was part of her supportive (and beloved) community. Shortly before publication, Kara passed away, and Jill completed this book while loving on Kara's family and friends as they all grieved this loss.If you've read Kara's first book "The Hardest Peace," then you'll have already absorbed pieces of her story. That book was also written during her fight with cancer, and out of her pain and sickness she gifted readers with words of life, a glimpse into her family and their Big Love. She captured, in a few short chapters, why it is so good and so hard to be human.If you haven't read "Hardest Peace," then perhaps you grabbed this book because of the subtitle: the dance of walking through suffering together. Perhaps you're trying to navigate the rough waters of a terrible diagnosis in your family, and you need somebody who understands how you feel as you take care of somebody else.Jill and Kara are good guides to turn to. The first portion of this book is intensely practical. They begin by explaining that when it comes to blessing somebody in a hard situation, Just Show Up is the most important principle. If you don't take the risk of going to them, nothing beautiful can happen between you.They next suggest ways to show up and meet specific needs according to your abilities, at the right time and with no expectations.Then they address the need for the "helper" to have their own support system, and the need to be honest about how bad you'll feel even as a supposedly "unaffected" helper. You'll probably feel guilty thinking like this, but the thoughts will come: "This is so hard for me! They're the one who's suffering, and I feel so bad! Who do I turn to?" Jill and Kara make it clear: when you have somebody you're giving comfort to, and you need somebody to dump on.Together, Jill and Kara go to their vulnerable places in this book. Once they move past the more advice-based parts, they return to Kara's story, as seen by Jill and other friends who walked beside her. At the end, you know this truth unshakably: The God who is God-with-us made us to be with each other, and if you choose to be with someone in the hard, then you may never know how very much your choice means, because it does.I thank David C Cook for providing me with a review copy in exchange for my thoughts.

Alright, so I broke down and read a full-length Mary Connealy novel.And it was really funny."Fire and Ice" is almost pure comedy, with a note of complex family relationship and some troubles that need to be overcome by hope.The early interactions between Gage and Bailey had me snorting with laughter. First they do this whole "You're stealing my land/No you're stealing MY land" routine- complete with gunfire and dynamite- and then they settle into a truce. They'll work together on this one certain problem, but they won't promise be happy about it.From there, we see them getting rather attached to each other. They're stubborn mules, both of 'em. They deserve each other. And they're gonna need each other, because ranch life isn't simple. There's danger and deception and hysterical in-laws. And of course, there's cows in need of fresh grazing and mares having a hard time foaling.Read this book if you want a Wild West comedy, the sort that would make a great film.Thank you Bethany House Publishers for providing me with a copy in exchange for a review.

Pastor Alcorn isn't content just to tell us to be happy. He insists on searching Scripture and showing us the Gospel-centered reasons for a happy life.And if you trust him for a few hundred pages, he'll convince you that there's a lot of happiness to be found, first in God Himself, then in the gifts He gives us, and in our response to God and His world.I really enjoyed reading this book. (Frankly, if a book called "Happiness" wasn't a pleasure to read, wouldn't that be a major problem right there?) Randy clearly studied his subject, because this book was peppered with quotes from philosophers and scientists and preachers and artists and songwriters, all of them engaging with "happiness."I agree with him that for Christians, happiness has become one of those unspiritual concepts. We don't want to seem like we're obsessed with personal satisfaction or self-gratification, so we shun happiness in favor of a joyful holiness. And joyful holiness is wonderful, but Randy argues that we've devalued the concept of simple, easily recognized human happiness to our own detriment.For Randy, happiness (along with joy and gratitude and contentedness and peace, etc. etc.) rounds out the wholesome life.In this book, Randy devotes many pages to studying the most precise meanings of various words in Scripture. There's a reason for this. Often our translation of a word can give it a whole new meaning, sometimes subtle, sometimes glaring. There are a lot of really strong happy words in Scripture, and maybe you've never realized that before. If it's become easy to skim over phrases like "blessed," and "rejoicing," then spend some time with these sections, being startled by the bold, brave, bright happiness that God is fond of evoking.All in all, this is a really comprehensive look at happiness: how we can have more of it now, why we can be assured of it for all eternity, and why we should celebrate the fact that we want happiness to begin with.Also, as you're sitting there holding a thick book with "Happiness" emblazoned on the cover, you may have somebody come up and ask you what you're reading. Won't it knock their socks off when you tell them?  Now that's a way to start a Christ-conversation, with happiness.I thank Tyndale Publishers for providing me with a copy of this book in exchange for my opinion.

Last Chance Hero is a fine finale for this series. It starts with a plot worthy of a Hallmark movie. She's a young doctor trying to set up a practice in a small town; he's a former NFL player come home to coach his high school team. They meet, and they seem really good together, but she hates football, and it's the center of his life.Now, that sounds pretty cute. But don't be fooled: just like the previous three "At Home in Last Chance" books, the story gains depth as it progresses.Andy isn't just a fun-loving football-obsessed guy, and Jess isn't just the new-blood fighting the established order. They've both got choices to make as they confront the past and look forward to the future, and they have to decide how they'll contribute to their community, both individually and together.Final assessment? If you've begun this series, then you've gotta take one final trip to New Mexico by reading Last Chance Hero. Andy and Jess have a good story on their own, and it's enhanced by the cameos of Ray and Lanie, Sarah and Steven, Chris and Kaityn and Grandma Elizabeth. When I read the scene of the festival, I felt like I was right there, saying "Hi" to old friends and catching up with their lives.Such is the power of a good book.I thank Revell for providing me with a review copy in exchange for an honest opinion.

"Gather Around the Amish Table" would be a fabulous gift for anybody who is fascinated by the simple life of the Amish.This is a softcover cookbook, filled with full-color photography and engaging personal stories, and every page highlights the good food that can be found in Amish kitchens.When you work hard and tend the land well, your reward is the bounty of the seasons. Judging from these recipes, Amish cooks know how to use that bounty, making their meals both nourishing and enjoyable.There are recipes for any day of the year and almost any skill level, because the contributors ranged from young Amish girls to their kitchen-wise grandmothers.As with any cookbook, you'll likely never make some of these dishes (you'd have to butcher your own hog to get the ingredients!) but if you're a fan of the Amish life, then you'll find the more obscure recipes interesting all the same.And there is plenty for the average cook to work with, such as cauliflower bacon salad, "Party Potatoes," "Broccoli Bonanza," "Best-Ever Meatloaf," "Lisa's Lasagna," and various delectable brownies and cookies and pies and granola bars and puddings.  There are muffins and breads for breakfast, one-dish dinners, lots of noodle recipes, and many desserts.So next time you need a present for your favorite Amish-wanna-be, consider this cookbook.I thank Litfuse Publicity for providing me with a review copy in exchange for an honest opinion.

"The Atheist Who Didn't Exist," by Andy Bannister. Bannister is the Canadian Director for RZIM, which is Ravi Zacharias International Ministries.
