Like most cases, it's impact resistant", however, I'm not purposely dropping this thing to test it out.  It has a frogskin grip and a stylus holder to easily place your stylus as you see fit.  The 3 position stand is really nice and sells this case for me in the end.  The stand works very well and encourages you to use the Surface in multiple situations.  Well worth the money!

What is the there to say about a placemat?  This package of four spices up the kitchen by looking bright and vibrant, and they are easy to clean as well.  I'm using these in my kitchen to place bowls of fruit, etc.  I'm also using one to place a plant on which is a nice effect.  They stay on tables and countertops without sliding around, and are very steadily made of polypropylene ribbon which make them easy to clean, but fancy looking.  Simple, affordable, and in tons of different colors -- what more do you need?

I'm not much of a foodie at all -- in fact, I have little to no passion about food whatsoever.  I do, however, love cookbooks that are creative, funny, and bring something new to the table.  As a video game and scf-fi nerd, I can wholeheartedly recommend this cookbook to just about everyone!The cover may be a bit misleading as it says "unofficial recipes from Doctor Who, Game of Thrones, Harry Potter, and more", but the real charm lies in the little video games and random homages to great and quirky movies.  For instance, the author's love of Zelda is on display in her opening self-illustration, and also dedicates a drink to the game as well (Lon Lon Milk).  The Alcoholic Beverage section is great with nods to Clockwork Orange (Moloko Plus),  and Mass Effect 2 (Serrice Ice Bandy).  The Snacks and Appetizers section is also fun with an Elder Scrolls tribute (Elsweyr Fondue), and Soylent Green, which looks awful, but actually doesn't taste all that bad!  There are also sections entitled "Soups and Stews", "Entrees", and "Cakes and Cupcakes".  This is the best of the lot with recipes based on Portal (Delicious Moist Cake), Bioshock (Creme-Filled Cakes), and my personal favorite of the entire book, 1up Mushroom Cakes inspired by Super Mario Brothers.I've only had the time to cook a few of these recipes, but what I have done taste pretty good.  This book is all about the presentation, though.  It also is clearly a homage to video gaming for than anything else, but movies make admirable appearances as well.  The pictures are very colorful, and most of the recipes are very vibrant, bordering on the electric, but hey, this is sci-fi and video gaming, right?  Kudos to the author for being creative and putting a very refreshing spin on a tired book subject.  Great work!

Alien Isolation really starts off well.  Despite a lame story and bad voice acting, the atmosphere created is very interesting as it sets up the surroundings with sharp graphics and cool sounds.  The first few hours of the game are the best as I was in constant anxiety that the alien (or some other hostile) was going to appear and try to take me out.  After about 5 or 6 hours in though, I wish I had just stopped altogether.As I mentioned before, the graphics and sound are top notch.  As you first emerge and your objective becomes clear, you start to hear thumping and banging in the vents, footsteps, and other sounds that cause some legitimate nervousness.  I was definitely tense playing the first few hours of the game.  The way the smoke billows out of the vents and casts ominous shadows on the floors and walls was great too, really building a weird atmosphere and feeling of impending doom.I love stealth games, and Alien Isolation is absolutely a stealth game at its core.  Those of you who want to be running and gunning should look elsewhere because this game is most certainly not that.  I enjoy sneaking and ducking, searching around quietly, ducking into a vent, or hiding in a locker.  It definitely set up a feeling of helplessness that contributed to anxiety.  Unfortunately, this is where the game stops at being fun or interesting.First off, the least interesting aspect of this game is the alien itself.  The game seems to stop following its own framework when dealing with the alien as it seems to teleport itself around the levels, and conveniently land right in front of you out of nowhere, when a split-second earlier it was on the opposite side of the level you're on.  It takes a lot of the tension out when the alien seemingly is some sort of god that can just appear in places at will.  Given how much you die in this game (oh yes, you will die a lot), there are laughably few kill shots as well.  The alien kills you over and over and over again, and you get to watch the same drawn-out and lame kill-cams every single time.  YAWN.  Another painful aspect of the game are the droids you have to fight.  They just lumber around muttering to themselves, and like the alien kills, will strangle you every time until you try and wait for the load screen to pop again.  Just tedious, man.  Additionally, trying to distract the alien with the given tools to do so (noise makers, for example) don't really work because you rarely have opportunity to use them.  The alien conveniently knows your general location, no matter how well you sneak, so when you attempt to throw something in the opposite direction to distract it, the xenomorph can hear you throwing it, and thus kills you.  There is no escaping the alien once it sees you, so after a while I just started ignoring the beast and creeped along hallways regardless of its presence.  I found that just blindly trudging forth and paying no heed to the alien's presence had the exact same effect than if I carefully hid and tried to distract it.  In fact, it seemed to facilitate my progression.  There were actually a few times where the alien literally landed from the ceiling vents right next to me, but didn't see me because it was looking the other way -- I was standing on its damn tail!  Therefore, in the end, I was left with the thought of "what's the point of hiding and creeping?  Isn't that what this game is about?"  Yet another hair-pulling aspect is when you're in a situation where you have to use your hack tool, you have to give it your full attention, thus turning your back to the surroundings.  So before you use it, it's a good idea to examine the area first and make sure the alien does not appear.  In these situations, I would thoroughly examine the rooms for minutes, and after no activity, I would go to use the hacking tool.  Guess what?  Within 2 seconds of pulling it out, the alien would magically appear and kill me from behind.  I had so many "oh my GOD, are you KIDDING me????" moments I thought I was going to hurl the controller at the television.The most frustrating thing with Alien Isolation is the hilariously bad backtracking!  I can't express enough how much idiotic backtracking goes on in this game, and it's absolutely inexcusable.  In 1995 this would have been acceptable, but in 2014 it's just poor design and execution.  This game will SEEM long, but it's only because of the constant dying and endless backtracking you'll be doing to get to the next level.  The backtracking only gets worse as the game progresses as well.  During the last part of the game, it just utterly falls apart with having to cover the same ground, mixed with the game throwing every damn enemy at you you've seen during the game all at once.  There is a difference between a game that is challenging, and a game that arbitrarily changes the rules and makes you repeat actions in order to proceed: this game falls in the latter category.  The game makes up for a relative lack of content by just amping up the walking, sneaking, and treading old ground.  I was truly in disbelief during the last act when it's supposed to be the most tense, but instead I'm literally walking through hallways and being attacked by droids as if I was playing in the third hour of the game.You also have to endlessly pull levers, push buttons, ride elevators, and collect things to build, like SCRAP.  Because collecting scrap is a blast, right?  Ugh.  There was a part at the end of the game where you have to blow something up, and the game makes you run to one end of the level, then the opposite end of the level, then back to the other end.....I was actually laughing at the tediousness of it.  I ended up just wanting to finish the damn level to end the painful experience and move on.  There are also about 5 or 6 false stops to the game that are comical, not tense.  It's like, "oh, the aliens are gone!  No, they aren't!  Oh, yes they are now.  Oh wait, no they're not!"  Stop it already!  It's just irritating.  Anyone who has seen "Alien" will not be the least bit surprised with any of the "twists" or "turns" of the plot -- they pretty much take the end of the movie and use it with the game as well, so there wasn't anything new or interesting happening.  The ending is, quite honestly, terrible.  You're pushing forward, pushing forward, pushing forward, then, a ponderous meaningless conclusion that ends in a millisecond.I guess the one thing that really got to me is the game was not scary at all in the long run, and there was no ultimate sense of "isolation".  Someone is always yammering away in your headset, guiding you through things, so you never feel truly alone.  The game works best when you're creeping around in hallways with noises all around you, but nothing to suggest that any human lifeforms are nearby.  The game sprinkles these moments throughout the game, which keeps you interested just enough to continue, but then it bashes you over the head with repetition and arbitrary "difficulty".  People who call this game "hard" are missing something major, and that is, this game is NOT hard at all.  It's packed with filler making it SEEM hard.  Just because you die a million times does not make it hard, it just means that the developers integrated unnecessary deaths into the game to extend the story.  And how is that fun?  It isn't.  Finally, what makes Ridley Scott's "Alien" such a masterpiece is that there is ONE single alien who lurks in the shadows, picking off people one by one.  It's the idea that there is one entity outsmarting the humans to finally take control.  At the end of "Alien Isolation: it turns into James Cameron's version of "Aliens" with the creatures just bouncing off walls and screeching at you.  Not that I dislike "Aliens", but it's clear Isolation is trying more to be Scott's version, not Cameron's version.  When the two mingle, it just annoys.I was going to give this game three stars, but because of the last painfully tedious and repetitious chapter, it gets a two.  It completely fell apart at the end, had a lame and unsatisfying ending, and I was left with more annoyance that I pumped so many hours into an experience.  The atmosphere and tension have moments of true greatness, but the lazy writing, sloppy difficulty, and completely stupid backtracking cannot be recommended.  I feel like with the state of technology these days, and the relative ease with creating awesome graphics and sound, this is easy for developers to create in a game, and they did so here.  The challenging parts come in a game's playability and writing, and they failed miserably with these aspects.

These are very absorbent and I like the color combination with this particular package.  I use these in my kitchen and they soak up liquids very well.  This is my second instance using the DII brand of dish towels, and I have to say that I'll be using these products in the future.

Not much to say here -- these are mini-starbursts that are unwrapped, so you can pop in a mouthful and get all kinds of flavors happening at once.  This combo has cherry, watermelon, fruit punch, and strawberry.  I'm not quite sure what all the complaints are about in terms of these not tasting like normal Starburst candy as it tastes exactly the same to me?  Good stuff!

Easy installation and effective use make this screen protector an interesting buy.  It's easy to apply, and comes with flattener to squeeze out the bubbles.  I've got to say it took a while to get them all out, but once they were gone they stayed gone -- usually takes a few hours for them to fully go away.  All you need to do is tilt the phone slightly and the screen darkens out the screen.  For those of you who are looking for some privacy and not worry about anyone peeking, this is will undoubtedly work for you.

These are just solid roller shower curtain rings, no more no less.  I've used my other set for over three years, and they haven't worn down or corroded in the slightest.  The fit with any shower curtain, and the rollers never quit.  The also clip on nicely, and I haven't had one come loose in the three years I've used them.  For fifteen dollars you can do a lot worse.  Worth every penny!

These Skittles are delicious, flavorful, fruity, and fun.  Perhaps more noteworthy is the fact that, the second I popped a handful of these into my mouth, the spirit of Marshawn Lynch possessed me and I spun out of all conscious control for approximately one hour.  I started tackling furniture, performing elaborate spin moves in my living room, and shunning the press.  I even sprinted down to the mall at top speed, breaking tackles the entire way, and bought myself some golden grills.  The grills are spectacular and encrusted with real diamonds, but the drawback to this is the Skittles get easily caught in them while chewing.  Eh, a small price to pay.  I did get a bit carried away when my 90-year old landlord (I call her "coach") came to collect the rent and I stiff-armed her down three flights of stairs in a moment of Skittles-induced hysteria.  As she laid in a crumpled heap at the bottom of the stairs, I threw the bag of Skittles at her and said "taste the rainbow".  A rainbow appeared from nowhere and without hesitation, she rode the colors up to my third floor apartment with a unicorn and immediately gave me free rent for the rest of the year -- her breath smelled of mango tangelo, kiwi lime, and banana berry.  Skittles have all kinds of benefits.  Boss.

I use this with a Mac Mini to store all of my sound files, and the setup is extremely easy and lightning fast.  I use the cloud options regularly and it works fantastically.  It has a few extra USB ports which is nice, and it's easily upgradable.  I'm only using 6 gigs at this point so I can't imagine getting close to upgrading any time soon, but it's nice to have the option.  The dual drive does support some pretty impressive speed for the individual leisure user.  The speeds won't blow you away if you're looking to use this for a business, but most people it will work just fine.At the end of the day, 12TB's with all the options you get is well worth this price!

I've been using this turntable for over three years now, and it's been an absolute beast that is as reliable as anything.  I highly recommend making some extra purchases with it (in fact, you'll have to), but if you do some research this player will last you a long time and be worth the time money and time you invest in it.I have a couple of Technics 1200's that I've used for years, and while they're the old trusty standard when it comes to djing, the Project Debut actually sounds better for mere listening purposes, provided you get the right head cartridge, platter, and pre-amp to go with it.  Quite frankly, the head cartridge that comes with this isn't bad at all, and features some very nice mid-range sound.  I upgraded my head cartridge to a Denon DL-110 and it sounds ever better -- magnificent sound all around.  I also purchased an acrylic platter which reduces hum and general noise that stock metal platter will certainly produce.  This is a must, but I highly recommend splurging on one if you want to best sound possible.  I have a Project Tube Box preamp which serves the rest of the parts very nicely as well.  With these added additions, the sound I get from this table is pretty phenomenal.  These extras will cost you an additional $1,000, but it's worth every penny in the end.  I primarily use this turntable to record my vinyl collection to Flac format, and the vinyl rips produced from this setup is some of the best I, and many of my audiophile friends, have ever heard.One of the things that does kinda suck is you have to pull off the platter to adjust the speed (change the belt).  It's a minor annoyance, but you need to do it nonetheless.  I have a lot of 12" singles, so I do have to do it quite a bit, but once I hear the great sound I quickly forget about this trivial detail.If you can afford it, I cannot recommend this turntable enough.  Once you accompany it with the right bells and whistles, you'll have a record player that will last for years, and sound amazing!

This water resistant lock is built to resist all kinds of elements including weather and theft.  It's resistant to up to 8000 pounds of cut resistance pressure, and 3000 pounds of pry resistance.  It comes with a 4-digit combination code under a push and lift front slider.  It includes a double locking device for extra security and easily resettable combination dials.  It has a stainless steel body to avoid corrosion.  The only thing that causes concern is on the back label where it reads "this product contains one or more chemicals known to the State Of California to cause birth defects or other reproductive harm".  Uhh, what?  Is California privy to something the rest of us are immune to?  Super weird.  Otherwise, this is a top of the line lock.

Not much to say about these other than they work just fine.  I'm using these with my trackpad mouse for my Mac Mini, and my Xbox 360 controller.  They claim to last 35% longer than energizer and at this point I see nothing to refute those claims.  Just a solid 8-pack of AA batteries!

This case hits all the points it claims to, and looks nice as well.  It may be a bit bulky for some, for it fits well and offers solid protection.The stand works quite well, and the tablet will be easily accessible and readable while in this position.  It comes with a built-in screen protector which is a really nice touch.  It doesn't seem to squeeze the tablet too hard either, so everything fits and protects nicely.  All of the cutouts are in perfect alignment and do not impede upon any of the features you use with the tablet.Not much else to say, really.  It works very well, fits perfectly, and looks good!

For 25 dollars I'm a little surprised at the quality you get here.  This is a very small speaker, no more than two inches in length, but it easily straps over your shower head and it sounds great!  It's obviously a very small speaker, but it has a surprising amount of range with its treble and bass.  I've hit it with water and it keeps on chugging away.The setup couldn't be simpler: you turn it on, it immediately starts looking for a pairing, you turn on your phone, and bam, they're synced.  The speaker comes with very simple instructions.  It's also easy to put on the rubber strap that comes with it.  The speaker has three buttons: one for play, one for tracking back, and one for tracking forward.  My phone sits about fifteen feet away when I use it, and I've had no delays or issues with it tracking immediately from this distance.For 25 dollars, this is totally worth it!

Does Eternity For Men really need an introduction, a thorough review, and an end cap?  I've never been much a of a cologne wearer, but this is the one exception in my life.  Not too strong, has that "woodsy" smell, but never too strong or overbearing, and hey, the ladies love it.  Isn't that the reason why dudes wear this stuff?This tiny little bottle seems to be the smallest of the variations, so if you're a guy who doesn't imagine wearing this too often, this amount should last you for a nice long time.

For you Depeche Mode fans out there who remember Martin Gore going on his vintage synthesizer-buying spree back when the band made the "Sounds Of The Universe" album, "MG" won't be all that surprising to you.  Picture a more brief, instrumental, and ambient version of that album, and you'll get a decent glimpse into what "MG" sounds like."MG" is a very solid effort of minimal and short vignettes into the mind of Martin Gore.  Some of this album reminds me of vintage DM going back to albums like "A Broken Frame" -- final track "Blade" has the same tone and vibe of b-side "Oberkorn" from the "Leave In Silence" single from 1982, which is no bad thing!  Gore is basically playing with his old toys on this release, and his production styles manage to be very tight, yet purposefully roughed up.  The overall feel is slick and updated, yet harking back to older and more rough approaches.  Some of the melodies and beats will undoubtedly please the more seasoned Mode fan, however, if you're the fly-by-night DM fan who only knows the hits, "MG" will assuredly disappoint you with its more experimental atmosphere.I've seen some griping about this album being too long, but in my opinion, it's entirely too short!  With 16 tracks totaling under an hour, this album seems way too short on ideas in the long run with pretty much every track lasting at three minutes.  The album would been more satisfying at this length with maybe 10 tracks lasting around 5 minutes per song -- as it stands, a lot of these tracks seem to end abruptly.  A lot of the ideas end up unrealized and rushed for my tastes.For the most part, "MG" is a cool exercise where Gore primarily tests out his walls of keyboards and comes up with a slightly retro nod to DM's quirky instrumental b-sides of the 80's.Quick side-note about the vinyl packaging: couldn't be cooler!  All the credits are stamped (not printed) into the gatefold jacket, and the inner sleeves are generic and poly-lined, guaranteeing your vinyl to remain in top shape as you slide them in and out over the years to come.

This Quad Lock mounting system for iPhone 6 does everything it claims to, and is certainly worth the asking price.  This Run Kit version has worked perfectly for me and is in no way cumbersome when I'm taking my evening walks around the neighborhood.The nylon/lycra armband is adjustable for any size arm, and this one fits my average/toned bicep area.  It's close enough to my headphones where bluetooth can still reach it without causing any interference, and it's super light as well.  I really like the "twist and lock" feature -- once your phone is in the case and locked, it's not going anywhere.  Obviously, if you already have a case for your phone, you'll need to take it off so you can put the Quad Lock on, but the case is simple to put on and take off.The case claims to stand up against "extreme conditions", but I've only used it in mild weather thus far.  For my purposes so far, though, this case has been very solid and handy for my exercise needs!

This pedometer is very easy to use, easy to set up, and very lightweight.  To set it up, you put the battery in, download the app, then sync your phone to it.  The step by step instructions included with the device are extremely easy to follow, and you'll be up and rolling within five minutes.  The app is slick and easy to navigate, and it's easy to upload your exercise info from the device to the app via bluetooth.  The device is always using a battery save measure, so to display the amount of steps you're walking, you shake the device a few times and the number pops up.That's really it in a nutshell.  The only way this could have been better is if the tracker had a little clip or something so you could attach it to your belt or something, but I think it's made to just stuff in your pocket and forget about.  Fair enough.  I really have no idea if 50 dollars is a good buy for this as I've never used a pedometer, but this Omron works well, and is very lightweight, so that may make it worth it to you.  I'm always a little annoyed to have to give up my email address to register for the app, but it's a necessary evil, I guess.All in all, a very cool device that does everything it claims to!

I don't get all the people knocking this because of how much sugar and calories are in this -- it's flavored spread, people!  What do you expect, man?  Cookies 'n' Cream spread exists because no one in their right mind is gonna smear Broccoli spread on their graham crackers.  So shut up, open up this can of spread, and get smearing, because you only live once!So yeah, you can see the three flavors available here, and they all taste pretty awesome.  They're super rich and sweet, and very flavorful.  Yes, you're gonna gain two pounds just eating a few spoonfuls of this stuff, but that's what exercise and moderation is for.  I've tried the spreads with the oreo cookies and graham crackers as recommended, and they are super good!I don't feel like it's too expensive as you're getting three full jars of this stuff, and it's presented nicely.  It gives you a little booklet recommending food to use these with.  I also tried dipping these with fruit (I used an apple).  Of course, the peanut spread with the apple is killer, totally love it!Live a little, people -- this stuff is great!

This case looks snappy and sharp and has cool colors to boot, and it fits very well to the iPhone 6.  Thats about all it offers, though, and the protection is borderline non-existent.  This is clearly a case that is made for looks and status, but do not under any circumstance purchase under the pretense that it will protect your phone.  I'm using a case that costs twice as less as this that looks snazzy and protects my phone very well, so there are certainly many more affordable options if you shop around, but again, this is all about the colors schemes.One thing this has going for it is it's very light and in no way bulky.  Lots of cases are lumbering and ponderous, making holding the phone a challenge, but this is super lightweight and easy to haul around.  Then again, that raises the question of why it's so expensive.  It's half leather, so maybe that's why?  I dunno.This case is okay.  Not worth the asking price for my needs, but perhaps someone else will find value here.

Not much to say here that differs from what the description says -- this just smells great!  The bottle comes with a pump outside of the bottle, so all you do is take the cap off the bottle, stuff in the pump, and you're ready to roll.  It ultimately has a citrus-type fragrance over everything else, and it's not overpowering.  I like to squirt it in the bathroom from time and time and it smells awesome.  Pretty simple -- this smells very nice!

Very nice looking, simple to install, and solid as an ox, this Brinks Home Security push/pull door is a strong investment.  All you need is a Philips screwdriver and you're ready to roll.  This is being used on a wooden garage door, and the installation was much more simple than I expected.  There are lots of parts and pieces, so from the get-go it can look daunting before you get started, but before you know, the thing is in place and working like a charm.This works on left or right handed doors, and you can pretty much turn the handle any which way and the door opens and closes smoothly.  It fits all doors 1-3/8" to 1/3/4" thick, and the latches fit 2-3/8" or 2-3/4" backset.The satin nickel looks very nice, and this is built for usage outdoors.  There really isn't much to say other than it's an easy installation given the plentiful and easy to follow manuals, and the performance of the set once it's installed.  I was concerned I'd be totally clueless installing this, but Brinks made it easy!

I have owned this blower for a little over two years. I also own several other 2-cycle engine products, so I understand that they can be a little finicky at times.Unfortunately, this one is beyond finicky, and it has at least one major design flaw.First of all, it is very hard to start. The instructions tell you to prime it at least ten times, an unusually high number. However, even after that, it always takes about 8-10 pulls before it starts. It then runs rather slowly and unenthusiastically for about thirty seconds.After that, it works fine.The big problem, and the reason for the low rating, is that about six months after I owned it, and after only about 8-10 hours of use, it started losing power, and became even more difficult to start. It also started dripping oil, something that shouldn't happen in a 2-stroke engine. After a little investigation, the problem was obvious: the cylinder head had come loose. This created a gap which reduced compression and allowed exhaust oil to ooze out all over the external parts of the engine. I took it apart and found the five torx screws that fasten the head to the block, and tightened them back up.A few months later, they came loose again, but when I opened it up to re-tighten the head bolts, I found that the force and vibration which resulted from the loose bolts had sheared one of them off. I don't have the tools to drill out the broken bolt and then re-tap the resulting hole.I repeated this process every few months, and finally a second "bolt" sheared off. (I should note that calling them "bolts" is a disservice to real bolts: they are very wimpy, very thin screws).So, bottom line, the build quality is horrible, and this product does not stand up to even moderate homeowner use. Get something else.
This works great in my old Nikon D-70 DSLR.

I bought this to replace the bulb in an old, original design Black & Decker "snake light." This light does not have a Mag-Lite-style focus mechanism. I did a before/after test, and there is no doubt that this bulb is brighter, but it also produces a broader scatter of light that, on my snake light, does not get focused into a tight beam. The reflector in this light is designed for the specific pattern of the older, incandescent bulb, and this light doesn't fit that pattern. Therefore, while more light is put out, the net effect, while brighter, isn't as spectacular as I had hoped.However, it is still a worthwhile upgrade, and the snake light definitely is now more useful (because it is brighter). So, it is a good upgrade, but falls short of being a fantastic improvement.

I have several All-Clad frying pans, including their amazing non-stick 12" skillet. However, I've never owned any of their sauce pans.I needed a good sauce pan to use with my new Max Burton portable induction cooktop. This particular model is at the top of almost every cookware review as the best sauce pan you can buy. Cook's Illustrated has it at the top of their ratings. Sometimes these reviews are correct, and sometimes they are not.In this case the reviews are correct: this is the best sauce pan you can buy.It heats evenly; it perfectly transfers heat from both a gas stove and a portable induction cooktop; and it provides a beautiful, smooth stainless surface that doesn't interact with any food. The lid fits tightly for those times when you want to simmer for a long time without losing much liquid.My only issue -- and almost everyone mentions this -- is that the handle is too long. I guess this was done to keep it out of the heat, and also to let you easily get to the pan if it is placed on the back burner on a large commercial stove. On my more modest home stove, this really isn't needed. The long handle does get in the way of the faucet during cleaning.However, while cooking, the handle is not an issue, and the pan's cooking performance really can't be beat. This is a great pan.

This was recommended by "Cooks Illustrated," so several years ago I purchased one for myself. I already have a full line of Henkel's top-of-the-line knives, so I am accustomed to pretty decent blades. I was a little skeptical that a knife at this price point could be any good.When the knife arrived I was a little put off by the material used for the handle. The Henkel knives use a beautiful wood which is riveted to the bolster. This knife has some sort of slightly soft material that appears to be pushed over the top of the bolster and glued. I wasn't sure how well it would hold up.Well, I've had this knife for many years, and it has held up just fine. More important, it is a better knife in every way to my much-loved Henkel knives. It cuts better, retains its edge longer, and had great "feel" and balance. It is the only knife I use for vegetable prep and chopping, although it also works well for thinly slicing certain cuts of beef, like flank steak.I like the knife so much that I have purchased several for friends and family. You should get one too.

The design of this thermometer guarantees that it will fail. Mine did fail, and after it went kaput, I contacted Taylor and was told, despite what you read in the product description, that this product can NOT be used in a barbecue.Read on.I purchased this as a gift, and we used it for the Christmas turkey. Unfortunately, the unit kept turning itself off after thirty minutes, even though the temperature in the turkey was constantly increasing (it is only supposed to turn off if the temperature doesn't change over a thirty minute period). This ruins the whole concept of having a pager that will alert you when the temperature is getting close to the desired end temperature, and also beep again when it reaches final temperature.So, the first strike against this product is that it cannot be reliably used for anything that takes longer than thirty minutes to cook.Next, the temperature reading went up and down during cooking. This, of course, was not really happening because a large turkey does not get colder in a 350 degree oven. Why did this happen? Well, I read in the reviews here on Amazon, the response from the engineer at Taylor. I read this BEFORE I used the thermometer, and I knew that several other reviewers had the temperature vary considerably, and that the "solution" given by the Taylor engineer was to make sure the probe was fully inserted. So, that's what I did. For our turkey, I inserted the probe all the way down into the breast, away from the bone, all the way up to the large bend in the probe.However, the real killer, and the thing that ultimately caused the unit to fail and makes it completely unfit for its intended purpose, is that it cannot be used in the BBQ. Yes, you read that correctly. Again, I read the cautions from the Taylor engineer about making sure the probe wire goes through a hole in the BBQ and is not crimped by the hot lid. I did EXACTLY as he advised, "snaking" the the wire through a hole. It was not crimped in any way whatsoever.However, the probe wire melted, after just six minutes, at the point where it went through the hole.Now here is where it gets interesting.After the unit failed, I called the Taylor service line. The woman I spoke to was very helpful, knowledgeable, courteous, and nice. Taylor gets an A+ for good customer service. She could not have been any better. I told her my story, and she then said: "that thermometer is not intended for use in a BBQ." I then asked, thinking I had missed something: "Do the instructions make any reference to this, or are there any warnings or cautions on the box or anywhere else?" Her answer was no. What's more, I then returned to this Amazon page where the description states: "For use in oven or on barbecue or smoker."So, the whole concept of this product is to let you tell, at a distance, whether something you are cooking has reached the proper temperature. The BBQ is the one obvious place where this would be useful. However, it cannot be used in the BBQ -- even when following the advice given by one of the people who designed it -- without destroying the unit.Thankfully, Amazon has a great return policy. However, Amazon should simply not carry this product because ultimately they will get a lot of returns.One final thing. I purchased this because of the reviews at America's Test Kitchen/Cook's Illustrated. I am becoming very concerned about whether their testers are really doing the testing they claim to be doing or, potentially more disturbing, are being biased or influenced by certain manufacturers. I am now viewing all reviews from this source with a certain suspicion.I hope this helps!!

I did extensive research on this two years ago when everyone was going hands-free. My main criteria was getting the best possible sound. The audio quality -- both for the person speaking and the person on the other end -- is absolutely awful with most cell phones. I wanted to improve that. Almost universally, this headset won all the reviews.I paid $99 two years ago, so the $69 price is a great deal.I'm sure you can get a much cheaper unit, but this product is awfully good. Of course if fashion or other considerations are important, this may not be what you want. It fits over the ear, rather than in the ear, and it has an actual microphone, unlike the "jawbone" earpieces that pick up vibrations from your jaw.I often cannot understand my daughter when she calls while walking down the street because of the wind and street noise. This unit has advanced noise cancellation technology that eliminates almost all background noise. I cannot tell if she is in the car going down the street at 60 mph, or in her apartment.I don't own a cell phone myself, but I borrow my wife's from time to time, and when I use the earpiece (I got one for her too), I can hear the other person much, much better than I can just using the cell phone by itself.Battery life has not been a problem either for my wife or my daughter although, like any Bluetooth device, your cell phone battery will not last as long when using a headset. When not using the headset, disable Bluetooth on your cell phone. (Just to be clear, this "problem" has nothing to do with this device, but is simply the result of the cell phone needing to use more power to transmit not only to the cell tower, but also to the local headset).Plantronics is an old-line company that has been selling professional headsets to telephone operators, both in the phone company and at corporate switchboards, since the early 1960s, and have made many of the headsets used by astronauts, pilots, as well as phone operators.

I purchased this battery in August 2009. It lasted two years. I have several other laptops with batteries that are close to six years old and are still running.Not only did this battery not last very long, but it failed all at once, meaning that it won't run the computer for even one second, even though the computer claims that it is fully charged.I still give the battery two stars because it did work for about eighteen months before it began to not run the computer for as long. Also, it is possible that the fault lies with the Fujitsu S7110 charging system. I have no way of knowing.

I purchased this meter to understand why my electric bill has become so high. I knew that I had lots of devices connected 24/7 that were each using small amounts of electric power, but didn't know whether that was my problem. Also, I have two refrigerators, but one of them is seldom opened. I didn't know if it was a major contributor to my problem. And finally, I have some devices that we use frequently which clearly consume a lot of power, like our television and home theater system, and I didn't know if watching that for several hours a day was causing a problem.The product provided answers to all my questions.What it doesThe meter plugs into a wall outlet, and then you un-plug the device you want to measure, and instead plug it into the meter. You immediately can see how much power the device is using at that moment in time. When you do this, you have to remember that some devices have a standby mode, where they are consuming some power, but are not consuming as much power as when they are being used. A good example is a TV set. It uses a little power all the time so it can read the "on command" from your remote control. Then, once turned on, the TV consumes a lot more power than in standby.So for many devices, you have to measure the standby power, and then measure the power again once the device is turned on.Almost any power meter can measure these two types of power. However what makes this particular meter so useful is that it can accumulate measurements over time, so you can figure out how much power a device will use, on average, over a cycle of many days. A good example of this is your refrigerator. You can wait until you hear it running and then plug it into the meter and read the power. I did this with the old fridge in our garage and found that it uses 248 watts while running. However, that is not a useful figure because, of course, any refrigerator cycles on and off during the course of the day. What you really need to know is how much power it uses over the course of 24, 48, or 72 hours. With the P4460 Kill A Watt EZ power meter, you can plug in an appliance, walk away, and come back in an hour, day, or week, and read the total amount of power used over that period of time. It is easy to then figure out how much power the appliance will use, on average, during the course of a month, and how much it will cost.To help you with the cost calculation, the meter lets you enter your energy cost in cents per killowatt hour (a figure you'll find on your monthly bill) and it will then tell you how much the appliance will cost per day, week, month, or year. This is pretty neat, although there is one flaw in this approach. The flaw is that PG&E (our electricity provider) has a multi-tier rate system where we pay very little for the first 90 killowatt-hours of electricity, then more for the next 30, even more for the next 60, and even more for everything after that. You'll have to come up with your own math if you want to figure out which rate to use. My solution was to use the most expensive rate because our bill always triggers the top tier (as I expect most people's bills will do if they own a home instead of an apartment). Thus, any new electricity usage will always be charged incrementally at the top rate.What it doesn't doThis meter requires that you be able to plug the device into the meter. This means that you have to be able to get at the plug and disconnect it from the wall. By contrast, you can purchase a "clamp on" power meter that only requires that you be able to access a wire that feeds the device, and you then clamp onto that wire, without disconnecting the device, and the meter reads the power by reading the induced magnetic field from the wire. This is a much more elaborate way of measuring power, and these devices cost at least ten times what the P4460 costs.The meter also cannot help you measure anything that is built in. Thus, you can't measure the power used by all the lights in your kitchen (we have a lot of track lights which are quite clearly consuming a lot of power, but I can't measure this with the P4460). The Kill A Watt also cannot measure 240V appliances like your dryer or electric oven.Summary -- Is It Useful?So, having used this meter for a few days, was it worth the cost and is it useful? The answer to both questions is a resounding YES! I was able to find out that the almost ninety devices I have connected to the wall in this house use enough standby electricity (the amount used when connected, but not turned on) to cost me almost $40 per month. Some of the whacko "green" people try to tell me that I should disconnect these devices, but that is not practical. Do I really want to turn off my Internet modem, my router, my wireless access point, my fax machine, my telephone answer machine, my portable phone, etc. and only turn them on at the instant I'm going to use them? I suppose I could, but it would make them far less useful, and would be a total pain in the neck.However, I did find several devices that used a lot more standby power than I would have thought, and which I CAN turn off. A good example is the furnace. During the summer, I don't need to have these connected (I actually have two small furnaces, instead of one large one). I had never bothered to unplug them. However, the P4460 tells me that they are using 13.2 watts of power, all day, all night, every day. I found that at my electricity rates, every 5 watts of 24/7 power costs me $1 per month. Thus, by unplugging the two furnaces I am going to be able to save about $2.25 per month for about four months of the year.So, I have identified appliances that I can disconnect, without greatly affecting my lifestyle, and by doing so, I can save money. I'll certainly pay for this gadget within the first year, just by doing this.I am NOT doing this to "save the planet," because quite frankly what I do -- and even what lots of people like me doing the same thing -- won't make a hill of beans difference (take a look at how much electricity is used to create a pound of aluminum or roll a sheet of steel ...). I am an electrical engineer, and believe me, you don't change things by operating at the margins of the problem.Instead, I'm doing this because it is going to save money on my electricity bill. The cause may not be as noble as the fiction of "saving the planet," but it is far more real and -- this is the whole point -- far more MEASURABLE!

I ordered a package of 24 60W Sylvania bulbs, despite the many reviews suggesting a quality control problem.Unfortunately, those reviews are accurate. The bulbs arrived totally intact (no broken glass), and the package was in perfect shape. Thus, I don't think there was a problem in packaging. However, because of the reviews, I tested each of the 24 bulbs. 10 of the 24 -- almost 1/2 of all the bulbs -- were defective. I could see the filaments inside were detached. In addition, each bulb had a different amount of frosted coating, and in many cases the coating was non-uniform.So, bottom line, these bulbs are junk, the product of incompetent manufacturing practices. Under no circumstances should you waste your time ordering these. I am returning mine for a refund, and will purchase light bulbs instead at 1000bulbs.com, bulbster.com, or bulbs.com, all of which I have used before, and none of which has shipped even one bad bulb. I don't blame Amazon for this, but I will blame them if they continue to sell such an obviously substandard product.[Edit]The day I wrote this review, I returned all these defective bulbs, and Amazon promptly refunded my purchase. Thank you Amazon! I then ordered several dozen bulbs from "bulbs.com". This new order included not only 24 incandescent bulbs, but also many, many other bulbs. I tested all sixty bulbs when they arrived an every single one tested OK. So, instead of 10 out of 24 defective units, I had 0 out of 60. This improvement was due to the fact that bulbs.com shipped quality product, and also to the fact that they did the most unbelievably wonderful job of packing that I've ever seen. My kids had a science project in eight grade where they had to design packing that would let them drop an egg from two stories up onto a concrete sidewalk, and not have the egg break. The folks at bulbs.com would have easily won that competition. So, if you can get things from bulbs.com through Amazon, then order your bulbs there. If not, just go to their site and order from them directly.[Edit #2]December 19, 2013.I have recently received several nasty comments on my review above. The people leaving these comments claim that I am working for bulbs.com because I mention that I eventually purchased A19 bulbs at that site and was happy with the product. You can look at my other reviews and should be able to tell that I am just another Amazon customer because I have reviewed many dozens of products and almost none of them are available at bulbs.com.Also, please note the date on my review. I wrote it in 2011. If you look at other reviews done around the same time as mine, you will find that many other customers were reporting serious quality control problems. More recent reviews seem to be more positive, so it is possible that the product has been changed, or the source of supply is different.So please don't accuse me of being dishonest. I do not represent any company or site, and have no hidden agenda. I simply reported, accurately, on my experience with this product.

I purchased this bulb to use in an old photo/video lighting stand.First, as others have written, this bulb is extremely large. If you remember the old "mogul" base bulbs, it is even bigger than those. It is MUCH larger than the 300W incandescent bulbs that I was hoping to replace.Second, the light has an ethereal quality to it. If you have used any of the modern LED flashlights, perhaps you have experienced this feeling: the light itself looks bright when you look directly at it, but objects illuminated by the light seem to be dimly lit. I have heard that, with LED lights, the narrow spectrum of light is responsible for this effect. That is, LED lights supposedly only put out light in one part of the spectrum, so your eye is not receiving a uniform mixture of all colors from light reflected from objects receiving light from this bulb. I don't know if that is a valid explanation, nor do I know if this CF's color output is broad-based. I do know that if you want to use this light to actually be able to see things easily, you may be disappointed.The ballast runs very cool. The bulb itself gets moderately warm to the touch, but not hot.The color is supposed to be daylight color balanced (5500K). I do not have equipment to check that. My impression is that the color probably tends to be closer to the greenish blue of traditional cool white fluorescent bulbs. I am going to try to do some photography with it and see if I can get decent color. Unfortunately, because this bulb is SO MUCH bigger than I expected, I cannot use it with my existing lighting kit. It is my fault for not carefully reading the specs. To save you from finding these yourself, here are the specs: 10.5" long and 3.9" in diameter. Thus, it is ALMOST A FOOT LONG!! And, it is almost 1/3 of a foot in diameter.So, if the color balance turns out to be correctable (for photography purposes) this might be a very interesting bulb to use, if you are building your own lighting kit from scratch. However, for insertion into existing fixtures or kits, measure carefully before purchasing this bulb. And if you want to make a room appear really bright, I don't think this bulb is the answer.

This program came bundled on my Dell computer a few years ago. Unlike Symantec/Norton Anti-virus which slows your computer to a crawl and is truly an evil program, PC-cillin does its job without causing your computer to slow to a crawl. It is relatively easy to configure.However, I have seven other computers, none of which has ANY anti-virus software. These computers have never had a virus. Guess which computer has had three viruses? Yes, the one with PC-cillin installed. I am a computer programmer, so I know how to spot a virus, and therefore I am quite certain that the other computer do not have any problems.The real kicker on this program, however, is the outrageous Trend Micro renewal policy. Look at the price for this program at the top of this page, and then go to the Trend Micro page and type "renewal" in the search box. What you will quickly find is that a one year renewal for this program is $79!! That's right: they are going to charge you almost twice what you paid for the program -- and do that every year -- just to get new virus patterns, something other vendors sometimes do for free.So, even though I was happy with this program when I first got it (because I was coming from the horrendous Symantec fiasco), I am now terribly disappointed because of Trend's customer-antagonistic renewal policy, and its rather poor ability to actually prevent viruses.

I was in the desktop publishing business in the 1980s. Companies sent us their printers for evaluation. Since that time I have used or reviewed dozens of printers.Two years ago, a client gave me the Epson R260 so I could print on inkjet-printable DVDs that I was delivering to him.The one piece of good news is that, when it works, the Epson R260 makes beautiful prints on DVD discs.That is the ONLY good news.In every other respect, this is a horrible printer. I hate it.First of all, the CD/DVD tray jams constantly. I complained to Epson tech support and they sent a new tray to me (the jamming happened within a few weeks of my first use). The jamming continued.Second of all -- and this is unforgivable -- every time the printer has any kind of major jam or malfunction (which seems to happen about every 50-75 DVDs), it goes into some sort of reset mode which includes dumping ink. And not a little ink, but approximate 25% of the ink in all six cartridges. Now, I purchase nothing but genuine Epson ink, and in case you haven't looked, a complete set costs $80, plus tax. So each of these episodes costs me a twenty dollar bill. Just imagine every time you have any problem with your printer, you have to reach into your pocket, pull out a twenty dollar bill, and put it in the waste basket.I have own three HP inkjet printers (the P1000, P1100, & HP855C) and I've had them for years and years. They work perfectly every time, use very little ink, and are wonderful in every way.So, do not purchase any Epson inkjet printer, ever. Stay away! Get an HP or Canon.

I have used this product for almost five years. I used many other PC backup products prior to this and was impressed by the simplicity of the Trueimage interface, the fact that it would do both drive image backup (for restoring an entire partition) as well as file backup. It was also MUCH faster than products I previously used from Stomp and Seagate.Over the years, I recommended this product to dozens of friends and clients, and actually looked forward to the chore of backing up.But then, Acronis lost its way.Somewhere around version 9, the backups I created sometimes would not "validate" (a feature built into Trueimage to tell you whether your backup is going to be able to restore). And then, one day when disaster struck and I had to restore for real, I found out that the image backup of my boot drive was "corrupt" and I was unable to restore. Fortunately, I had another image backup that I had created a few weeks earlier and was able to use that.I then spent the next year working with Acronis tech support and posting on their forums trying to get an answer. What I found is that dozens and dozens and dozens of other people are having the exact same problem. Acronis tells everyone that it is due to faulty RAM, but everyone who has the problem goes ahead and runs the MEMTEST32 program, finds out that their RAM is perfectly fine, and are then left hung out to dry. (To be fair a very small percentage find out they do have a RAM problem, so this is not entirely a red herring - although it is pretty close to that).So, what you have here is a fantastic, dynamite product, with all the features, speed, and user interface you could ever hope to have, sold at a reasonable price, but with a fatal flaw that renders it unusable to a sizable percentage of its intended market.So go ahead and buy it (better yet, download the trial) and see if it works on your computer. Make sure to select the "validate" option so that you can tell if the backup you just made has any chance of being restored. If you get the message that the archive is corrupt, do NOT purchase this product because it is going to be nothing but a headache.The Acronis tech support people were slow, but ultimately responsive, and did try to help, but it has become clear that they know they have a problem, and that their engineering team is unwilling or simply unable to provide a fix to the flaws they have let creep into this wonderful program.
Super handy.  All first aid kits should have these for stubborn lacerations that a 'regular' band aid can't keep sealed.

Used this on a dock to help reduce rubbing effects of a boat on the dock on a freshwater lake for about 4 months of dockside boat storage.  In-laws were nervous about permanently securing it to their fancy dock system so we attached it using white heavy duty cable ties.  It's sort of hillbilly but it's a good way to try it out before permanently installing this.  After one season, the redneck cable tie system remains intact.  Your mileage may vary.

Another device you should not go another second of your life without.  For all of you lost souls out there who have somehow subjected themselves to the dust-bunny wrestling madness that is wiring up the back of a modern stereo receiver, this is for you.  It's a pain in the, well, you fill in the blank, to wire up the speaker wires.  Which is positive, which is negative, now I have to move and reconnect the whole thing again.  Fear not.  Identify your negative lead and put the black banana plug on it.  It's easy like Sunday morning.  Then the red one goes on the other wire.  Then you just plug it into the back of the receiver - like every other wire on the back of the receiver.  Literally, no screwing around.  Just plug and done.  Anyway, maybe this isn't worthy of a Nobel Prize but really, it's awesome.  Or you can just wire it up old school style.  But why man, why?  Thank me later, this will change your life.  For the better.

You had me at "master feeler".  I'm not sure what these do but they sure look nice in my sparkplug drawer.  Ok, so they are used for gapping sparkplugs.  Keep it oiled or it looks like it might get rusty.

This solves the problem you didn't know you had.  Looking for those dang tire caps that go missing for no apparent reason.  Like socks in a dryer.  A pack of 40 will last until the Apocalypse.  Probably.  Anyway, they're exactly as described and make capping tire valves a real joy.  No more unsightly metal threads to mock your pathetic lack of maintenance ability.

There are probably cheaper versions of this out there but this one works well.  You fill the tire, check the pressure and if there's too much pressure, you hit the button, bleed air out and check it again.  And it glows in the dark.  Not that you'll be filling tires up in the dark that often but if you make a habit of dark-filling your tires this thing is the tool for you.  If you have a gearhead in your family get one for them.  They'll appreciate the quality and wonder why they didn't get one before.

This worked great on an aluminum dock.  We used long cable ties (zip ties) to secure it to the dock instead of screwing it into the aluminum.  The white zip ties held up for the summer and were hard to see so it didn't look completely hillbilly.  This material seems similar to the material TaylorMade uses in their other water products.  Good stuff, easy install, worked as directed.  I'm going to get a few more next year now that I'm confident in the product.

I have a few friends in the Warden Service.  They always tell these crazy stories and you're left thinking there's no way that can happen in the real world.  Then you watch the show and sure enough, it happens.It's great to have a show that shows how challenging their job is.  Some of the people they meet out in the woods are real characters and the accents aren't fake either.  Some of the wardens are real characters too.If you're from Maine or just "Maine-curious" this is a great show to watch.  If you have a relative from Maine and you're looking for a cool gift definitely consider giving them a DVD of North Woods Law.  There's something for everybody whether it's the Maine woods scenery, the "cops" style action or the interesting characters that they run into.

Purchased directly from the manufacturer.  It works as advertised.  It was very easy to install.Couple of points.Doesn't seem like you can play music on your local network at home.  Strange since the original Xbox and the 360 both could.  Perhaps there is an app on the way to facilitate this.Connecting to Netflix and Amazon online video services was very quick and easy.Took about 15 minutes or so to install Ghosts to the hard drive.  That's annoying because no one likes to wait.  But it worked fine and started and stopped quickly once installed.What's coolest is that games run as 'apps' basically so you can just switch right back to the home screen in about 1 second.  This is cool if you have kids that you don't need to be watching combat games or if the phone rings etc. it's like having a pause button built in.  The old system would have required you to quit the game.  This may not seem like much to non-gamers but it's really awesome in practice.Switching between apps on the Xbox is very, very quick.Connecting it was easy.  HDMI cable (buy them at Amazon if you need one longer than provided in the box), power cable, cable for the Kinect.  God bless HDMI.The kids loved trying to tell the Xbox what to do.  It didn't work well but was very entertaining as they tried dreadlocks and redsocks and hexbugs etc.  If you enunciate carefully it works great with the expected gimmicky behavior common to voice input.I had no problems with the disc drive.  Some have reported this to be an issue but wasn't a problem on my device.  The drive played games and bluray quickly.  Oddly it requires a bluray app to be installed but it took about 2 minutes to do this so no complaints.It's absolutely quiet in operation.  A soft white glow from the power supply is it.The revised controller is evolutionary.  Nothing really to report about it that is exceptional or problematic.Not much is a 5 star product.  On a ten scale this'd be a 9.  I think that because the XBone is so app centric that it will allow Msoft to improve it over time.  Hopefully they allow it to play nice on home networks and stream local content like songs saved to a local hard drive or photos etc.

Updated 12/8/2014One year in...This review is for the the no-ad 64 GB wifi-only HDX 8.9.I use a Galaxy S5 Android smartphone so the HDX is for media / web surfing / offline viewing for travel.  Since I had already been using Amazon Prime and Prime Music it was a no brainer for me to use the HDX to fill the role of media / web surfing on a tablet.Be informed about the download limitations to this device.  Amazon has been adding clarification to this which should help would-be purchasers make a more informed opinion.  This wasn't as obvious as it should have been when I ordered mine so they're listening which is good.Be aware that their most popular Prime content *may* not be available to download (and save) to your HDX.  You can save certain videos to your HDX but you won't know which ones until you buy an HDX and try it out.  *** Edited 12/21/2013  You can now see a list of Prime movies and shows that can be downloaded to the device.  That's an improvement and more clearly shows the available downloadable Prime content.  +1 for Amazon. ***I was also under the assumption that you could download as many videos as you'd like with the limiting factor being the memory capacity of the HDX.  Also NOT the case.  So again, I bought the larger capacity HDX under this assumption.  That was dumb on my part as it turns out because you're not limited by storage capacity.  You're limited the NUMBER of downloads you can have on your device.  Kids' content can be really short so you may find yourself running into that limitation, but most people never will.  Many people will opt up for the 64 GB device like I did only to find that 16 GB would likely do fine since it would be hard to download enough content to fill 64 GB, particularly on 'standard' resolution.  As another commenter pointed out if you downloaded long movies in full HD perhaps you'd really want the bigger device.  Which brings me to the final point.The final criticism is that once you start watching content you have to finish watching the content within 48 hours or you need to reconnect to the internet.  Again, I was surprised to find out that the content I downloaded expired.  This is odd since you'd download because you were likely traveling to a location that didn't have wifi.  Hopefully these criticisms lead to a more informed purchase decision on your part.Here is the official word from Amazon which is indeed on their site and the purpose for my edit.  I was unable to find this prior to my purchase and learned about it only after I acquired the device.*  Many (but not all as I note above) Prime Instant Video titles are also available for download on Kindle Fire HD 2nd Generation and Kindle Fire HDX devices. The detail page for each Prime Instant Video title indicates whether the title is available for download. You can download available titles to only two separate devices at one time. If you have already downloaded a title to two devices, you need to delete it from one of them before downloading it to another device.*  You can have a maximum of 25 total Prime Instant Video titles downloaded at a time across all devices associated with your Amazon.com account. While not all Prime Instant Video titles are available for download, the same videos may be available for rental or purchase from Amazon Instant Video, and rented or purchased titles can be downloaded to compatible devices.*  Viewing Period: If you have a Prime membership or Prime free trial, you can stream any video that is currently designated as a Prime Instant Video title on its detail page. You can watch Prime Instant Video titles that you've downloaded within a limited viewing period, which varies by title. A typical viewing period is either 48 hours after you start watching the title or 15 or 30 days after the download, whichever is earlier. We'll typically notify you when the viewing period for a title is close to expiring. After your Prime membership or Prime free trial expires or is cancelled, you cannot watch any Prime Instant Video titles unless you've also rented or purchased that title.For about 9 months the camera on this device caused it to take weird pictures.  It seems that along the way a firmware update fixed the camera problems I had earlier so this should not be a concern for users who use their tablet to take photos.Amazon has made subtle improvements to this device over the past year.  It's not 100% Android compliant and doesn't always run YouTube videos very well.  Just hangs and you need to restart it.  Other times w/ the same YouTube content it works.  Weird.  The interface has been improved and it has been reliable for the last year as an intermittent toy.  This is the perfect device for a person new to tablets or heavily invested in Amazon Prime.  The Prime interfaces are outstanding and the device is intuitive and easy to use.  Is it better than an iPad?  It's different.  If you use Amazon a lot I'd give the HDX a try.  If you use Apple all the time, an iPad may be a better choice.  It's very personal and subjective.Amazon really owes it to their faithful customers who purchase these devices to continue to clarify the Prime download experience and this will be a home run.  I hope these comments help you ask good questions and help Amazon continue improve their product and content experience.
Arrived on time, heavy duty, rings stamped as made in USA.  Will have them welded on a car hauler as tie downs.
In case you were wondering this works fine on a Samsung S3.  The blue glow from the adapter is sort of cool.  It's not so bright that it impairs your night vision or anything.

Ok they're batteries.  However, no plastic packaging means at least the packaging is readily recyclable.  We buy them two boxes at a time to support the kids' electronica addictions and have had positive (get it?) experience with them to date in terms of as-advertised performance.

Initial impressions are that this is a well built quality item that should last for a long time.  I use a little vegetable oil on it to help reduce surface friction and improve overall cleaning.  Seems to help.

Whoever invented the tri-ball receiver hitch should have received a Nobel prize for common sense.  Buy one (don't forget to get a couple of pins too as these seem to 'wander' particularly when you most need one), keep it in the cab.  Attach it when you need it.  No more, "dang, I left my XX" hitch ball at home...".  When you're done, put it back in the cab.  A seriously awesome idea backed up by heavy construction.

I got this to use on our son's "spy robot" costume.  Where it's battery powered, it worked well in the pressboard costume.  I got two which is good as the first one didn't really work that well.  The "lightning" didn't really show up that well.  Sort of fuzzy.  The second box contained the unit that is well represented by the photos showing clear lightning bolts.  When there is noise, the lightning activates.  It is very cool especially among 5 year old males.  Ok, ALL males.  Amazon was outstanding in accepting the return of the improperly functioning unit.  Perhaps it's wise to buy two at a time but I only did it due to a time crunch on the costume and needed to be certain I'd have a functional device.

I've had this album on CD for about 12 years now.  I would characterize this as being similar in nature to James Taylor.  Coffee house type fare.  Pretty low key punctuated by some power without hitting the listener over the head with overproduced ruckus.  Closer to You would be the most likely of the songs to hear any commercial airplay but it would be a shame to miss the other great works on this album.  Low key but happy with a nice emphasis on vocals over instruments.

I had A-wires for about 12 years and recently lost them.  Despondent, I sought an equivalent replacement and found these to hit the mark even better than my beloved A-wires.  I bought the "Dark w/ ice iridium, polarized".  They ain't whistlin' Dixie.  These things are DARK.  I did not compare these to non-polarized lenses so I can't comment on whether or not there is a difference between the two.Fit is going to be extremely individual but these are not as tight on the temple as their older wires.  This is something to consider if you are going to wear these under a helmet so be sure you can return them if that becomes an issue.  They are extremely light.  The optics are very clear.  They look more formal / professional (?) than the all-plastic models in my opinion.  They are very finely crafted which is important considering the premium you pay for them.  If these last 10 years the cost will be a bargain.

This printer is very good unless you are using 64 bit Windows 7.  I've spent many hours trying to make this work and it just seems to be incompatible.  I don't know precisely why I thought it made sense to use 64 bit Windows in the first place as I'm only running 4 GB of RAM but that's another story.  On my 32 bit Windows 7 it ran fine and was a nice companion to print 11x17 / ledger / tabloid color projects and I would recommend it.  2 stars for poor driver support for 64 bit.

This works on the 2002 WRX in case you were searching and wondering if this is the correct part.  Installed on mine and it works as advertised.  I can't say if it is a marked improvement as it was done in conjunction with a pantload of other modifications.

I've used this for a while.  I got a copy cheap from the Microsoft store years ago and actually used it to layout our house.At work I use it for making org-charts and I have to say that's a hit or miss experience.  Sometimes it works the way you want it to and others, not so much.It is highly advanced and probably a lot more so than most of us need.  I mean, do you really need to mess around with importing and exporting data into Visio?  I suppose you could if you had to update it a lot.The schedule thing is pretty cool to do a quick timeline and the calendar function is really great for making jumbo sized calendars assuming you're into that kind of thing.It's great for process descriptions or stepwise type routines that you need to put in a manual or a procedure.I'd say it's sort of the Swiss Army Knife in the Microsoft suite of software.  It can do a lot of cool things but also has tools that you might never use.Overall, it's really too bad you don't get this w/ Office Professional instead of Publisher as this is a much more versatile tool.  And, best of all, the folks at Microsoft have the awesome try before you buy plan.  If you like it you just download a key and keep using it.

I got a PS3 for Christmas as a Blu-Ray and regular DVD player.  I was an early adopter on the Xbox 360 and was SURE that HD-DVD would be the winning format.  History has shown that to be wrong.  Stinging from my poor decision, I waited it out and well, what the heck, adopted Blu-ray hoping that my purchase wasn't the start of some sort of Blu-Ray pandemic that would 86 yet another own-your-own-media format.  When it tanks, I'm movin' to Uruguay to harvest guano.However, I am one of the few people alive that can comment on the Xbox remote control vs. the PS3 Remote.  The major difference is that the Xbox control LIT UP.The PS3 does not light up.  Which really, is numb.  Oh sure it's Bluetooth but when we watch movies, it's not in a brightly lit room.  We're rockin' the home theater experience which means it's dark and you have to watch out that you don't inadvertently sit on a nesting feline.  The ergonomics are weak meaning that there is no real texture telling you that one button means play and the other stop or pause or fast forward or chapter ahead.  They are sized a whisker differently but really, why no lights?  Or even something that glows?  Or package it with a flashlight.  You're killin' me here.And I'm dying to know, what are the multi-colored buttons for?  Actually, that's hyperbole.  I truly don't care.  Someone will post that the buttons actually have an importance rivaled only by the discovery of the polio vaccine or fire but I could give a hoot.  I'd press these pretty buttons (they sure are tempting since everything else is blacked out) but in the event it somehow controls some behavior on the PS3 that would forever eliminate the color red from existence, I'm keeping my curiosity at bay.That said, when you can actually see the buttons it does work without any flaws and you don't have to wave it around trying to make contact with the PS3 as it's not an infrared signal from the remote to the Blu-ray.  And mixing Bluetooth with Blu-Ray is pretty awesome.  Not really but is it simply coincidence all of this bluish high tech stuff?  I think not.Anyway, Xbox remote which still works on my 6 HD-DVD's which will one day be relegated to ultra-high-definition beer coasters gets 5 stars.  Ho hum PS3 darkened remote gets 2 because it's of very little use in a darkened room and it has the potentially doomsday multicolored buttons.

I own and game on an Xbox 360.  This is also used as our media hub.  I was an early adopter and was convinced that HD-DVD would be the wave of the 1080p hi-def own-your-own-media future.  Umm, no.  And MSoft is avoiding BluRay like the plague going so far as to call it a "big bag of hurt".  Ouch.  What to do?So I got a PS3 slim 250GB player for Christmas for the primary purpose of playing BluRay movies.It is a very easy installation.Be advised it does NOT come with an HDMI cable so if you order one online, be sure to also purchase an HDMI cable or 2 instead of getting it at the local stores that charge 3 to 10 times as much.  The PS3 does not supply even component cables which is a surprise in a way, but since not everyone has a modern TV I suppose you can see where Sony is covering the primary bases.I have mine running an optical connection out to the receiver; HDMI direct to the TV (Panasonic plasma).  The only reason for this was because I only had one HDMI cable at the time so this is jury-rigged but it works fine.It outputs at 1080p as advertised and is easy to set up.  You'll want your receiver manuals and TV manuals handy but it only takes about 15 minutes or so to rig it up.  My TV and receiver are pretty modern; both are only a year old so they can take full advantage of all of the PS3 digital gee-gaws.  Again, check your TV / receiver first to ensure they can match up to the PS3's digital hotness.  If not you may be chagrined to not get 1080p on your old TV etc.The PS will find your wireless network (if you have one) and connect to it automatically (unless you need to put in usernames and passwords etc.; then it's pretty simple to enter in your information and go).  You can also plug it into a typical CAT5 jack (those blue computer wires are CAT5) if you have one handy.  The internet connection is the way they keep the firmware of the Bluray player up to date.  This was an issue w/ early Bluray players.I was hopeful that it would play lossless .wma files like the Xbox does but it definitely doesn't like those files at all.  It sees them but won't play them.  This is a technical issue that you wouldn't really find by reading the PS3 box and probably isn't much of an issue except for geeks.  Geeks like say, me.As a Bluray player it works fine and is very quiet in its operation.  The Xbox sounds like a dump truck driving through a nitroglycerin factory in comparison.  The image is very clear as you would anticipate and the sound is top notch.  It's a little bit of a mystery at first how to operate the usual play / stop / start modes with the little game controller but after dubbing around for a few minutes you can figure it out.  The game controller is a rechargeable unit so after the first hour or so you can unplug it from the mini USB charger that goes on the front of the PS3.Haven't tried Netflix on this yet.  On the Xbox it's seamless and easy; my understanding is on the PS you need a disc to insert and then you can play your 'watch it now' Netflix on the PS.  This is pretty cool on the Xbox as you can occasionally get hi-def content free w/ your Netflix subscription and download.  A selling point for the PS?  For some folks, sure.  Will increase the Wife Approval Factor which can be critical.As a media server, the Xbox seems to be better though it's way harder to set up the Xbox.  Perhaps because I had the Xbox set up already the PS could 'find' media files much quicker.  As noted though, it doesn't 'like' lossless format whereas the Xbox plays lossless .wma.  This is a big deal if you have saved your CD's to an external drive or something.  If you haven't done that yet and buy a PS3 then just be aware of the limitations in advance.  For most people this is a non-issue.As a standalone Bluray player it probably doesn't make sense in terms of its high price.  However, if you don't already have an Xbox but you do have some of your digital media (e.g. pictures / videos / .mp3s) saved on your local network and you don't want a lot of gear to play your .mp3 / iPod files on your stereo then this is a good choice.  If all of your stuff is in Microsoft formats, the Xbox is a better media server / erstwhile game unit.

Our son wanted a crane for Christmas so naturally we caved to his desires and picked up this sweet Playmobil crane.He spends a lot of time watching the Fred Levine series "Little Hardhats" with Rusty and George and is now into the boats / harbors / cranes.  That's a really good series in case you are curious.  We have used this to dodge the Wiggles and Barney so it's worth the $$.The crane is well constructed but I'm not sure how durable it will be over the long haul.  If it lasts a year I'll be surprised.  It's an indoor only toy.  The tower and arm of the crane are plastic trusses.  The crane hook is steel and goes up and down with the press of a button.
