The box they come in isnt fancy, but looks very nice if giving the earrings as a present.

Homicide detective Livy Reynolds doesnt have much respect for private investigators, but she agrees to help PI Alex Jennings investigate the disappearance of a senators daughter, Samantha Jo. Livy doesnt really care for Alex, but she needs something to get her mind off her administrative leave from her job and the case is very similar to her cousin Robyns disappearance two years earlier. Although some think Robin chose to walk out on her family, Livy thinks there is more to the story. The case takes some unexpected turns, as do Livys feelings for Alex.This is the third in the Logan Point novels, but the first Ive read. Gone Without a Trace is an enjoyable romantic suspense novel, and I was interested to see what would happen with Robyn and Samantha Jo and also if the romance between Livy and Alex would progress. I found all of the characters interesting, but there were more than a few plot holes. Robyns actions in particular dont always make sense and the premise surrounding her disappearance is difficult to believe.If you dont mind suspending disbelief, this is a quick read with characters you will root for. Ive rated the book 3 stars, but because of the likeability of Alex and Livy, would actually say its more like a 3.5.I received this book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of Revell, in exchange for an honest review.

Keeps beer cold, and doesn't let it go flat. It is made of metal so it is not as breakable as the glass growlers my husband has had before. I am a little concerned about the plastic top, the hinge may be the weak link there.You can also use it as a normal thermos, but at 64 ounces it is a big thermos. Overall very nice.

Reading a new book in the #1 Ladies Detective Agency series is a special treat. Although they are technically categorized as Mysteries, these tales set in Botswana are first and foremost, beautiful stories. Mma Ramotswe, who started the agency, is a compassionate and wise woman who solves all sorts of problems for her clients. In this story, she feels pressured to take a holiday and leave an important case in the hands of her former assistant, now Co-director, Mma Makutsi. With her knowledge of human nature, Mma Ramotswe is usually teaching others, both her clients and her friends. However, in this book it Grace Makutsi, who teaches Mma Ramatswe about friendship and trust.I have never been disappointed by any of the books in this series and The Woman Who Walked in Sunshine is another five-star read. I enjoyed this book from the beginning to the end and the highlights are touching scenes between Mma Ramatswe and Mma Makutsi, as well as an amusing scene with the two detectives and Mma Makutsis nemesis Violet Sephotho. Both new readers and those who have read the prior books in the series will enjoy the latest by Alexander McCall Smith.

I have followed this series for a long time, and I enjoy reading about Monk and Hester. Anne Perrys novels are always well-written, and there are some very touching scenes with Monk, Hester, and Scuff, the young man they have basically adopted, which were the highlight of this book for me. Overall, however, something was lacking in this installment compared to others in this long-running series.In Corridors of the Night, Monks case with the Thames River Police takes a backseat to a case involving Hester. In fact, the focus was so much on Hester that events with Monk and his team were really meaningless and didnt add much to the book at all. I would be okay if Monks case wasnt the focus, but unfortunately, Hesters case was also lacking. The background on the history of the first blood transfusions was interesting and Hesters situation was definitely suspenseful. It may have been just me, but Hester didnt seem like herself to me. She seemed wishy-washy about the fate of one of the characters who performed atrocious acts in the name of science and that just didnt seem like the Hester Ive gotten to know who is always a protector of women and children. The book kept my interest while I was reading it, but isnt one that will stay with me now that Ive finished it. I am hoping the next installment is up to Perrys usual excellence.

Nice laminated quick reference electrical code book, quite handy to keep in the toolbox without worry about it falling apart. It covers most aspects of residential code requirements in an easy to handle book. It has photos to help you with what you are looking up. This should be a must have for many homeowners as it will quickly explain the wiring in their house. As an electrical engineer I reviewed it and I can say it helps when you have a quick question for crews in the field and is a lot more handy than dragging the code book around.

The 6 port power strip/surge protector is a good unit to have to protect your electronics. This one comes with 1000 Joule rating which should do the job protecting most equipment (unless you have something really sensitive to surges). It also has connections for insulating the antenna from surges which is a plus. It has a $150,000 warranty against damage to equipment connected to the device. I do like that it does not have a switch on the face of the unit as I am constantly hitting this when plugging in, or unplugging equipment from my other power strips.

Bella Jordan is recently widowed and unemployed and has run out of options. For the good of her son, Max, the two leave Bedford, New York and head for Chicago to temporarily stay with her judgmental mother-in-law. Car troubles, an unexpected storm, and a pregnant cat in need force them to stop in Lily Dale, New York. Young Max loves the friends he has made in the unusual town, but the penchant the residents have for regularly communicating with the spirit world, as well as a very human murderer, leave Bella unsure about calling Lily Dale their new home.Wendy Corsi Staub has a successful Young Adult series set in Lily Dale, New York, but this is the first book in a new cozy mystery series for adults. I enjoyed the setting and the characters very much. Readers familiar with the authors thrillers will find this mystery just as suspenseful, but less intense and without any graphic violence. A little research show that many of the events, such as the Message Service, and places such as the Sweat Lodge and Inspiration Stump described in the book, actually exist in the real town of Lily Dale.In addition to the appealing setting, the book is enjoyable because Bella is a relatable main character. She is a young widow with a smart, sweet five-year-old son, looking for a fresh start after her beloved husbands death. She isnt over her husbands death, but is trying to move on for her sons sake. Its logical and in fact smart of Bella to be careful who she trusts in Lily Dale, since there has been a suspicious death and other strange events which could be related. However, it gets really old hearing Bella repeatedly say she has to leave Lily Dale as soon as possible, since she at least has a temporary job, a beautiful home in which she and her son can stay for free, and several new friends. The only thing waiting for her in Chicago is the prospect of sharing a small apartment with her disapproving mother-in-law who isnt eager to open her home to Bella or her young son. It also isnt unusual that Bella would be skeptical of some of the self-proclaimed psychics in the town, but she goes a little overboard in her fear. However, the plot kept my interest from the beginning to end and the town is full of quirky, likeable characters.It wouldnt be a true cozy without a cat, but Chance the Cat, based on a real pet of the authors, isnt just something to add to the cozy feeling of the mystery. Chance plays an important role in leading Bella to Lily Dale and to helping her solve part of the mysterious happenings at the Valley View Manor. Everything is wrapped up at by the end of the book, but the stage is definitely set for a sequel, which I would love to read. I recommend this book for those who dont mind a bit of the supernatural in their mysteries. However, there is nothing so over-the-top that it makes the book far-fetched, so its a great balance of the natural and supernatural.

After a major set-back in their house-hunting caused by a dishonest real estate agent, Hannah Ives, and her husband Paul, have finally purchased a seaside cottage they love. Its a historic building, so it needs an abundance of restoration work to make it inhabitable. When work is being done to repair the chimney, the contractors discover the mummified body of an infant. Its obviously not a recent death, but Hannah will not rest until she is able to find out who the baby was and why the body was hidden.This book is part of The Hannah Ives mysteries series. Ive read a few of the prior books, but its not necessary to have read any of the other books to enjoy this story. Hannah is a likeable main character who is intelligent and independent and also has a great relationship with her husband who is also smart, kind, and unlike in many mysteries, supportive of Hannahs investigating. Their kids are grown and they were looking forward to enjoying their new cottage before the horrible discovery of the infants body. I enjoy reading about Hannahs quest for the truth. Some of the middle parts of the book grew a bit repetitive and the story doesnt have the suspense of Dark Passage, an earlier installment in the series. However, this is a very well-written book containing many interesting historical facts, including information about interracial marriages in this country in the 1950s and 1960s that I wasnt aware of.  I found this to be a satisfying mystery with a touching ending.I received this book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of Severn House. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

This book is nice for some light reading to get you in the mood for the holidays, but is not my favorite book by Wanda Brunstetter. Although the story is upbeat and often amusing, I feel the characters dont have enough depth for the book to warrant a rating higher than 3.5 stars.The main characters in the book are twins Thelma and Elma Hochstetler who are almost identical in looks, but very different in personalities. Thelma sometimes come across as flighty, but she is kind, loving, and fun.  Elma is organized, serious, and sometimes nagging, but has a good heart. The twins are supposed to be in their early thirties, but come across as much younger, not all of which can be explained by their Amish way of life. The story would have been more enjoyable if their ages matched their actions. They are away from home for the first time and as a way to become a part of their new town, they agree to bake something to sell at a charity auction. Their lopsided Christmas cake serves the purpose and leads to them meeting two eligible bachelors, quiet, hard-working Joseph and handsome, outgoing Delbert.The twins have never been married, but they havent given up on marriage, so they are eager to get to know the two men and see what happens. Thelmas outgoing personality is the perfect complement to Josephs shyness, while Elma and Delberts strong opinions and no-nonsense attitudes creates obstacles to their romance. The couples have various ups and downs and a well-meant girlhood promise almost gets in the way of happiness for one of the pairs. The bond between Thelma and Elma is a highpoint of the story.Ive read and enjoyed several of Wanda Brunstetters Amish novels. This book was written by Wanda, along with her daughter-in-law Jean. What I like about this book is its written so that there is the expected happy ending, but the story takes some unexpected turns. Everything doesnt turn out perfectly for all the characters, and I appreciate this realism. The Brunstetters give us a glimpse of the Amish way of life and show us that not all Amish people are the same, even identical twins. The book has a fun plot with some very touching moments, but unfortunately, there is too much silliness and not enough depth to the characters in this short book. The authors do provide a nice bonus, though. The recipe for the famous lopsided cake is included at the end of the book.I received this book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of Shiloh Run Press. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

Maggie Crozat has returned to the bayou of Pelican, Louisiana to help her family run their bed-and-breakfast. The Crozat family plantation makes a beautiful place for guests to stay, but its barely turning a profit, and thats before the family are suspected in the murder of one of their guests! Its up to Maggie to prove to the police chief, who happens to hold a serious grudge against the Crozats, that someone outside her family is guilty of murder.I really enjoyed this Southern mystery. The book has an interesting mix of characters, both the natives of Pelican and the guests of the bed and breakfast. Most of the characters are unique and some a bit quirky, but still realistic. Only Rufus Durand, the police chief, is a bit over-the-top in the animosity he has against Maggie and her family. The mystery provides plenty of possible suspects and Maggie is a likeable amateur sleuth. She has plenty of chemistry with detective Bo Durant, in spite of the fact that hes Rufus Durands first cousin. As rude and narrow-minded Rufus is, thats how pleasant and kind Bo is and hes a great match for Maggie.This is a wonderful debut in what is hopefully only the first Cajun Country Mystery. It has a cozy feel with a warm, Southern setting and fully developed characters, an interesting plot, and plenty of humor. This fun mystery by Ellen Byron reminds me of a cross between a book by Anne George and Debbie Macomber and I look forward to reading more from this author.

This is a nice-looking, casual watch. It has an attractive leather band which seems like it will be durable. Its easy to read when telling time since the numbers and lines are large. The day and date are also easy to see. As expected for this type of watch, it has second hand. Also note that the watch does require a battery. Nothing fancy, but good for an everyday watch.

A non wireless extender which uses your household wiring to extend the Ethernet system in your house. All you have to do is plug this into a outlet, plug in your router or switch, take the other one to the area you want to use it, plug this into a outlet there, plug in your cat5 cable and you have a Ethernet drop without the dropouts or lagging that occur with wireless Ethernet systems. Great to get Ethernet to areas that are difficult to get wireless to work. And you can still have an outlet on the front of each unit.  Plugged one in by my router, the other in the yard by the cabana and had high speed internet without the wireless signal drop hassle that I normally fight. This is also a option to relocate items like a printer or say a DIRECTV receiver that is not wireless, but not near a Ethernet drop.

Its almost Halloween and Lucy Stone and her family are getting ready the upcoming celebrations taking place in their hometown of Tinkers Cove, Maine. In fact, Lucy thinks her husband Bill is going a little overboard in the preparations and is tired of Bills friend Evan making himself at home while they work on their contest entries. However, Lucy never would have wished for Evan to meet the fate he did and is devastated when Bill becomes the main suspect in his friends murder. Lucy knows her husband is innocent, so she wont stop until she finds the real killer.I like the main character of Lucy, who is likeable and fun and has a great sense of humor. I liked Lucys friends and family members as well, especially her easygoing husband, Bill. I hated how the local police officers latched onto Bill as a suspect without a proper investigation, but was glad to see that Lucy didnt give up and that their friend and lawyer was there to help.There were a couple characters I didnt care for. One was Lucys daughter-in-law whose over-the-top rules for her young son left me shaking my head, but luckily she was only in the book briefly. Lucys grandsons preschool teacher, Heidi, was equally self-righteous and annoying and I was surprised to see the other women in the town allow Heidi to get her way in planning a ridiculous Halloween party for the children of the town.Overall, I enjoyed the book. I like the cozy writing style of the author. However, I did confused about who was who in the Cousins family, which made it hard to follow all of the plot details. I have to give kudos to the author for dealing with a serious subject in such a creative way. Flashbacks of a young woman from 1979 tie into the overall mystery as well as the domestic violence theme which plays an important role in the story. This gave depth to an otherwise lighthearted mystery novel and was very well-done.I received this book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of Kensington Books. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

Grace Blade is a caring, compassionate psychologist specializing in the treatment of patients who have gone through traumatic events. Its not just her training that helps Grace to get results  Grace survived horrific events in her own life and knows what it takes to survive. However, the calm, cool Grace has a secret life that nobody else knows about. When her personal and professional lives collide and put Grace in danger, she finds herself involved in a murder investigation and playing a very dangerous game.I have read almost all of the books in Jonathan Kellermans Alex Delaware series, so I was eager to read this book, featuring a different main character. Both Grace and Alex are intelligent, clever, and excellent therapists, the two characters are very different, as is the tone of this book compared to the Delaware novels. Graces childhood years spent with her biological parents and then a series of foster homes had an everlasting effect on Graces life. She is extremely intelligent, but regularly behaves recklessly. Although I admired her courage and intelligence, it was hard to relate to some of the things she did both before and during the investigation.Not all of the story is believable, but I still found it to be an exciting book. Although I didnt fully connect with Grace, I cared what happened to her and found the flashback scenes of Grace with her various foster families to be very interesting. When she was fortunate enough to be given a good home, the interactions with those families showed another side of Grace. After a big build-up, the ending was a bit of a let-down, but I still enjoyed the book and found it hard to put down.I received this book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of Ballantine Books. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

Electronic Scrabble Twist is a great idea and it more like an electronic version of Boggle in which players can make as many three, four, or five letter words as possible from a random group of letters before time runs out. Simply press the buttons on the unit to spell the words and twist to save the word - the bigger the word, the more points you receive for that word. Unfortunately, I love the idea more than the execution. There are both good and bad features of the game, which Ive summarized below.Good: Games are quick and rules are basic The game can be played by anywhere from 1 to 8 players, depending on the game mode There are different games that can be played and different levels of difficulty with varying lengths of the time players are given to find words The game quickly shuts off automatically if not in use The letters will automatically display in the right direction even if the unit is turned, which is good for the party mode in which the unit is passed and also means it works well for both left and right handed players The Turbo mode, for head-to-head play between two or more players is fun The sound can be turned off for quieter playNot So Good: The worst part of the game is that the letters are hard to read and is a strain on your eyes after playing for a while. People in my family of all age groups said the same thing. Three AA batteries are required, but theyre not included The instructions on using the game unit arent clear (I was able to figure out how to use it by playing the game a few times.) The solo mode tracks high scores, but not by name. It doesnt feel like youre working toward anything since you cant really compare scores from game to game since it depends on the letters you had for each game. When the sound is on, its loud, even at the lowest level. Different sounds do alert you that youve played a valid word. A second sound plays if the word youve played is invalid or a duplicate. Sounds also let you know if time is about to run out, but I found that this distracted me from finding my final words

Eddie G. has just been promoted from his job as a pit boss at the Sands and is trying to get used to his new position of Casino Host. He doesnt mind catering to the high rollers coming into the casino, but it feels strange to him to be getting paid for just sitting around at the hotel bar. Eddie doesnt have much time to think about things because he soon finds out, the hard way, that somebody is trying to kill him. Eddie would have helped him anyway, but when he gets a request from his friend Frank Sinatra to help Judy Garland with a problem in Los Angeles, its the perfect reason to temporarily leave Las Vegas!I really enjoy reading the books in the Rat Pack series. The atmosphere and characters are perfect and the books transports you to 1960s Vegas, and in this case, old LA as well. There isnt as much involvement in the book by Frank and Dean, but I enjoyed getting to know Judy Garland. Although the book is fictional, I learned some things that actually happened in Ms. Garlands life that I never knew before. The fictional characters in his series are just as appealing as the real ones. Eddie is a tough guy, but an honest person and a loyal friend. His part-time bodyguard Jerry is a great mixture of toughness and vulnerability and he and Eddie make a unique and likeable pair. I enjoy seeing them get into scrapes, dodging danger, and helping their famous friends.This installment of the series has an intriguing beginning and is action-packed throughout the book, wrapping up with a touching ending. There are other books in this series that Ive liked more, but its still a fast-paced, fun read that will make you feel like youve taken a step back in time and spent some time with the real Rat Pack.I received this book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of Severn House Publishers. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

Caprice De Luca enjoys her career as a home stager in the small town of Kismet, Pennsylvania, but is wary of her newest client. She agrees to help Alanna Goodwin sell her home, only as a favor to Ace Richland, a prior client and friend. Alanna is difficult to work with, but when Alanna is murdered, Caprice is saddened and also worried about her friend Ace, who seems to be the main suspect. Caprice is determined to find out who is really responsible for Alannas death, even if her informal investigation may made her the killers next target.Ive not read any of the Caprice De Luca Home Staging mysteries before, but Drape Expectations is the fourth in the series. I was able to quickly get to know Caprice and her friends and family. Caprice is a free spirit, preferring Beatles t-shirts and flats to business suits and heels, but she is intelligent and creative and makes an excellent amateur sleuth. I love seeing Caprice interact with her family since they are all there to support each other in times of trouble. Caprice is also right in the middle of a love triangle. She would love to see if she could make a relationship work with Dr. Seth Randolph, but he is away in Virginia for a one-year fellowship and his future plans are unsettled. She has known Grant, who is now an attorney, since he roomed with her brother Vince in college, but recently their long-time friendship seems to have potential to become much more.I found the mystery to be interesting and Caprice a refreshing and likeable character. The dialogue is well-written, although some of the transitions between the characters conversations and the books narrative could sometimes be smoother. However, I enjoyed the book and would love to see what happens next for Caprice. I enjoyed reading about her custom-themed open houses, which are really spectacular real estate events, and this unique profession makes an interesting addition to the story. Cozy mystery lovers will like this clever, fun-to-read mystery.I received this book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of Kensington Publishing. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

American Pru Parke is now a permanent resident in England and is now planning her wedding to Detective Chief Inspector Christopher Pearse. However, before they become husband and wife, Pru agrees to complete a short-term assignment at the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh. This assignment will challenge her gardening knowledge in a new way. She has hired to determine if a journal was actually written by botanist and explorer Archibald Menzies. Not everyone at the garden is happy with Prus involvement and when a difficult co-worker is killed, Pru herself becomes one of the main suspects.I feel fortunate to have discovered author Marty Wingates cozy novels. This is the third book in the Potting Shed mysteries and it doesnt disappoint. Pru balances the stress of a new assignment, planning a wedding, and then investigating a murder with her usual intelligence and grace. She is an interesting main character and I love reading about her relationship with Christopher. The premise of this installment, as well as the investigation, is equally interesting. I enjoyed this book and am eager to see what will happen next for Pru and Christopher. Fans of Ellery Adams or Hazel Holt will enjoy the style and setting of this charming series.I received this book from NetGalley through the courtesy of Random House/Alibi. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

This is an excellent portable speaker with a lot of fun packed into the design. Even the packaging is fun. Its like a poster with the speaker rolled up inside. There is one drawback, though, since the few instructions that are included with the speaker got torn when opening the package!The speaker itself has a cool design. Its lightweight, but sturdy and comes with a small bungee cord attached to make it easy to carry. I also like the unique bright yellow color of the charger, which is just another thing that makes this speaker different from others Ive seen or used.I was pleased that the speaker was charged right when I took it out of the package. It was easy to pair, which is good since the torn directions were hard to read. Most importantly, the speaker has a great sound at both low or and high volumes. All of these features, this is a fun speaker for enjoying your music when youre on-the-go.

Im very pleased with this Lightening charger from Belkin, which is a name I trust for electronics accessories. The charger worked well for charging an iPhone 5. I like that there is a light to indicate its plugged in. I also like that its not bulky once its plugged into the dashboard. The charger, also can also be used in the house, so its not strictly a car charger, which makes it even better.The length is awkward. Four feet is long for a car, but even in my small car, it doesnt reach from the front to the back seat, so the extra length gets in the way more than it helps. However, I still like the charger and am happy it works so well with iPhones.

Chilling Effect is the second in a new series by author Melissa F. Miller. I read (and enjoyed) the series debut, but its not necessary to do so before reading this excellent follow-up novel. As in the first book, Aroostines Native American background and reliance on her spirit guide for wise advice put a new twist on the typical legal thriller.Aroostine is supposed to be relaxing on a romantic vacation with her husband, Joe, but she cant resist getting involved in a case when her boss in Washington, DC calls for a favor. What looks like a routine embezzlement case at a Native American casino turns into a dangerous dance with a killer. Aroostine and Joe work together to tackle this case and once again, Aroostine uses her Native American background to help in solving the case.I really enjoyed this book and would love to read additional installments in this series. Aroostine is a strong, independent woman and makes a great main character. She is brave, caring, and compassionate and does what she thinks is right, usually ignoring the consequences. Sometimes her husband Joe seems selfish to me, but he really grows personally and in his support of this wife in this book. The case is intriguing and will keep you guessing at who the killer really is. I enjoyed the fast pace and the authors writing style. I would recommend the book for fans of Thomas Perry or James Doss.I received this book from NetGalley through the courtesy of Thomas & Mercer. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

If you have a SUV this is what you want. Used this on both my car and SUV, the only issue in the car was the vacuum with the brush attachment was too bulky to reach everywhere. In the SUV it cleaned everything well.It is powerful and it worked flawlessly getting the back storage area, back seats, and front foot wells clean. I have used it around the house with the extension hose with both the brush and the wand, and again it is very powerful cleaning up any mess. It empties easily, and it is easy to change from the brush attachment to the hose attachment.

When you pick up a new Barbara Delinsky novel, you expect to read about a strong female character, some sort of conflict to be overcome, and of course some romance. Ms. Delinsky delivers on all counts in her latest novel, Blueprints. There are two main characters, a mother and a daughter, each with strong opinions which provide obstacles in their relationship. In the midst of all their problems, somehow each finds romance.I liked Caroline from the beginning of the book. She learns she is being forced out of her job for someone younger. This is becoming more common in the workplace, but Carolines situation is unique  she is being replaced by her own daughter! Caroline hosted a home improvement TV show and network execs want her daughter, Jamie, who previously took a back seat to her mother, to take over the lead role. Caroline becomes suspicious of Jamie and unfortunately when a tragedy strikes, the two become estranged, just when Jamie needs her the most.It took me a little longer to warm to Jamie, but once I did, I was rooting for her and found myself taking her side in her problems with Caroline. I dont want to give anything away, but Jamie was forced to take on a huge responsibility and she definitely rose to the challenge.The book was fast-paced and kept my attention from the beginning to end. There were parts of the story that frustrated me, though. The male love interests of both mother and daughter are both wonderful, but the male leads who arent so nice seemed one-dimensional. Jamies relationship moved unrealistically fast, even though the story is sweet. My biggest complaint is that it doesnt ring true that a mother who had previously been so close to her daughter would abandon her when she really needs her because of pride. Maybe this would have been believable if their relationship had been strained, but the two adored each other before Caroline lost her top billing on Gut It! The ending is great and even though I didnt love every part of the book, I liked the book and I think other fans of Delinsky will enjoy the book as well.I received this book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of St. Martin's Press. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

Lucy Toomey always looked up to her big sister Alice, especially when Alice saved in life. Later in live, Alice is the one who has an accident that leaves her mentally impaired. Alice remains self-sufficient and happy with her life in the small town of Nilsons Bay, Wisconsin, but longs for her sister Lucy to come for a visit. Lucy talks to Alice on the phone almost every day and takes Lucy on trips, but having left Nilsons Bay for an exciting life in politics, she has no desire to revisit her hometown and many of the unhappy memories she has of that time in her life. Just when Lucys hard work may be leading to a job in the White House, sad circumstances lead her to a forced sabbatical in Nilsons Bay. Lucy is now forced to examine both her past and her future. I like the character of Lucy and the way the story unravels. Lucy is forced to evaluate her career, where her life is heading, and what she wants in the future. Before she can do that, she has to remember some events from her youth she would rather forget. I like the message of the book and how the story shows how hard forgiveness can be, especially when the person you most need to forgive is yourself. I was fairly certain how the story would turn out. I wasnt wrong, but I liked the ending and was happy for the ways things turn out for Lucy.This is the first book I have read by author Marie Bostwick. Although some parts of the story were predictable and some a bit melodramatic, I enjoyed the book and story of Lucy and Alice. Fans of Debbie Macombers Blossom Street series will enjoy the book.

This is a fun ride-on toy for kids. I like that it sits close to the ground, which makes it better for younger kids, but the design is still cool enough that older kids will still like it. The dune buggy has a lot of good features. First, the blue color will appeal to both girls and boys. The vehicle has two speeds, which is nice. However, the parent lock-out needs to be removed to access the higher speed. The lock-out is a screw thats fairly difficult to remove because of its location. The higher speed is definitely needed to easily ride in the wet grass, even on flat ground.  Its fairly easy to steer the vehicle and is a lot of fun for kids to drive.To stop the vehicle, take your foot off the gas pedal. It will still slide a little on pavement, possibly because of the plastic wheels. It also will continue to slowly roll going downhill, even on a small incline. Thats why even though the guidelines say ages 3 to 7, I would use caution for younger kids unless you have a large, flat area with no nearby hills. Older kids, up to 11 or 12, will like it, too. However, with the position of the steering wheel, their height will determine how well theyll comfortably fit in the dune buggy and be able to easily steer.Be sure to charge the battery the night before using the first time. The battery only lasted about 15 minutes right out of the box after being putting the car together. I also learned the hard way that the dune buggy is heavy to push if it does bog down or if the battery dies. (The battery is rechargeable battery, but there isnt a battery indicator, so I wasnt expecting it to go dead so quickly.)Once the dune buggy is assembled and the battery is charged, its a lot of fun for kids. The assembly is a chore for adults, though. I took almost an hour and a half to assemble. Most of that time was spent putting on the wheels. The directions arent clear and some of the screws are hard to get to and there isnt room to use an electric screwdriver. As long as you allow enough time for assembly and charging the battery, this dune buggy will be a hit.

Critical Vulnerability is the first in a new series by author Melissa F. Miller. The main character is federal prosecutor Aroostine Higgins and when the story kicks off, she is having the worst week of her life. It all starts when Aroostine is assigned a high profile case with little time to prepare and a very unsympathetic judge presiding. Things go downhill from there when Aroostine is plagued with mysterious clerical errors affecting her case, a fire in her home, and a near fatal surgery. Soon she realizes this isnt just a run of bad luck - someone is trying to ruin her life and she is determined to find out why.This is the first book Ive read by this author and I really enjoyed it. I liked the main character and the plot kept my interest throughout the book. I would have liked the characters to have been fleshed out a little more and a more backstory given. However, the narrative did get right to the heart of the plot and resulted in a fast-paced book. Also the information given about Aroostine really sets the book apart from other legal thrillers. Aroostine was adopted at a young age, but still follows some of the Native American customs she learned at a young age from her biological grandfather. Aroostine uses the tracking skills she learned as a child and in times of trouble, her spirit guide is there to help her.The fast-moving story, unique main character, and Aroostines interesting background make this a great book. I look forward to reading more books by this author.I received this book from NetGalley through the courtesy of Thomas & Mercer. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

I have the pink and white polka-dot case and I love it. It's a cute case for a reasonable price and fits my Galaxy Tab 4 perfectly. It was easy to place my tablet into the case and there are openings for the camera and charging port. I love the magnetic closure of the case and the stand for use when reading or watching a video. As a bonus, it also comes with a combination pen/stylus which is held with an elastic loop outside the case so it doesn't scratch the tablet.I was overwhelmed with all the choices of cases for my tablet and was pleased to find this one by rooCase. I have ordered this brand for my Kindle and liked it, so I was happy to see they make cases for Samsung tablets as well. I'm happy with this purchase and recommend it for anyone looking for a nice case that isn't too expensive.

I like the clever design of this charging device for small electronics, which is a combination flashlight and charger in one device. Samsung packs plenty of power into a small, highly portable device. To locate the port for charging, just pull off top of the flashlight. Note:  The Flashlight works only when attached to rest of device. It isnt intended to work when detached from the rest of the charger.The device is fully charged and ready to use right out of the package. It quickly charged an iPhone and is perfect for those times when you cant use a traditional phone charger, but cant be without your phone.

I have read both books in this authors Potting Shed series and liked them, so I wanted to give this debut book in her new series a try. Im glad I did, because as much as I liked those books, I enjoyed this one even more. The pacing of this book is better and I found it a quick and fun read. In the beginning, the main character, Julia Lancaster, seems a little stubborn as she refuses to accept that her father has remarried. However, as the reader learns more about the situation, its easier to understand Julias point of view. I soon came to enjoy the character very much.Im not a bird watcher, but I do enjoy watching birds at my backyard feeder, so I found the bird watching aspect of the story interesting. As mentioned, I like the main character. Julia is down-to-earth, which make her easy to relate to. I love the chemistry between her and Michael. Not everything runs smoothly in their growing romance, but I like that the misunderstandings they experienced werent allowed to continue too long and instead provided a realistic and entertaining romance that added interest to their investigation. The murder mystery itself is interesting with enough suspects and red herrings to keep the reader guessing and eager to find out what would happen next.Readers who enjoy a cozy with an English setting as well as bird watchers, will want to read this charming book. I hope there is a sequel soon because I can see this series becoming one of my favorites.I received this book from NetGalley through the courtesy of Random House/Alibi. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

The TSST portable charger took about 3 hours to full charge from a starting point of about 20%. Once charged I first tried it with my Note tablet which was about 15% battery level, after about 3 hours of charging the tablet was 90% charged and the TSST portable charger still had about 25% left on the battery. I recharged the battery and then used it to recharge my Galaxy s5 which was about 10% charged. The TSST charger had it to 100% charged in about 2.5 hours, and still had over 50% charge left. The size is about the size of a phone (just a little smaller than the s5) but the power it delivers, and the ability to charge multiple times on a single charge makes it worth it.

Assistant Prosecutor Elsie Arnold regrets that someone has been killed, but cant help but be happy she has been assigned to her first murder case. A woman has been brutally murdered and the prime suspect is a fifteen-year-old boy. This is a case that could help Elsie make a name for herself or could backfire because of the suspects young age. As the case goes on, Elsie feels like everyone is against her, including her boss, co-counsel, boyfriend, and even her own mother.  Elsie has never felt so alone, but is determined to learn the truth about the murder, even when it appears the investigation could be putting her own life in danger.A Killing at the Creek is author Nancy Allens fast-paced follow-up to The Code of the Hills. I read that book first, but dont worry if you missed the debut in this series. This book stands on its own and can be enjoyed without having read the prior book. I really liked the first book, but enjoyed this one even more because of the intriguing plot. It first appears to be an open and shut case, but the plot takes a few turns that kept me guessing about the murder and the accused.As much as I loved the story, the best part of the book is the richly drawn characters. The characters are human, and none of them are written as all good or all bad. Even Elsie, the main character, is an imperfect hero. Elsie is strong and intelligent, but she doesnt always have all the answers and quite often makes poor decisions, especially in her personal life. This is what makes Elsie so believable and likeable. I was rooting for Elsie throughout the book, hoping things turn out for her, both in her career and with love interest Detective Bob Ashlock.A Killing at the Creek offers suspense, humor, insider legal background, and relatable characters with many complexities. I also enjoy the Southern Missouri setting and hope this isnt the last we see of Elsie Arnold.

This is a handy and simple way to keep extra power to recharge your phone handy. Charging this device took about 2.5 hours and it was ready to go, used it to recharge my cell phone (which was around 25%) to 90%+ which took around 30 minutes. I llike its compact size and the indication on the top to show the charge level that was currently at on the device. I will keep this close to me to use when I need  a quick charge on my phone.

The Conference Cam Connect is a great device for video conferencing, it is compact, portable, and easy to set up. This video conferencing system connects easily up by either USB or Bluetooth and is ready to use right away. While being small and portable, it is full of features.The camera delivers good quality video capability, the video is crisp and clear and bright, it does not have any framing or freezing issues that occur in other systems I have used. The ability to zoom and pan the camera using the remote is very handy feature on this unit. The microphone is good quality and picks up conservations from all angles very well, there are no apparent dead spots in its coverage. The speaker is also of good quality and delivers good sound quality, crisp and clear and not "tinny" sounding. The remote is a very handy addition to to the device and is the best way to control the unit, it allows panning, zooming, muting, and volume control.The device is battery powered, compact, and portable, and connects wirelessly via Bluetooth. This allows you to move the device around to different areas without losing connectivity if so desired. It works great for small to medium size rooms and is compatible with all video conferencing software apps I have used to date.

I got the Linksys dual band extender and installed it right away to replace an older extender that I had previously used. The Linksys was easy and quick to set up as it has on its webpage you use to set up the device. It takes all common security settings to keep the network secure. The device is a dual band extender which was good, as I use a dual band router, and again I used the webpage to setup the network for both network bands. The Linksys has been robust in signal strength and has good throughput for the device. Before when I was using another device, I had network dropouts as a common occurrence. Since I have installed this device, I have not had any dropouts, and it does not consume a outlet due to the plug face on the device.

This is an excellent cookbook for families, kids, or other beginning cooks. The book itself is a nicely bound, hardback book that stays open to whichever recipe you want to look at. The colors and font are appealing for kids, but the pictures are actual, color photos and not cartoons, so older kids or even teens would not be put off by the appearance of the book.The cookbook starts with an overview of various information about what makes up a healthy diet, weights and measurements, safety and hygiene in the kitchen, photos and names of a variety of kitchen gadgets, and more. Then, more than 150 recipes follow, organized into categories such as Breakfast, Light bites, Main meals, Desserts, Party time and others.I love the way the recipes are presented with a list ingredients, as expected, but also a list of kitchen equipment that is needed to prepare the dish. All have full color photos of the completed recipe and many have photos which accompany each step of the preparation instructions. There are also tips for preparation, storage, or for substitutions with many of the recipes, and are presented in a way to keep things fun while still teaching kids about cooking.The recipes themselves are real meals and desserts and not childish twists on standard recipes. I cant wait to make the white chocolate and raspberry brownies, the BBQ Chicken Skewers, and the baked potato and carrot chips myself. Some such as the cream puff may require some adult help, but others such as the fruit crumble or the beef pasta are straightforward and easy to prepare.Clear, colorful presentation of a large variety of tasty recipes make this a great cookbook for all ages!

Vanished is the second in The Profiler series by Elizabeth Heiter. Dont worry if you missed the first book. I hadnt read it and had no trouble following the storyline or connecting with main character, FBI profiler Evelyn Baine. Evelyns work with the FBIs Behavioral Analysis Unit is never easy, but her latest case is especially difficult because she has a personal connection to the case. A young girl in South Carolina has disappeared and the crime seems to be related to an abduction that occurred eighteen years ago. That little girl, Cassie Byers, was Evelyns childhood best friend. This new case brings back all the memories and determination Evelyn had to solve Cassies case and she wont stop until she does, no matter what the consequences are.I really enjoyed this book. I wasnt familiar with the works of this author before reading the book, but Im impressed. The book could be classified as romantic suspense, but holds its own against thrillers written by more famous authors. The main character is likeable, but complex, and seems like a real person, with real problems and fears, and who makes mistakes. She is good at her job, but feels like she is always having to prove herself, but doesnt let the politics of the job get in the way of seeking justice for the victims. The case is scary and suspenseful and very entertaining. I also enjoyed the details of Evelyns personal life and her interactions with her partner Greg Ibsen and her love interest Kyle McKenzie. I like the profiler angle and think it adds depth to the story.I had my own suspicions about the identity of the murderer. I was able to correctly guess part of the solution, but the ending still held many shocks. I really enjoyed this book and am looking forward to the next in the series. I would rate the book 4.5 stars and recommend it to those who enjoy a thrilling, romantic suspense story with complex characters.

Joanna Brady has a busy life  she is a happily married mother of two and is the sheriff in Conchise County, Arizona. In her job, shes currently juggling two murder cases and trying to make sure there are no further victims.This series just keeps getting better and better. All of the main characters are likeable and I love seeing how they have grown. I love seeing Joanna both on the job and interacting with her family. Both cases in Remains of Innocence are suspenseful and one of the cases has a shocking conclusion which I wont spoil by saying too much. The book is completely accessible to anyone new to the series. Those who have read other books in this series will be thrilled with how suspenseful and satisfying this latest installment is.As a bonus, the edition I purchased included a novella featuring Joannas husband Butch. I enjoyed this peak into Butchs life before he had met Joanna and think this is an excellent story. I would definitely recommend the novel and the novella to both Jance fans and anyone who enjoys a well-written, suspenseful mystery.

Monster power high def bluetooth speaker came a few days ago and I tried it out several times over the weekend. First the packaging is top notch and it comes with a usb power cord and a carry bag, instructions were included. Setup was straight forward for bluetooth connectivity, after charging the speaker it connected right away. My issue was with the sound. It did not sound as rich as other speakers I have. I played around with several equalizer settings but never quite got the sound to the levels of other speakers I have, it was good but could have been a little better. An odd note if the phone is in close proximity to the speaker it tended to "pop" at high volume (can't say I have ever run into this in the past). The life of the battery was very long compared to others and I spent the whole day listening to music on it. All in all a nice unit with tons of battery life, I may try music off a tablet that I have that has a much better equalizer app than the phone equalizer and see how that affects it.

I have read and enjoyed all of the prior books in Margaret Graces charming Miniature mystery series, and Manhattan in Miniature is no exception. Gerry Porter and her granddaughter Maddie get the chance to travel to New York City right before Christmas to assist Gerrys friend Bebe at a huge craft fair. Gerrys friend Cynthia is thrilled Gerry will be in New York because she needs Gerrys help investigating her Aunt Elsies suspicious death.I love this series and really enjoy the friendship between Gerry and her granddaughter Maddie. Maddie is a tween that usually manages to be cute and precocious without being obnoxious. I think she is at her best in this book. She is growing up and is a huge help to Gerry as she tries to balance her obligations to Bebe with her determination to help Cynthia. Cynthia is sometimes unreasonable in what she expects of Gerry, but other than that, I really enjoyed the book. Its wonderful seeing New York at Christmastime through Maddies eyes and the case of Aunt Elsies death kept my interested from the very beginning. I enjoyed my time with Gerry and her friends and family and can't wait for the next installment!Its not necessary to have read the other books in this series to enjoy this clean cozy. Fans of this series and this author (who also writes mysteries under the names Camille Minichino and Ada Madison) will enjoy Gerry and Maddies newest adventure.

Some long-running series seem to have books with recycled plots, but author Anne Perry keeps the series fresh with her latest installment in the Charlotte and Thomas Pitt series. The storyline in The Angel Court Affair is about Sofia Delacruz who is visiting London from Spain to preach her controversial message about love and Gods forgiveness. The events in the book take place at the end of the 19th century and most consider Sofias beliefs to be blasphemous. Even those who arent as judgmental feel uncomfortable by her message. When a vicious murderer strikes and Sofia is missing, its up to Thomas Pitt, commander of Special Branch, to solve both.I enjoy the uniqueness of the plot, even though some of the major points in the story were a little repetitive. It doesnt take long to realize Sofias message is offensive and its not necessary to keep saying that in different ways. Also, there is too much drama surrounding Thomas and Charlottes daughter Jemimas reaction to Sofias message and her disappearance, although she and Charlotte have a touching moment in which Charlotte encourages Jemima to be herself.My favorite parts of the investigation are the ones in which Aunt Vespasia and her new husband Victor Narraway, former Special Branch commander, are on the case. They were an unexpected, but delightful couple and I love their scenes. I like the book because the storyline is so different, but whats really missing in many of the newer Pitt books is Charlotte. Thomas acknowledges the high profile and high stakes of the cases he now investigates mean he has to keep many things about this cases confidential and cant discuss them the way he used to with Charlotte. As much as I enjoy Aunt Vespasia, I miss Charlotte having an active role in Pitts cases. I hope Perry finds a way to have her more involved in future books, because to me she was the heart of this series.I received this book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of Ballantine Books, in exchange for an honest review.

After the Fall is the first book I have read by author Patricia Gussin. The book has several subplots that do eventually come together in support of the main plot of dirty dealings going on during the approval process of a new drug that could help save lives. Laura Nelson is the main character who after a tragic accident is forced to change careers and gets caught in the drama of those who want the drug approved and someone who would do anything to delay that process.The suspense throughout the book is wonderful and once I started, I didnt want to put it down. Laura is intelligent and determined and I enjoyed reading about her. Some of the male characters didnt have a much depth and were clearly the good guy or the bad guy. The bad guy was a jerk without many redeeming qualities, but Lauras love interest seemed too good to be true. At one point in the book, Laura confides to him that she had been keeping a major secret from her deceased husband, one that could speak to her integrity and he barely blinks and says its okay with him. I would have expected a little bit of a dilemma on his part. I also found some of the dialogue to be unnatural which made some of the scene awkward. However, the plot grabbed me enough that I was able to ignore the flaws and still kept reading, eager to find out what would happen next in Lauras life and in the fate of the new drug going up for approval. Although it doesnt have all of the elements of conspiracy, I think fans of Robin Cooks medical thrillers would enjoy this book.I received this book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of Oceanview Publishing, in exchange for an honest review.

The main character and reluctant amateur sleuth in See Also Murder is a book indexer working from her farm in rural North Dakota. Marjorie Trumaine has the responsibility of creating the index for each new book assigned to her by her New York publisher. She puts her organizational skills to use to try to figure out the identity of a murderer before its too late.The idea of someone creating a book index from home, after learning the trade from a government correspondence course was intriguing to me and it was just as interesting as I hoped. I enjoyed learning more about the course and the profession, which apparently really was offered to farm wives in the 1960s.Marjorie has a rough life and the murder of her neighbors which begins the book is just one of the tragedies she has experienced. Marjorie tries to remain stoic, but she becomes the most likeable when she lets her show through her exterior toughness. The atmosphere of the book is oppressive due to the small town, Marjories responsibilities at home, and the danger of a killer on the loose. You can feel her burdens and isolation throughout the book. For this reason, the book isnt a light, cozy read but I was still able to finish the book quite quickly. The tension continues to build as the story progresses keeps the reader interested in what will happen next. The reader is kept guessing at the identity of the murderer and especially the reason behind the crimes.This is an excellent book and it author Larry D. Sweazy has follow-up books planned, I would be interested in reading more about Marjorie.

What a surprise that such good quality sound comes from such a small speaker. When I received this speaker I thought it was on the small side and wondered about its performance. I linked it up to my phone and BAM! The quality sound and the shear volume was just surprising coming from a speaker this size. It was simple to link and overall was very straight forward in its operation. I have not really had it wet but am planning on taking this to the pool this summer for tunes, and perhaps the lake for lounging on the raft. If you have any need for a waterproof speaker this fits the bill well.

The decoy is compact and easy to carry, sets up easily and is realistic in its appearence. I set this up with a set of decoys and it filled out the set very well. I also set it up alone and inadvertently left it out overnight, the next morning it was surrounded by a small flock of Turkeys eyeing it and generally moving around it like it belonged in the flock. A slight wind made this decoy look like it was moving and added to the effect of the decoy.

This shower curtain set is perfect for a tween or teens bathroom or college dorm or apartment.  It comes up with a fabric shower curtain, a quilted, padded bath mat, and 12 shower hooks. (The shower hooks, rug, and curtain make up the 14 piece set.) The bath mat is a little smaller than I had expected, but is a nice size for a smaller bathroom.The pink in the curtain, mat, and hooks has a purple tint to it and goes well with the gray and white. You definitely need to be a fan of pink, but it looks nice.  I think the curtain could be used right out of the package, but I decided to add an inexpensive white shower curtain line to be certain no water leaked from the shower. Overall, Im happy with this set.

This product is a very large bag (approximately 160 pieces of candy, per the description) of only Blue Raspberry flavored Jolly Ranchers. The weight printed on the bag says its 88 ounces or 5 pounds, 8 ounces of candy. Blue Raspberry is my favorite flavor because to me it has the perfect level of sweetness  sweeter than apple but not as sweet as the cherry or grape flavors. The candies were in perfect condition when they arrived and those I tried tasted great as expected.This large bag isnt resealable, so this is best suited to purchase for occasions when a bulk supply of candy is needed and you want all of a particular flavor or color. The light blue color of this specific flavor would be perfect for making party favors or a large bowl of candy at the center of the table at a baby shower.  Depending on school colors, this could work for a graduation party, too.

In a dark, dark wood with snow-covered roads and a home with spotty cell phone coverage and a broken landline, Nora Shaw is attending a weekend hen party that goes wrong. Nora is an author and loves nothing more than staying home writing, but surprises herself when she accepts an invitation for a weekend in the English countryside to celebrate the wedding of Clare Cavendish, an old school friend she hasnt seen in ten years. She and friend Nina barely arrive when they both have second thoughts about the weekend. By the time they decide to cut the weekend short and return home, its too late!The story is told in the first person, narrated by Nora. Most of the book takes place at the weekend bachelorette party for Clare, but then there are other scenes which are first are hard to tell if they are flashbacks or flash-forwards. There is tension and a strong sense of foreboding throughout the whole novel. Its a face-paced book, and about half way through becomes very intense and impossible to put down. Part of the ending is satisfying, but also heartbreaking and left me full of what-ifs, wishing things could have turned out differently.One thing that was a bit jarring to me is that the author, setting and characters are English, but the mixture of British words and slang (mum, hen party, postcode) is mixed with talk about Texans, rednecks, and running nine miles. I dont know if this was the authors wording or a change made by the publisher, but when I came across one of the clearly American words, it took me out of the story.I was able to guess at some of the pieces of the puzzle before they were revealed, but still found this to be an enjoyable, suspenseful thriller and I came to care about Nora even when it wasn't clear if I should be rooting for her or not.

Manhattan Mayhem is a collection of all new short stories by some of the most popular of todays mystery writers. The collection contains almost twenty short stories, each focusing on a different area of Manhattan, such as Jeffrey Deavers story set in Greenwich Village, a story by Julie Hyzy which takes place in Central Park, and a tale by Mary Higgins Clark with a Union Square setting. The book has nice touches to support the theme. There are small maps at the beginning of each story showing the street location of the books setting. There are also actual photographs of New York included.I had the opportunity to read an advance reading sample that included only the first four stories of the collection. The first is Nancy Pickards story of a young woman who receives tragic news and is then murdered. This story is set in the Upper West Side of Manhattan which fits the story well. I was surprised by the twist this story took and enjoyed it very much.The second story is by author S.J. Rozan and is set in Chinatown. Its told from the mother of Rozans beloved detective Lydia Chin. Lydias mother is frustrating in Rozans novels, but Chin Yong-Yun is a clever and entertaining detective in this story.I wasnt familiar with Ben H. Winterss mysteries before reading his Chelsea-set story in this sampler, but I enjoyed his story about actors in a play written in the format of a play. I love the humor and laughed out loud several times.The fourth and final story in the sample I was able to read is by Brendan DuBois and takes place in post-World War II Times Square. The historical setting is interesting and the ending is surprising.If the first four stories are any indication of the rest of the book, this will be an excellent collection of mystery stories for those who love New York or just love a well-written, entertaining mystery. I would definitely like to read the entire collection!Update:  I was able to receive the full book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of Quirk Books.The entire book lived up to the promise of the first four stories I had previously read in the sampler. Of course as is to be expected with an anthology such as this one, my reactions to the stories range from love to dislike. However, there were only a couple in this collection that left me confused or unmoved. Most are excellent and worthwhile for those who enjoy a well-written short story.

I have been reading Mary Daheims Alpine series for a long time. I enjoy main character Emma Lords sharp wit and seeing the inner workings of a small town newspaper. The banter between Emma and her co-workers has always been amusing and the friendly bickering between Emma and Sheriff Milo Dodge entertaining. Best of all has been Emmas friendship with co-working Vida Runkel. The two women dont always see eye-to-eye, but have always been there for each other when it counted. Sadly that element is missing in the prior installment and much of this one.I was glad to see Emma and Milo finally realize how much they love each other a few books back, but their funny squabbling has been replaced by two much mushiness, even for newlyweds. This book is a little better than the previous installment. Emma and Milo are still acting like teenagers going steady, but seem more like themselves. Vida is completely obnoxious in the beginning of the book. Although her tirades are somewhat humorous, Emma and Vidas friendship has been the highlight of this series. I like when things get closer to normal by the end of the book and Emma could confide in Vida and trade theories about the strange things going on in Alpine. Those things are an eccentric young woman coming to town with a strange story about her parents being murdered and the current danger she is in, as well as a dead body found at the town dump. The various subplots are interesting, but the most important part of this book is the wrapping up of various things in the characters lives since I have come to care about these characters after reading each of the books in this series. I had assumed this would be the final installment of this series, but the author's website said this isn't the end. I recommend Alpine Zen to readers of other books in the series, but new readers would be better off reading a few of the earlier books before reading this one.I received this book from NetGalley, through the courtesy of Ballantine Books. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

The ticks have just started to come out so I immediately put this on my Golden, which runs through our woods on a daily basis, to keep these off her with the warmer weather coming. It was simple to administer and I have not noticed the telltail "stripe" or smell I have had with other treatments I have used previously. I have also noticed that she does not seem to be irritated by this product as she has been by others we have used previously. So far no ticks, fleas on her after applying the fiproguard.

Single mom Kate Page is one of three investigative reporters trying to land a full-time reporting job with a well-known news agency. Kate uncovers a story about a young mother who becomes separated from her baby during a deadly tornado. This is a tragedy, but it appears the baby may have been kidnapped. Despite the objectives of her new would-be boss, Kate refuses to give up on this investigation, both for the sake of the story and for the mother and baby.Whirlwind is the first book by Rick Mofina featuring investigative reporter Kate Page. I first read the follow-up to this book, Full Tilt, and because I liked the character of Kate so much, I went back to read the series debut. I enjoyed seeing Kate fight for a job in the face of strong competition and office politics and I admire her determination to cover the story of the missing baby. Kate feels a connection with the young mother, who feels guilty that her baby is lost, perhaps abducted, in part because of the guilt Kate feels over the disappearance of her little sister many years ago. Kate also wants to land a full-time job so she will be able to better provide for her young daughter.The story is told from multiple points of view, which allows the author to move the story forward with information that Kate would not know about. However, I prefer the chapters told from Kates point of view. The others often interrupt the flow of the story and sometimes causes it to drag. The story behind the babys disappearance is complex and some elements, like the involvement of a Russian mobster, are far-fetched, but overall the book is interesting and exciting. The information presented about what people must face in the aftermath of a natural disaster provides an excellent backdrop to the story. There are a few random events toward the end that deflate the drama that had been building, but the story is suspenseful and I was glad for the chance to read another of Kates adventures.

Investigative reporter and single mom Kate Page is no stranger to tragedy. After twenty years, she still hasnt gotten over her feelings of sadness and guilt over her little sisters disappearance. A body of a young woman is found in upstate New York, possibly the victim of a serial killer. Kate is shocked when she learns there could be a connection to this case and her sister Vanessa. When the investigation becomes dangerous, Kate refuses to let it go until she can finally find out the truth about her sister.The is the second book by Rick Mofina featuring reporter Kate Page, but the first one I read. I had no difficulties getting to know Kate or catching up on important details about her life. The mystery about Kates sister was intriguing and the reader is left guessing how or if Vanessas disappearance is connected to the horrific crimes under investigation. Kate puts her reporting skills to use getting to the bottom of the case and refusing to give up until she finds out if Vanessa could have survived the long ago accident and if she did, has she now become a victim of murder.The chapters told from Kates point of view are the best. Details like Kate putting her young daughter Grace to bed before she can get back to researching her story make the book realistic and helps the reader get to know Kate. These are also the most exciting and fast-paced chapters in the book. Those told from the point of view of Ed Brennan of the Rampart police department and other law enforcement and forensic personnel arent as successful. The supporting characters are interesting and these chapters serve to move the plot ahead and give insight into the investigation. However, they arent as compelling as the chapters focusing on Kate and end up slowing down the story. Ultimately, as all of the pieces of the book start to fit together, the story remains exciting no matter who is telling it.I enjoyed the book as well as the main character and would read other books featuring Kate Page. Readers who enjoy Hank Phillip Ryan will enjoy the character of Kate and the premise of this book.

Ani FaNelli is petite and beautiful and appears to have it all. She has a glamorous job in New York City and a rich, handsome fianc. Even though Ami seems to have a bright future ahead of her, she cant seem to forget her traumatic past, when she was known as TifAni and struggled to fit in with her peers, which may just get in the way of the new plans shes making.TifAni makes a lot of poor choices in her youth and as an adult, shes hard to feel sorry for as she complains about starving herself to get down from a size 2 to a size 0 and not being able to afford to buy the latest from designers the average person hasnt even heard of. However, Ani does grow as the story progresses and I think most people can relate to feelings of not fitting in or being judged based on your physical appearance or your background.The book has been compared to Gone Girl, but it reminds me more of Bond Girl by Erin Duffy. Both deal with what happens when your dreams seem to be coming true, only to discover what youve always dreamed of may not be what you thought it was going to be.  The twists and turns in Luckiest Girl Alive are not just surprising, but downright shocking, and sometimes difficult to read. However, the story has stayed with me and Im glad I read it. I was pleased with how Ani chose to overcome the tragedies she had experienced. There is more to Ani that what it appears in the beginning, so its worth sticking with the story to find out all the details of her school days and how the story progresses.

Compulsion is a follow-up to Notorious and is the second of Allison Brennans novels to feature investigative reporter Maxine Revere. Max is covering the trial of serial killer Adam Bachman, who is accused of killing five people. Max thinks a missing couple who havent been seen in almost a year are also victims of Bachman. However, when Max starts digging into the case to try to prove her theory that Bachman is working with a partner angers her boss and the prosecutors office and may just put her in the targets of a dangerous killer.Max is a driven, sometimes bossy character, but her determination to help victims wins my respect and makes me like the character very much. I enjoy seeing the contrast between the toughness Max shows with the bad guys and when facing the politics of her job with the softer side she shows when dealing with victims family members. Supporting characters such as Maxs personal assistant/body guard/friend David Kane and Queens, NY detective Sally OHara have depth as well and play an important role in the story. In fact, I could easily see David and Sally in a spin-off story of their own.Compulsion starts out as a compelling, but typical thriller in which the main character learns something in a course of an investigation which puts him/her in a killers crosshairs. However, the book takes an unpredictable turn which is as exciting as it is surprising. I love this latest Max Revere novel by Allison Brennan. Fans of Hank Phillippi Ryan or Rick Mofina will enjoy this suspenseful novel.

Enjoyed this standalone book by Debbie Macomber. I enjoy her Blossom Street, Cedar Cove, and Rose Harbor Inn Series. This book is different than all of these, but will appeal to Ms. Macombers fans that enjoy the Blossom Street series. Last One Home features a strong female character who fights adversity to make her life better.Cassie is a single mom, a hair stylist, and also volunteers as a victim advocate for abused women. Cassie experienced abuse in her own marriage and although she is currently free and safe from her ex-husband, her life will be forever changed because of what she went through and is currently estranged from her sisters. I liked how the book opened with a prologue showing the reader how close Cassie was with her sisters Karen and Nichole at one time and makes you even sadder seeing how their relationship turned out when they grew up.As the book progresses, I enjoy seeing Cassies life turn around for the better and seeing her interact with her daughter, Aimee. I also like seeing Cassies growing friendship with her Habitat for Humanity mentor, Steve.  The details about the Habitat for Humanity program are interesting and make a relevant and unique setting for the book.Overall, the book is enjoyable and it was a quick read for me. Less effective was Aimees matchmaking attempts. I was happy to see that after all she had experienced in her young life, she was open to her mom getting involved in another relationship and possibly even re-marrying, but her blatant matchmaking wasnt as realistic and seemed silly. The characterization of Cassies sisters was a little too over-the-top for me, too. Their dismissal of their sister seemed harsh and their characters seem very harsh and judgmental at the beginning of the book. By the end, they are more likeable, but I never could relate to their characters.Last One Home isnt my favorite book by Debbie Macomber, but judged on its own, still a sweet story of friendship, forgiveness, and second chances at love that her fans will enjoy. Readers who enjoy books by Luanne Rice will also like this book.

This lap desk by LapGear is small and lightweight, which makes it comfortable on my lap, as well as easy to store. I like using my netbook small PC to type in Word documents, respond to E-mails, and surf the Internet while sitting on the couch, and this lap desk has become invaluable. Its perfect for holding my PC and the wrist rests make it comfortable to type.The media slot holds a variety of sizes of tablets. The Kindle Fire HD fits well for watching videos. I have a large smart phone (LG Vista), and it fits well, too, and would also be great for watching videos.In addition, there is a no slip area on the surface of the right-hand side of the lap desk to place your phone so you can keep it handy and keep it from sliding down the desk.I am very pleased with this lap desk. It has been a while since Ive used one, but the compact size of this one makes it more useful and more comfortable to use. I definitely recommend this product.

Small/Spot carpet cleaner that does the job well. I used it to clean carpet in the car and the size was great. It really got down and cleaned out spots and dirt that were deep in the carpet. I also used it on upholstery in the car and in the house. It cleaned the vehicle seats so they were looking new. Also used it on a chair in the house and it cleaned that chair more than I ever thought it would.The unit is self contained which helps when moving around the different areas of the car and made the task easy to complete and quick to finish. Setup is easy and straight-forward, clean-up is quick and low mess/no mess.

Trixie Matkowski enjoys serving the residents of Sandy Harbor, New York the best in comfort food from the Silver Bullet Diner. Shes happy to learn that her best friend Antoinette Chloe Brown has decided to open an old-fashioned drive-in movie theater right next door. A fun groundbreaking ceremony is planned, but the excitement turns to horror when the digging reveals the dead body of Antoinette Chloes missing boyfriend, Nick. Trixies friend is devastated over Nicks death, but if thats not bad enough, Antoinette Chloe is arrested for the murder. Trixie knows her kind-hearted friend is not the guilty party, so she decides to start her own investigation to find the real murderer.The best part of this book is how funny it is. Reading the title, "Diners, Drive-ins, and Death" is so clever and the writing in the rest of the book is just as humorous. The quirky characters and funny situations as worthy of a Janet Evanovich novel. Fans of that series will enjoy the adventures of Trixie and Antoinette Chloe. This is the third novel in the Comfort Food series, but this is the first one Ive read. I was able to quickly catch up on who is who in Sandy Harbor. The only thing I cant understand is why Antoinette still seems half in love with her ex-husband, who apparently tried to kill both her and Trixie in a previous book.I enjoy the comradery between Trixie and Antoinette Chloe as well as the friendship between Trixie and Ty. I dont know if the hunky deputy Ty will be more than just a friend to Trixie in future books, but its obvious there is chemistry there, even though Trixie tries to deny her attraction to Ty. This may sound picky, but the name Antoinette Chloe is a mouthful.
