Sometimes Trixie and Ty refer to her by the nickname ACB, but unfortunately most people call her by her full first and middle name each time they talk to her or about her, which soon becomes monotonous to read.The book is entertaining because of the interesting characters and funny dialogue, but Trixie could use some help in the sleuthing department. At one point in the story, Trixie and Ty acknowledge that ACB is in danger from another possible suspect in Nicks murder. Strangely, only a couple of paragraphs later, the two are completely baffled as to who would possible have a motive for framing ACB. There are a few other times when Trixie isnt able to figure out some pretty obvious clues. Perhaps in future books, even if they dont get together as a couple. Trixie and Ty can work together so they are better equipped for an investigation.Everything gets wrapped up at the end and the epilogue is cleverly done in the format of an e-mail from Trixie to her Aunt Stella. A few recipes from the diner follow this to wrap up the book. There are some missteps in the book, but overall, I enjoyed the story and would read another in this series to catch up on whats happening next in the lives of Trixie, Ty, and ACB.This review was originally written for Smitten by Books. The book was provided to me in exchange for an honest review.

I really like this goal zero recharger. This is the second Goal Zero product I've used, and I like this one a lot better than the other (a solar powered portable speaker). I'm not a serious hiker, so my use-case for this is less about trips into the woods and more about emergency preparedness. I was once in a situation in which a phone was out of battery at a time when it was very much needed, and since then I've taken steps to ensure that that'll never happen again. In this case, I find this to be an outstanding product to keep in my car.It's easily rechargeable using a USB port, and it also has solar panels. It can charge a phone, act as a flashlight, or spin a handheld fan. Having this on hand brings me a peace of mind that I think is very important. It's compact, easy to store, and easy to tote. So, it delivers on the promises it makes in the product listing. I'm very pleased with this.

This is a nice shower curtain. It's thicker than the kinds I've had in the past, and it is not see-through. (In general, I prefer shower curtains that let some light in, as the only window in my bathroom is next to the shower.)It's attractive, washable, and is made of strong material. It's affective as a curtain, and it doesn't clash in any way with our decor.

These Philips Fidelio Headphones are simply outstanding.1. The materials: Leather padding, strong materials.2. The fit: The headphones fight snugly, not overly tight, very comfortably. The result is the best noise-blocking I've ever experienced with headphones.3. The sound: Fantastic. The music comes through clearly, well-balanced, better than any headphones I've ever used.The only thing I would change is not a fault in a product, only an item on my wishlist: If only they could plug into standard jacks and not just the newer Apple products. I have some other devices I would love to use these with, but that's not what they're made for. Do note, if purchasing these, which product they're compatible with.Though I do not consider myself an audiophile, I do appreciate good comfort and sound (both of which are necessary). I have used and own a variety of different types of headphones (over the ear, ear-buds, noise-cancelling, wireless) and these are undoubtedly the best I've ever used.

I won't say The Dark Knight Strikes Again is the worst graphic novel ever written, but I will say it's the worst one I've ever read. I simply could not find things to enjoy as I experienced boneheaded decision after boneheaded decision. I will not go on at length, but essentially it boils down to this:1. The plotting is a mess, with too many characters and no solid foundation.2. The art is poor throughout.3. The jokes aren't funny.4. The core ideas are not interesting.5. The presentation is questionable at best (multiple splash pages of a Superman/Wonder Woman sex scene, for example)Others have written about all these things extensively. For me, it's important to say that I knew it would be less-than-great going in, but I had no idea it could be this bad. With a third Frank Miller Dark Knight graphic novel due to come out, I was hoping this wouldn't be too bad and the third would make up for it. As it is, I don't think I can ever read Frank Miller's later work again. I regret having read this. My advice is to enjoy The Dark Knight Returns and stop there. As a completist in most things, I normally wouldn't say that, but in this case I think it's the wiser move.

There are two problems with this product:1. It does not making my charging area less messy. To charge devices, you still have to have long cords very close together. It's still a bit of a tangle and not very attractive.2. The slots aren't big enough, and they are not adjustable. The phones in my house all have cases. Without the cases, the phones would sit happily in the slots, but with the cases, they are a tight squeeze or just don't fit. Most people with phones have cases, and phones are larger than they used to be, so I'd advise anyone looking to purchase this to note whether its thin enough to fit right.The hope for this is that you can get a lot of charging done in a consolidated area while using just one outlet. As far as function, it essentially works, but it isn't helpful enough that I find it preferable to simply plugging my devices into a power strip.

One thing's for sure: Florence + The Machine have a distinct sound. Big, bombastic, emotional, cathartic, dense . . . no one else sounds like this. At once modern and timeless, this is a band (and especially a singer-songwriter) who is in it for the long haul, carving out a place that will outlast the trends of a season or a year.On their third album, F+TM have created their most immediate music, delving deeper into the sounds and song styles that made their first pair of albums such successes. One could easily argue that it is a retread, and perhaps doesn't push farther away from their core sound. I think that would be a valid criticism, but I also think there's something very special about a band at its peak. Especially looking at the first three songs here, I could already assemble a "best of Florence" playlist that would be as good as many long-established artist's Greatest Hits collections. These are the defining years of the first era of this group, and I do hope they are able to expand further on this sound in the future, as well as explore some different lyrical territory, but for now I'm excited and captivated by this new set of songs.Ship to Wreck, What Kind of Man, How Big, How Blue, How Beautiful, Third Eye - these are instant classics. Meanwhile, the rest of the album thrills and haunts in equal measure. This is a great album, one that will most assuredly satisfy Florence's fans, and I suspect it will continue to draw newcomers in.

This set is a great addition to my collection of cookware. These kitchen tools are nice and thick, while also being a bit soft, so there are a number of advantages: Dishwasher safe, which is a must. Strong enough to hold food. Soft enough not to scratch my pots and pans.My only concern in getting these was that they'd be flimsy or somehow "cheap," but they aren't at all. They've quickly become my first choice kitchen tools, and I happily recommend them.
This box is very sturdy, unfolds easily, and really gets the job done. It fits easily on a shelf in my living room and is a nice way to keep certain items out of site but easily accessible.

For technical details, there are some very good reviews already written for this product, so I really recommend you check them out. My review concerns my own behavior as a limited user. I'm not using this as a complete backup in coordination with time machine, but am instead interested in this cloud drive as a second backup for all my digital music, and I'm interested in how it is used when accessing my entire collection remotely.My first issue when I got this was that my mac (bought in 2011) didn't have a recent enough OSX. It needs a minimum of 10.8, so I spent $20 to upgrade to 10.8.5, which isn't the most current OSX but meets the minimum requirements. It was a helpful coincidence that my internet was upgraded at this same time, so I've got a very strong connection in my house. Having done that, I plugged in the Personal Cloud, it found the internet, interacted with my computer very quickly, and was set up in mere minutes.One thing I didn't like during the set up was that other download windows popped up during the product registration. Seagate should not let that happen. Their site should be free of that kind of nonsense. At first, it seemed to indicate I had to download some extra software, but then I realized it was just spammy sites that had nothing to do with this product.It was very easy to set up a password and to install the associated Seagate Media app on my phone and tablet. One thing I didn't realize at first, due to the lack of documentation provided by seagate (you can get some info online, but they should really include more in the box), is that you can only access the things in the "Public" folder remotely. The stuff in the folder with your user name is only accessible when connected within your network. This raises certain security questions. "Public" doesn't mean accessible to anyone in the world, but it's unclear to me how the limitations are established so that only people who are logged into this cloud can reach it.I was able to stream music remotely while at the gym, as well as from my house, but the Seagate Media app is, so far, not a particularly smooth means of selecting music. iTunes remains the gold standard as an interface, and I'm fine with the music app on my android phone or the amazon app. The seagate interface is not great in this regard, but may be "good enough" if I'm only using it occasionally.This comes preloaded with some classical music, lame photos, and videos. The music is a nice little bonus, but the photos and videos were pointless, so I just deleted them.There are a number of features I don't expect to use from this that enable streaming to a television or automated backups. Overall, I'm very pleased with this backup for my music.I'm increasingly paranoid as my collection has grown quite large that something will happen that results in my losing all those mp3s, and this is an excellent tool for me to use in addition to my other external hard drive.

My family's used air purifiers for a few years now, starting even before we had our child. The first one we ever got was much too big and noisey, and the second one was a pretty nice size, with some different settings. This AeraMax is every bit as good as that other one, and possibly better, with one small caveat: the blue display lights.This purifier is extremely easy to set-up, right out of the box, and it has some different fan settings, which is great, because it can run very quietly or go up to another setting, which mostly helps in terms of being a white noise maker. The only thing, as I mentioned, is that it has glowing display lights. In this age of electronic everything, it sometimes seems like you can't escape glowing lights, when you just want the room to be dark at night. The solution is simply to turn it to face away from the bed, but that would be the one thing I'd change about this.

This is a very good, basic electric toothbrush. There are other toothbrushes with bluetooth that work with apps to track habits, or light up, or do all sorts of extra things that I think just go too far. The features here include: adjustable speeds, vibration to help time your brushing, and that's about it. To be clear: I like that.Charging is easy, and charges last a very long time. The brush head itself is smaller than I'm used to, but it's fine, and I didn't notice the size much after only a few uses.The main thing I like about this is that they don't overload you with features that get in the way of simply brushing your teeth. When you have lots of features, there are more things that can break, and an investment in an electric toothbrush is one that should last a while, so that's the only remaining aspect yet to be seen. Hopefully this will last for years to come, as it's a good tool to keep my teeth feeling good and remaining healthy.

The Curious George Teach stuffed animal has been a very nice addition to my daughter's stable of animal pals.Her first reaction when she saw this was, "The monkey!" because she knows him from "the monkey book" we have, a Curious George collection that we've read with her numerous times. The second thing she said was, "Monkeys don't wear clothes!"George's outfit has a few features that kids can use to explore their developing dexterity: a button, a snap, velcro, a buckle, string. Another thing I like is how extremely soft he is. Most stuffed animals are soft, of course, but this little guy is just fabulously soft and smooth. I highly recommend this as both a learning toy for young children and as a treat for fans of the Curious George stories.

This is a very nice, simple magnet set. It really is exactly what you see pictured: all the letters of the alphabet with accompanying pictures, made of wood, with a good strong magnet on the back. My daughter is 2.5 years old right now, and she had a set of animal magnets that she uses on our refrigerator. The instant we handed her this box, she launched into a little dance and cheered, "magnets, magnets, magnets!" It's a really good, portable, easy way to keep her occupied in the kitchen, and I think is the perfect gift for kids of that age, especially since it's not a noise-making toy that could irritate parents. Also, it's a good way to support teaching kids their letters. I was pleasantly surprised when my daughter picked out the first letter of her name, recognizing it as such. I definitely recommend this magnet set without reservations.

Steve Earle (whose hobbies include political activism and getting divorced) is truly one of the great musicians of our era. His songwriting is second to none, and his gift for melody and tone are outstanding. His post-prison run of albums were astonishing, with Transcendental Blues being the peak of his greatness, along with El Corazon and The Mountain. Since that time, his albums have gotten a little more uneven, with a lot of great songs, but also a few clunkers, and a little less of the magic that made the first couple phases of his career so exciting. Earle is at his worst when he slips into his "spoken word"-style poetry, as he did on "Warrior" back in 2004. He only slips into that mode once on Terraplane, but it's not so egregious a misstep. The rest of the album is Earle doing what he does best: creating music that fuses country with roots rock and, in this case, a whole lot of blues.The sound suits him well. Though his voice isn't quite what it once was, it's still quite expressive, and this style of music fits his gruff singing and lyrical style better than his New Orleans-inspired songs. These songs are not boring retreads of old blues riffs, though blues riffs abound. There's a variety of tones and tempos, from gentle balladry, with Earle's distinctive finger-picking style, to thumping blues-rock. If it doesn't match his high points of late '90s into 2000, that's understandable. It nevertheless returns him to a place that I think was missing a bit from his recent albums. Terraplane is every bit the album I was hoping it would be, and it is a welcome addition to one of the great catalogs in modern music.

The Tone Pro is really quite good, but it's very important to note this particular style of earbud and neck band is not suited to everyone. I've had a lot of trouble with different products with this style of earbud, as they tend to fall out of my ears. Other people I know swear by this kind and generally have better results than I do.The most notable, and unusual aspect of this product is the band that sits on your shoulders. Again, this is not suited to everyone. I would be too self-conscious to wear something like this for all to see, but, conversely, it's an improvement over clunky bluetooth earpieces if you have it under your jacket in the winter so that only the earbuds are exposed.The sound is quite good through the earbuds, and the controls are very easy to use. I had a little trouble reading the instructions, as the print is excruciatingly small, but luckily the product was pretty easy to get used to.A big issue I've had with bluetooth headsets has not been a problem with this one: connectivity. Music has been playing fine, without losing connection, even when interrupted with a phone call. Switching to and from a call has been surprisingly easy, and overall the function is the best I've used in the past few years.

I remember my father's pillow from when I was growing up. It was very thin, a little lumpy, and seemed like it had been completely beaten down over the years. By contrast, my mother's was puffy, not unlike the kind you get at a decent hotel. I wondered why my father used such a worn out old thing, but as I got older I found myself having the same preference for thinner, somewhat harder pillows. For a while, I'd been using a pillow I'd describe not as thin, but as very firm and quite heavy. It was good. This Classic Brands pillow is a little better.It's firm, but it does give to accommodate the shape of the head lying upon it. It's a very nice size, and, best of all, the cover is the exact size of the pillow and zips around perfectly, so you don't get any of that pillowcase-slipping-off stuff that can be a bit irritating. I find this pillow very comfortable and hope it can maintain its shape and behavior for the long run.AS for the "cool sleep" aspect, I confess I can't fully analyze that at this time (the middle of winter). In truth, I doubt that it'll be that big of a deal. The main most important aspect of any pillow, by far, is how well it supports your desired sleep comfort level, and this pillow has thus far met my needs wonderfully.

This lock was very easy to install and set-up. It's sturdy and secure, and we were very happy to install it at my brother's home. I mention that specifically because I felt a bit leery about installing it at my row home that only has one major entrance (the back can be accessed, but only through a narrow back area).My only concern about this is the fear of the battery losing power. There is a way to jump the battery, but I fear that that would ever happen and leave me stuck outside for any reason, even temporarily, especially with my young child still in the house.For my brother's house, though, he's got a few entrances, including a garage door. Having this combo lock gives a great keyless option for any visitors to get in without the need for transferring keys or (something I've never liked) using a hide-a-key. Ultimately, I think I would feel slightly better if I could only use keyed entry systems, but I really like the idea of having both options available for a home with multiple entrances.

Many parents fantasize about sharing their interests with their kids, whether it's loving Star Wars or going to baseball games, weaving or reading, or any number of things. One thing I've looked forward to is sharing my love of tennis. One question is, how young can one get their child out there playing? Even if you have access to public courts, there may be a time limit, the net may be too high, or it may be too inconvenient to get there on a regular basis. One of the great things about this set is that it gives younger players a new option, as well as equipment that can be used by younger kids before venturing out to play full-size (think tee-ball before baseball).A problem for me is only that I live in a place that does not have a lot of flat surface area. I can't help but laugh at the demo video, showing people playing on a perfectly flat driveway. I'm not aware of any non-sloping driveways anywhere I've been, and, living in South Philadelphia, I don't even have a driveway or parking or any place nearby to set this net up (at least, not safely, as the only option near me would be the middle of the street), However, I do have a relative with a cement back "yard," and my brother and I used to play all sorts of games back there growing up. This net fits that space perfectly.It's easy to set up and put away. It comes with a case, so traveling with it in the trunk of a car is minimally intrusive, and it's got everything you need to get started. I love that I can play with my nephew, and in just a few years my daughter as well. It's so important to be active and outside, and I find this to be a very nice set that encourages a lot of fun and exercise.

This is a perfect, basic carrying case for a 7-inch Tablet.I have a number of products that seemed almost like incidentals at first glance, not flashy or exciting, just functional and simple, and they've turned out to be the best items, lasting a long time and serving their purpose. This carrying case is well-constructed, nicely padded, with a zipper that opens very wide (along the top and right edges) for easy placement and removal of the tablet. It also has a pocket for a charger, if you're bringing that with you.When I travel, I don't want to scream out, "look at me, I have an expensive tablet and all sorts of fancy gear!" What I want is to keep my device protected, and I'd like to have easy access to it. This Five Star Tablet Sleeve provides that exact function.

This product does work, sealing wine bottles and locking in the air, but I find using it awkward and no better than just pushing the cork back in. I imagine this is most suited as a small gift for a wine lover who has a frequent desire to reseal wine bottles for extended periods of time and like to use gizmos (think: affordable stocking stuffer). I found the instructions a bit difficult to follow, but it's not that hard to figure out how to use this just by looking at the pieces and testing it out.Ultimately, I come away feeling that this product simply isn't necessary unless you regularly find yourself having half a bottle of wine at a time, with a significant period of time between opening the bottle and returning to it.

This is a perfect clip light. It's small and light, but the light is bright. The clip is not obtrusive, and it stays in place without a problem, whether you're reading a paperback or hardcover. The mustache design is cute but ultimately irrelevant, because these devices are ultimately about their function. I've had a different clip light for almost 20 years (I've only used it occasionally, which is why it's managed to last so long), and it's rather bulky, so it's ill-suited to paperbacks. The Carson LED light does not pose a problem in that regard. I highly recommend this for anyone who wants a small light with which to travel or read late into the night.

This case is very comfortable to hold, fits the LG Volt phone perfectly, and looks good.I had a bit of trouble getting it properly onto the phone until I realized it's actually two pieces. I was then able to wrap the soft black cover for a perfect fit, and then click the hard white component into place. Everything lined up, and it's exactly what I wanted. Except for one thing . . .The hole for the headphone jack is too small. I have three different places where I use the audio line out: speakers in my home, in the car, and headphones. My headphones have a thin end to the cord, so they fit just fine. My cords at home and in the car are a bit thicker at the ends, and the hole in this case prevents it from clicking all the way into the phone. I've had to delicately cut into the hole to make it wider to make it work. Hopefully, it will not result in ruining the whole case over time, but it would have been nice if the hole were a bit larger to begin with.

I give this Linksys router a good rating, but I'd like to relay the story of how it was problematic for me to install and resulted in my not using it. Instead, we installed it in my brother's apartment, where it installed and works great. (Details about that are at the end of this review, if you want to skip down.)I went to set it up, and things started out okay. And then I got a message on the Web that my internet provider had temporarily disabled my account. (In fairness, I won't list the name of the company for the purposes of this review.) But the site wouldn't let me log-in to my account to deal with it. And so the customer service dance began.I called the provider and went from mildly frustrated to red-hot mad as the automated system, over and over again, told me to log into their site for support. When you can't access the internet, that kind of stuff is not helpful.When I finally got to a customer service guy, I tried to explain that I couldn't access my account, and it took us a while to get on the same page as to what was going on.As it turns out, my account wasn't suspended (connecting the computer with the cord worked fine), so the error message wasn't accurate. And, ultimately, the guy said to me, "You know, we could test out the connection problem with the Linksys for who knows how long, but there's a different solution that take care of all your problems. Our latest modem has built-in wi-fi, so you don't need a third-party router, and if anything breaks, it's all stuff we can control and deal with."They upgraded me to their latest modem/router at no charge, so I went with that. In the time since then, I have had no connectivity issues, and I'm confident if something goes wrong that they'll be able to address it.So, my first experience with the Linksys router was that it was incompatible with my older modem and unnecessary for the new one. I contacted my brother and sister-in-law to see if they'd like to try this router, so we installed it at their house. They had long suspected, as it turns out, that their current router was not giving them a good enough connection. The sense with the Linksys is that it has improved the connection. Installation and set up took a total of 5 minutes, and we had no issues whatsoever with suspended accounts or any other hassles. The router itself looks nice and modern. It came with a number of disks, none of which were necessary to use.In conclusion, I'd advise you to confirm you need a third-party router of this kind. If that is in fact the best route for you, and you have a compatible modem, the Linksys works well, with an easy install and improved speeds.

These clippers keep things nice and simple. I've owned a number of clippers over the years. My *favorite* was a device that caught fire while I was using it. I'll never forget that day when I had to go to a store (on a warm day, with a winter hat on) to get a replacement so I could finish the job.These days, I don't go for the crew cut, but I'm still a hairy guy, and it definitely grows faster than I'm willing to go to a barber, so I need to take care of my sideburns and my neck on my own. I have some clippers with a dozen pieces and various settings, but after a while, you just don't want to deal with the bulk and the big case when it's really just a small, quick job that needs to be done.With this Remington, though, you get two great things, if your needs are just trimming a bit: A name brand that you can trust for a long lasting product (I'll update this review should it fail prematurely) and a small, easy to handle product. I do like this, and thus far have had no qualms whatsoever.

This is a solid water bottle. The textured grip is very comfortable, and this is an ideal size to replace purchasing bottled water with this filter that should last anywhere from two months to half a year or more, depending on your frequency of use. It's easy to take the lid off and twist it back on, and it has a cover to prevent any minor leaks when tossed into a bag.When you first use it, the instructions tell you to fill it with water and squeeze it out so some black gunk can come out. Heed this instruction. You certainly would not want to drink that. Once cleared, though, everything is easy as can be, the water tastes good, and it can easily become part of your regular routine.The one criticism I have is that there isn't a line marked for how much to fill the bottle to get it full after the filter piece (which is part of the lid, basically) descends. If you fill the bottle all the way, you'll displace some and get some spillage. I fill it to the top of the textured grip, but there's more room. I think the bottle should mark the ideal height of the water before the lid is replaced. It's easy to figure out, though, so it's not a big deal.

I like this scale. Its base is a good size to stand on and see the numbers without a struggle, with a large text display. I found the set-up very easy and intuitive. When I get devices like this, I like to try setting them up without reading the instructions, and I was able to do so without any problems. (I then read the instructions to confirm I hadn't done anything stupid.)The scale seems accurate, though my wife complains that it gave a reading of 2 lbs heavier than our other scale. I kind of think this one is the correct one, as it's newer, with a fresh battery, but she's unconvinced. (By the way, I think it's funny how the sample weight listed in the product images is 126.4. Interesting that they don't make the sample reading 210 or higher, isn't?)I'm not sure the BMI reading can really be trusted, as it's a calculation without the "pinch test," as there's an obvious health difference  between muscle and fat in terms of where exactly one's weight comes from. I find it is best taken with a grain of salt, but is a good tool in terms of comparative measurements. There isn't an exact weight that's perfect for one's height, as some people are wider or slimmer due to genetics, but having these numbers available can be very useful when tracking goals one might set for oneself.Another good aspect is that it is consistent. I've had scales before that gave slightly different numbers if you stepped off and back on a few moments later. With this one, it gives the same number when I test it in that way.

I'm always curious about new gizmos, and I love to use technology to make my life, if not easier, then at least more interesting. The Oral-B Bluetooth toothbrush is at the very least an intriguing idea, offering a service that simply never would have occurred to me. The problem is, I think it wouldn't have occurred to me because it's just so unnecessary.The reason I'm giving this 4 stars is based completely on the toothbrushing experience itself. To put it simply, this is just plain the best electric toothbrush I've ever used. I have never in my life gotten the same "fresh from the dentist" feeling at home from any other product. I'm not sure I can do it justice with this description, but it's just so much better than my previous brushes, a noticeable improvement where I didn't think there was room for improvement. It's great.As for the Bluetooth aspect, I tried to approach it with an open mind, but it just doesn't feel worth it at all for me. I have so much to think about in life, integrating an app with my brushing habits is just taking things too far. I can't judge what other people will enjoy on this front, but go in with an understanding of how much thought you really want to give to your brushing.Bottom line, though, is that this device gets your teeth feeling great. Put aside the bells and whistles, and you've got one tremendous little machine.

I really like this Diono Booster. It has two major advantages for my family. First, it is much narrower than our other carseat, so people can sit comfortably in the back seat without the armrest/cup-holder of the car seat jabbing at your elbows. Second, it is good for a wide range of ages. While we have a different brand in our car, we installed this in my mother's car so she can shuttle around my daughter as well as her two other children, the oldest being 6.My brother and his family have had a different Diono car seat for a while and really like it, so that is a good indication that this one will also be good for the long haul. It feels very strong, and I had no trouble whatsoever installing it. The kids seem comfortable, and right now I have a lot of confidence in using it.I hope I never have an experience that would lead me to return to this review to indicate exactly how well it does in a crash.

This Belkin charging set is a 3-in-1 deal that is very useful. I've had a number of Belkin products in the past, especially their routers, including my current one, and I've generally found them reliable. So, seeing they made this charger kit, I thought it worthwhile to pursue.There are three pieces: The usb cable, which can of course plug directly into a computer, and the two adapters, one for the car and one for an outlet. The picture makes the wall-charger look a bit large, but it's really not. It's rather compact, as is the car charger.So far, it's functioning exactly as expected, without any set-up or hullabaloo. I don't mean to sound corny in saying this, but given how expensive technology can be, and how personal tech items are (I know I wouldn't want someone else picking out my devices), this really fits the bill as a great gift to give someone who already owns an iPhone or iPad of the current versions. Anyone who has one of those products can always use another charger or usb cord to keep in the car, at work, or just in a different room in the house.

There's a great Genesis compilation called the Platinum Collection that also goes in reverse order, but there's a huge difference in doing that for Genesis compared with Bowie. For Genesis, going back in time puts the big radio hits first and then gets increasingly more interesting and adventurous as you work your way back to the excellent 70s work and the Peter Gabriel era.David Bowie's career has so many more peaks and valleys, and it's hard to pin down whether certain eras represent an ascent or a descent. There's no way I could come up with a perfect compilation for him, that's for sure. Themes of subject matter, different eras, pop vs. art, and so many more aspects - I think part of Bowie's greatness is how hard it is to pigeonhole him or whittle him down into a career-spanning collection.I originally did not plan to buy this, since I have all of Bowie's albums, including a number of live albums and most of his b-sides and rarities. Some of the non-album tracks that might attract buyers here, like the songs from the lost Toy album, are already in my collection, so it seemed at first that all I'd need is to get the new song, "Sue," and I'd be all set. What ultimately made me take the plunge, though, was the fact that Amazon offered an auto-rip with all of the songs from the main collection even if I purchased the vinyl set. While I don't consider myself an audiophile, I do have an appreciation for vinyl and like to occasionally add to my record collection. This way, I got a collectible, a wonderful set of music on record, and the digital music, so I'm more than satisfied with this purchase. Also, these mixes are in fact noticeably different in some instances, like with Seven, which is much peppier here than the plodding original version. The other remixes/alternate versions are also welcome, like the version of Hallo Spaceboy here, which fares very well in this context, and the outstanding Time Will Crawl, which just plain sounds fantastic.The song selections on the records is great, and I have no complaints about that whatsoever. More interesting to consider are the song selections for the main set, which span Bowie's entire career and will inevitably draw criticism from those who think that his latterday albums are overrepresented at the expense of his earlier classics. I, too, feel that's the case, which is why I've rated this 4 stars instead of 5, though it is easy enough in the modern era to supplement this set with some additional favorites in a playlist (and also easy to remove the Dancing in the Street duet, which is probably the low point of his career and can be happily traded for something else from that era, like As the World Falls Down.) I definitely need a handful of songs from Low, Heroes, and Station to Station to make any Bowie mix more satisfying, as well as Conversation Piece, Watch That Man, Teenage Wildlife, Looking for Satellites, and a number of other must-haves from all eras.As a longtime David Bowie fan, I hope this helps draw more fans in, as there's so much wonderful music here for people to appreciate and then perhaps decide to dig deeper into his catalog. There are plenty of collections out there, and some people will be better served by something shorter and more glam-centered, but this is definitely a great overview of a tremendous career. Newcomers, this is definitely not a bad place to start. Established fans, this might not be a vital addition, but the remixes and alternate versions may make this worth it.

There are few bands who have meant as much to me throughout my life as U2. I was 8 years old in 1987 (one of the greatest ever years of music) when The Joshua Tree came out. I remember my babysitter playing the cassette and finding myself completely enamored with it from start to finish. Since then, I was hooked, especially when Achtung Baby came out and completely redefined the band--and my conception of what music can be. U2's run between their debut and Zooropa is one of the great career arcs in pop music history. Though they stumbled with Pop (and I hesitate to mention the disaster that was the Million Dollar Hotel soundtrack), they have made music that has ranged from good to great since All That You Can't Leave Behind, when they fully embraced rock clacissicm and a big "U2" arena sound, a wise financial move even if it perhaps closes the door on the greatness that they achieved in their first fifteen years.All of that is just for me to say that a new U2 album is not just a record release: it's an event. Of course, Songs of Innocence will, for better or worse, be remembered for its release more than its songs, at least for a little while. I don't need to say much about the huge iTunes free release, which has been well documented and debated, except to answer the question, with the album available for free, does it make sense to buy? The answer, for the die-hard U2 fan, is an unequivocal yes. Yes, because the CD sounds so great. Yes, because the bonus tracks are incredible. Yes, because my physical collection of U2 albums simply wouldn't be complete without this standing proudly beside their last few albums.Rolling Stone gave this album 5 stars. Most other reviewers that I trust gave it 3 or 3.5. I'm somewhere between that, giving it 4. I think this is undoubtedly the best U2 album since All That You Can't Leave Behind, and I'd even tentatively say it's their best since Zooropa or Passengers. It's a fantastic collection of songs, Bono is in fine voice, and the band is tight as ever. Lyrically, it's more personal, like Achtung Baby, rather than preachy, which can be a little wearisome at times.This is what the bonus disc reveals in the deluxe edition: the strength of the songs. U2 is well known for their produced, sometimes overly produced, music. By stripping the songs down, they show that these really do hold up without all the production tricks. Not only that, but the entirely new songs on the bonus disc are very strong, and one could easily question the decision to leave them off the album proper.Without entering too much into the debate about whether the iTunes release was the right thing to do or not (I was happy about it, though I understand the concerns about invasion of privacy), I will say that I am proud to be a U2 fan. There are only a few bands and musicians that mean as much to me as this group, and I am thrilled that they put so much effort into every one of their releases. That they could make an album this good this deep into their career is extraordinary. It doesn't reach the same heights as masterpieces like War, The Joshua Tree, or Achtung Baby, but it's a truly outstanding album that only adds to their legacy. Casual fans will be satisfied with the album as originally released, but devoted fans like me will likely agree, this deluxe edition is indispensable.

This product is recommended for children aged 4 and up. I set it up for my 2-year-old and her cousin of the same age, and they really enjoyed it. (Their artistry is was quite haphazard, but hey - that's not the point.) I really like the way this gives the kids a big canvas to draw on and play with. Any toy that keeps kids active and creating things is better than a gizmo with flashing lights, as far as I'm concerned. This is definitely a good size, sturdy, and has provided a lot of enjoyment.One thing I'll mention - and this does not affect my rating of the product - is simply that I've felt my daughter has had at least as much fun playing with giant cardboard boxes when I've flipped them on their side and cut out some holes for windows. This kit provides a more direct route to a fun coloring-house, and I think it would appear in particular to kids who enjoy organizing things and being precise. For other kids - and some could go either way - taking a shipping box from something else and wrangling it into something new could be a good way to go, too. Again, that's not a knock on this toy, but it's something to think about.

The concept of the Goal Zero Rechargeable Speaker is a good one: It's totally rechargeable, either through its built-in solar panels or through a USB connection. The charge lasts a long time, and this is the best aspect of the speaker.It has a built-in cable to either daisy-chain the speaker or to do a wired connection. For me, this is necessary, as I feel it has rather poor bluetooth connectivity. I've used both my iPod Touch and an Android phone to connect with bluetooth. The iPod did terribly; the Android did a little better, but the connection has been hard to establish, and it disconnects at random times.The sound quality is an upgrade over simply using your iPod or phone's speaker, but it's not as good as some other portable speakers I've used. It's mediocre, nothing to celebrate or disparage.This is marketed to hikers. The instructions are easy to follow but strange, referring to "your crew" in what appears to be an attempt to be hip and appealing to young outdoorsy people. I admit, I wouldn't use this while hiking, though it's built to strap onto your bag and has a sleeve dedicated to putting your ipod/phone, which is a good idea. I have found it best fits my needs by putting it on my kitchen shelf and connecting my iPod (with the cable) if I want a little music while cooking. In that way, I'm getting a good use out of it, and it's cute enough that it doesn't look terribly out of place.

This Hoover vacuum is easily on the better side of vacuums I've used in my home. It has all the standard stuff you'd expect as far as attachments and retractable cord (something that I consider an absolute must in a modern vaccum). My home has a mix of carpeted rooms and hardwood floors, some with area rugs. This vacuum has no trouble going from one surface to another while doing a more than acceptable job sucking up the dirt and crumbs that plague a house with a small child in it.In general, I hate vacuum bags, so going bagless is always the way to go. It just plain makes sense and removes an entire level of hassle, so this Hoover Windtunnel really fits the bill for my tastes and needs. Assembly was no problem, and its ease of use is notable. For a solid vacuum for your house or apartment, I think this is equal to or better than the comparable vacuums on the market.

My daughter is at the very earliest stage of potty training. She's got three different potties at this point. One is a freestanding one that is as much a toy as anything, with a little handle that makes it cheer when you "flush" it. She also has a toddler potty seat in our upstairs bathroom and this new OXO Tot Sit Right Potty Seat in our downstairs bathroom. So far, she hasn't shown a particular preference for - or aversion to - any of these seats. I would say that the OXO seat is at least equal to the other brand's seat we have upstairs.One thing that's very easy to see even from the picture is how simple the design is: there's nothing to click into place, so it's easy to put on or off, and it's designed not to slide so it stays steady. It is also smooth, without a bunch of design flourishes, so cleaning it is also a very simple and direct process. I also like the handles, as it's certainly very important for a child to feel balanced when on the toilet.Overall, this is a very light, well-designed product that I fully expect to get a significant amount of use from. Potty training is a formidable enough task, so adding worries about the state of the seat is not something I'd want to have in the mix. With this seat, I know I've got a solid tool to help us out.

This is a great set of blocks. It's 136 pieces in a wide variety of shapes, are a great next-level toy for a kid who has thus far used mega bloks and legos. The box is rather large and sturdy, which is cool. It's actually a lot larger than I had expected. One feature I like a lot is that it comes with an instructional booklet, so you have the option to carefully create something predesigned, or you can play and invent for yourself. One of my favorite aspects of any building toy like this is that it's something a parent can enjoy along with the child, as it's really quite relaxing, interesting, and fun. (It certainly beats all the blinking lights and loud noises of other childhood toys.) It's also educational without beating you over the head with dumb lessons: playing with blocks teaches balance and basic principles while encouraging creativity and three-dimensional thinking.This is definitely the finest block set I've encountered, on a par with - and perhaps better than - comparable products by companies like Melissa and Doug or even Lego (both of whom create outstanding toys). I definitely recommend this for any child who is old enough not to put small pieces in their mouths, as these could be a choking a hazard for younger kids.

Perhaps my main need for a new toaster oven was just the fact that my old one got so grimy that it was beyond ever getting clean again. That said, when I started using this one, I was impressed by how quickly it heated up, how roomy it is inside, and how easy it is to pull the crumb tray out and wipe it off after each use.The dials are easy to use, though I would be a bit more comfortable if I could be sure of the exact temperatures, rather than spinning the dial to what appears to be the proper spot. This is essentially ready to use right out of the box. Just stick the trays in, plug it in, and you're good to go.Having proven that it can cook well, and evenly, the key factor at this point is simply longevity. If something should happen that indicates this one doesn't last, I'll return to this review to update it with those details.

This little charger is great. When I first opened the package, I was a little skeptical, because it appeared I could only charge it via USB and my computer, as it only came with the one USB cord. I soon discovered I could plug it into the wall using my Android phone's charger. That method charges this faster, but both methods worked.I then took this on an 8-day vacation, in which a lot of driving was involved, and driving for my family means listening to music through my iPod. My device for charging through the wall broke a few months ago, and I didn't bring a computer through which to charge the iPod. Using the TP-LINK, I was able to recharge the iPod whenever I needed, and there was plenty of juice left at the end of the 8 days. In other words, it worked perfectly, and I was very satisfied. The fact that it works with both iPods and Android phones is my favorite aspect, as I need both of those things to function if I'm away for an extended period.Overall, this has been an outstanding performer, and it gives peace of mind that I won't find myself in a situation where I've got a phone that's out of battery. There are certainly some times in my past in which that would have been a huge help.

This is just plain a great game for kids. It's a matching game, simple and pure. One thing I love about it is that it packs up into a small tin, the coaster-sized pieces contained well so that you can pop this into any bag or purse and have it with you if traveling.Last year, I bought the regular Spot It! game for my nephew, who was 5 years old. It turned out that he already owned it, but he immediately popped it open and started playing with it anyway. That's the kind of game this is. Even if a child has it and is familiar with it, he or she can still get excited for it. This version is a new variation with different images from the original, so it adds a little bit of newness to a classic game. I've had a lot of fun playing with my nephew, and I look forward to when my daughter (now 2) is old enough to enjoy it as well.I feel I should add: if you're like me and don't necessarily have a ton of money, but need to get a child a gift for his or her birthday or for a holiday, this is a real winner that won't break the bank.

As much as I loved the Sam Raimi Spider-Man movies (especially the first two), I have to say that Marc Webb's entries thus far are even better. I can point to a number of reasons for this: the action scenes have more weight, the stories dig a bit deeper, and - standing out in particular - the acting is extraordinary. The Amazing Spider-Man 2 could have easily slipped up and become overcrowded with villains and bombastic action sequences. But everything stays contained throughout, balanced, and anchored by two outstanding actors, Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone, especially Stone, who is pitch perfect in this role.I'm keeping this review very short, because I mostly want to point out that the fate of Gwen Stacey is no secret. It's part of Spider-Man's history, arguably the most important part. The way it is weaved into this film is nothing short of astonishing. When dealing with such important scenes, everything has to come together just right, and I really think it did in this movie. I could quibble with a few bits here and there for this movie, but so many things go right, especially in the key scenes, that it's almost hard to remember what I might have done differently.This product itself is packaged well, and I love having both the Blu-ray and DVD discs. It's my favorite way to own movies these days, and I'm satisfied in what they've delivered. First and foremost, though, it's about the movie, and we've now got a pair of Marc Webb films that I am sure will stand the test of time.

--Summary:I have seen a lot of mixed reviews on this set, a lot of them from people that bought through Amazon. I'm wondering if sitting in the amazon distro centers or if amazon stock are of lesser quality or something, I'm not sure. I got my kit from a local radio shack ($10 cheaper retail, and I had a $10 coupon so $20 less than current price on Amazon). The kit I received was great, I inspected every bit with a magnifying glass, not even a hint of discoloration let alone rust or anything. I will walk through each section of the kit with a summary of my thoughts on this great kit.--Carrying Case:Overall the carrying case is very nice. A solid durable nylon material with a very strong Velcro seal to close it up. It is a tri-fold and the fold is off centered with is odd at first but it does close well and i think will stand up well to many years of use (and abuse)--Spudgers (plastic and metal):The plastic spudgers are a dime a dozen, they are given away for free with any "iphone screen replacement kit" you order online. I have about 20 of them. That said, if you don't already have them they are good to have, better to start with these than the metal ones in some cases.The metal spludgers and scrapers are nice and solid. Textured handles ensure a good grip. They are heavy and solid where they need to be and on the ones that are supposed to be a bit flexible they do have a bit of a give which is important when popping off parts of phone cases or what have you.--Tweezers:I have read in one of the main reviews how bad the tweezers are in this kit but I have to say, based on the set I have there must be a some rea quality control issues resulting in a wide range of tolerances to get through. The Tweezers I received are all amazing. They all have nice rubber ESD proof grips as advertised, but more to the point, quite literally, they ends are amazing. Each of the ends grab with great precision and hold tight. They are precise and tight enough to pick the skin right from your finger. All three pair hold the precision through a full grasp. The curved set and the fine most pointed set hold the most precision, with the very end staying completely closed even with a full grasp. On the thicker of the 2 straight sets, the pointe end started to open a bit but not until about 90% strength applied to a full grasp. Still in my opinion these are very nice and precise.--54 Bit Driver Kit:The driver kit is wonderful. I read many other reviews where people had issues with missing bits, or bits with rust on them. As a result when I got my kit I reviewed each one as noted in the summary and not a single issue. So for me im saying the set of 4mm bits are all great. The driver itself is nice. Again it's got good weight, and a very solid feel. The included extension fits in the hole on the end to create a T-bar for added torque, which can be helpful since you can't always get a lot of leverage with these types of drivers. The palm spinner also works nice, I have had no issues with it getting caught at all. I have also found that these bit work perfectly with the General Tools 500 Cordless Precision Screwdriver and getting that with this set really is a great match. The bits themselves are not magnetic but the driver has a strong magnet to hold the bit in. As a result the bit, when in the driver carries this charge and when the bit is in the driver it will have a slight magnetic charge which is generally a very helpful thing and will allow it to still pick up small screws. The added magnetic bit is also very nice to have. I haven't really had much use for the flexible extension bar. Its decent quality, but a bit hard to turn with an angle over 45 degrees from what I can see.This may seem really nit-picky but in all honesty my biggest issue is, with the quality and precision that went into this kit, and its not a cheap $20 kit. The Driver kit pieces all sit in a very thin, cheap as hell, white plastic mold. Just seems that an extra dollar or 2 to make the setting a bit more solid would have been what made this perfect.--Others:With the misc other stuff there isn't much to really say. The Suction and ESD strap are standard. The Razor is nice quality heavy/solid feel to it. The ruler was a little underwhelming. The ruler itself was fine but with the quality of everything else I was a bit disappointed with how cheap the attached cross bar was. It just didn't have the high quality precise feel of everything else.--Overview:Overall i highly recommend this tool set, there seems to be some questionable quality from the kits fulfilled by Amazon, but my kit from Radio Shack had none of the issues noted by others.**If you find this review helpful please click the button below.**

First off this is actually a very nice precision powered driver. It comes with a few common bits that are very helpful to get you going.The handle and feel of the unit overall is good. those with large and small hands alike should find themselves comfortable with this device.This is a precision screwdriver, please make sure you are getting it for the right reason. this is for working on small finely details projects that. the rotational speed of the bit is not fast nor should it be, but it has some good torq, so if you are driving into a soft material make sure you stop just before the end and finish turning by hand. When not powered the bit is pretty much locked so you can tighten it down by hand without the risk of stripping anything.**Optional Bits**This was one of the biggest issues i have read when i went through the reviews, well i want to tell you all that there are lots of options and i will give you 2 VERY amazing ones right now. This driver is the "perfect' companion to the iFixit kits. Both the iFixit Pro Tech Toolkit and just the iFixit 54 Bit Driver Kit come with a crap ton of bits. Actually each comes with 54. In addition the top row of bits in each kit are varies sized adapters so you can use any bits sized from 2mm up to 5mm in this precision screw driver. Buying this driver with one of those sets is really a match made in heaven. I have the pro kit and this driver and i have yet to find something i cant tackle.The battery life of the driver is pretty good too it lasts me quite a while. i haven't actually times it but others have reported ~100 hours or so and i cant disagree with that. Im currently using the supplied Alkaline batteries, and once i can find my AAA NiMH batteries i will be giving those a try.Overall this is a great driver, with no issues, regardless what others are saying.I would totally recommend this product**If this review was helpful please click the button below

Its a low cost Keyboard and it works well but its def has its goods and its badsPro:* Its the basically the same keyboard you find on other sites and in certain kits (especially Raspberry Pi) for $40+ or so.* It works just as good, no issues with any of the mini computers i have tested it with. Raspbery Pi, UDOO, BeableBone Black, pcDuino, etc.* Its RF not Bluetooth, so no special drivers, just pug in in the dongle and it works* recharble, so no replacing batteries* Built in storage for the RF Dongle, surprising how great this feature is until you have something like this and its impossible to keep track of the dongle.* The laser point is dumb, but makes for a fun cat (or dog) toy :-)Cons:* The range is not the best, couple feet at best before keystrokes start to get missed. I would say about 5' give or take, maybe more with Line of Sight* The form factor makes typing anything more than a few keystrokes very awkward* the longer length keys long the backspace, space bar, and enter key have 2 physical buttons under them making it very easy to double press leading to typing mistakes.* while the built in battery is rechargeable, it is not replaceable. but at price of this unit, its probably better to just buy a whole new one anyways.overall this is a good keyboard, but unless you must have the laser pointer, i find Hausbell  Mini H7 2.4GHz Wireless Keyboard with Touchpad to not only be cheaper, but far more comfortable to hold, use and has better button placement

Good deal on these odd sized batteries. I have used these is a few small portable electronics and they have proven to be more than adequate. Not really a lot to say about them that hasnt been covered buy others reviews.The price was good and they work well. Free shipping makes them a good call.The main reason I have acquired these for use in the Smartthings presence nodes.

its ok, if you can find the right sized peppers, which has been my biggest issue.To this day, i have yet to actually get good use out of this because the peppers i find are either to large or small to really fit in the holes. We make a couple types of peppers that we really wanted to use in this. We get the bags of small peppers from costco and pretty much every pepper int he back is too large for even the large holes in this rack.I wanted to give this 3 stars but will give it 4 since the main issue has been on my side. I should have paid more attention to the hole sizes, so in closing i will leave that as my word of advise. Check out the hole sizes before you buy and check with some of the peppers you will work with. you may find it will work well, you may not. But ignoring the hole size as i did and assuming it will work for small peppers may leave you like me, with a rack that is collecting dust.

The plastic is great and durable, the containers are nice and all fit well in the overall case.I purchased this for someone who just recently had gastric by-pass surgery and it has allowed her to very easily portion out her lunch foods, take them to work, and eat comfortably. Since the inside containers are easily removable they make for great holders for her on short trips. She can separate out a couple portions of left overs for the next day or setup  the whole lunch. The extra room in the case works for utensils or other items.Overall its a bit pricey for a 'lunch box' but for a gastric by-pass patient, or anyone with similar needs this was the most perfect thin. It has received near daily use for many month now and has held up great. its very durable and nice.**Please click the button if you find this review helpful

Summary:This is a great idea and a good product.It works good, but the bends in the metal don't seem to be exactly right. Things are tight where they should be loose, and loose where they should be tight. Not in major ways, but enough to be noticeable. Its a Pyrex, and as i have come to expect form all Pyrex, it's a great high quality product.I purchased this as a replacement when someone dropped my old one and shattered it on my tile floor..Next to that, to that these things are extremely durable and long lasting.This is one of those kitchen products you buy and will have 20 years later working just as well as the day you got it.

Summary:Good design, decent buttons, features, attaches well, and sounds pretty goodPhysical side:Starting with the physical aspect of things with the suction cup. the device has suction cup the same diameter as the device it self and seems to hold on quite well. its made of a plastic that has a soft finish, but a hard slick plastic, its a nice feel. the buttons are large pads with a single pushpin button about 3mm in diameter so you want push right in the middle of each to actually get the button under it. There is a single LED under the rubber power button that indicates the state of the device, on, off, charging or in Bluetooth pairing mode. when its turned for the first time its discoverable by your phone and connects easy.The charger is a standard USB plug on one side with a proprietary 2mm barrel jack on the side that goes into the device. this is a bit of a bummer, as i dont see putting a water gasket over a micro USB that much harder that this, but regardless this is what it is. Just means you better not loose the cable.Software:The Bluetooth connection established quick and easy. i had no issues on my GS4. it worked as expected with any music app i had, Slacker radio, Pandora, Tune-in, Google Music, etc all worked as expected. Pause/Play, skip track all worked normally. The ability to answer an incoming call worked quite well also. I didn't test this in the actual shower, but in a quiet room, the receiving person just noted that it sounded like i was on any normal speakerphone, as expected. I could imaging it would be a bit hard to hear in the shower, but have no doubt it will work. will post an update/correction if i get contradictory info.Sound quality:As to be expected, from many devices like this, the sound is lacking in the bass/low areas. As with most of the tons int he mids and highs.. it has enough lows to still sounds good and by placing the speaker in the back it deflects the sounds off the surface its attached too with an outward angle added from the suction cup itself. This allows the small device to really fill the area with sound. Again now the most complete sound from a range stand point, but it does have more low tones that i have seen in many common "shower radios" which seem to be just tweeters.Overall:* This is a very good, low cost waterproof shower speaker that will do well for most people.* I dont have good batter duration info at this time, but will try and add it when i can* The proprietary charging cable is a real negative, replacing this if lost could be challenging.* Yes, overall i would recomend this product to others.**if you found this review helpful please click the button below

These are quite solid, thick, durable lead cables. The cables themselves are much thicker than i expected, each lead cable is about the thickness of a good USB cable. Making the combined pair pretty thick and durable, more than expected. Its also worth noting that these cables come combined as a single cable. They could be pulled apart if desired, but i found this to be nice. its easier to store them.The banana clips are normal/common, the metal banana clip end is completely attached to the plastic part, i have had some where they come apart of pulled to hard, these are solid. Additionally on the alligator clip end the screw into the lead wire is clean, solid and holds up very well. I have used these in a few projects and given them some good pulls/tugs.These are not $1-$2 cheap leads, they are worth the money and i think will serve me well for a while, im happy i got 2 sets when i did.**Update** 1/9/14I have been using these in a test project, been in use nearly 24/7 for at least 2 weeks now and been running very good. Not putting a lot of load through them (5v, 0.1A-2.0A), but still they are a lot better than the smaller dual cable flimsy cables i was using before**If this review was helpful please click the button**

first regarding the version, from what i can tell reading the iFixit website, this is in fact the pro-model.It has the non-slip backing and a decent magnet.. not that i have another one to compare it toThe magnetic board in 2mm thickThe foam bad is about 0.5mm thickThe total thickness is just under 3mmQuality:Overall this is a very good project pad, well designed, thick enough to be strong and useful but not too think to be in the way on the desk (note thicknesses above). The non-slip backing works well to keep the pad from sliding, but it will move if pushed intentionally. The whiteboard quality is also very good. Many types of whiteboards like this will leave residue, or ghosting when erased, this one is very good and cleans up easy.Intended uses:This is the key thing, Please make sure you are getting this for the right reasons. This pad is intended to help you work on small electronics. Tearing apart and fixing laptop, cell phones, robots, drones, circuit boards, Arduino projects, etc. the magnetic backing is safe for most all electronics including memory cards. For these use cases the pad is wonderful. it holds the tiny screws in place with your written labels making re-assembly much quicker. If you are trying to fix a toaster oven, AC unit or some other large project, then this may not be what you want to use.Overall:Overall this very nice quality mat. its heavier than i expected (good thing). Its seems quite durable, and i was very happy to see that the the dry erase marker was really a fine tip marker, of really nice quality. It also has a small dry eraser on the back to clean up the board like a pencil eraser.I quite like this pad, have already used it a couple times with some Arduino related projects and love it.

This was purchased to replace my mothers aging windows XP netbook.She is not very computer literate but was able to quickly pick up the Chrome OS and get to her normal routine.Its larger and lighter than her older netbook and she seems very happy with it.Overall the performance of the chromebook is very good, and as usually the interface is clean and inviting.The keyboard and trackpad also work well and feel nice.The screen is nice and vibrant.Its important for prospective buyers to ready the product information on this page, this is not a typical laptop computer, a chromebook is a new type of laptop running the Chrome OS based system and while fast, efficient and functional, it may not be suited for all people. It is very powerful and ultimately can do many things a light user will need.it is also very well suited for those that do everything on web sites and use cloud/web services.The bonus 100+ GB of free Google Drive space for 2 years is a nice.

I purchased this strip knowing full well it wasn't going to be very powerful and it wasn't.My specific use of this strip was to just run a few USB thumb drives, an ARCTIC Breeze Mobile USB Fan, and to run a series of USB-serial console cables, USB FTDI cables and such for my electronics projects. This is one of the better DMM i have used. its got pretty much every feature available (except temperature) and it works very well.- In comparison to other DMM and testing equipment its proven to be very accurate.- The leads are interchangeable with other types, which is very convenient. They do have these covers to cover the 'sharp' points. these covers are great idea, but they are a bugger to keep track of. The idea of a tether would be nice, but i can see that just causing them to get in way as they dangle. either way. Not a huge issue but notable- It runs on standard batteries so no crazed searching when you have dead DMM. Comes with standard 1.5v Alkaline, but seems to work with rechargeable 1.2v NiMH also.- internal fuse to protect the unit.. oddly enough mine blew at some point, i had no idea, the meter has still be working and i have some new ones on order.. odd.- It has a nice kickstand and strap so you can sit it upright on your desk/bench or attach it to your hand easily. The elastic band does really get in the way of the kickstand which is irritating, but again, not that big of a deal.Overall: i like this DMM, would recommend it and at this point if i lost or broke it, i would probably buy this one again.**[...]**

This is a great fan for general cooling needs in electrons or personal casesPersonalConnect to a USB port in your keyboard and you have a great personal fanElectronics- Connect to a USB strip and you have a quick cooling fan to cool an overclocked Raspberry Pi or Beaglebone.- Its got obvious uses for cooling USB ASIC Erupters- i have one running cooling a Re:Load 2 constant load generator, and its perfect for that.The goose neck isnt as flexible as i would have hoped, it takes some over twisting to get it to stay in the right position. not a huge deal and still great value.

So with over 900 reviews i doubt this will get read by many but i wanted to get this published all the same.I do a lot of testing with various portable batteries and cables, and i have found this cable to do just fine with data transfer speeds at the expected USB 2 speeds, but find that its power transfer rates are quite sub-par.The look and feel of this cable would lead you to believe its a good quality cable, but it doesn't charge like one. On a 1000 mA power source it will only pull 800 mA, i have occasionally seen it get a bit higher, but not consistently. A quality cable can allow all 1000 mA to a normal USB device like a phone. Even when upping the load current to 2000 or 2100 mA there is little change. USB Standards do not require a full 2000 mA through a USB cable, but most good cables will max out at 1200 mA based on my testing. Again this is cable sits tight around 800.Overall this may not be something most people care about but it should be noted that it will caused longer charge times to your devices.Update: Corrected mAh to mA

NOT recommended.the batter itself seems to be working fine (which is why its getting 2 stars not 1).
